The longer hull allows the engineering plant to be split into separate spaces to resist damage.  Historically, this was the US Cleveland-class and British Fiji-class light cruisers.

The relaxation of the limits of the Washington Naval Treaty means that destroyers can have a standard displacement greater than 1500 tons.  These destroyers have five or six 127mm (5 inch) guns and a large torpedo battery.  Frames which run the entire length of the hull give these destroyers the ability to withstand more damage than previous designs.  Historically, this was the US Fletcher-class and Japanese Kagero-class destroyers.

This is a small, easily produced escort vessel.  Corvettes are typically armed with two or three small guns and an extensive battery of ASW weaponry.  Diesel engines give these escorts sufficient range to accompany convoys of transoceanic routes.  Historically, this was the UK River-class and US Evert-class escorts.

This is a specialized vessel designed for transporting troops in a combat zone.  They have limited means for defending themselves against enemy planes and warships.  Additional hull framing gives these ships the ability to absorb limited damage.  Historically, this was the US Henderson-class transports.

Attacks by submarines meant that merchant vessels in convoys are being sunk at alarming rates.  A simple, mass producible ships is required to keep the trade routes open.  These vessels have simple steam plants and either a reciprocating or turbine engine depending on availability.  Simple construction techniques make these vessel fragile.  Historically, this was the US Liberty ships.

These merchant vessels were initially designed to transport high value, perishable cargoes.  A pair of high pressure boilers and a geared steam turbine allow these ships to achieve high speed for a merchant vessel.  These ships typically have an amidships or forward house and five or six cargo holds.

This radar is designed to work with secondary battery directors.  The antenna mounts to the secondary director and is useful in targeting both aircraft and surface ships.  The accuracy of the centimetric radar allows true blind fire if the target is obscured by smoke or darkness.

The development of centimetric radar allows fire control radar sets to be made smaller and more accurate.  The radar antenna is mounted on the main battery director and gives an accurate range and bearing to the target.  The improved accuracy of the centimetric radar allows true blind fire.  The design of this radar is optimized for use against surface targets.

This is the first generation of fire control radar.  The radar attaches to the front of the director and allows the ship to get an accurate range to the target, even if the target is obscured by haze or smoke.  This radar is not accurate enough to get a bearing on the target, so true blind fire is not possible.  The antenna is heavy and can only be mounted on battleships.

These are small, disposable ASDIC/sonar transducers that can be dropped by an aircraft into the area where a submarine is suspected to be.  A small radio transmits the returning data to an operator on the aircraft.  Once the position of the submarine is determined, the plane can attack the enemy submarine.

These are small, disposable ASDIC/sonar transducers dropped over the side of the vessel.  The transducer to able get beneath the layer where a sharp changes in temperature tend to reflect ASDIC/Sonar signals.  These small transducers are inexpensive enough to be disposable.

A towed hydrophone is made up of multiple transducers towed at the end of a long cable pulled behind the destroyer.  This allows passive detection of submarines while the vessel is underway.  With hull mounted sonar, the engines create enough noise to cover the noise of a quiet submarine.  A towed sonar allows the transducers to be far enough from the engines and propellers to enable them to hear submarines while underway.

The use of multiple transducers allows the ASDIC/Sonar to be 'steered' on target without physically turning a piece of equipment.  This is made possible by electronics which analyze multiple signals and combine them into a single signal.  This allows the operator manipulate to manipulate the signal to make submarine detection easier.

The small wavelength of centimetric radar allows the operator to 'see through' surface clutter and bad weather with more clarity.  The wavelength also allows better distinction between multiple targets.  Centimetric radar sets are small enough to be mounted on small warships which were unable to mount the heavier decimetric radar.

The reduction in the wavelength of radar signals allows the antenna to be made smaller.  This allows small warships to mount effective air search radar.  The smaller wavelength also allows the operator to distinguish between individual aircraft on the screen.

Many of the improvements in electronics have gradually found their way into the specialized field of marine electronics.  Smaller radar antennas have enabled radar to be incorporated into more systems.  Improved electronics have also been incorporated into anti-submarine equipment.

This is a simple mechanical computer mounted deep within the vessel.  Simple switches allow the crew to enter the variables of range, speed and deflection.  A mechanical computer uses the variables to calculate a fire control solution.  The solution is transmitted to the director where the aim of the guns is adjusted.

These small directors are mounted to control the medium and light anti-aircraft guns.  These directors consist of set of control handles and a simple sight.  By tracking the target, lead information is calculated and transmitted to the anti-aircraft guns.  These directors are small enough to be mounted in overlapping fields of coverage.

The same technology that allows improvements to be made in main battery director can be applied to directors designed for controlling secondary guns.  These directors are fitted with a rangefinder and simple computer to allow calculation of the proper firing solution.  These directors are also used for controlling the guns against aircraft.  These directors have only a lightweight shield to protect the crew and equipment in the director from shell splinters.

Main battery directors are mounted high in the vessel to give long range visibility.  The director is able to control and fire the main battery turrets remotely.  By controlling all of the guns from a central location, the firing of the guns can be timed to fire at the perfect time in the ships roll.  This allows for accurate fire at long range.

Optics have become more precise as manufacturing processes improve.  Optics now can be mounted in directors and turrets that allow engaging targets at night and in reduced visibility.  Turret optics are now advanced enough that 'long base' rangefinders can be mounted in the turret to facilitate local control in the event of damage to the director.

Better manufacturing techniques and improved electronics allow better control systems for weapons systems to be developed.  The use of radar is now available for use in solving the range portion of the fire control solution.

This system fires small, contact fused depth charges ahead of the vessel.  The contact fuse removes doubt as to whether or not an attack is effective.  If there is no explosion, the charges have missed their target and a follow-up attack can be made.  Firing the charges ahead allows a single destroyer to make an attack while still tracking the target.  Historically, this was the Mousetrap ASW system.

High frequency direction finders (Huff Duff) allow a vessel to get a bearing to a transmitting radio.  An antenna in the shape of a loop is rotated until the signal strength is the strongest.  The bearing to the transmitting submarine is plotted on a chart.  If more than one vessel gets a bearing, it allows the position of the transmitting submarine to be triangulated and then investigated.

Multiple destroyers working together are more effective for destroying enemy submarines than a single destroyer.  Tactics for the coordination of attacks has taken time to develop.  The most efficient method is for one destroyer to track the submarine while another destroyer makes an attack.  During attacks with a single destroyer, contact with the submarine is lost just before the destroyer passes over the submarine.  By using the second destroyer, contact isn't lost at the time of an attack allowing for faster follow-up attacks.

Flying boats are converted to make anti-submarine patrol aircraft.  The planes are fitted with depth charges racks for attacking submarines.  Flare dispensers allow attacks to be made against submarines on the surface at night.  The long range of the flying boats allows convoys to have air cover farther out to sea.

As was the war continues, experience in hunting and destroying submarines continues to increase.  Submarines are slower while operating submerged.  If the escorts can force the submarine to submerge, it limits the search area.  Even if the submarine isn't destroyed, the slow speed of the submerged submarine ensures that the convoy can escape.

As crews get more experience in hunting and destroying enemy submarines, improvements to the systems used in ASW are developed.  The new technology is designed to combat the massed submarine attacks that are common in 'wolfpack' tactics.  These new systems can detect the submarine and allow faster attacks before the submarine can evade.

Amphibious assaults require large quantities of supplies.  Until a port is secured, supplies have to be brought across the beach from ships offshore.  Amphibious vehicles are more effective because of their ability to drive up onto the beach before unloading the supplies.

Amphibious operations require command facilities that can monitor both the battle ashore and the surrounding sea area.  Merchant ships are converted to add extensive communications equipment.  Cargo holds are converting into spaces for planning and controlling operations on shore.

These are infantry landing craft modified to fire rockets and guns in support of troops on shore.  They get close to shore with their shallow draft and reinforced bows.  Firing concentrated salvoes of rockets at targets of opportunity targeted by spotters ashore allows the troops on shore to advance easier.

The Landing Ship (Tank) allows vehicles to land directly onto an unprepared beach.  The LST pushes her bow up on the beach and extends a ramp allowing the vehicles to drive directly into combat.  These vessels can also transport cavalry directly into combat without waiting for horses to arrive separately.

The use of specialized landing craft allows troops to land with armor protection.  Landing craft get the troops on shore without crossing the beach under fire.  These craft can also land a limited amount of supplies across the beach.

Coordinated naval gunfire is made possible by detailed fire support plans and communications with troops on shore.  Specially trained spotters with the troops radio targets and corrections to ships offshore.  This allows efficient fire at targets of opportunity.

As the war progresses, nations have discovered that they need specialized forces for scouting and preparing enemy beaches.  The British created the Special Boat Service (SBS) and the US created the UDT divers.  These forces make it easier for the marines following them to succeed in their assaults.
The use of electronics became more important in the field of naval combat.  It also allowed for detection at longer ranges.  This meant that the combat happened at longer ranges as well.

The protection of carriers takes many forms.  With a new generation of fleet carriers, the new design has to be updated with an armored flight deck that is important for protection.  Unfortunately, this design carries fewer aircraft than carriers without the armored flight deck.  This is done because of the limitations in stability and space that occur as a result of the armored flight deck.  Historically, this was the British Malta-class and Japanese Taiho-class aircraft carriers.

The relaxation of the tonnage limits with the Washington Naval Treaty means that more capable carriers can be designed and built.  One of the improvements incorporated is a more robust engineering plant.  The concept allows 'split plant' operation.  This means the destruction of any single engineering space does not incapacitate the carrier.  There are also advantages in the fact that these carriers are bigger than their predecessors.  Historically, this was the US Essex-class and Japanese Unryu-class aircraft carriers.

The protection of carriers from attack is always a difficult question.  Carriers by their very nature are required to carry large quantities of flammable materials.  One solution to protecting carriers is the armored flight deck.  A traditional carrier has a protective deck under the hanger to protect the engineering spaces and the magazines.  These carriers add a second layer of armor at the flight deck.  This second layer of armor provides additional protection from bombs.  Unfortunately, this reduces the size of the air group that can be carried aboard due to stability considerations and space limitations.  Historically, this was the British Illustrious-class aircraft carriers.

Experimentation with converted carriers resulted in designs for carriers built specifically for that purpose.  The first carriers are intended to act as scouting and support elements for the traditional battleline of battleships.  As the their tactics evolve, they have become independent strike units.  These carriers have lightweight decks and limited armor protection to optimize the number of aircraft that can be carried.  Historically, this was the British Ark Royal-class, US Yorktown-class, and Japanese Shokaku-class carriers.

During the 1930s, many nations looked at building a hybrid cruiser-carrier to supplement their carrier tonnage which was limited by the Washington Naval Treaty.  Aviation cruiser designs typically have two or three turrets with 152mm (6 inch) guns forward.  A small flight deck and island are placed on the stern in place of the after turrets.  They have a limited air group with 28 aircraft, but also have armor on the scale of contemporary light cruisers.  All of the countries that have looked at the design determined that it is not a worthwhile use of limited cruiser tonnage.

The Washington Naval Treaty contains provisions that when a non-signatory power builds a battleship that exceeds treaty limits, the limits will be increased.  With the refusal of the Japanese to renew the treaty, the limits are expanded to a standard displacement of 45,000 tons.  The additional displacement allows for a higher design speed.  A small length to beam ratio is achieved by lengthening the design.  This means that the same power is able to achieve higher speed.  Unfortunately, it means that there is now more hull area that needs to be armored.  This means that the increase in speed is bought at no increase in armor protection or armament.  Historically, this was the US Iowa-class battleships.

When an object made out of metal is placed in a magnetic field, the metal distorts the magnetic field lines.  This principle is used to detect submarines (metal) when operating (Earth's magnetic Field) submerged.  A very sensitive magnetic compass is carried which detects the subtle changes in the Earth's magnetic field that occur as the result of the submarine's metal hull.  These changes are very small so the detector has to be close to the submarine.  This means the submarine has to be operating at a shallow depth to be detected.

The development of the automatic 203mm (8 inch) gun helps keep the heavy cruiser as a viable design.  The problem with other heavy cruiser designs is the slowness of the main battery fire.  The slowness of fire makes it difficult to engage targets that are maneuvering or at close range.  The new 203mm gun is combined with a larger hull and better protection in an entirely new design.  Historically, this was the US Oregon City-class heavy cruisers.

The dual purpose 152mm (6 inch) gun has been on the drawing boards since before the war.  The priority of other projects delayed the development.  With the completion of the gun design, new anti-aircraft cruisers can be developed.  The twin turrets are larger than the twin 127mm (5 inch) mounts they replace.  This requires the hull to be lengthened to accommodate the new turrets.  Historically, this was the US Worcester-class and British Tiger-class light cruisers.

The blimp, equipped with magnetic anomaly detection gear and depth charges, is an effective antisubmarine warfare platform.  The blimp has excellent visibility over the convoy and greater speed than any contemporary convoy escort.  This allows the blimp to fly to the area from which a torpedo attack occurred to prosecute a counter-attack on the enemy submarine.  Historically, this was the US 'K' class blimps.

Enormous rigid airships like the Hindenburg and Akron proved dangerously fragile and subject to loss from fire and inclement weather.  Small blimps, airships without an aluminum inner skeleton, are more robust operationally, although they have a smaller payload than the big airships.

Increasing the diameter of the torpedo from the standard 533mm (21 inch) to 610mm (24 inch) allows the torpedo to be made more powerful.  The additional volume within the torpedo body allows a large warhead to be combined with longer range.  This makes the torpedo a very effective weapon.  The increased size of the torpedo means that the torpedo tubes have to modified in an extensive overhaul.  Historically, this was the Japanese 'Long Lance' torpedo.

The increasing speed and weight of naval aircraft means that the equipment used for stopping them on deck has to be made stronger.  The hydraulic rams are made larger to absorb more energy.  The wire ropes themselves are also made thicker the withstand the increased stresses.

As aircraft get larger, the amount of space that they take up on deck increased.  This means that aircraft have to be moved around the deck more often than in the past.  Specialized handling tractors are developed to move aircraft around the deck quicker.

Directional homing beacons send out coded radio signals.  As the bearing back to the ship changes, a received Morse code letter changes.  This allows aircraft to find their way back to the carrier from long ranges.

The system for aviation gasoline (avgas) on the carrier is vulnerable to damage, fire, and explosions.  By moving the pipes outside of the hull and installing a system that fills the pipes with carbon dioxide, it reduces the threat of exploding fuel vapors.

During the early years of the war many nations looked at converting available light cruiser hulls into aircraft carriers to get carriers quickly into the fleet.  These are complex conversions.  The main battery magazines are converted to magazines for bombs and torpedoes and fuel storage created within the hull.  The hangar and flight deck are built up on the hull and a small island is added.

During the early years of the war nations looked at converting readily available merchant vessels into aircraft carriers.  These conversions are simple.  Moving the stacks and engine intakes to the edges of the deck and adding a flight deck and hanger to the existing main deck.

Advances in general aviation eventually made their way into the specialized field of naval aviation.  Naval warplanes have become lighter, faster and more maneuverable.  This means facilities on the carrier have to be improved to maintain and operate these more advanced aircraft.

Superheated steam is created by running the steam through the boiler a second time.  Superheating removes all of the water from the steam resulting in 'dry steam.' Superheating the steam allows more heat energy to be added to the steam.  Hotter steam is more efficient in driving the turbines.  The 'dry steam' is better for equipment by limiting corrosion.

The use of a diesel engine to drive a generator means that emergency generators can be mounted in spaces outside of the engine room.  These generators are tied into separate buses where power can be provided to critical systems.  Back-up power can be provided to gun mounts and electronics in the event of damage to the engine spaces.

A diesel engine allows damage control equipment to be spread around the vessel.  The diesel engine can be mounted in a space that is unconnected to the engine spaces.  A large centrifugal pump is tied into the fire main.  This allows the fire main to be broken into zones to protect against damage, but also allow the pump to pressurize the entire system in the event of damage to the engine spaces.

Improvements in marine engineering have improved the redundancy and efficiency of warships.  The importance of damage control means that most of the focus of new engineering designs is focused on increasing survivability.

VHF (Very High Frequency) radios allow instantaneous communications between ships within visual range.  The small radio sets are mounted on the bridge where officers have instant access.  Maneuvering and targeting commands can be quickly passed to a group of ships without the use of a flashing light or radio operator.  The short wavelength radio signals limit radio's range to the horizon.

The use of skywaves allow the operator to communicate with vessels at longer ranges.  Skywaves are radio waves 'bounced' off ionized layers in the atmosphere.  The use of skywaves allows the radio mast to be made shorter.

Sonar/ASDIC works by sending sound waves into the water where they are reflected off the target.  By timing the reflected sound wave the distance to the target is found.  Basic sonar/ASDIC cannot detect a submarine running on the surface because of reflections from the water's surface.

This is a simple surface search radar.  The operator watches a line on the radar screen.  When a target is detected, a 'blip' appears along the line corresponding to the range.  A separate gauge tells the operator the bearing of the target.  The long wavelength that these radar sets use makes them vulnerable to clutter from nearby land.  This means that targets can be lost or not seen in confined waters.

Radar was originally developed for use by stations on shore.  Before the radar sets could be used on ships they need to be 'hardened' to withstand the stress of being on a moving vessel.  The radar antennas need to be sealed to protect them from the corrosion associated with salt water.  These radar sets are so large that they must be mounted on a large vessel such as a cruiser, battleship, or carrier.

As the field of electronics grew during the 1930s, production of cheap vacuum tubes made the development of devices like radar and small radio sets possible.  These improved electronic systems improve the ability of warships to survive combat and destroy enemy vessels.

As navies made attacks against enemy held beaches, they have discovered that specialized equipment is necessary to make those attacks successful.  Specialized equipment protects the troops as they come ashore from enemy fire.  The specialized equipment is also designed to be manufactured quickly.

The development of a nuclear power plant for naval vessels allows a new generation of long range designs to be developed.  These ships are redesigned super battleships with nuclear reactors replacing the boilers.  The internal arrangement has to be altered to create room for the reactors.  The secondary battery magazines are shifted toward the ends of the ship.  The removal of the stacks allows anti-aircraft batteries to have improved fields of fire.

The development of the nuclear power plant allows new long range designs.  These are modified super carriers which replace the boilers with nuclear reactors.  These ships are considered to be the ultimate in naval power.  Over 300m (1000 ft) in length and having the ability to steam non-stop around the world makes these carriers the focal point of carrier taskforces.  Historically, this was the US Enterprise-class and Nimitz-class nuclear powered carriers.

These are large, multi-role carriers.  They are designed to operate jet fighters, heavy strike aircraft, and anti-submarine aircraft.  The increased size of these ships allows large air groups to be effectively used.  An armored flight deck gives these carriers the ability to survive bomb and missile hits.  Historically, this was the US Forrestal-class and French Foch-class carriers.

The increased speed and range of submarines means that they have to intercepted before they can approach a fleet or convoy.  To provide long range protection, specialized carriers carry anti-submarine aircraft and Sonar systems.  These carriers serve as flagships for specialized anti-submarine taskforces and escort groups.

The development of nuclear power plants for naval vessels allows the development of new long range designs.  These ships are guided missile battleships modified to replace the boilers with nuclear reactors.  There are two long range surface-to-air missile launchers in place of the aft turrets.  The forward 406mm (16 inch) turrets are retained as anti-surface weapons and for use during shore bombardment.

This is a battleship optimized for anti-aircraft protection of taskforces.  A pair of long range surface-to-air missile launchers are mounted aft in place of the aft turrets.  The 406mm (16 inch) guns are retained forward to provide shore bombardment and anti-surface weapons.  These ships are based on the post-treaty battleship design.  The reduction in fire control equipment for the main battery guns allows the superstructure to be consolidated.  This gives anti-aircraft guns and missiles improved fields of fire.

The Washington Naval Treaty limits battleships to a standard displacement of 35,000 tons.  This isn't much larger than battleships completed at the end of World War I, but is much smaller than the designs that were being built or on the drawing board following the war.  This means that designers have to find a way to balance the new requirement for speed with the need for heavy armament and protection.  Historically, this was the British King George V-class and US North Carolina-class battleships.

The success of the pocket battleship opened up new avenues of design based on ships with a smaller caliber main battery guns.  Although the pocket battleship was able to outfight cruisers limited by the Washington Treaty, they are liable to be chased down by battlecruisers or new fast battleships.  The larger design replaces the diesel engines of the pocket battleship with high pressure small tube boilers and geared turbines.  The larger hull also allows the number of heavy guns to be increased.  Historically, this was the French Dunkerque-class and German Scharnhorst-class battlecruisers.

The Germans were limited by the Versailles Treaty to battleships of 10,000 tons.  To remain within the limits of the treaty, a cruiser (small battleship) was designed that had more firepower than cruisers limited by the Washington Naval Treaty.  The weight of their armament limited the tonnage available for the engines.  To get long range for commerce raiding and reduce weight, a diesel plant was adopted.  This limited the speed of these cruisers to 28 knots.  This design was analyzed by other maritime power as an option, but was rejected as an inefficient use of valuable battleship tonnage.  Historically, this was the German Deutchland-class pocket battleships.

The Washington Naval Treaty created the class of heavy cruiser (as opposed to light cruiser).  Heavy cruisers are cruisers with a main battery of 203mm (8 inch) guns.  The treaty limited cruisers to a standard displacement of 10,000 tons.  Heavy cruisers sacrifice armor protection for increased gun power.  These cruisers are sometimes known unaffectionately as 'Tin Clads.'  Historically, this was the US Northampton-class and British County-class heavy cruisers.

The Washington Naval Treaty created the class of light cruiser (as opposed to heavy cruiser).  Light cruisers are cruisers with a main battery of 152mm (6 inch) guns or smaller guns.  The treaty limited the size of all cruisers to 10,000 tons standard displacement.  The use of turrets for the main battery reduces the length of the vessel and provides additional room for engine rooms by eliminating magazines.  Historically, this was the British Leander-class and Italian Da Barbiano-class light cruisers.

The development of large destroyers filled two roles within the fleet.  These destroyers use their larger size to provide space for the staff necessary to command destroyer squadrons.  The large destroyers are also more survivable in combat.  The construction of large destroyers was limited by the Washington Treaty.  These large destroyers use almost twice the tonnage of the standard 1500 ton destroyers without twice the capability.

This type of destroyer is representative of the first classes of interwar destroyers.  These destroyers take into account lessons that were learned during the first world war.  Advances in engineering, weaponry, construction techniques that were developed following the war increase the survivability of these destroyers.  Historically, this was the French Bourrasque-class and US Farragut-class destroyers.

The introduction of a standardized medium cargo vessel design allowed the production of modified vessels equipped with diesel engines.  The use of diesel engines allowed the vessel to use less fuel and run with a smaller engineering crew.

As trade routes are centralized, the need for numerous, small cargo vessels is reduced.  These larger ships are designed to carry large volumes of cargo between a limited number of ports.  Typically, these ships have an amidships house and six or seven cargo holds at the ends of the vessel.  Historically, this was the US Maritime Commission C-2 cargo ships.

The relaxation of the limitations of the Washington Naval Treaty opens up new areas of shipbuilding technology.  The use of marine electronics become more common as radar systems and small radios become available.  There are also improvements in naval aviation as fleets gain experience operating large groups of aircraft.

These are small cruisers which are built in countries which need a large seagoing cruiser, but do not have the need for a large fleet cruiser.  These cruisers have main batteries of 152mm (6 inch), but have fewer guns than larger light cruisers.  They typically have 6 to 8 guns.  Historically, this was the British Leander-class and Dutch Tromp-class light cruisers.

The Washington Naval Treaty created a class of warships called sloops.  These ships were intended to be flagships and patrol vessels in colonies of the major powers.  By treaty, these new ships were limited to 2000 standard tons and guns no larger than 152mm (6 inches).  Historically, this was the US Eire-class and British Bridgewater-class sloops.

Due to their high speed and greater range of view, airships appear to offer a cost-effective way to perform naval reconnaissance in place of cruisers.  This is of special importance to the United States, which possesses two vast naval frontiers on the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.  Implementing this involves intensive training with the fleet and the development of mobile mooring facilities.  These mobile facilities are mounted on specially modified surface ships so the airships can operate closely with the fleet.

Aircraft launched from the ship spot the fall of shells that are beyond visual range.  An observer in the aircraft is able to provide accurate spotting information because of his location high above the battle area.  The observer radios corrections back to the vessel after each salvo.

The basic secondary battery director is a result of the refinements in director technology.  As the technology gets better, it also becomes smaller.  This allows separate directors to be mounted to control the secondary battery guns.  Typically, there are two or more directors depending on the number of guns in the secondary battery.

As fire control technology gets better, the ability to engage targets at long range improves as well.  Most directors are fitted with a long base rangefinder as an integral part of the director which allows quicker fire solutions.  These improved directors control all of the aiming and firing of guns within the turret.

Advances in director technology is driven in part by better optics.  These optics allow precise targeting at longer ranges.  These optics are also installed in the turret to serve as a back-up system in the event that the director is put out of action.

The increasing range which modern guns can fire at makes centralized fire control more important.  Increased range makes the danger area where the shell will hit smaller than at short range.  Small errors in the timing of firing the guns or the range prediction can result in the shells missing the target.

The change from air to oxygen for powering the torpedo frees up space within the torpedo for a larger warhead.  The larger size of the warhead is combined with improved explosives to increase the hitting power of new torpedoes.  These new warhead designs can also be used in the torpedoes used by torpedo planes.

Improvements in engine design allow the torpedo to create thrust more efficiently.  The fuel and oxygen are burned to provide an exhaust which is run through a turbine.  The turbine is connected to the propeller at the rear of the torpedo.  Ways have to be found to counter the gyroscopic force which is generated by the spinning turbine.

Basic torpedoes work on a kerosene powered engine with standard air.  The kerosene is burned with the air to provide the energy to propel the torpedo through the water.  The replacement of the air with pure oxygen will make more space within the torpedo for more fuel or a larger warhead.

The increased speeds and operating depths of enemy submarines force the development of better weapons to combat them.  Depth charge throwers enable the destroyer to lay larger patterns of depth charges.  The improved hydrodynamic shape of new depth charges allows them to sink faster.  This allows submarines to be effectively attacked at deeper depths.
The use of dual speed torpedoes allows more flexibility in their use.  Dual speeds give the captain the choice of a long range shot with a slower speed, or a faster, short range shot.

In previous designs, separate anti-surface and anti-aircraft guns were necessary.  With the limitations dictated by the Washington Naval Treaty, more efficient methods of mounting the guns had to be developed.  Ideal anti-surface weapons need a high muzzle velocity and a heavy shell.  Ideal anti-aircraft weapons have a quick rate of fire and train.  The dual purpose gun combines some of the characteristics of each type, but makes some sacrifices compared with each type.  This saves weight by allowing a single gun to replace two separate weapons.

New weapons systems are more functional than previous designs.  These weapons systems are more useful in a variety of situations.  They allow weight saving though the replacement of multiple weapons mounts with a single mount.  This allows designers to increase the firepower on treaty limited designs.

Diesel engines are traditionally used in vessels where speed doesn't matter, like merchant vessels.  The use of diesels in heavy warships will give benefits in range and reduced manpower.  The new high speed diesel engines combine the reliability of a diesel engine with the horsepower of a steam plant and turbine.

Using models in tanks, it was discovered that a flat stern (transom stern) has the same hydrodynamic properties as a traditional curved stern.  The reduction in length saves weight through the removal of the complex framing associated with the traditional curved stern.  The weight saved can be used for increased armor protection or engine power.

Aluminum is lighter than steel, but doesn't resist damage as well.  The use of aluminum for structures that don't have to resist damage saves weight for armor or weapons.  Special joints have to be made where aluminum and steel structures come together.  Typically, aluminum is used for superstructures or lightweight shields for guns.

A small tube boiler allows a boiler to produce the same amount of steam in a smaller space.  The steam generation tubes are placed closer together and are shorter because of their smaller size.  Smaller generating tubes also allow higher operating pressures to be developed.  The combination of smaller volume and higher operating pressures allow smaller engineering spaces to be used which saves weight.

Sloped armor saves weight because of the virtual increase in armor thickness gained when the armor is angled.  By angling the armor away from vertical, the cross section of the armor is thicker.  This allows protection to be increased without an increase in armor weight.  The problem with the internal belt armor is access.  If the armor is damaged, it is more difficult to repair because of its location.  The sloped belt also takes up more internal space than traditional belt armor.

The concentration of the secondary guns into turrets allows a simplified arrangement.  In earlier designs, the secondary guns were distributed along the length of the hull in single gun casemates.  This prevented damage from taking out the entire secondary battery, but made ammunition distribution more difficult.  The use of turrets saves weight by concentrating the magazines and ammunition supply equipment to limited areas of the vessel.  Turrets also limit the area of the vessel that has to be protected with armor.

The Washington Naval Limitation Treaty put limits on the size of most warships.  This treaty took effect with all warships that were built after 1922.  The treaty forces naval architects and marine engineers to develop technologies that allow new warships to be more powerful than their predecessors, but follow the weight restrictions of the treaty.

The Washington Naval Treaty was signed in 1922.  As part of that treaty, nations agree to limits in displacement and weapon size.  The treaty also ended the naval building race that started shortly after the end of World War I.

Although hydraulic catapults are more efficient, their use was limited on surface warships.  The problem with the hydraulic catapult is that it requires openings in the deck for the hydraulic lines.  This is difficult if the catapult is going to be mounted on top of an armored turret or deck.  The black powder catapult doesn't require any openings and the powder charges are kept in the ships magazine.
Experimentation with the various conversions gives valuable experience in carrier operations.  This experience allows nations to determine which features will be best in purpose built carriers.

Many nations had fast battleships or battlecruisers that were surplus after the signing of the Washington Naval Treaty.  These hulls are perfect for conversion into large aircraft carriers.  The mountings for the turrets are removed and the hull built up to support the flight deck.  Historically, this was the US Lexington-class and Japanese Akagi-class carriers.

These are heavy wire ropes run across the carrier's deck.  The landing aircraft has a hook mounted on the tail which snags the rope bringing the aircraft to a stop.  The arrestor wire is connected to a series of hydraulic rams which absorb the energy of the landing aircraft.

A catapult is used to launch the aircraft that is too heavy or when there is insufficient wind to provide lift.  The catapult works by harnessing the energy in a compressed fluid.  Hydraulic fluid is compressed in a reservoir where it can be released into the catapult.  The high pressure fluid pushes the shuttle down the track accelerating the aircraft to flight speed.

The first carriers are naval auxiliaries or battleships converted with simple flight decks and aircraft handling facilities.  These conversions are mainly used for experimentation and the refining of the technology.  These simple carriers also have a limited role in combat.  Historically, this was the US Langley-class or French BÈarn-class carriers.

In the years following the first world war, naval technology kept growing due to a renewed naval building race.  This building race was stopped with the signing of the Washington Naval Limitation Treaty.  This forced nations to develop technologies that were more powerful, but still met displacement restrictions.

The construction of rigid, lighter than air craft allows them to go farther, and to carry a larger payload than contemporary aircraft.  The first lighter than air craft are simple silk bags filled with hot air.  This new design is a rigid steel frame supporting individual cells filled with lightweight hydrogen gas.  The increased lifting power of the hydrogen gives the new craft a great increases in capability.

The use of seaplanes for scouting and attacks was pioneered during World War I.  The first combat use of seaplanes was by the British Royal Navy during a bombing raid on German Zeppelin sheds.  Experience with seaplanes leads to developments in both the aircraft the effective use of them at sea.  Methods are developed to launch seaplanes while underway.  The use of platforms mounted on the bow generated wind to provide additional lift for the aircraft.  This pioneered the technology later used by aircraft carriers.

Early in the first world war, it was discovered that effective means were needed to combat submarines.  Effective weapons and tactics needed to be developed.  Depth charges and basic tactics are effective in combating submarines which can only submerge for short periods of time.

Submarines are difficult targets to attack.  First they have to be found, and then an attack has to be made.  One of the first pieces of equipment developed was a simple system of hydrophones.  These are simple waterproof microphones that hear the sounds generated by the submarine's propeller.  This allows the submarine to be tracked while submerged.

Interlocking gears are used to transfer the power from the turbine to the propeller shaft.  These gears use a herringbone pattern to prevent energy loss from slipping.  The use of a gear system allows a high pressure and a low pressure turbine to be used to drive a single propeller.  This makes the use of steam more efficient.  The use of the gears also allows the turbines to turn at their most efficient speed without causing cavitation with the propellers.

Forcing air into the boiler allows more efficient combustion of the fuel.  Air is used to both atomize (spray) the fuel into the boiler and provide extra air for combustion.  Large fans are mounted in the upper levels of the engine room which compress the air and force it into the boiler.

Experience during the first world war showed that the operation of aircraft off ships at sea is possible.  The use of aircraft in attacks on targets ashore during the war showed that aircraft could fill roles that surface ships traditionally filled.  Maritime nations can develop specialized vessels for deploying aircraft at sea.

Even after the Battle of Jutland, the value of the battlecruiser in fleet actions remained.  To remedy the faults of previous battlecruisers, more armor was added to protect the magazines from plunging fire at long ranges.  Flash protection in the turrets was improved to prevent damage to the turret from spreading to the magazines.  This results in ships that are virtually fast battleships.  Historically, this was the British battlecruiser Hood.

The concept of the fast battleship was developed to give navies the option of choosing the time and the place of engagement.  These ships were historically limited to specialized squadrons designed to operate independently from the rest of the battlefleet.  These ships are typically armed with eight 356mm guns or similar caliber weapons.  Historically, this was the British Queen Elizabeth-class and Japanese Nagato-class fast battleships.

The development of more powerful naval guns makes these battleships more formidable than previous classes of battleships.  In addition to larger guns, these new ships also have thicker armor belts and more powerful engines.  The danger of long range gunfire requires thick deck armor which also resists bombs dropped by aircraft.  They main battery of these ships is typically eight to twelve 356mm guns or similar caliber weapons.  Historically, this was the German Bayern-class and US Colorado-class battleships.

The battlecruiser is designed to fight through the enemy cruisers and serve as a scout for the battleships.  Because of their heavy guns, battlecruisers became part of the battlefleet themselves.  They are typically armed with eight heavy caliber guns of equal size to dreadnaughts, but lack the armor protection.  Historically, this was the Japanese Kongo-class and Turkish Yavuz-class battlecruisers.

This battleship is an improvement of the pre-dreadnaught type.  By replacing the multiple medium caliber weapons with large caliber weapons, they increased the hitting power.  They are typically armed with eight to twelve 305mm guns for attacking enemy ships at long range.  They are also armed with some small caliber weapons for defense against smaller warships and aircraft.  Historically, this was the French Corbet-class and Spanish EspaÒa-class battleships.

This is a small battleship armed with two main gun turrets, numerous medium caliber secondary guns, and smaller weapons as a tertiary battery.  They are slow with heavy armor.  These battleships aren't able to fight a modern battleship one on one, but they are more than a match for cruiser if they close the range.  Historically, this was the Swedish Sverige-class or Greek Kilikis-class battleships.

These are small battleships which are suitable for use in coastal waters.  They are armed with two or four 254mm guns, or a similar caliber weapons, with numerous secondary and tertiary weapons.  They have lighter armor than full sized battleships, but still have heavier armor than cruisers.  For their size, these ships are heavily armed.  Historically, this was the Norwegian Norge-class and Danish Peter Iuels-class coast defense battleships.

The first world war provided a wealth of experience in fleet operations.  Fleet commanders learned how to use and maneuver large groups of warships.  Admiralty Boards learned how to use advantages of wireless communications with distant fleets.  The use of convoys to combat attacks by submarines was another valuable lesson that was learned.

For decades, the fastest ship to cross the Atlantic Ocean has been the holder of the fabled 'Blue Ribband.'  The ship that holds the Blue Ribband at any particular time has the distinction of being the fastest, and usually the most popular vessel making the crossing.  The design of these ships is much more complex than the design of other passenger liners.  They have larger, more elegant passenger spaces and the engine spaces are larger and more complex as well.  Historically, this was the British Queen Mary and the French Normandie.

Anti-submarine operations in the North Atlantic require a vessel larger than a standard destroyer.  The escort sloop trades speed for a more stable hull and better endurance.  These sloops differ from their larger cousins by having more anti-submarine warfare capability and smaller guns.  Historically, this was the British Flower-class and Australian Grimsby-class sloops.

The conversion of merchant vessels is a quick way to get serviceable warships.  Unfortunately, these converted warships still have the vulnerabilities common to all merchant ships.  They lack subdivision and redundancy of machinery that is typical of other warships their size.  They are armed with multiple medium or small caliber guns.  Historically, this was the German raiders Atlantis and Thor.

These cruisers are slow and heavily armored and armed.  They are typically armed with a few large caliber guns and numerous smaller weapons.  Their slow speed prevents them from operating in a scouting role for modern fleets, but their heavy armament and armor makes them effective at protecting convoys from commerce raiders.  Historically, this was the Italian San Giorgio-class and Japanese Idzumo-class armored cruisers.

These ships are useful for scouting and serving as flagships for destroyer flotillas.  Armed with numerous small or medium caliber guns as a main armament, they are designed to rely on firepower and speed rather than armor protection.  Historically, this was the Japanese Sendai-class and German Emden-class light cruisers.

This is a small, lightly armed, and unarmored cruiser typically used for colony defense.  They are armed with numerous small guns (127mm) as the main battery.  Historically, this was the US Chester-class and German Gazelle-class cruisers.

These are small destroyer with minimal armament and protection.  Typically armed with three or four 105mm guns and eight torpedoes, these are the first effective fleet destroyers.  They are designed to counter enemy torpedo attacks and make torpedo attacks of their own.  These destroyers are typical of the mass produced designs from World War I.  Historically, this was the US Clemson-class and UK V-Class destroyers.

These are small destroyers with minimal armament and protection.  Typically armed with two or three 105mm guns and four torpedoes, these are basic destroyers.  They aren't well suited for combat with modern naval units, but they are sufficient for use by small nations.  Historically, this was the Brazilian Para-class destroyers or Danish Dragen-class torpedo boats.

These large vessels are designed to carry passengers on voyages across the Atlantic or Pacific Oceans.  During times of war they are readily convertible into troop transports.  Liners are also used for conversion into auxiliary warships.  These ships' high speed comes from extremely large engines and long hulls.  Their large size and complicated engine plant mean that they are more difficult to build than standard merchant vessels.  Historically, this was the British liner Queen Mary or French liner Normandie.

These small, general purpose vessels are cheap and easy to build.  Powered by a large marine diesel engine, it has a long range and a small engineering crew.  These vessels typically have an amidships house, and three or four cargo holds located at the ends of the vessel.

These small, general purpose vessels are cheap and easy to build.  Powered by an efficient reciprocating engine that gives fairly good range and a small cargo carrying capacity, these vessels make up the bulk of national merchant marines.  The superstructure is typically located amidships, and there are three or four cargo holds located at the ends of the vessel.

These are basic designs that can be built by most nations.  These transports, destroyers, cruisers, and battleships are mostly characterized by numerous small guns and slower speeds than later designs.  These designs are typical of warships built prior to, and during World War I.

These are specialized troops trained to make assaults on enemy held beaches.  Because of the high level of training required to make these assaults, these troops are considered elite in many nations.  The use of marines date back to the days of sailing ships when they were used to defend warships against boarders and to provide anti-personnel fire.  More recently, marines have been used to protect national interests in foreign countries.

Basic training allows regular infantry units to make attacks on enemy beaches.  The use of basic landing craft such as prams or barges allow troops to be landed on a hostile shore.  These improvised landing craft are unable to withstand enemy fire, so their ability to attack defended beaches is limited.

The director is the key component of a centralized fire control system.  All of the range and bearing information is gathered in the director which calculates the fire control solution.  The targeting information is transmitted to the turret where the gunner puts the turret on target and fires the guns.  The gunner simply has to match the turret settings with the settings transmitted from the director to hit the target.

Information from spotters located high in the vessel is passed to a central location.  This information allows more accurate correction of the range information which is transmitted to the individual gun turrets.
These are basic optics that improve the ability to hit the target in conditions other than perfect visibility.  These optics provide minimal amounts of magnification and light amplification.

Fire control is necessary to ensure that the weapons hit the target.  Basic technology is needed to start the process of moving the targeting of weapons from the individual gun pointer to more centralized locations.

This is the initial development for surface torpedoes.  Torpedoes are warheads that are driven to their target with a motor.  They strike the target below the waterline allowing water to flood the target and sink her.  Experimentation is necessary to get the torpedo to run straight and at the correct depth.  These torpedoes are a relatively short ranged weapon with a small warhead.  Historically, this was the British Whitehead torpedo.

The production of large marine diesel engines is useful because of their efficiency in the use of fuel.  A marine diesel engine runs on lower grades of diesel fuel than are needed by road vehicles because of the larger size of the pistons.  It takes a lot of development work to be able to build a diesel engine that has enough power to efficiently propel a vessel of any size.

Steam from the boiler is injected into the turbine where it hits blades which are attached to a central hub.  The force of the steam hitting the blades causes the hub to turn.  The hub is attached directly to the propeller shaft.  This allows high speeds in a small engine.  Steam turbines aren't as efficient in fuel use because of the need to keep rotation speed small to avoid propeller cavitation.

This is the first type of engine development and the most simple.  Steam from the boiler is injected into a series of cylinders where expansion of the steam pushes the pistons.  The pistons are connected to a rod which is attached to the propeller shaft.  Most engines of this type have three cylinders per propeller shaft.  These plants are efficient in fuel use, but are difficult to maintain because of the wear and tear from stopping the pistons and rods at the end of each stroke.

A basic steam plant generates low pressure steam (50-100 psi) for use in providing power and propulsion for the vessel.  The steam is generated in a boiler and then run through a piston or turbine.  The steam is then run through a condenser and condensed back into water.  The condensed water is pumped back into the boiler to start the process again.

Marine engineering is the study of how to get ships to move through the water.  The main concept is how to generate steam and use it to turn the propeller.  This is done many ways, but the two main ways are through pistons or turbines.  Basic engineering is also used to design basic weapons systems.

Battleships are designed to fight any vessel, anywhere.  Battleships have heavy armor and guns designed to sink enemy vessels at long range.  In addition to their heavy main battery guns, they also have numerous smaller weapons as a secondary anti-ship and anti-aircraft battery.  They are also useful in supporting amphibious operations by firing at targets on shore.

Cruisers are the workhorses of any fleet.  In times of peace, cruisers are useful for protecting national interests by 'showing the flag' in foreign ports.  In times of war, cruisers are useful in scouting and escort duties.  Cruisers have evolved from having smaller weapons spread in individual mounts around the vessel to having their guns concentrated into turrets.

The design of destroyers has evolved from turn of the century torpedo boats.  As the torpedo boats became larger, the torpedo boat destroyer became large enough to operate with the fleet.  The destroyer eventually replaced the torpedo boat all together.

Transport designs are fairly generic.  Transports are designed to maximize the internal volume for carrying cargo.  Merchant ships are also designed to be easily run by a small crew.  They typically have one, large engine room with the boilers and associated control equipment in a single space.

The design of naval and merchant vessels is a technical process.  The design has to have a balance between the amount of weight used for weapons, armor, and propulsion.  The ability of countries to make their own designs with outside help requires the training of skilled personnel.  These personnel are trained to make the detailed plans that are required for building complex designs.

These vessels are necessary for replenishing the fuel used by vessels while they are underway.  This fuel is typically transferred while the vessel is tied to a pier.  Following the development of underway replenishment doctrines, the transfer of fuel can occur while the ships are at sea.

These vessels are necessary for replenishing the ammunition of warships following battle or target practice while away from base.  This transfer of ammunition typically happens while the ship is tied up to a pier. Following the development of underway replenishment doctrines, these transfers can occur while the ships are at sea.

These vessels are necessary to get supplies from naval bases to the vessels that require them.  These supplies include everything from food to spare parts and replacement personnel.  These are typically merchant vessels that have been acquired for use by the navy.

This is the infrastructure required to maintain the fleet in operational status.  This includes long range communications, naval strategy boards, naval training schools and other support activities.  Bases have to be established to provide locations to repair and replenish ships.

This is the infrastructure needed to procure supplies for supporting naval operations outside of coastal waters.  Logistical support is provided by a central organization which ensures commonality throughout the fleet.

This is heavy armor that is used as the main belt armor of battleships and battlecruisers.  The armor is face hardened through use of metals other than steel and special processes.  This gives the armor the ability to break up enemy shells on the face of the armor, but still retain enough flexibility to not shatter.  A softer backing material provides the flexibility.  Historically, this was the Harvey and Krupps face hardening processes.  This armor is also known as 'Class A' armor.

This is light armor that is the main belt armor for cruisers and other small warships.  This armor is also used as the superstructure armor on heavy warships like battleships.  The armor is homogenous meaning that the armor properties are uniform through the thickness of the armor.  This armor is also known as 'Class B' armor.

The construction of large bore, heavy naval rifles make the construction of battleships truly possible.  These large naval rifles fire two or three shells per minute and are loaded with machinery within the turret.  The shell is loaded separately from the powder which is contained in several bags.  The bags of powder are loaded after the shell is in place.  These guns serve as the main battery for battleships, battlecruisers, and armored cruisers.

The construction of medium bore, rapid firing naval rifles requires different skills than are used for manufacturing smaller weapons.  These weapons typically have a separate shell and cartridge to keep the total weight down.  The shell is still light enough to be loaded by a single person.  These weapons serve as the main battery for cruisers and also as secondary battery weapons on battleships.

The construction of small bore, rapid fire naval rifles is necessary for the construction of any warship.  These guns serve as the main battery for small warships and as the secondary or tertiary batteries, of large warships.

The construction of naval vessels takes very specialized equipment.  The slipways needed to build the hulls of large naval vessels have to be able to support the additional weight of armor.   The redundant engineering systems also add weight to the hull.  There have to be facilities for the installation and testing of the combat systems.

The construction of merchant vessels is more simple than the construction of naval vessels.  This is due to the large spaces within the vessel and a more simplified layout. Because of the reduced crew complement, the superstructure is also simplified compared to a warship.
These are the basic industries that are needed by a country before the buildup of naval forces.  This includes the construction on infrastructure and ship design capabilities.

When nuclear fission was first discovered, the navy was quick to see the potential as a propulsion system that wouldn't require air.  The reactor is used to heat water.  The superheated water is sent into a steam generator where the radioactive water is used to make non-radioactive steam.  The steam runs a conventional steam turbine to provide propulsion.  The water is pumped back into the reactor as coolant and the cycle restarts.  These are the first submarines built since before World War I that use a steam turbine for propulsion.

Improvements in Air Independent Propulsion systems allow better designs to be developed.  The heart of these new designs are better engines, but there are also improvements in the auxiliary systems which have been developed from war experience.

The development of the nuclear reactor means that a submarine can be built that is totally independent from outside air for propulsion.  The power plant consists of a water cooled nuclear reactor that is used to generate steam which is used for driving a standard steam turbine.  The nuclear reactor doesn't need air which means that the submarine is only limited by the endurance of the crew.  The only limitation to the submarine's range is the amount of food that can be carried onboard.  Historically, this was the US Nautilus-class and Soviet November-class nuclear submarines.

Improvements in the Walter turbine enabled the submarines equipped with the turbine to be more effective.  Hydrogen-peroxide is broken into hydrogen and oxygen then combined with diesel to create steam which is run through the turbine.  This allows the submarine to make short bursts of submerged speed while attacking enemy convoys and taskforces.  This allows them to evade counterattacks more effectively.  These submarines have less range than a standard long range submarine because of the hull space that is taken up by the hydrogen-peroxide tanks means that less diesel fuel is carried.

Improvements in the Walter turbine enabled the submarines equipped with the turbine to be more effective.  Hydrogen-peroxide is broken into hydrogen and oxygen then combined with diesel to create a steam that is run through the turbine.  This allows the submarine to make short bursts of submerged speed while attacking enemy convoys and taskforces.  This allows them to evade counterattacks more effectively.  These submarines have less range than a standard medium range submarine because of the hull space taken up by the hydrogen-peroxide tanks means that less diesel fuel is carried.

Improvements in the Walter turbine enabled the submarines equipped with the turbine to be more effective.  Hydrogen-peroxide is broken into hydrogen and oxygen and then combined with diesel to create a steam that is run through the turbine.  This allows the submarine to make bursts of submerged speed while attacking enemy convoys and taskforces.  This allows them to evade counterattacks more effectively.  These submarines have less range than a standard short range submarine because of the hull space taken up by the hydrogen-peroxide tanks means that less diesel fuel is carried.

Improvements in the closed-cycle process enabled improvements to be made in the original closed-cycle  designs.  Liquefied oxygen is carried onboard the submarine to provide air for the diesel engines while running submerged.  This oxygen is mixed with an inert gas like argon which is recycled to save space.  It also makes the combustion process more efficient.  These submarines are larger than standard long range submarines in order to provide space for the cylinders of oxygen.  Unfortunately, there is still less room for fuel within the hull giving them a shorter range than standard long range submarines.

Improvements in the closed-cycle process enabled improvements to be made in the original closed-cycle designs.  Liquefied oxygen is carried onboard the submarine to provide air for the diesel engines while running submerged.  This oxygen is mixed with an inert gas like argon which is recycled to save space.  It also makes the process more efficient.  These submarines are larger than standard medium range submarines in order to provide space for the cylinders of oxygen.  Unfortunately, there is still less room for fuel within the hull giving them a shorter range than standard medium range submarines.

Improvements in the closed-cycle process enabled improvements to be made in the original closed-cycle submarines.  Liquefied oxygen is carried onboard the submarine to provide air for the diesel engines while submerged.  This oxygen is mixed with an inert gas like argon which is recycled.  This makes the process more efficient.  These submarines are larger than standard short range submarines to provide room for the cylinders of oxygen.  Unfortunately, there is still less room for fuel within the hull giving them less range than standard short range submarines.

The improvements in submarine technology have been aimed towards developing this generation of submarines.  This class of submarines includes all of the improvements that have been developed in pressure hulls, diesel engines, sensors and batteries.  These submarines are more capable than previous generations of long range submarines.  They are able to dive deeper and stay submerged longer than their predecessors.  This makes them very capable while attacking enemy convoys or taskforces.  Historically, this was the US Guppy modified Gato-class and Soviet Foxtrot-class submarines.

All of the improvements in submarine technology have been leading up to this generation of submarines.  This submarine includes all of the improvements that have been developed in pressure hulls, diesel engines, sensors, and batteries.  These submarines are able to dive deeper and stay submerged than their predecessors.  This makes them very capable while attacking convoys or enemy taskforces.  Historically, this was the German Type XXI-class U-Boats.

All of the improvements in submarine technology have been leading towards this design.  This submarine combines all of the improvements in pressure hull, sensors, battery and diesel engine technologies.  These submarines are able to dive deeper and stay submerged longer than their predecessors.  This makes them very effective in attacking convoys or taskforces.  Historically, this was the Japanese Sen(suikan) taka sho-class submarines and German Type XXV-class U-Boats.

The use of the nuclear reactor to power a submarine will increase the ability of the submarine to operate.  With the development of aircraft and increased sensor ability, it is dangerous for submarines to operate on the surface.  Even technologies like the Walter Turbine and the Closed-cycle engine need to put a snorkel above the water to get the most out of those systems.  The nuclear reactor will allow the submarine to remain submerged almost indefinitely because of its complete independence from air.

Improvements to the Walter Turbine allowed the engine to become more efficient.  The turbine works by breaking hydrogen-peroxide into its base components of hydrogen and oxygen which are very hot.  The oxygen is mixed with diesel fuel and ignited by the temperature of the oxygen.  The gas and hydrogen are run through the turbine in the same manner as a conventional steam turbine.

Improvements to the concept of the closed-cycle engine allowed it to become more efficient.  It was observed that combining the oxygen with an inert gas like argon would improve the efficiency of the engine.  The argon is injected with the oxygen into the cylinder of the engine and then collected as exhaust on the other end of the reaction.  The collected argon is recycled so the amount of argon carried onboard is minimal.

These designs are the culmination of years of submarine development which stretch back to the late 1800s.  These submarines use technology which was undreamed of just years before.  They are a combination of lessons learned through combat and the evolution of submarine and naval design.

The use of the Walter Turbine gives the submarine the ability to make short sprints at high speeds to avoid enemy counterattacks.  Hydrogen-peroxide is broken down and combined with diesel to provide steam for the turbine.  The steam is highly corrosive and explosive so the system is hazardous to use.  The submarine is larger than a standard long range submarine to make room for the large hydrogen-peroxide tanks, but there is still less room for diesel fuel.

The use of the liquid oxygen to provide air for the diesel allows the batteries to be recharged while the submarine is operating submerged.  This system works to supplement the snorkel when the boat is unable to raise the mast due to enemy attacks.  This increases the distance and speed that the submarine can use for evading attacking enemy forces.  By increasing both the distance and the speed, the area that the enemy forces have to search is increased exponentially.  This will result in the submarine surviving the encounter more frequently.

The use of nuclear power for submarines gives them large advantages over any conventionally powered submarine.  The main advantage is the ability to remain submerged without having to worry about providing air for diesel engines or fuel for alternative engines.  This will give the submarine nearly limitless range.  This will be a long process of design and experimentation.

The problem with torpedoes is that once they were fired no changes could be made.  With the inclusion of a control wire into the torpedo will allow simple commands to be sent to the torpedo and information to be sent from the torpedo back to the submarine.  A lightweight, extremely thin wire is connected to the submarine and spooled out as the torpedo runs toward the target.  This set-up allows the torpedo to run maneuvers which will help keep the location of the firing submarine more in doubt.

With submarines operating underwater for longer periods of time, the need for a method of underwater navigation became apparent.  The internal navigation system uses sensors to record the path that the submarine has taken since submerging.  Three sensors measure the submarine's movement in the six axis of motion.  This information allows the navigator to determine the position of the submarine to a certain degree.

Advances in hydrophones combined with advances in active sonar systems resulted in combined systems that are better than the individual parts.  These sonar systems are able to accurately track submerged targets and targets on the surface.  The hydrophones are able to accurately measure the bearing of the sound as well as signal strength which allows passive sonar tracking of targets.

Improvements in optics meant that new periscopes were more precise than their predecessors.  Ranging with the periscope was done with a stadimeter which compared two images.  The waterline of the upper image was 'brought down' to the masthead of the lower image.  Using the height of the mast the range can be determined.  The accuracy of the optics will affect the accuracy of the range prediction.  These improved periscope optics allow for more accurate range estimations and better performance in low light situations.

Improvements in power generation also meant that there were improvements in the equipment that is used for charging the batteries on submarines.  These chargers are able to charge the batteries more quickly than their predecessors.  The use of a trickle charger which adds a small amount of current to the batteries continuously keeps the batteries charged to full capacity.

Improvements in the storage batteries allowed for more efficient storage of energy for use by the electric motors which drive the submarine while submerged.  These batteries are sealed units which don't require maintenance by the crew to keep them operating.  This makes them more safe to operate and less prone to damage than their predecessors.

These are lightweight, powerful engines.  The extensive use of aluminum in the construction of the engine means that the weight is saved for other systems on the submarine.  These engines are also more powerful than their predecessors.  These diesel engines are also easier to maintain through more simple construction.  The cast aluminum parts are easy to manufacture which means that engine production can be dispersed into different manufacturing locations.

Improvements in the design of pressure hulls meant that the newest generation of the submarine would be able to dive deeper.  These new pressure hulls had to be more hydrodynamic to support the higher speeds that are required by operations.  These pressure hulls are also more resistant to damage through more advanced metals and better welds.  These pressure hulls also have fewer penetrations which would weaken the hull.

The improvements in submarine building technology would provide the technology that would lead the submarine into the post-war period.  This technology was developed in response to the improvements in anti-submarine technology that was making life difficult for the submarine.  Most of these technologies were designed to give the submarine increased ability to attack and move while submerged.

The Walter Turbine Engine allowed a submarine to make short bursts of speed while submerged.  The Walter Turbine converted hydrogen peroxide into steam which powered the turbine when combined with diesel fuel.  The turbine required large volumes of hydrogen peroxide to operate which meant that the submarine used a lot of the volume available for the storage of fuel.  This meant that the submarine is larger than other medium range submarines.  The volume used for the hydrogen peroxide means that the range is reduced compared to other medium range submarines.  Historically, this is the German Type XXVII class U-Boats.

The Walter Turbine allowed a submarine to make short bursts of submerged speed.  The Walter Turbine converted hydrogen peroxide into steam which powered the turbine when combined with diesel fuel.  The turbine required large volumes of fuel to operate which meant that the submarine used a lot of the volume available for the storage of fuel.  This meant that less volume was available for diesel which gave these submarines less range.  Historically, this was the German Type XXII-class U-Boats.

The development of the closed-cycle engine meant that submarines could be developed that could use their engines for a short period of time while operating submerged.  This is accomplished through using liquefied oxygen contained in tanks to supply air to the diesel engine while submerged.  These submarines are larger than other medium ranged submarines due to the requirement of fitting large tanks to carry the liquefied oxygen.  Historically, this was a number of prototypes developed by Germany and utilized by the other nations following the armistice.

The development of the closed-cycle engine meant that submarines could be developed that could use their engines for a short period of time while operating submerged.  This is accomplished through using liquefied oxygen contained in tanks to supply air to the diesel engine while submerged.  The space taken up by the oxygen tanks means that the torpedo complement is limited.  Historically this was the Soviet Project 618 prototype submarine.

Improvements in the equipment available for constructing submarines were incorporated into the designs for long range submarines.  These submarines are able to use their improved designs to make more effective attacks on enemy convoys and taskforces.  Historically, this was the US Tench-class and British U-class submarines.

The acoustic homing torpedo uses the noise generated by the target's propeller to home on the target.  The torpedo has four hydrophones spaced around the body of the torpedo.  The torpedo is designed to turn the torpedo towards the loudest sound source.  The torpedo can search in both the horizontal and vertical planes.  The space in the torpedo that is needed for the hydrophones means that these torpedoes have a smaller warhead than other torpedoes, but it is usually sufficient to disable an attacking escort rather than necessarily sink it.

Improvements in radar technology allowed the radar antenna to be made smaller.  This allowed the antenna to be mounted on more submarines.  The improvements also allowed the radar to be used while the submarine was operating submerged.  A waveguide is placed into the periscope tube which will allow for more accurate ranging of targets.  This makes the periscope head slightly larger, but the advantage of being able to use the radar while submerged is a significant improvement.

The Walter Engine is a revolutionary concept for providing propulsive power while operating submerged.  The Walter Turbine Engine uses nearly pure hydrogen-peroxide and breaks it down into its base components of hydrogen and oxygen.  This mixture was hot enough to generate steam.  Diesel fuel was injected into the hot mixture which increased the temperature and pressure of the steam.  This steam was injected into specially built turbines to provide propulsion.  This turbine propulsion allows the submarine to be maneuvered at high submerged speeds.  The drawbacks to this system were the highly corrosive effects of the fuel itself and the high volatility of the fuel which would explode if not handled correctly.

The concept of the closed cycle engine is to give the submarine a way to supply oxygen to the engines while running submerged.  This is accomplished by having compressed oxygen in cylinders supply oxygen for the engines.  This allows the engines to be run when the submarine is unable to use the snorkel or surface.  Unfortunately, this is a capability that has to be built into the submarine and can't be retrofitted into existing hulls.

The development of the snorkel didn't just include the development of the hardware itself, but also included the development of the tactics necessary to utilize the new system in combat.  The use of the snorkel would enable the submarine to recharge their batteries while operating submerged.  This will allow the submarine to avoid one of the most vulnerable periods in their operations: operating on the surface while recharging their batteries.
