The snorkel is fitted to a retractable mast on the conning tower of the submarine and is fitted with a valve that will prevent water from entering the submarine while submerged.

As submerged attacks became more of a necessity, it became apparent that the deck gun was becoming obsolete.  The development of radar meant that submarines were no longer able to make night attacks on the surface.  The removal of the deck gun would have the added benefit of increasing the submerged speed of the submarine because of the reduced drag from removing the deck gun.  This also made the submarine quieter by removing a source of noise from the water swirling around the parts of the gun.

As the war continued, more operational experience was gained.  At the beginning of the war, submarines had been able to make attacks with little to worry from counterattacking destroyers and aircraft.  As anti-submarine experience improved, submarine losses started to increase at frightening rates.  Measures had to be developed to enable the submarine to remain effective in this more deadly environment.

The improvements in the technology available for constructing submarines resulted in submarines that were superior to their predecessors in both attack and defense.  The medium range submarine was designed to be mass produced and be used to cut the lines of communications of the enemy.  These submarines are more capable of penetrating the anti-submarine screens of enemy convoys and then evade counterattacks.  Historically, this was the German Type VII/42-class U-Boats.

The improvements in the technology available for constructing submarines resulted in a new generation of submarines.  The smaller, short range submarines were the first ones that benefited from the improved technology.  The small submarines were more able to penetrate the anti-submarine screens for enemy convoys and taskforces and evade counterattacks by enemy destroyers.  Historically, this was the German Type IID-class U-Boats.

Improvements in electronics allowed for more precise hydrophones to be developed.  The improvement in the accuracy in the hydrophones would allow effective attacks to be made without having to visually track the target through the periscope.  This meant that an attack could be made without having to expose the submarine on the surface.  More accurate hydrophones also allowed the submarine to make more efficient evasion maneuvers because they could more accurately track the attacking destroyers.

Although the concept behind the periscope is simple, it is possible to find way to improve the periscope.  The optics that make up part of the periscope are the first step in improving performance.  Better manufactured optics will make estimates of heights and bearings more accurate.  There are also improvements that can be made in the ability of the periscope to resist damage.

The improvements that allowed small generators to be used to provide emergency power for damage control allowed the generators used for recharging the batteries to be made smaller.  These improvements included advances in the tightness of the windings within the commutator and the efficiency of the generator.

Improvements in the batteries used in submarines would give them extra range while submerged.  The use of different metals than the traditional lead meant that the batteries would be more efficient during charging and discharging the energy.  These batteries are also more resistant to damage because they can be sealed.  Previous batteries tended to leak when exposed to extreme lists or trim.  By sealing the battery it would reduce the deadly chlorine gas that occurred when acid was mixed with seawater.

The new diesel engine technology is mainly concerned with getting more horsepower out of a smaller package.  By developing smaller diesel engines it would free up valuable internal space for other equipment.  The improvements would also allow the fuel efficiency of the new engines to be improved.  This would allow the submarines to operate at longer ranges from their bases.

With the development of propulsion systems that allowed the submarine to remain submerged for longer periods of time meant that underwater performance became more important than surfaced performance.  The idea was to eliminate sharp edges which reduce the underwater performance and also provide surfaces for air bubbles to develop which makes the submarine noisy while running submerged.  The flooding system also had to be redesigned to eliminate the large free flooding holes in the exterior of the hull.

Improvements in design and construction of the pressure hull meant that the next generation of submarines would have better operational ability.  They would be able to dive deeper and be more resistant to damage.  Much of this additional strength comes from the ability to distribute the stress more evenly over the surface of the pressure hull through the use of welding the seams.

As the war continued, naval architects were able to come up with design solutions that would allow the next generation of submarines to be more survivable.  These design improvements combined with new technologies would make these submarines the most technologically advanced that would be produced during the war.

The improvements in the ability of aircraft to attack submarines meant that it could be easier for the submarine to stay on the surface and fight the aircraft.  This meant that the number and size of the anti-aircraft had to be improved.  Large platforms are constructed on the forward and after sides of the conning tower where the guns can have large fields of fire.  This modification slows down the submarine because of the added weight and drag of the platforms and the guns.

When aircraft radar sets were converted from decimetric to centimetric wavelengths, the current radar detectors were unable to detect attacking aircraft.  This meant that a new detector had to be developed to enable the submarine to detect potential attackers before they are in range to attack.  These detectors are specially constructed to be quickly assembled and disassembled.  This allows them to be set-up and taken down while running on the surface and eliminate the need for extensive waterproofing.

This is a small radar set which is attached to a mast on the submarine.  The radar allows the submarine to accurately get the range of a target and attack more accurately.  It also allows the submarine to detect targets at greater range than is possible with just lookouts alone.  These radar antennas are specially constructed to allow them to be immersed in salt water for long periods of time.

With the increasing accuracy of sonar/ASDIC, it was realized that something had to be done to help submarines that had been detected.  A series of countermeasures were developed to create false targets on the enemy sonar.  These took a number of different shapes.  The most simple was a neutrally buoyant balloon which when released, would float underwater creating a target.  Another type was canister which would release bubbles which would reflect the sound waves creating a false target.

The pattern running torpedo is very important for use against convoys.  Many attacks failed because the torpedo simply missed the target.  Even in a convoy where many targets are bunched together, the odds of hitting a ship on the far side of the target were remote.  A pattern running torpedo increased the odds by giving the torpedo more chances to hit a target in the tightly bunched convoys.  The pattern run could be selected by the captain depending on the configuration of the convoy.  The captain could choose from a ladder pattern which would advance either right or left along the course of the convoy in long legs, or a snake pattern which would weave back and forth along a course line.

One of the most difficult jobs for submarines on patrol was finding targets to attack.  By coordinating with aircraft, the effective sighting range of the submarines was increased.  The aircraft would be launched to find convoys and other targets.  When a target was found, the position was radioed to a central control center which would pass on the information to the proper submarines

The use of submarines to scout enemy facilities and landing locations allowed for better intelligence to be gained.  Unfortunately, this meant that the submarine would be required to enter shallow waters that would make detection easier.  Once in the area where the observations were to be made, the submarine would take pictures through the periscope.  The benefit of the intelligence data was believed to outweigh the increased risk to the submarine.

Submarines are remarkably suited to modular construction.  The cylinders which make up the submarine's pressure hull are fairly easy to manufacture and then stick on a railroad car for transportation to the shipyard.  This means that the resources of the shipyard can be focused on assembling the submarine and any technical work that has to be done for completion.

Improvements in anti-submarine equipment and tactics meant that submarines were having to spend more time submerged.  This meant that methods had to be discovered that would allow the submarine to run submerged for longer periods of time in order to evade attacking escorts.  A Walter engine runs on Hydrogen Peroxide.  The oxygen is already contained in the fuel, so no external source of oxygen is necessary.  This means that the boat can run for extended periods of time submerged without needing air for the engines.  The difficulty with the Hydrogen Peroxide is the flammability of the fuel.  It is extremely flammable and poses an extreme explosion hazard.

Improvements in anti-submarine equipment and tactics meant that submarines were having to spend more time submerged.  The limitations of batteries meant that the range and maneuverability of the submarine was more limited while the submarine was submerged.  The concept of the closed cycle engine is that compressed oxygen is stored onboard the submarine for use in powering the diesel engine while the submarine is submerged.  This is only done while the submarine can't use its snorkel or other air breathing device to conserve the supply of oxygen.

The concept of the snorkel is simple.  Extend a pipe above the surface of the water to provide air for the diesels while the submarine is submerged.  Although the concept is simple, the execution of the idea is more complex.  The pipe that is extended above water has to have a reliable means for shutting to keep water out in the event that it goes beneath the surface.  The other problem is how to deploy the mast which contains the snorkel.  This meant that there needed to be a long period of testing and evaluation before the new tool could be used with operational units.

AS the war progressed, experience continued to find better ways for submarines to operate and to be built.  Tactics and equipment that were good were updated and improved.  Pre-war ideas that were obsolete were discarded.  This made the submarine force more formidable.

Improvements in the technology available for submarine construction allowed for improvements in the standard 'fleet boats' that made up the long range striking arms of most of the users of submarines.  These boats were more capable than their predecessors through increased ability to remain submerged, higher submerged speeds, and better detection equipment.  Historically, this was the US Gato-class, British T-class submarines and German Type-IX class U-Boats.

Experience early in the war showed that there were reliability problems with torpedoes.  Testing prior to the war was carried out under ideal conditions.  War shots were made at less than ideal angles and conditions.  As submarines came back into port reports were filed stating that the torpedoes were faulty.  Initially, the reports were dismissed as commanders trying to cover the fact that they were missing the target.  Eventually, it was realized that there really was something wrong with the torpedoes.  Further testing narrowed down the problems and allowed remedies to be found.

The increase in the number of attacks on submarines by aircraft was causing losses.  In order to counter these attacks, anti-aircraft guns had to be mounted.  These guns were different than the standard guns mounted on surface ships.  These guns were more waterproof due to the requirement for continuous immersion in salt water while the submarine was submerged.  Minimizing corrosion was important to prevent misfires.

Radar removed the advantage of darkness from the submarine.  Enemy surface ships and planes with decimetric radar sets were able to detect the surfaced submarines still on the surface.  The decimetric radar detector would allow the submarine to start diving before the radar signal would reach sufficient levels that the submarine would be detected.  Historically, this was the German Metox radar detector.

These are simple sound filters that will allow the operator to filter out background noise.  This is important in detecting targets at a distance.  By being able to pick up a target at a distance allows the submarine to move into position ahead of the target and track it longer.  It also allows the submarine to make more effective evasive maneuvers while avoiding attacking escorts.

Improvements in optics for fire control systems allowed for improvements in periscope technology as well.  The visual accuracy allowed for better ranging of targets.  The ranging was accomplished by using the height of the target on a reticule within the periscope.  These more accurate optics will make the submarine more effective.

Improvements in electronics allowed for improvements in detection equipment.  These new hydrophones were more precise than the old 'Y Tube' detectors that were previously mounted.  These new detectors had numerous receivers that were directional.  These hydrophones are placed in an arc that will allow for more precise directional information.  This allowed the submarine to make more effective attacks and evade counterattacks more easily.

One of the difficulties with submarine operations was insufficient supplies and range for extended operations.  This meant that a method had to be devised to supply submarines while still at sea.  Early in the war, a complex network of merchant vessels was used to resupply the submarines at sea, but they proved vulnerable to attack.  The solution to this was to build a submarine that could resupply other submarines at sea.  Historically, this was the German Type XIV-class (milch-cow) U-Boat.

The use of electric propulsion was experimented with before the war, but battery technology wasn't able to give the torpedo sufficient range to be effective.  With advances in battery technology, the concept of an electric torpedo became viable.  Electric torpedoes didn't leave a wake on the surface to alert the target of the incoming torpedo.  It also meant that it was more difficult for the escorting destroyers to trace where the torpedo came from and attack the submarine.

With the outbreak of war, it was discovered that many of the preconceptions that effected submarine designs during the interwar period were no longer valid.  One of the big differences was the almost immediate start to unrestricted submarine warfare.  Although many countries had agreed that submarines would follow the 'Rules of War' in the regard of prize laws.  Merchant ships were armed with weapons which meant that submarines had to make attacks without warning to avoid attacks.  This meant that new equipment had to be developed to operate under these conditions.

The improvements in the hulls and power plants for submarines meant that the units were much more capable than before.  Their range was longer, and they were more effective at attacking protected convoys with their higher speeds.  These were the mainline submarines that served as the heart of most nation's submarine forces for most of the war.  Historically, this was the German Type VIIC-class U-Boats and Italian Marcello-class submarines.

Improvements in the design of submarines are usually incorporated into smaller submarines before they are brought into the mainline fleet boats.  The improvements in pressure hull construction and power were fairly easy to adapt to the short range submarines.  Historically, this was the German Type IID-class U-Boats.

The use of welding made the submarine hull stronger.  With a riveted hull, the hull plates are held together with large metal studs.  With welding the two plates are joined on the edge effectively making one plate.  This means that the structure of the hull in stronger.  The stronger hull means that the submarine can dive deeper and be built more quickly.

During attacks by enemy anti-submarine forces, one of the limiting factors was the amount of time that the submarine could stay submerged.  The amount of oxygen was the main limiting factor.  When carbon dioxide level reached 7% it would be fatal to the crew.  The first type of air scrubber was basically a fire fighting OBA (Oxygen Breathing Apparatus) canister which would use a chemical process to emit oxygen.  This was a limited solution as it would only give additional time measured in minutes, but sometimes that would be enough to make the difference between survival and destruction.

The difficulty with previous charging systems was the use of separate propulsion and charging engines.  This resulted in a large percentage of the hull volume being taken up by the engineering spaces.  The new concept uses the same engines for propulsion and battery charging.  The generator used for charging is attached to a power take off on the forward side of the diesel engine.  The power that the engine can devote to moving the submarine is reduced while charging, but it frees up space within the hull for additional torpedo storage.

Improvements in energy storage technology found their way into the submarines.  These improvements resulted in batteries that could hold two or three times the charge of previous cells.  These cells were installed in chains within the hull to provide power while the submarine was operating underwater.

Improvements in anti-submarine tactics and equipment meant that submarines had to be able to operate at deeper depths than before.  Early submarines were able to operate at depths of around 60m (200 ft).  If this could be increased, it would allow submarines to operate deeper than the operational depth for depth charges.  These pressure hulls are designed to operate at depths of 75m (250 ft).

The next generation of submarines was designed using the experience that was gained during the period between the two world wars.  The technology that was developed would be used to design the next generation of submarines that would form the backbone of submarine forces for most of the war.

Operations in large ocean areas requires a lot of range.  The concept is to have the submarine able to have enough fuel and provisions to transit to the patrol site and still be able to return to base without further refueling.  This design is the culmination of the first generation of submarine designs.  They are designed to operate both against commerce and against enemy naval units.  Historically, this was the British Parthian-class submarines and German Type IXA-class U-Boats.

These are large submarines designed to carry one or two floatplanes.  The submarine has a large hangar located forward of the conning tower which holds the aircraft partially assembled.  When it is time to launch the aircraft, it is moved out onto the forward deck where the final assembly takes place.  The aircraft is launched from a catapult that is mounted into the forward deck.  These aircraft are used for scouting purposes as well as independent operations like sneak air attacks.  Historically, this was the Japanese Kaigun Dai-class submarines.

The concept of the cruiser submarine grew out of the desire to have a submarine design that could also serve as a gunned commerce raider during wartime.  These submarines were characterized by a large gun armament, and a large hull.  The large hull made these submarines very slow to dive, and unmaneuverable while operating underwater.  Historically, this was the US Argonaught-class and the French Surcouf-class submarines.

Following the Great War, the concept was put forward of large 'cruiser submarines' armed with a heavy gun armament that would serve as commerce raiders in a time of war.  The main armament for these submarines is a 152mm (6 inch) gun which has been modified for use on submarines.  This gun has additional waterproofing, and a smaller shell to facilitate operations onboard the submarine.

The use of aircraft aboard a submarine would improve the ability of the submarine to scout for the battlefleet and to conduct independent operations.  The aircraft is housed in a watertight hangar mounted on the forward end of the submarine.  A catapult runs along the forward deck of the submarine for launching the aircraft.  The submarine is vulnerable to attack while air operations are happening.  The submarine has to remain on the surface while the aircraft is assembled and launched.

The development of heavy torpedoes for surface ships allowed for longer range torpedoes that had larger warheads.  Unfortunately, submarine torpedo tubes were not as readily adaptable for conversion to the larger torpedo due to the physical location of the tubes as a part of the submarine's hull.  The submarine needs to be extensively modified to provide storage space and new torpedo tubes for the larger tubes.

Diving the submarine beneath the surface is a dangerous undertaking.  Because the process is so dangerous, numerous accidents occurred during the development of submarines and following their deployment with the fleet.  This required the development of specialized equipment to rescue the submariners following an accident and to recover the submarine.  The equipment consists of a diving bell which is lowered from a support vessel located on the surface.  The diving bell is attached to one of the hatches on the submarine and the hatch is opened.  After the hatch is closed, the diving bell is raised to the surface.  The process is repeated until the entire crew has been evacuated.

Air conditioning is used to keep the interior of the submarine cool.  Air conditioning works by circulating a coolant through a closed system.  This coolant is pumped into the piping on the cooling side of the system under pressure.  This coolant is allowed to expand at a controlled rate.  The expansion of the coolant absorbs heat as it evaporates into a gas.  The gas is returned to a compressor which removes the heat and returns the coolant to a liquid form where it can be used for cooling again.

This device is valuable for determining the depth of the water beneath the submarine.  This is important due to the errors that are present in the charts for many parts of the world.  If a submarine is unsure of the depth of the water beneath, then the submarine could be damaged during a dive.  The device sends out a sound wave which is bounced off the seafloor and received by a hydrophone.  It is a simple matter of calculating the distance based on the time it took for the signal to go from the boat to the seafloor and back.

The magnetic detonator works by detecting the variances in the Earth's magnetic field that a metal ship hull creates.  As the torpedo moves through the water, it will detect the changes in the magnetic field and detonate under the target.  This will hopefully break the ship in two as it vents the force of the explosion straight up into the most vulnerable spot on the ship.

The calculations for hitting a moving target with a torpedo requires a lot of calculations in order to have any chance of success.  Although these calculations are not difficult, they are time consuming.  By building a mechanical computer to perform these calculations, it makes the process faster and less prone to error.  The problem with these computers is the fact that while the calculations are being run, no part of the data can change.  This includes the course of the target and the course of the firing submarine.

The use of long range radios on submarines allows for better coordination of attacks by individual submarines.  The ocean is a large area to search, so the ability to transmit sighting reports to a central location that can pass the information onto the other submarines gives a large advantage.

Diesel engines were a relatively new technology when they started to be mounted in submarines.  These early diesel engines were not very reliable and were largely made individually.  The refinement of the technology allowed for better reliability of the engines and for increased production.  Another side effect of increased reliability was the decrease in fuel consumption.  This allowed the submarines to have greater range.

Early submarines had their fuel tanks mounted outside of the pressure hull.  This made them vulnerable to damage and also allowed leaks from the riveted construction of the fuel tanks themselves.  By moving the fuel tanks inside the pressure hull, it protected them from damage and helped to keep the fuel from being contaminated by seawater.

Submarine hulls had been optimized for operations on the surface.  With the emphasis on attacks from underwater, a higher priority was placed on underwater speed and maneuverability.  This required a longer hull form and larger control surfaces.

After the Great War, most of the investment in naval technology slowed down.  Much of this was due to the Washington Naval Treaty, but another part of it was due to the state of the world economy.  Most of the nations (other than Germany) continued with submarine research, but with the surplus of submarines left over from the war, there was little new construction.

Operations outside the North Sea against British commerce, required a submarine with longer range and more firepower.  These submarines have the longer range required for operations outside of the littoral zone near the coast that is required for operations against protected convoys.  Historically, this was the British L-class submarines and German U-43 class U-Boats.

The 127mm (5 inch) deck gun is more powerful than the 102mm gun that was mounted on submarines prior to and during the Great War.  During the war, it was discovered that submarines often used their deck gun in attacks made while operating on the surface.  In part this was due to the fact that early submarines didn't carry many torpedoes, so they were fairly precious.  The 102mm gun was discovered to lack the stopping power for the larger merchant vessels that were being built.  The new 127mm gun fires a smaller shell than the standard surface model to ease the storage requirements.

A hydrophone is basically a microphone that can be mounted underwater.  This allows the submarine to hear destroyers that are hunting them, allowing them to better evade attacks.  These microphones were directional which also helped narrow down the location of the attacking destroyers.

The pressure of the water can be used to determine the depth of the submarine.  A hydrostatic depth gauge works with a metal bellows which expands or is compressed depending on the depth of the water pressing on the bellows.  This bellow is attached through a set of gears to a needle which reads the depth on the gauge.

The development of the gyroscopic compass allowed for more accurate navigation while submerged.  A traditional magnetic compass works by a magnet that points toward magnetic north (different than true north).  This reading is further deviated by the steel of the hull and the movement of any metal within the hull.  A gyro compass works through a gyroscope which will track true north without error from the steel hull.  The drawback to this system is the size and weight of the gyro compass itself.

Reloading torpedoes can be a brutal process that was typically done while surfaced.  While operating in enemy waters it was difficult to accomplish.  A mechanical system replaced the manpower intensive system which relied on block and tackle dating from the days of sail.  This allowed torpedoes to be reloaded more quickly and while submerged.

The war showed the necessity of quick diving to escape attacks by destroyers.  The ballast tank design was improved by making the individual ballast tanks smaller and making the intakes for water larger.  This allowed that tanks to fill more quickly and allowed the submarine to dive more quickly.

Experience during the first world war allowed for improvements in the torpedoes that were to be used by the submarines.  One of the largest improvements was the increase in diameter in submarine torpedoes to 533mm (21 inch).  This allowed submarines to attack from longer ranges and have higher speed torpedoes.

The first world war was the first conflict where submarines took a large role in naval combat.  The Germans and British used their submarines from the beginning of the war in an anti-naval unit role.  They followed the 'rules of war' which said that commerce warfare would still work the same way that it worked during the Napoleonic Wars.  The introduction of unrestricted submarine warfare meant that any target in the war zone could be attacked without warning, warships and merchant vessels alike.

This is the first mass produced submarine design that is available.  These submarines have a very short range and are most useful for defense of coastlines and harbors.  Their short range prevents their use for extensive commerce interdiction.  Historically, this was the US L-class submarines and the German U-31 class U-boats.

A deck gun for use on a submarine has several differences from a weapon of the same caliber used on a surface warship.  These guns have to be able to stay immersed in salt water for long periods of time and still be serviceable.  This requires waterproofing on the gun and its controls.  There also has to be a different ammunition supply method due to the limited space onboard the submarine.

The torpedoes used on submarines was basically the same torpedo that was used by surface ships.  These torpedoes had to be modified to be used onboard the submarine.  The primary difference between submarine torpedoes and surface torpedoes was the diameter of the weapon.  Early submarines were too small to use the heavy 533mm (21 inch) torpedoes that were commonly used on surface ships.  The smaller torpedoes used by submarines meant that they had shorter range and smaller warheads than their surface launched counterparts.

The periscope allows attacks to be made while submerged.  A periscope is basically a hollow tube fitted with mirrors that allows a lens above the water to transmit an image down to the commander in the conning tower.  The length of the periscope was what determined 'periscope depth' for the submarine.  This was the greatest depth that the submarine could submerge to and still be able to carry out an attack.

This is system for recharging the battery banks that are used for underwater propulsion.  These chargers are connected to diesel engines that can only be used to charge the batteries while surfaced.  This limits the underwater endurance of submarines.

Initial submersible designs used human power while submerged.  This had limitation as to the size of the submarine and the underwater performance.  The inclusion of large banks of batteries would give the submarine the ability to move and maneuver while submerged.

Early submarines used simple gasoline engines for propulsion.  The problem with gasoline engines is the flammability of the fuel.  Gasoline fumes could build up in the hull where the proved to be a hazard to the crew and the submarine.  By using diesel for the fuel, it gave the submarine better range and better survivability.

Initial submarine experiments had hulls where they were kept underwater entirely by weight of the water in tanks.  This resulted in unreliable underwater performance due to the free surface effect of partially flooded ballast tanks.  This new design relies on horizontal rudders on the bow and stern called planes to maintain depth.  The submarine is designed to be neutrally buoyant with all of the ballast tanks full.  This gives the submarine better underwater performance.

The training of crews to man the submarines takes special schools.  You can't just take a man off a surface warship and expect him to be a submariner.  The establishment of training schools for the volunteers and the provision for trained personnel ashore to maintain the submarines is necessary before deployment of submarines can begin.

The first submarines were all unique designs.  These submarines served as prototypes to determine what were desirable characteristics in a design.  Once these characteristics had been determined, standardized designs could be produced in greater numbers for use with the fleet.

The first successful submarine attack occurred during the American civil war when the Confederate submersible Hunley sank the Federal frigate Houstatonic.  This proved that submarines could be effective for coastal defense.  A truly effective submarine design would have to wait until John Holland launched his first submarine in 1897.
Many nations in this era had primarily agrarian economies, based on food production and export.  They had little need for rubber, tungsten and other rare materials to power their light industries.

Late war designs, such as high velocity tank cannons, advanced vehicles and new types of planes required new standards of quality. Thanks to new methods of control and constant development of production process new, almost experimental designs, could be put into mass production almost instantly.
The Small Arms Assembly Construction Process allowed small arms to be assembled in vast quantities at one production site. This allowed infantry units to be produced quickly and inexpensively.

The partial sterilization treatment of a liquid such as milk by heating it in order to destroy harmful bacteria (increased Pasteurization), leads to better preservation of food, lower waste and better health.
Introduction to elements and compounds, chemical bonds, formulas and equations, this leads to research and development into many other related fields.

In the first half (1939-1943) of World War II German economy worked on the slow pace, not switching entirely to 'war mode'. That was mostly due to the political reasons - Germany was apparently winning the war, so there was no sense in mobilizing the industry. All have changed in 1943, when Germany suffered some major defeats including capitulation of the whole 6th Army in Stalingrad cauldron and allied landing in Africa. Facing combined forces of USA, USSR and UK Germany mobilized their industry by using workforce from occupied countries and redeploying production facilities to counter Allied bomber offensive. While very effective in terms of quantity, it also resulted in lower quality of the equipment and weapons.
This technology grants you a serious challenge by raising costs of R&D and units training. Also supplying existing units will be much more challenging.
This technology is intended to block special AI techs for human players. This technology is locked for AI's.

This technology is intended to allow AI's to develop technologies disabled for human players, as well as modify starting position of AI to allow it more competitive and effective R&D work. This technology is locked for human players.
After the war, tank technology advanced slowly, with scientific analysis of armor and firepower allowing much greater protection than believed possible under weight limitations.

The medium assault gun (75mm+ Medium) was based off a modified basic medium tank chassis, and mounted a medium 75mm+ Anti-Tank Gun. Historically, this was the German Sturmgeschutz III and Sturmgeschutz IV

These launchers were mounted on the sides of the turret, and when the tank was in trouble, the crew could trigger them from inside the tank, creating a instant smoke screen that could be used for defensive purposes.

Anti-Personnel Land-mines were mounted on the sides of the turret, and when the tank was being assaulted by infantry close in, the crew could electrically trigger them from inside, killing the attacking infantry.
A 80mm+ mortar is mounted inside the tank for use against attacking infantry and to provide smoke with smoke rounds. Historically, this was the German Nahverteidigungswaffe.

A small tank equipped with a remote control is used by engineer units to carry a large quantity of high explosives to a target and then detonate the explosives, destroying both itself and the target. Historically, this was the German Goliath.

Infantry support tanks were based around the Great War concept of the land battleship, advancing with infantry and breaking defenses thanks to turrets containing cannons or machine guns. Historically, this was the British Matilda I and II, French Renault R35 and Japanese Type 89 I-Go. Battalions of those were usually added to the units assaulting heavy fortified enemy positions.

Armored cars were used successfully in the Great War and they remained an important part of the arsenal of many countries in the inter-war years.  They were used in formations up to brigade size by some nations to fulfil roles previously conducted by horse cavalry, with armored car units normally attached on a battalion or brigade basis to an infantry force. Heavier armored cars were armed with tank cannons rather than machine guns which allowed them to be used in an anti-tank role, relying on superior mobility rather than armor to avoid destruction.

Armored cars were used successfully in the Great War and they remained an important part of the arsenal of many countries in the inter-war years.  They were used in formations up to brigade size by some nations to fulfil roles previously conducted by horse cavalry, with armored car units normally attached on a battalion or brigade basis to an infantry force. Most armored cars were armed with medium or heavy machine guns, making them primarily useful against infantry and cavalry.

Sloped Armour had existed to some degree in armored vehicles for many years. But not until World War II was it practically implemented in the overall design of tanks. The sloped armor increased the protection of armored vehicles without adding actual armor and weight. Instead the sloping armor could redirect a projectile, allowing it to skid off the vehicle's hull.

During the late 1930s, development of the tanks as fast, attack weapons was still countered by their 'traditional' role - infantry support. One of the designs prepared for this role was flame tank - usually standard light or medium tank with main armament (gun) replaced by heavy flamethrower. Flame tanks weapons had extremely short range, but were quite effective against fortified positions, as well as in jungle fighting. Historically those were German Pz III Flamm, Soviet OT-26 and OT-34 and US modifications of M4 Sherman.

This tankette was armed with a single .50 caliber Machine Gun. Historically, this was the British Carden-Loyd Mark VI an polish TK/TKS.Since their inability to survive on the battlefield, tankettes often were used as a scout vehicles.

This tankette was armed with a single .30 caliber Machine Gun. Historically, this was the British Carden-Loyd Mark I. Since their inability to survive on the battlefield, tankettes often were used as a scout vehicles.

A theory was put forward by the great French tank enthusiast General Estienne, who helped design France's first tank and was a proponent of the light tank, of the idea of skirmishers armed with light tanks rushing an enemy position. The idea was that the massive onslaught by a high speed and protected group of soldiers would be unstoppable in action. These tanks would be called Tankettes, and would have a crew of one man.

Infantry support tanks were based around the Great War concept of the land battleship, advancing with infantry and breaking defenses thanks to multiple turrets containing cannons or machine guns. Historically, this was the German PzKpfw.NbFw.V

Engineering tanks used specialized equipment and weapons to assist engineers in clearing obstacles and fortifications in front of the advancing troops. Historically, this was the Churchill AVRE, which mounted a 290mm spigot-type mortar gun known as the 'Petard', capable of damaging severely even the most sturdiest of fortifications.

The tank was a formidable opponent on the battlefield due to its protection and speed. It could be found alongside infantry, used in conjunction with other mechanized equipment or combined into a tank unit depending on the doctrine by which it was employed. The Advanced Medium Tank (75mm+ Medium).

After the first period of war it became obvious, that traditional methods of repairs not suit new, fast style of warfare. In battles most of the tanks were not destroyed, but damaged. Vehicles that were knocked off or received damage beyond their own ability to repair had to wait for repair teams, thus slowing the advance. The answer for that problem was the heavy evacuation vehicle, able to remove damaged tank right from the battlefield even under enemy fire and repair it right on the front line. Historically those vehicles were modifications of standard medium and heavy tanks, like M4 Sherman, Cromwell or Churchill.

The tank was a formidable opponent on the battlefield due to its protection and speed. It could be found alongside infantry, used in conjunction with other mechanized equipment or combined into a tank unit depending on the doctrine by which it was employed. The Improved Medium Tank (75mm+ Long) was equipped with a 70mm+ Long Tank Gun allowing it to defeat soft and medium armored targets. Historically this was the British A30 Challenger with a 17-pounder gun, and rebuilt lend-lease Sherman Fireflies.

The new breed of tanks combined both speed, firepower, and armor into a package that had been impossible just a few years ago. Examples of the new class of Main Battle Tanks, as they were now being called, were the Soviet T-54, the American M-46 Patton, and the British Centurion Mk. III.

The post war tank used the latest armoring techniques to allow for more protection on less weight than thought possible before. Sometimes those vehicles used modified versions of standard large caliber howitzers, as it was much easier to manufacture and support. Historically, those models of tanks (like Russian IS-2 and IS-3) were put into service at the end or just after the war and become predecessors of modern main battle tanks.
The post war tank used the latest armoring techniques to allow for more protection on less weight than thought possible before. Historically, this was the British Centurion.
The post war tank used the latest armoring techniques to allow for more protection on less weight than thought possible before. Historically, this was the American M-46.
The tanks of the immediate post-war period had been designed in the closing days of the war, and as such, had not finished testing in time to participate in the war.
Due to experience gained with the early war tanks, tank tracks were re-designed to be more efficient in moving a tank around, with less wasteage of fuel and less wear and tear on the engine.

As the war progressed, it became apparent that some design features of tanks actually harmed their chances of survival, by allowing enemy shells to ricochet off certain areas and into thinner and less well-armored areas of the tank. The identification and removal of these so-called 'shot traps' greatly improved tank survival rates.

Now that the hectic pace of the war was over, a more leisurely and orderly approach to tank design could be followed, implementing all the lessons learned over the war years into a single coherent whole. This new tank design would replace both the medium and heavy tanks with a single tank known as the Main Battle Tank.

The Schmalturm (Narrow) turret was the result of a scientific study on the percentages of hits that a tank received on a particular arc. The front was found to be hit the most, and by narrowing the turret, a dramatic increase in frontal turret armor could be achieved. Historically, this was the German Schmalturm turret designed for the Panther II.
A .30 Caliber machine gun was mounted typically near the commander's hatch in a special mount designed for defense against attacking aircraft. Historically, this was the US M1919A6 in the AAMG role.
A .50 Caliber machine gun was mounted typically near the commander's hatch in a special mount designed for air defense against attacking aircraft. Historically, this was the US M2HB in the AAMG role.

Armored cars were used successfully in the Great War and they remained an important part of the arsenal of many countries in the inter-war years.  They were used in formations up to brigade size by some nations to fulfil roles previously conducted by horse cavalry, with armored car units normally attached on a battalion or brigade basis to an infantry force. Most armored cars were armed with medium or heavy machine guns, making them primarily useful against infantry and cavalry.

While very attractive on the drawing boards, the whole super-heavy tank concept met serious problems when it come to implementation stage. Historically, units of super-heavy tanks never existed - Germans had 3 prototypes of 'Maus' tank and USA only toyed with the idea. If those tanks were ever put into action though, they would be used in small units attached to the larger, standard tank formations - just like earlier German Tiger battalions and Soviet IS regiments.

The post war tank used the latest armoring techniques to allow for more protection on less weight than thought possible before. Historically, those models of tanks were put into service at the end or just after the war and become predecessors of modern main battle tanks. 120mm long barrel tank gun was at the time ultimate anti-tank weapon and vehicles armed with this were ultimate tank-killers of the late war period as well.

As the war progressed, concept of armored cars developed from the mobile infantry support weapon to scouting vehicle, capable of long-range raids at the spearhead of the armored columns. Historically those were UK Staghound Mk. I-II, USA M8 Greyhound and German Sd Kfz 234/2 Puma.
Many tank crews welded applique armor consisting of armor plates salvaged from wrecked tanks over critical spots on their tanks, improving the armor thickness in those areas.
Refinements to HEAT ammunition allowed for greater velocity in mid-air than with the older HEAT rounds, and also greater penetrative power.

The application of Shaped Charge technology to conventional weapon ammunition created a new type of shell, the HEAT shell, which allowed even low velocity weapons to be able to knock out heavy tanks in a single shot.
Now that the Shaped Charge had been proven in combat, improvements were made, leading to greater penetrative power for the same weight of explosives.

The Shaped Charge dates back to the 1880s, but it was not until the 1930s and 1940s when it was scientifically analyzed. This would lead to a new type of weapon that was lightweight, yet capable of punching through incredible quantities of armor.
The first intercontinental bombers required special, new airframes to support extreme weight and size of the new planes.
Supersonic planes required special, new technologies to work in extreme conditions of supersonic speeds.
New bombers required special, new technologies to achieve supersonic speeds.
As World War II ground to a fiery halt, radical new systems were tested and fielded by both sides in a desperate attempt to gain the upper hand.

Unlike early war heavy tanks, vehicles like Pz VI Tiger or KW were mobile enough to support large tank formations without slowing them down. Better protection granted by armor and mobility made units armed with those tanks real elites.

The early war heavy tanks carried thick armor and reasonable firepower, but had little, if no mobility. Most of the time, heavy tank battalions were used as a reserve units - either to break heavy fortified enemy positions or to deny enemy breakthrough.
As World War II progressed, tank design improved and became more efficient and deadly as flaws were identified and corrected.

The tank was a formidable opponent on the battlefield due to its protection and speed. It could be found alongside infantry used in conjunction with other mechanized equipment or combined into a tank unit depending on the doctrine by which it was employed. The Advanced Medium Tank (85mm+) was equipped with an 85mm+ Tank Gun allowing it to defeat heavy armored targets. Historically this was the Soviet T-44

The tank was a formidable opponent on the battlefield due to its protection and speed. It could be found alongside infantry, used in conjunction with other mechanized equipment or combined into a tank unit depending on the doctrine by which it was employed. The Advanced Medium Tank (75mm+ Long) was equipped with a long barreled 75mm+ Tank Gun allowing it to defeat soft and medium armored targets. Historically this was the German PzKpfw V Panther, and the British Comet.

The tank was a formidable opponent on the battlefield due to its protection and speed. It could be found alongside infantry used in conjunction with other mechanized equipment or combined into a tank unit depending on the doctrine by which it was employed. The Improved Medium Tank (85mm+) was equipped with an 85mm+ Tank Gun allowing it to defeat medium armored targets. Historically this was the Soviet T-34-85

Now that tanks had proved themselves on the battlefield, the military establishments of the world looked for new uses for these land-based behemoths, ranging from useful applications to ones that were off-the-wall.

The Tank Destroyer was a tank chassis fitted with an Anti-Tank Gun. The Tank Destroyer would cooperate with the infantry and aid in the destruction of tanks and other hardened targets. The Medium Tank Destroyer (85mm+) was equipped with an 85mm+ Anti-Tank Gun allowing it to defeat medium tanks. Historically this was the Soviet SU-85 the German Elefant, Nashorn and Jagdpanther

The Tank Destroyer was a tank chassis fitted with an Anti-Tank Gun. The Tank Destroyer would cooperate with the infantry and aid in the destruction of tanks and other hardened targets. The Medium Tank Destroyer (75mm+) was equipped with a 75mm+ Anti-Tank Gun allowing it to defeat medium tanks. Historically this was the British Archer the US M18 Hellcat and the German Hetzer and Jagdpanzer IV

The tank was a formidable opponent on the battlefield due to its protection and speed. It could be found alongside infantry, used in conjunction with other mechanized equipment or combined into a tank unit depending on the doctrine by which it was employed. The Improved Medium Tank (75mm+) was equipped with a 75mm+ Tank Gun allowing it to defeat soft and medium armored targets. Historically this was the German PzKpfw IV Ausf F2-J, the Italian Carro Pesante P26/40, the Soviet T-34-76, the US M4 Sherman and the Japanese Type 2 Ho-I and Type 3 Chi-Nu.

The previous generation of tanks had proven themselves and already the military establishments of the world were drawing up plans for improved successors to the highly successful tanks currently in service. These Improved tanks would have thicker armor and more powerful guns than before.

Turrets large enough to hold three or more crew members drastically increased the efficiency of the vehicle. It gave the commander a respite from gun loading duties, allowing them to better command the vehicle. Larger turret sizes also allowed for improved radio receivers and even basic transmitters

This is a medium tank equipped with a powerful radio transmitter and receiver. These tanks were able to communicate with local tank formations as well as with Battalion HQ. Historically this was the Panzerbefehlswagen

Rivetted tank hulls offered a cheap and fast method of creating armored fighting vehicles, however sacrificing durability. Historically they were the early British Cruiser series and Italian Medium Tank series

Cast tank hulls were extremely durable and capable of shrugging off powerful hits, yet was extremely expensive and time consuming to produce. Historically this was the British Matilda and early Russian T-34 tanks

The Assault Gun was a tank chassis fitted with an Infantry Gun. The Assault Gun would cooperate with the infantry and aid in the destruction of hardened targets and function as direct fire support. The Light Assault Gun (150mm+) was equipped with a 150mm+ Infantry Gun allowing it to defeat only soft targets. Historically this was the German sIG 33 150mm

The Assault Gun was a tank chassis fitted with an Infantry Gun. The Assault Gun would cooperate with the infantry and aid in the destruction of hardened targets and function as direct fire support. The Light Assault Gun (120mm+) was equipped with a 120mm+ Infantry Gun allowing it to defeat only soft targets.
This is a medium tank mounting a short barreled 75mm+ Close Support gun.

The tank was a formidable opponent on the battlefield due to its protection and speed. It could be found alongside infantry used in conjunction with other mechanized equipment or combined into a tank unit depending on the doctrine by which it was employed. The Basic Medium Tank (37mm+) was equipped with a 37mm+ Tank Gun allowing it to defeat soft and lightly armored targets. Historically this was the Soviet BT-2, the French Hotchkiss H-39 and the German PzKpfw III E

The tank was a formidable opponent on the battlefield due to it's protection and speed. It could be found alongside infantry, used in conjunction with other mechanized equipment or combined into a tank unit depending on the doctrine by which it was employed. The Basic Medium Tank (MG) was equipped with a machine gun allowing to defeat only soft targets.

Development of the new generations of medium tanks, as well as new, more effective AT weapons, resulted in change of light tanks use. Unable to withstand modern battlefield firepower, light tanks were employed as recon vehicles and as a support for their heavier counterparts in hard terrain.

The Tank Destroyer was a tank chassis fitted with an Anti-Tank Gun. The Tank Destroyer would cooperate with the infantry and aid in the destruction of tanks and other hardened targets. The Light Tank Destroyer (37mm+) was equipped with a 37mm+ Anti-Tank Gun allowing it to defeat light tanks

The Assault Gun was a tank chassis fitted with an Infantry Gun. The Assault Gun would cooperate with the infantry and aid in the destruction of hardened targets and function as a direct fire support. The Medium Assault Gun (75mm+) was equipped with a 75mm+ Close Support Gun allowing it to defeat soft and medium armored targets. Historically this was the Soviet SU-76 the US M8 the British Churchill Mark I the German Sturmgeschutz III and Sturmgeschutz IV

The Assault Gun was a tank chassis fitted with an Infantry Gun. The Assault Gun would cooperate with the infantry and aid in the destruction of hardened targets and function as direct fire support. The Light Assault Gun (100mm+) was equipped with a 100mm+ Infantry Gun allowing it to defeat only soft targets.
After many stops and starts and failed design avenues, the first truly practicable tanks were about to be designed. They would combine armor, speed, and firepower to an unprecedented extent.
The Vickers suspension is common and inexpensive but did resulted in fairly slow tanks. Historically this was the Italian Medium Tank Series, Japanese Type 89 and Czech LT vs 35
The Christie suspension was expensive but resulted in an extremely fast tank. Historically this was the British Cruiser Tank Series, Russian BT and T-34 Series, German Pz.kpfw 38(t) and Panther

The tank was a formidable opponent on the battlefield due to its protection and speed. It could be found alongside infantry used in conjunction with other mechanized equipment or combined into a tank unit depending on the doctrine by which it was employed. The Improved Light Tank (37mm+) was equipped with a 37mm+ Tank Gun allowing it to defeat soft and lightly armored targets. Historically this was the US M3 Stuart, the French FCM 36 and R-35, and the Japanese Type 98A Ke-Ni and Type 2 Ke-To

The tank was a formidable opponent on the battlefield due to its protection and speed. It could be found alongside infantry used in conjunction with other mechanized equipment or combined into a tank unit depending on the doctrine by which it was employed. The Basic Light Tank (37mm+) was equipped with a 37mm+ Tank Gun allowing it to defeat soft and lightly armored targets. Historically this was the Japanese Type 95 Kyu-Go Ha-Go

The two decades between the two World Wars was a time of great experimentation into tankettes and multi-turreted monstrosities that in the end proved to be utterly impractical in real-world conditions. However, the experience gained in developing these abortive attempts would be invaluable in designing the first real workable tanks.

Tanks were first used in World War One to break the stalemate of the trenches. Most were armed with either machine guns or cannon. In some examples, both cannon and machine guns were fitted. Historically, this was the British Mark V tank.

The new improved General-Purpose Machine Gun, or GPMG, was an improvement over the previous model. It kept all of its advantages, but corrected its failings and took advantage of the latest advances in weapons technology and the experience achieved during the war. Like its predecessor, it could be changed from a light machine gun in support of an infantry squad to a heavy machine gun in the fire support role by simply mounting it onto a tripod and/or changing the feeding method from drums to belts. It was designed to be capable of holding sustained fire during long periods of time, using fast barrel change methods to minimize barrel weariness. Those changes were so fast that a 3 men MG group could perform it at the same time that the ammunition belt was changed. Historically, this was the German MG-42. Other countries adopted this design after the war and used it to make their own GPMGs, like the American M60.

The General-Purpose Machine Gun, or GPMG, was a completely new concept. It used the standard 7.62mm+ rifle caliber and was air-cooled, unlike the older water-cooled heavy machine guns of the past. It could be changed from a light machine gun in support of an infantry squad to a heavy machine gun in the fire support role by simply mounting it onto a tripod. Also, it could be belt or drum fed without having to modify the weapon at all. All these improvements made it very versatile and practical. Historically, this was the German MG-34.

The .30 caliber (7.62mm+) heavy machine gun remained essentially unchanged from its World War I origins, with only minor changes made to increase reliability, accuracy, and reduce weight. Historically this was the British Vickers .303 and French Hotchkiss

The 120mm+ Heavy Mortar allowed infantry units to carry an even heavier punch than was possible with the older 81mm Mortars. Historically, the Russians were the first to come out with a 120mm mortar, the M-1938 120mm. Shortly after Operation Barbarossa, the Germans pressed captured Russian Mortars into service, and eventually produced a carbon copy of the M1938, the 12cm Granatwerfer 42.

Improvements in guidance and manufacturing methods allowed the guided anti-tank missile to achieve its true potential against all hard targets.  Apart from cost, the only major drawback is the time to target which can allow an enemy tank to fire back and disable or suppress the guide if the launch flash is detected.

Those machine guns were direct evolution of Great War fighter planes armament, but of much better quality, rate of fire and ammo support. While not very effective against heavier targets, those guns served quite well against other fighter planes. Historically this was the American M2 .303 Browning, the British Vickers VGO .303
Among the best mountain guns ever built, large numbers of these weapons survived the war and were to be found in service with a number of European countries until the middle 1960s.

Further research and development into self-propelled AA systems corrected the faults of the earlier systems, making the new ones more deadly. This system also used the newly developed 50mm+ AA Gun. Historically, this was the Russian ZSU-57-2 Sparka.
Further research and development into self-propelled AA systems corrected the faults of the earlier systems, making the new ones more deadly. Historically, this was the American M-42 Duster.

Further research and development into self-propelled AA systems corrected the faults of the earlier systems, making the new ones more deadly. Historically, this was the German Flakpanzer IV (3cm) Kugelblitz.

The 70mm+ Recoilless Gun was the first of it's kind, and was designed for parachute units, so they could have a hard-hitting gun that was light and yet packed a strong punch. Historically, this was the German 75mm LG 40 Recoilless Gun and the American 75mm Recoiless M20

This remarkable howitzer was the heaviest weapon ever developed for mountain use. Among the best mountain guns ever built, large numbers of these weapons survived the war and were to be found in service with a number of European countries until the middle 1960s. Historically, this was the German Geb H 40 105mm Mountain Howitzer.

This was a 75mm+ Field Gun, but designed to have high elevation and be broken up into several easily manageable pieces that could then be transported by a few men each or pack animals. Historically, this was the German GebG 36 75mm Mountain Gun.

This low velocity gun fired a very large HE charge, and was found mostly on engineering vehicles. Examples included the British 290mm 'Spigot' Mortar known as the 'Petard' found on the Churchill AVRE.

Even 30mm cannons in ground attack aircraft were proving to have a hard time penetrating the armor of heavy tanks, and the answer was found in a modified 75mm cannon that had reduced recoil mountings. These cannons were so heavy and cumbersome that they could only be mounted in tactical bombers. Historically, this was the German 75mm BK 7.5 and the American 75mm M-4 Cannon. Later, these cannon were modified to fit onto Advanced Light Tanks such as the American M-24 Chafee.

The 75mm+ (Long) tank gun had nearly as much hitting power as the larger 88mm tank gun, but with less explosive power against unarmored targets. Historically, this was the German 75mm KwK 42 L/70 used on the Panther, and the British 17-pounder gun used on the Sherman Firefly and A30 Challenger.
The 75mm (Medium) tank gun had moderate hitting power, and historically was the US M3 75mm gun, the German 75mm KwK 40 L/43.

Soon, even 20mm cannons weren't enough to bring down the newest aircraft, and so, technicians looked ahead, to the 30mm cannon, which was capable of downing even the sturdiest fighter in one shot, and destroying a bomber in three. Examples included the German MK108 cannon.

As aircraft became faster and more sturdy, more firepower was needed to bring them down. Machine guns soon found themselves supplanted by 20mm and above cannons, which had the punch to down fighters in a few shots.

These machine guns replaced the earlier 7.62mm+ MGs (.30 Cal), and had greater range and firepower than the older rifle caliber guns. Examples of these new guns were the American M2 .50 Browning, the German MG131 (13mm).
The 50mm+ Anti-Air gun gave light AA units a more powerful, harder hitting gun that could reach out farther than the old 40mm guns. Historically, this was the Russian 57 mm S60 cannon.

The 85mm+ Recoilless Gun was designed for parachute and mountain units, so they could have a hard-hitting gun that was light and yet packed a strong punch but was very expensive. Historically, this was the German 88mm RW 43 P¸ppchen
New advances in artillery since the Great War has resulted in a modern and significantly more effective range of Heavy Artillery
This 200mm+ Heavy Artillery Gun was used by a few major powers. It was reliable and had an acceptable rate of fire and a medium range, although clumsy and fed with huge and heavy shells.

The 150mm+ to Infantry Gun was frequently used by many nations. Originally an elderly field artillery piece it was converted into infantry use. It retained the horrible range of the 70mm+ Infantry Gun but was too heavy to be used in the assault role but was very potent in breaking up enemy attacks
Advances in tank armor and speed have resulted in the demand for an anti-tank gun capable of destroying this new generation of armored fighting vehicles
The 85mm+ Tank Gun was a heavy gun capable of inflicting damage on armored vehicles. It could penetrate the armor of Medium Tanks and Heavy Tanks

Muzzle Brakes redirect much of the gas out of the side of the barrel rather than its end. This greatly reduces the recoil of the gun, resulting in more accurate artillery, anti-tank and anti-aircraft guns
Powered Anti-Air Gun mounts drastically increased the effectiveness of light anti-aircraft guns. Their primary use was on board naval vessels but some were found on ground mountings
Advances in tank armor and speed have resulted in the demand for an anti-tank gun capable of destroying this new generation of armored fighting vehicles

This Self-Propelled Artillery piece had a gun caliber comparable with the infantry guns and field artillery guns. Combined with its mobility and protection its lethality on the battlefield was virtually unmatched. Historically this was the US M7 Priest and the German Wespe

The 100mm+ Recoilless Gun was designed for parachute units, so they could have a hard-hitting gun that was light and yet packed a strong punch. Historically, this was the German 105mm LG 42 Recoilless Gun.

This 50mm+ Anti-Tank Gun was the first effective tank-killer used by the infantry. It was designed to penetrate tank armor and it had a high enough caliber to kill Light Tanks and to damage Medium Tanks. Its main deficits were its moderate armor penetration power and its medium range - which was less than most Tank Guns - thus the gun was less effective when protecting friendly armor. Historically this was the German 50mm PAK 38 and the British 6-Pounder
As the armor of tanks increased basic Anti-Tank Guns proved to be incapable of knocking them out. A new group of Anti-Tank Guns, ranging from 50mm and 75mm, was developed to counter the new tanks

This Self-Propelled Artillery piece had a fairly light caliber gun and thus could not achieve the same target destruction as the infantry guns and field artillery guns but due to its mobility and protection its overall lethality on the battlefield was almost identical.  Historically this was the British Bishop, Canadian Sexton and the Italian Semovente 90/53

This 170mm+ Heavy Artillery Gun was used by some major powers. It was reliable and had an acceptable rate of fire and a long range. With very few deficiencies, it was one of the most powerful field artillery pieces produced during the war. Historically, this was the German K18 Gun and British 7.2 inch Howitzer

This gun was a major improvement over previous 305mm (12 inch) guns and was of simpler, lighter construction.  Designed to fire 'super heavy' armor piercing shells, it gave penetration almost the equal of pre-war 356mm naval guns.  The gun fires a 500 kg (1150 lb) shell to a range of 19 nm (35 km).
Improved Anti-Aircraft Guns featured the high rates of fire of Light Anti-Aircraft Guns with a heavy shell and high range of Heavy Aint-Aircraft Guns
New advances in artillery since the Great War has resulted in a modern and significantly more effective range of Medium Artillery.
New advances in artillery since the Great War has resulted in a modern and significantly more effective range of Mountain Guns.

This class of 203mm (8 inch) guns use separate (cased) powder in place of bags of powder.  With automatic shell handling and loading, a fire rate of three times greater than previous 203mm guns was possible.  These guns fire a 150 kg (330 lb) shell to a range of 15 nm (27 km).

The 152mm Dual-Purpose gun was developed for a new generation of modern Anti-Aircraft Cruisers. It was designed to fire at high angles for anti-aircraft defense as well as against surface targets. This gun fires an armored piercing or high explosive 50 kg (105 lb) shell to a range of 13 nm (21 km).

The 460mm (18 inch) naval gun is the heaviest gun afloat.  The gun fires a massive 1500 kg (3200 lb) shell to a range of 23 nm (42 km).  The construction of these guns is a complex process involving heating, shrinking, and expanding the various tubes that made up the barrel.

This is an improvement of the 406mm (16 inch) naval gun to take advantage of advances in shell and gun construction.  The gun fires a 'super heavy' 406mm shell weighing about 1200 kg (2700 lbs) to a range of 21 nm (38 km).  At long ranges this gun can equal the heavier 460mm gun in penetrating power.

The 406mm (16 inch) naval gun is an improvement of the older 356mm naval gun to fire a heavier shell. It is mounted in turrets with two or three guns. The heavier shell weight allows it to penetrate thicker armor. The shell travels on a flatter trajectory which makes it easier to hit a target at long ranges.

The 356mm (14 inch) naval gun is an improvement of the older 305mm naval gun. It is mounted in turrets with two or three guns. The 356mm gun fires a heavier shell and achieves a higher muzzle velocity. This allows the gun to fire farther and penetrate thicker armor.

The 305mm (12 inch) naval gun was the main battery weapon of early battleships. The gun is mounted in turrets with two or three guns per turret. The entire turret and understructure can rotate to train the guns on target. The lower levels of the turret (or barbette as it is known) contain handling rooms for shells and the bags of powder necessary to fire the guns. These guns have been in service with the major navies since before the first world war, but are a necessary step to heavier guns. This gun fired a 400 kg (870 lb) shell to a range of 10 nm (18 km)

The 254mm (10 inch) naval gun is the smallest of the heavy naval guns. The 254mm gun has separate bags of powder that can be moved onto the loading tray by a single person. The shell is placed on the loading tray and the shell and powder are rammed into the gun and the breach closed. These guns were the main armament of armored cruisers and second rate battleships prior to the first world war. This guns fires a 230 kg (510 lb) shell to a range of 10 nm (18 km).

This is a medium gun because of its size compared to battleship main guns, but it still fires a shell that is heavy enough to require a mechanical loading system. These guns serve as the main armament of heavy cruisers and as the secondary guns of pre-dreadnaught battleships. They are mounted in multiple gun turrets with light to heavy armor protection for the crew. This gun fires a 120 kg (260 lb) shell to a range of 16 nm (29 km).

This is a medium sized naval gun. It can serve either as the main armament of a cruiser or as the secondary guns on a battleship. These guns fire a separate shell and powder charge that allows each piece to be loaded by a single person.  On older cruisers these guns were mounted on deck without any armor protection for the crew, but in later cruisers they were mounted in multiple gun turrets. This gun fires a 50 kg (105 lb) shell to a range of 13 nm (21 km).

This is a small, lightweight naval gun that can be mounted as either the main armament on a destroyer or small cruiser, or as secondary or tertiary guns on battleships. The 127mm (5 inch) gun can be quickly loaded by a single person. These guns typically have a minimum amount of armor protection to protect the crew from splinters. This gun fires a 23 kg (50 lb) shell to a range of 10 nm (18 km).

This is a small, lightweight naval gun. The 102mm (4 inch) gun has a combined shell and powder charge allowing it to be reloaded quickly by a single person. The gun is mounted on deck without any armor protection for the gun crew. This gun serves as the gun armament on early or small destroyers. This gun fires a 15 kg (33 lb) shell to a range of 8 nm (14 km).

Towards the end of the war, Germany was working on a new concept called the Revolver Cannon, which was based on a revolving chamber loading and unloading the shells instead of a linear back-and-forth bolt action. It allowed rates of fire exceeding 1000+ rounds a minute, compared to a mere 600-700 for conventional cannon. Historically, this was the German MG213C.

The 85mm+ Anti-Air Gun was an early heavy gun capable of targeting high-flying aircraft. As a bonus, it could also be used in an anti-tank role in a pinch, where it's high muzzle velocity proved to be invaluable in punching through the thick armor of heavy tanks.
This gun was a modified 75mm+ Infantry Gun mounted for use in armored vehicles designed for close support duties. Historically, this was the German 75mm KwK 37 L/24 gun found on the Panzer IVA-F1.

This 75mm+ Anti-Tank Gun was the first effective tank-killer used by the infantry. It was designed to penetrate tank armor and it had a high enough caliber to kill Light Tanks and to damage Medium Tanks. Historically this was the German 75mm PAK 40.

Based upon the chassis of a Light Tank, the Self-Propelled Anti-Air Machine Gun offered armored and mechanized formations rudimentary defense against low flying aircraft. Historically this was the Vickers Mark V twin Besa 15mm and German Flakpanzer I

Mechanized Ammunition Carriers were vitally important in supplying Self-Propelled Artillery. They were basically unarmed Self-Propelled Artillery Tractors designed to carry and transfer large amounts of ammunition to active batteries of Self-Propelled Guns. Historically this was the German Munitiontr‰ger Wespe and Hummel

Motorized Artillery Carriers were capable of transporting larger amounts of supply faster and more efficiently than the traditional horse Artillery Carriers. Historically this was the German Sdkfz 7 and British Quad Gun Tractor

Developed from tankettes, these small tracked vehicles were used in large numbers to tow anti-tank guns and other loads for infantry and cavalry units. They were well suited for rough or harsh terrain. Historically they were the French Renault 37R, Belgian Vickers Utility tractor and British Universal Carrier

Most militaries developed Anti-Tank weaponry in between the ranges of 37mm and 40mm in the inter-war period. These weapons could easily penetrate contemporary armor and were produced in great numbers.

The 120mm+ to Infantry Gun was frequently used by many nations. Originally an elderly field artillery piece it was converted into infantry use. It retained the horrible range of the 70mm+ Infantry Gun but was too heavy to be used in the assault role but was very potent in breaking up enemy attacks
New advances in artillery since the Great War has resulted in a modern and significantly more effective range of Light Artillery

The Improved Gun Carriage increases the mobility of artillery pieces as well as the stability of the gun. They utilized modern pneumatic tires, high elevation, as well as contemporary recoil absorbers which increased gun accuracy as well as mobility
Improvements in Radio Communication and Optical Rangefinders resulted in drastically improved Fire Control systems which increased the accuracy of contemporary artillery
The 75mm+ Anti-Air Gun was an early heavy gun capable of targeting high-flying aircraft. It had a good rate of fire and an adequate range and was a capable anti-tank weapon
The 40mm+ Anti-Air Gun was a light gun capable of targeting low-flying aircraft. Historically this was the Swedish 40mm L/56 and the British Vickers 2-Pounder

This 120mm+ Field Artillery Gun was frequently used by many nations. It was reliable and had an acceptable rate of fire and a medium range. Historically this was the Soviet 122mm A-19 Model 1937 Howitzer and the British 4.5 inch Howitzer

The 100mm+ to Infantry Gun was frequently used by many nations. Originally an elderly field artillery piece it was converted into infantry use. It retained the horrible range of the 70mm+ Infantry Gun but was too heavy to be used in the assault role but was very potent in breaking up enemy attacks

The semi-automatic carbine was developed in the interwar era and refined for mass production once the war began. These weapons were as accurate as bolt action carbine rifles but were more valuable on assaults. Historically this was the American M1A1

The semi-automatic rifle was developed in the interwar era and refined for mass production once the war began. These weapons were as accurate as bolt action rifles but were more valuable on assaults. Historically this was the American M1 Garand

The Great War Gun Carrier was developed in order to transport heavy artillery and their ammunition across the battered and torn ground of the Western Front. Although not a full Self-Propelled Gun, it proved invaluable experience for future developments

Early Anti-Air Machine Guns were mounted on high-angled gun platforms and were used for protecting artillery batteries from low flying aircraft. As they became more common, they were later issued to infantry formations and on board ships but were only effective in discouraging attack and rarely hit anything. Traditionally these guns were landed aircraft machine guns or mounted Infantry LMGs
The 20mm+ Anti-Tank Gun was capable of piercing only thinly armored tanks and armored cars. Historically this was the French Canon Leger de 25 antichar mle 1934.

The Great War era 240mm+ Heavy Artillery Gun was used by a few major powers. It was reliable and had an acceptable rate of fire and a medium range. It was well suited for static warfare common during the Great War

This was a Great War era 75mm+ Field Gun, but designed to have high elevation and be broken up into several easily manageable pieces that could then be transported by a few men each or pack animals. Historically, this was the Austrian Skoda 75mm Mountain Gun M1915

The Great War era 150mm+ Field Artillery Gun was used by many nations. It was reliable and had an acceptable rate of fire and a medium range. Its greatest deficit was that it only shot High Explosive shells and that ammunition was tricky to move about.

The Great War era 75mm+ Field Artillery Gun was used by many nations. It was reliable and had a moderate rate of fire and range. Its penetration power was slightly worse than the heavier guns. Historically this was the French Canon de 75 mle 1897.
High-Elevation Gun Carriages were specifically designed for extremely high elevations, required for both Mountain Howitzer and Anti-Aircraft Guns

An advanced single-shot tube-launched rocket that was very effective against armored targets. It was very easy to use and was lightweight enough that it could be worn on the soldier's back. It was inexpensive to produce, easy to train with, and was ideal for untrained militia.

The first tube-launched anti-tank rockets introduced the shaped-charge (or HEAT) concept, which allowed a lightweight warhead to blast through incredible thicknesses of armor.
