Although Poland responded favorably and Italy hesitated to join Germany, there was an ominous official silence from Berlin set against blood-thirsty German propaganda.
The USA Reacts of Anschluss of Germany and Austria

The President is furious that Hitler has absorbed a sovereign country.  Previously agreed upon helium purchases by the Reich are cancelled.  This effectively ends Zeppelin service by Germany given the fiery demise of the Hindenburg.
The USA Reacts to Rhineland Reoccupation

President Roosevelt is furious that Hitler has violated a key provision of the Versailles Treaty.  He directs the Treasury to collect increased duties on German goods.  Germany responds in kind. The increased tarriffs disrupt trade and reduce exports, costing some Americans their jobs.
FDR Sends Diplomatic Note to Principals in Czech Crisis

It is imperative that peoples everywhere recall that every civilized nation of the world voluntarily assumed the solemn obligations of the Kellogg-Briand Pact of 1928 to solve controversies only by pacific methods. In addition, most nations are parties to other binding treaties obligating them to preserve peace. Furthermore, all countries have today available for such peaceful solution of difficulties which may arise, treaties of arbitration and conciliation to which they are parties. Whatever may be the differences in the controversies at issue and however difficult of pacific settlement they may be, I am persuaded that there is no problem so difficult or so pressing for solution that it cannot be justly solved by the resort to reason rather than by the resort to force.

The president is furious that Hitler has manhandled the European order again. He directs the Treasury to collect increased duties on German goods.  Germany responds in kind.  The American public is frightened by the possibility of war in Europe, especially given President Roosevelt's repeated invocations of the horror of war.
FDR Gives Foreign Policy Speech in Chicago

The President gives a major foreign policy speech in Chicago and declares, ëWe are adopting such measures as will minimize our risk of involvement, but we cannot have complete protection in a world of disorder in which confidence and security have broken down. . . . America hates war. America hopes for peace. Therefore, America actively engages in the search for peace.í

In 1935 Congress passed and President Roosevelt signed a law requiring the President to embargo arms shipments to belligerents.  On February 29, 1936, Congress toughened the law to prohibit extending loans or credits to belligerent states.  As recently as October, 1935, President Roosevelt had declared that the USA shall and must remain . . . unentangled and free.
No, the executive needs a free hand in foreign affairs
Congress Toughens the Neutrality Act Again

The Neutrality Act did not cover civil wars.  This was highlighted by the ambiguity of the application of the Neutrality Act to the Spanish Civil War.  Therefore, on January 6, 1937, Congress passed a joint resolution forbidding the US or US citizens from arming either side in the Spanish Civil War.  Such arms orders would have stimulated factory demand but enraged Isolationist sentiment.
No, the executive needs a free hand in foreign affairs

In the spring of 1937, the Neutrality Act expired.  However, Congress acted to reauthorize and tighten the law to include strategic materials and criminalize the travel of US citizens on passenger liners flying the flag of belligerent powers. Of course, vetoing the legislation would have opened the door to arms orders.  These would have stimulated factory demand at the risk of exciting the Isolationists.
No, the executive needs a free hand in foreign affairs
War Leads Congress to Relax Neutrality Act

Once war broke out in Europe, Bernard Baruch, a financier and government advisor, devised a 'cash and carry' plan.  Belligerents could buy American munitions, but they had to pay cash and transport them on their own merchant ships.  This was sold as way to keep US citizens out of harm's way and minimize the risk of huge war debts which might be repudiated, as was the case with World War One debts to the USA - except Finland's.  But since the Allies controlled the sea, it also effectively meant that only the Allies could buy American munitions.  Isolationist still strongly disapproved of the idea.
Yes, this protects Americans and will get factories humming again
No, we should veto these modifications

With the increased tensions in Europe and German success on the continent, the administration announced that US naval forces would patrol west of the 26th degree of longitude.  They would defend themselves if attacked.  Less publicly, the US Navy was instructed to pass along the location of any German U-boats discovered to the Royal Navy.
USS Reuben James Sunk by U-Boat

Once the Neutrality Patrols commenced, clashes with German U-boats operating in the Western Atlantic were inevitable.  A U-boat made an unsuccessful attack on the battleship USS Texas near Iceland.  The destroyer USS Greer was also attacked unsuccessfully.   Once US warships began escorting Commonwealth merchantmen on the high seas, casualities were only a matter of time.  The USS Kearney was torpedoed and seriously damaged.  Eleven sailors lost their lives.  A few days later the USS Reuben James was torpedoed and sunk, at a cost of 115 lives.  The President announced that a shooting war had erupted in the North Atlantic and that history had recorded who had fired the first shot.

The Social Security Act was passed in 1936.  It mandated that employees and their employers would start paying social security taxes on January 1, 1937.  This was the first peace-time payroll withholding tax in US history.  No pay-outs from the Social Security funds were provided for until 1942.  The people grumble at higher taxation.  However, the government pioneers new techniques for keeping track of everyone's accounts and accelerates development of data processing technology.
The president pushes through legislation which accelerates the start of pay-outs from social security to begin in 1940 instead of 1942.  The people are pleased.

The president gives an impassioned speech on foreign affairs in Chautauqua, New York.  In it, he declared, 'I have seen war. I have seen war on land and sea. I have seen blood running from the wounded. I have seen men coughing out their gassed lungs. I have seen the dead in the mud. I have seen cities destroyed. I have seen two hundred limping exhausted men come out of line-the survivors of a regiment of one thousand that went forward forty-eight hours before. I have seen children starving. I have seen the agony of mothers and wives. I hate war. I have passed unnumbered hours, I shall pass unnumbered hours, thinking and planning how war may be kept from this Nation. I wish I could keep war from all Nations: but that is beyond my power. I can at least make certain that no act of the United States helps to produce or to promote war.
FDR Gives 1937 State of the Union Speech

The president declares that he will press forward with the ideas of the New Deal despite the Supreme Court's wholesale rejection of his legislation as unconstitutional.  He also cites the previous month's Latin American Summit, declaring, '[At] the Inter-American Conference . . . new instruments to maintain peace and eliminate causes of war were adopted. Wider protection of the interests of the American republics in the event of war outside the Western Hemisphere was provided. Respect for, and observance of, international treaties and international law were also strengthened. Principles of liberal trade policies, as effective aids to the maintenance of peace were reaffirmed. The intellectual and cultural relationship among American republics were broadened as part of the general peace program.'

President Roosevelt declares, 'It is my constitutional duty to report to the Congress that our national defense is, in the light of the increasing armaments of other nations, inadequate for purposes of national security and requires increase for that reason.'

President Roosevelt declares, 'There comes a time in the affairs of men when they must prepare to defend, not their homes alone, but the tenets of faith and humanity on which their churches, their governments and their very civilization are founded. The defense of religion, of democracy and of good faith among nations is all the same fight. To save one we must now make up our minds to save all. . . . we have learned something else-the old, old lesson that probability of attack is mightily decreased by the assurance of an ever ready defense. . . . . we must have armed forces and defenses strong enough to ward off sudden attack against strategic positions and key facilities essential to ensure sustained resistance and ultimate victory. Secondly, we must have the organization and location of those key facilities so that they may be immediately utilized and rapidly expanded to meet all needs without danger of serious interruption by enemy attack.'

Heroic aviator Charles Lindbergh visited Germany shortly after the Munich Crisis.  He toured the giant Focke-Wulf aircraft factory and flew one of their new four engined 'Condor' aircraft to Berlin.  At a testimonial dinner that night, Herman Goering presented him with the Order of the Eagle in recognition of his pioneering efforts in flight.  Lindbergh spoke glowingly of Germany's contributions to Western civilization and the need to maintain peace.

The President, nudged by the British PM, believes the time has come to take a stand.  The Anglo-American powers declare that there should be no territorial aggrandizement or adjustment of borders without approval of the inhabitants.  That governments should be freely elected by a nation's inhabitants.  That there should be free trade and low tarriff barriers subject to respecting existing laws. Economic growth, and government collaboration to enhance it, is a good that leads to better social welfare. An expectation that after defeating the Nazis, people will be able to 'live in freedom and free from fear or want.' There is support for freedom of the seas.  Finally, a call to disarm, not only their own nations after peace in order to reduce the burden on taxpayers, but also a recognition that it is 'essential' to disarm those nations which 'threaten, or may threaten, aggression outside of their border.'

Germany is at war with plucky Norway.  Letters and telegrams pour into Washington from Norwegian-Americans urging action to protect relatives and loved ones in the old country.  The State Department files a protest with the German Embassy.

Germany is at war with the Kingdom of Sweden.  Letters and telegrams pour into Washington from Swedish-Americans urging action to protect relatives and loved ones in the old country.  Advisors in the War Department point out that Sweden does have a significant domestic weapons industry that will strengthen the Nazi's.  The State Department files a protest with the German Embassy.

Germany is at war with the Kingdom of Denmark.  Letters and telegrams pour into Washington from Danish-Americans urging action to protect relatives and loved ones in the old country.  A delegation arrives from Solvang, California to protest at the German Embassy.  The State Department files a protest with the German Embassy.

Germany is at war with the Kingdom of Yugoslavia.  Letters and telegrams pour into Washington from Croat, Serb, Slovene, and Bosnian immigrants.  They are urging action to protect relatives and loved ones in the old country.  The State Department files a protest with the German Embassy.
France Threatens War Over the Rhineland

Germany's reoccupation of the Rhineland triggers a massive war scare.  The French have mobilized their army and are preparing for war unless the Germans withdraw.  This French 'bullying' of the Germans is not popular in the USA and creates an element of sympathy for Germans.  However, members of Congress see this as an opportunity to cut military expenditures since the French are doing such a good job of keeping Germany in line.

Japan has conquered China and is deploying massive numbers of troops as a permanent garrison for the country.  The president is furious that the 'Open Door' policy has been reduced to tatters by this Japanese aggrandizement.  The Japanese ambassador has been lectured that this action is unacceptable and the US ambassador to Japan has been recalled for consultations.  The War Department delivers a mixed verdict on this action.  While the Japanese will be strengthened by access to raw materials, especially coal and tungsten, the vast numbers of Chinese to be policed will put a heavy burden on the Japanese Army.
Japan Signs Anti-Comintern Pact with Germany
Japan has signed the Anti-Comintern Pact with Germany.  This publicly aligns the two nations against the Soviet Union.
Italy and Japan Sign Tripartite Pact Pact with Germany

Italy and Japan have signed the Tripartite Pact with Germany.  This is a defensive alliance between the three fascist powers.  Together they could dominate Eurasia.  The State Department and War Department are alarmed.
Italy Signs Tripartite Pact Pact with Germany

Italy has signed the Tripartite Pact with Germany.  This is a defensive alliance between the two fascist powers.  Together they could dominate Europe.  The State Department and War Department are alarmed.
Japan Signs Tripartite Pact Pact with Germany

Japan has signed the Tripartite Pact with Germany.  This is a defensive alliance between the two fascist powers.  Together they could dominate Eurasia.  The State Department and War Department are alarmed.

America First organizer and aviator Charles Lindbergh addresses a crowd of 8,000 Iowans in the Des Moines Coliseum on 11 September 1941.  He accuses the Roosevelt Administration and special interest groups of wanting to involve the USA in the war.  Lindbergh declares, 'We cannot blame them for looking out for what they believe to be their own interest, but we also must look out for ours.  We cannot allow the natural passions and prejudices of other peoples to lead our country to destruction.'  While the speech rallies the America Firsters, the explicit identification of a religious minority among the special interest groups generates a firestorm of criticism of Lindbergh and the America First movement.  Socialist and pacifist Norman Thomas called it 'amazingly hurtful.'  Lindbergh continues to speak but privately lays plans to withdraw from the leadership of the America First movement.

The creation of the Vichy regime and peace between Vichy and England relieves the threat of immediate war from continental France and West Africa.  Although the War Department is skeptical that this will last, theState Department holds out hope that this may presage a negotiated peace between Britain and Germany, ending the war in Europe.

John L. Lewis, head of the United Mine Workers Union, makes a radio address heard by as many as thirty million Americans.  He derides President Roosevelt's foreign policy for playing 'a game that may make cannon fodder of your sons' and claims Roosevelt has an 'overweening, abnormal lust for power.'  Then he endorses the Republican candidate for President.

Just before the 1940 Election, President Roosevelt makes a major campaign speech in the Boston Garden.  He pledges 'And while I am talking to you mothers and fathers, I give you one more assurance.  I have said this before, but I shall say it again - and again - and again :  your boys are not going to be sent into any foreign wars.'

Signals decryption and sleuthing by Naval Intelligence confirms that the Japanese are improving defenses on their island posessions in the central Pacific Ocean.  The clause of the Washington Naval Treaty of 1922 that prohibited this lapsed in 1937.  The Navy Department is very agitated by this since it will make relief of the Philippines in time of war with Japan almost impossible before the islands may fall.  Political advisers to the President warn that making too much of this will inflame isolationist opinion and be seen as war-mongering.

The Japanese have sent a peace mission to the Washington.  However, the USA has recently cracked the Japanese diplomatic ciphers.  In decoding and translating the message traffic between Washington and Tokyo, US negotiators get the sense that the Japanese officials in Tokyo are 'stringing along' their diplomats in Washington.  The diplomatic demands for a free hand in Asia are unacceptable in any case.  A persuasive case is made that Japanese military action against the USA is very likely soon after the conclusion of these negotiations.

The Japanese have sent a peace mission to the Washington.  The diplomatic demands for a free hand in Asia are unacceptable.  The argument that this is a last diplomatic offensive before taking up arms is considered, but there is little evidence to back it up.  For Japan to war against the USA would be a desperate measure since the USA is potentially so much stronger than Japan.

The Japanese have announced that they no longer acknowledge Chiang Kai-Shek's  KMT as a legitimate government of China.  This makes the prospects for a diplomatic solution to the Sino-Japanese War even dimmer.  The Japanese ambassador is summoned to the State Department and given a note protesting this development.
US Reacts to Japan Gaining the Indies

Germany, having acquired the Dutch East Indies, honors treaty commitments to the Japanese Empire and turns over these territories to the Japanese Empire.  This puts Japanese bases in easy range of the southern Philippines and effectively makes US forces in that archipelago hostage to Japan.  This is viewed as a serious threat by the War Department.

Charles Lindbergh makes a speech on national security and airpower.  He notes that due to America's geography, whoever controls Europe or Asia must cross oceans to reach the USA.  Furthermore, unless an enemy is capable of seizing nearby islands such as Bermuda, the Bahamas or the Aleutians, airpower based in the United States would destroy the invading fleets.  Since the aforementioned islands are close the USA, its airpower would also be able to destroy fleets intent on taking those islands.  Therefore, American security is best served in building up local defenses instead of engaging any potential enemy far from home.  Intervention in foreign wars would be an unwise thing.

Leaders of the America First Committee meet.  Their goals have been utterly defeated now that the USA is allied with Great Britain and the USA is at war.  Popular opinion has rallied to the support of the administration and continuing the Committee's work will open its advocates to charges that they are unpatriotic.  Consequently, the Committee determines to disband, although some hold out hope that the work of the Committee may resume at some future date.
Henry Ford Gets German Order of the Eagle

During Henry Ford's 75th birthday celabration, the industrialist slips away and meets with the German Consul to Detroit.  The Consul gives Ford the German Order of the Eagle with a certificate signed by Hitler, applauding Ford's services to the German people.  When news spreads of this award, anti-German factions in the USA demand that Ford return the award.  Ford flatly refused.  Then those factions organized a boycott of Ford Motor Company products.

With the outbreak of war between Germany and England, the German-American Bund lost support since it was seen as a puppet of one of the belligerants.  Contributions dried up. Bund leader Fritz Kuhn, formerly a chemist at the Ford Motor Company, ended up embezzling funds from the treasury for his personal use.  He was convicted of embezzlement and packed off to jail.  Germany is embarassed in the court of public opinion.
Italy Signs Anti-Comintern Pact with Germany
Italy has signed the Anti-Comintern Pact with Germany.  This publicly aligns the two nations against the Soviet Union.

Ford and company executives attend a screening of a documentary produced by the US government recounting how the Germans have treated the populations of their occupied territories. When the lights come up an hour later, the executives were shaken by the film and even more surprised to find Ford slumped in his seat, the victim of a stroke.  Ford was permanently incapacitated by this stroke. Another stroke on April 7, 1947 led to his death.

The two great totalitarian dictatorships have fallen into war.  Never was such mayhem so richly deserved.  The Army Chief of Staff and Chief of Naval Operations both recommend strengthening our defense posture. The President is concerned about the expense and certainly the pacifist faction of his supporters will be outraged by overt rearmament. However, political advisors warn that Congress will expect something.
The President balks, but Congress insists

The great totalitarian dictatorships fall into war.  The Chief of Staff warns that whoever wins will probably be even more powerful than either are today.  He recommends increased mobilization, and the Chief of Naval Operations concurs.  Political advisors indicate that as long as the government pledges to keep troops in the Western Hemisphere, the Isolationists will go along with this.

The government directs diplomats to Washington to try and find a compromise with the USA that affirms Japan's honor and right to conquer China.  The diplomats are authorized to guarantee US possessions and disavow ambitions against any English speaking nations.  However, the Imperial government is also preparing military contingencies in parallel with the diplomacy.

The Army Chief of Staff declares that German victories in France indicate that the US must quickly increase the strength of its army.  The best way to do that is to place the National Guard, a part-time militia, under federal control and give the army the job of training the Guardsmen up to Regular Army standards.  New recruiting will have to be authorized to replace men who are unfit for duty or get exemptions.  Also money for new equipment will need to be appropriated.  Political advisors warn that this will prove very unpopular with the isolationists so the government will need to promise to keep the troops in the Western Hemisphere.  However, other critics are beginning paint the administration as soft on defense.

With the end of war in Spain, the survivors of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade come home to the adulation of the left.  Others praise Franco for his support of Church and tradition against the communists who took over the Republican cause.  Partisans of both sides work to strengthen or weaken, based on their own interests, the new government in Madrid in the eyes of the American public, business, and government.  What's more, it suggests to some people that force and violence can be justified to advance a stalled political agenda instead of abiding by the law.  The State Department isn't happy to see a dictatorship win, but it seems the lesser to two evils compared to ongoing war.

The President makes a radio address to the nation to reassure the people that the new Great War in Europe is not an immediate threat to the USA.  This is a struggle for the Europeans alone. The broad Atlantic lies between America and this distant conflict.  The Navy and the Army have been put on alert to prevent the spread of the fighting to the western hemisphere.  People are urged to carry on with daily life.

With war in the Far East amd Spain, Indiana congressman Louis Ludlow introduces an amendment to the Constitution.  This would require that a national plebiscite would need to certify and make effective any declaration of war by Congress which was not preceded by an actual invasion of the United States. The President agrees that American power should be restrained from over-hasty use.  The Ludlow Amendment passed and went on to the states for ratification.  There it died, winning approval in only 27 states and falling short of the constitutionally mandated three fourths majority.

With war in the Far East amd Spain, Indiana congressman Louis Ludlow introduces an amendment to the Constitution.  This would require that a national plebiscite would need to certify and make effective any declaration of war by Congress which was not preceded by an actual invasion of the United States. The President disagrees that American power should be so restrained.  The Ludlow Amendment failed in committee, but its sponsors tried to bring it to the floor for a vote. That required a suspension of the rules which won a majority, but failed to reach the mandated super-majority necessary to suspend the rules.  Therefore, it died in committee.

The world falls under totalitarian shadow as the Third Reich and the Soviet Union have formed a military alliance.  The Army's Chief of Staff is ashen.  If their armies ever get a foothold in the Western Hemisphere he believes the USA would eventually be defeated.  Mass mobilization is immediately required.
Mobilize - it the last hope of the West

The world falls under totalitarian shadow as the Third Reich and the Soviet Union have formed a military alliance.  The Army's Chief of Staff is ashen.  If their armies ever get a foothold in the Western Hemisphere he believes the USA would eventually be defeated.  Mass mobilization is immediately required.  The president scoffs at this, but popular forces agitate for rearmament.  Congress passes huge appropriations for new weapons.

The Director of the FBI approaches the President to indicate that he believes that Nazi agents are ghost-writing the speeches of some isolationist members of Congress.  What he doesn't know is whether the congressmen are simply stupid or actual traitors.

Now that the Soviet Union and Germany have signed a non-aggression pact, the Communist Party in the USA, along with its front groups and fellow travellers, promote line that the war in Europe is intended to protect capitalist 'fat cats' and is not worth one American life.  'No blood for Big Business' is the rallying cry.

The government's diplomatic offensive in Washington has failed.  There is little choice but to take up arms against America before it becomes so strong that it can dictate a Japanese withdrawel from China.

The government's diplomatic offensive in Washington has failed.  There is little choice but to take up arms against America before it becomes so strong that it can dictate a Japanese withdrawel from China.
The UAW strikes to organize Ford Motors

After the abortive effort to organize Ford in 1937, organized labor regrouped and continued to press for organization.  In March, 1941, the UAW reached critical mass and efforts by management to quash union organizers led to spontaneous walk-outs throughout the River Rouge Plant.  Ford offered high wages to 'scabs' to try and break the strike.
The Wagner Act says the working man can organize and strike.
This is a national security matter.  Send in the Army to break the strikes.

The Ford negotiates a settlement with the UAW.  Industry returns to normal.  However, the higher wages won the by union are passed on to consumers across the country, contributing to higher prices and a slowdown in the economy.
The UAW strike fails to organize Ford
The workers return to work without a new contract.  This is a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man again

Ford fights and wins a pre-emptive public relations battle with the unions by linking them to the Ku Klux Klan.  A disproportionate number of Ford's scabs are black and few of the union-men are.  The union backs down.

Having failed to pre-empt or foil the strike, and, having little belly for a prolonged disruption, Ford management concedes to union demands and recognizes the UAW. They believe that they can pass labor cost increases on to their customers, anyway.
The UMW Strikes the Coal Fields

The Great Depression has created high unemployment and mine-owners have taken advantage of that to cut wages to the bone.  John L. Lewis, leader of the UMW and a founder of the CIO, plans to strike for a better deal.  There will be violence as mine-owners will retaliate with company police and hire 'scabs', non-union temporary workers. The miners sometimes physically occupy the mines to prevent any work from being done.  There is severe economic dislocation in the coal-producing areas.
The Wagner Act says the working man can organize and strike.
This is a national security matter.  Send in the Army to break the strikes.
The UMW Gets a Better Contract in the Coal Fields

The mine owners negotiate a settlement with the UMW.  Industry returns to normal.  However, the higher wages won the by union are passed on to consumers across the country, contributing to higher prices and a slowdown in the economy.
The UMW Strike Fails in the Coal Fields
The miners return to work without a new contract.  This is a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man again!
The UAW strikes to organize General Motors

The Great Depression created high unemployment and the large automakers took advantage of that to cut wages to the bone.  The UAW decided to strike in order to organize the company and force them to accept collective labor agreements. The strike started as worked occupied the Fisher Body Works in Flint, Michigan.  It spread rapidly to other plants and rippled through the economy as GM cancelled orders to suppliers.  There was some violence as GM-hired company police or 'Pinkertons' clashed with strikers. There is severe economic dislocation through-out the upper middle-west, which was the heart of the American auto industry.
The Wagner Act says the working man can organize and strike.
This is a national security matter.  Send in the Army to break the strikes.

The GM negotiates a settlement with the UAW.  Industry returns to normal.  However, the higher wages won the by union are passed on to consumers across the country, contributing to higher prices and a slowdown in the economy.
The UAW strike fails to organize GM
The workers return to work without a new contract.  This is a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man again
The UAW strike fails to organize GM

GM works a skillful campaign to bribe and/or terrorize union leaders.  The strike collapsed almost immediately with minimal concessions to the rank and file. Workers returned to work without a contract.  This was a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man again

Having failed to pre-empt or foil the strike, and, having little belly for a prolonged disruption, GM management concedes to union demands and recognizes the UAW. They believe that they can pass labor cost increases on to their customers, anyway.
The UAW strikes to organize Ford Motors

The Great Depression created high unemployment and the large automakers took advantage of that to cut wages to the bone.  The UAW decided to strike in order to organize the company and force them to accept collective labor agreements. Ford owned and operated a 'vertical supply chain', from the mines that dug out iron ore, on to the huge Rouge River Works where ore came in and cars came out.  A successful strike would have rippled throughout the economy as Ford cancelled orders to suppliers.  Violence due to clashes between striker and company police or 'Pinkertons' would also be likely. There is severe economic dislocation through-out the upper middle-west, which was the heart of the American auto industry.
The Wagner Act says the working man can organize and strike.
This is a national security matter.  Send in the Army to break the strikes.

The Ford negotiates a settlement with the UAW.  Industry returns to normal.  However, the higher wages won the by union are passed on to consumers across the country, contributing to higher prices and a slowdown in the economy.
The UAW strike fails to organize Ford
The workers return to work without a new contract.  This is a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man again

William Reuther and several other UAW organizers are beaten up and thrown down the stairs of a pedestrian overpass in front of the Ford River Rouge Factory.  Other union organizers are also beaten up by anti-union Ford employees at the direction of management.  One man dies of complications about a month after his beating.  This thuggery cuts short the efforts to organize Ford.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man again

Having failed to pre-empt or foil the strike, and, having little belly for a prolonged disruption, Ford management concedes to union demands and recognizes the UAW. They believe that they can pass labor cost increases on to their customers, anyway.
The Steelworkers strike to organize US Steel

The Great Depression created high unemployment and the large steelmakers took advantage of that to cut wages to the bone.  The Steelworkers decided to strike in order to organize the company and force them to accept collective labor agreements. US Steel was the largest steelmaker in North America.  US Steel had been formed from the merger of Carnegie Steel and Federal Steel, and controlled up to 67% of the steel market in the USA at its height.  It was headquartered in Pittsburg.  A successful strike would have rippled throughout the economy as companies exhausted their inventory of steel and manufacturing lines would be idled for lack of raw material.  Violence due to clashes between striker and company police or 'Pinkertons' would also be likely. There is severe economic dislocation throughout the industrial heartland of the USA - the Chicago/Boston axis.
The Wagner Act says the working man can organize and strike.
This is a national security matter.  Send in the Army to break the strikes.

US Steel negotiates a settlement with the steelworkers' union.  Industry returns to normal.  However, the higher wages won the by union are passed on to consumers across the country, contributing to higher prices and a slowdown in the economy.
The Steelworkers fail to organize US Steel
The workers return to work without a new contract.  This is a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man again
The strike against US Steel is aborted

US Steel works a skillful campaign to bribe and/or terrorize union leaders.  The strike never got past the planning stages, and minimal concessions to the rank and file were made. No significant change in work conditions.  This was a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man again
US Steel concedes to the Steelworkers

Having failed to pre-empt or foil the strike, and, having little belly for a prolonged disruption, US Steel management concedes to union demands and recognizes the steelworkers' union. They believe that they can pass labor cost increases on to their customers, anyway.
The Steelworkers strike to organize 'Little Steel'

The Great Depression created high unemployment and the large steelmakers took advantage of that to cut wages to the bone.  The Steelworkers decided to strike in order to organize the smaller US steel companies besides US Stell.  The so-called 'Little Steel' companies were gaining market share from behemoth U.S. Steel, but feared that higher labor costs would make their product uncompetitive.  A strike would have rippled throughout the economy as companies exhausted their inventory of steel and manufacturing lines would be idled for lack of raw material.  Violence due to clashes between striker and company police or 'Pinkertons' would also be likely. There is severe economic dislocation throughout the industrial heartland of the USA - the Chicago/Boston axis.
The Wagner Act says the working man can organize and strike.
This is a national security matter.  Send in the Army to break the strikes.
The steelworkers organize the smaller steelmakers

The smaller steelmakers such as Republic and Bethlehem negotiate a settlement with the steelworkers union.  Industry returns to normal.  However, the higher wages won the by union are passed on to consumers across the country, contributing to higher prices and a slowdown in the economy.
The steelworkers fail to organize 'Little' steel

The workers return to work without a new contract.  A demonstration in Chicago turned violent and the municipal police shot and killed fifteen workers.  This is a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man again
The strike against 'Little' Steel is aborted

'Little' steel works a skillful campaign to bribe and/or terrorize union leaders.  The strike never got past the planning stages, and minimal concessions to the rank and file were made. No significant change in work conditions.  This was a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man again

Having failed to pre-empt or foil the strike, and, having little belly for a prolonged disruption, the smaller steelmakers' management concedes to union demands and recognizes the steelworkers' union. They believe that they can pass labor cost increases on to their customers, anyway.

The Great Depression created high unemployment and the retailers took advantage of that to cut wages to the bone.  The 'Woolworth Girls', retail clerks at the large discount department store, closed down the stores with a strike in order to organize the company.  These stores were located throughout the country in cities and were visible evidence of labor unrest in the commercial heart of the United States.  When products failed to move off the shelves at the retail level, orders were cancelled up the supply chain and threatened to close the factories supplying Woolworth with products. Woolworth survived to become retail giant Target while their rival, S. S. Kresge, became K-Mart.
The Wagner Act says the working man (or woman) can organize and strike.
This is a national security matter.  Send in the Army to break the strikes.

Woolworth's negotiates a settlement with the clerks' union.  Industry returns to normal.  However, the higher wages won the by union are passed on to consumers across the country, contributing to higher prices and a slowdown in the economy.
Beer and Mimosas at the Union Hall
The 'Woolworth Girls' fail to organize their employer
The workers return to work without a new contract.  This is a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man {and woman} again
The strike against Woolworth's is aborted

Woolworth's works a skillful campaign to bribe and/or terrorize union leaders.  The strike never got past the planning stages, and minimal concessions to the rank and file were made. No significant change in work conditions.  This was a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man {and woman} again
Woolworth's concedes to the retail clerks

Having failed to pre-empt or foil the strike, and, having little belly for a prolonged disruption, Woolworth's management concedes to union demands and recognizes the retail clerks' union. They believe that they can pass labor cost increases on to their customers, anyway.
Beer and Mimosas at the Union Hall
Machinists strike to organize the aviation industry

Despite the Great Depression, the aviation industry grew through the thirties and provided good jobs.  Nonetheless, the examples of other working men and women indicated that collective labor agreements would allow better conditions for these workers, too.  Therefore, the machinists sought to organize the great American aviation companies:  Boeing, Consolidated, Curtis, Martin, Lockheed, Douglas, Grumman, Vought, and others.
The Wagner Act says the working man can organize and strike.
This is a national security matter.  Send in the Army to break the strikes.
The machinists organize the aircraft manufacturers

The aircraft manufacturers negotiate a settlement with the machinists union.  Industry returns to normal.  However, the higher wages won the by union are passed on to consumers across the country, contributing to higher prices and a slowdown in the economy.
The machinists fail to organize their employers
The workers return to work without a new contract.  This is a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man again
The strike against the aviation companies is aborted

The aviation companies work a skillful campaign to bribe and/or terrorize union leaders.  The strike never got past the planning stages, and minimal concessions to the rank and file were made. No significant change in work conditions.  This was a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man again
The aircraft manufacturers pre-emptively concede to the machinists

Having failed to pre-empt or foil the strike, and, having little belly for a prolonged disruption, the aircraft manufacturers' management concedes to union demands and recognizes the machinists' union. They believe that they can pass labor cost increases on to their customers, anyway.
Beer and Mimosas at the Union Hall

After the United States joined the war, the government and the labor leaders reached an agreement where no labor actions were to take place for the duration.  However, John L. Lewis grew dissatisfied after inflation started reducing the buying power of his membership.  Despite the shooting war taking place, he led the UMW out on strike in 1943.
We don't want to martyr Lewis.  Let the strike occur
We are at WAR.  Send in the Army to break the strikes.
The UMW wins concessions from the mineowners

The mine owners negotiate a settlement with the UMW.  Industry returns to normal.  However, this is a Pyhhric victory as popular opinion turns against the labor movement for seeking selfish advantage during wartime.
The UMW fails to get a better contract

The workers return to work without a new contract.  This is a major defeat of organized labor, but the population as a whole applauds the loss since everyone has to contribute winning the war effort first.  Industry returns to normal.
The Republic has won over greedy workers who put Mammon before the common weal
The UAW strikes to organize Ford Motors

The Great Depression created high unemployment and the large automakers took advantage of that to cut wages to the bone.  Though the UAW had struck to organize GM, their strike against Ford did not get started until after the Supreme Court had declared the Wagner Act unconstitutional.  Therefore, they were operating under the old rules which did not automatically hold that the employer was guilty of inciting violence by failing to give in to union demands.  Ford owned and operated a 'vertical supply chain', from the mines that dug out iron ore, on to the huge Rouge River Works where ore came in and cars came out.  Henry Ford was strongly anti-union and under the threat of strike would pay premium wages to his 'scabs'. Violence due to clashes between striker and company police or 'Pinkertons' would also be likely. There is severe economic dislocation through-out the upper middle-west, which was the heart of the American auto industry.
Government has no business interfering in lawful union activity
This is a national security matter.  Send in the Army to break the strikes.

The Ford negotiates a settlement with the UAW.  Industry returns to normal.  However, the higher wages won the by union are passed on to consumers across the country, contributing to higher prices and a slowdown in the economy.
The UAW strike fails to organize Ford
Ford brings in enough labor to keep the lines running.  The UAW workers return to work without a new contract.  This is a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man again

William Reuther and several other UAW organizers are beaten up and thrown down the stairs of a pedestrian overpass in front of the Ford River Rouge Factory.  Other union organizers are also beaten up by anti-union Ford employees at the direction of management.  One man dies of complications about a month after his beating.  This thuggery cuts short the efforts to organize Ford.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man again
The Steelworkers strike to organize US Steel

The Great Depression created high unemployment and the large steelmakers took advantage of that to cut wages to the bone.  The steelworkers decided to strike in order to organize the company and force them to accept collective labor agreements. However, this was much more difficult to the court ruling invalidating the Wagner Act.  Now companies had much more flexibility in dealing with unions.  US Steel was the largest steelmaker in North America.  US Steel had been formed from the merger of Carnegie Steel and Federal Steel, and controlled up to 67% of the steel market in the USA at its height.  It was headquartered in Pittsburg.  A successful strike would have rippled throughout the economy as companies exhausted their inventory of steel and manufacturing lines would be idled.  Violence due to clashes between striker and company police or 'Pinkertons' would also be likely. There is severe economic dislocation throughout the industrial heartland of the USA.
The government has no stake in this labor dispute
This is a national security matter.  Send in the Army to break the strikes.

US Steel negotiates a settlement with the steelworkers' union.  Industry returns to normal.  However, the higher wages won the by union are passed on to consumers across the country, contributing to higher prices and a slowdown in the economy.
The Steelworkers fail to organize US Steel
The workers return to work without a new contract.  This is a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man again
The strike against US Steel is aborted

US Steel works a skillful campaign to bribe and/or terrorize union leaders.  The strike never got past the planning stages, and minimal concessions to the rank and file were made. No significant change in work conditions.  This was a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man again

The Great Depression created high unemployment and the retailers took advantage of that to cut wages to the bone.  The 'Woolworth Girls', retail clerks at the large discount department store, closed down the stores with a strike in order to organize the company.  These stores were located throughout the country in cities and were visible evidence of labor unrest in the commercial heart of the United States.  When products failed to move off the shelves at the retail level, orders were cancelled up the supply chain and threatened to close the factories supplying Woolworth with products. Woolworth survived to become retail giant Target while their rival, S. S. Kresge, became K-Mart.
The government has no stake in this labor action.
This is a national security matter.  Send in the Army to break the strikes.

Woolworth's negotiates a settlement with the clerks' union.  Industry returns to normal.  However, the higher wages won the by union are passed on to consumers across the country, contributing to higher prices and a slowdown in the economy.
Beer and Mimosas at the Union Hall
The 'Woolworth Girls' fail to organize their employer
The workers return to work without a new contract.  This is a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man {and woman} again
The strike against Woolworth's is aborted

Woolworth's works a skillful campaign to bribe and/or terrorize union leaders.  The strike never got past the planning stages, and minimal concessions to the rank and file were made. No significant change in work conditions.  This was a major defeat of organized labor.  Industry returns to normal.
The Robber Barons have cheated the working man {and woman} again

There are revelations that President Roosevelt and the Democrats blatantly used WPA relief money for patronage and bribes.  Scandal rocks the republic as Roosevelt's enemies see this as a betrayal of a sacred trust even as Roosevelt's partisans dismiss it as 'sour grapes.'

In response to the abuse of WPA funding distribution, Congress passes the Political Activity Act, better known as the Hatch Act, which prohibits federal employees and state or local government employees who administer federal programs from trying to influence the outcome of a political campaign, offering jobs to political campaign workers, or manage a political campaign.

In 1939 New York City hosted the World's Fair.  The site was located in Flushing Meadows, in the Borough of Queens, and was drained and reclaimed swamp and dump acreage.  Its theme was 'The World of Tomorrow.'  The dazzling modernity of the exhibits gave its visitors hope that the dawning new decade might prove far happier than the 1930s.  Among the exhibits were RCA's first mass public demonstrations of television receivers and Norman Bel Geddes' plans for a nationwide freeway system.
Mount Rushmore National Memorial is Dedicated

In 1927 the government authorized a national memorial at Mount Rushmore.  Enormous (20 meter) busts of four great presidents (George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Abraham Lincoln and Theodore Roosevelt) would be carved near the top of a 150 meter cliff overlooking a valley where the visitor's center and viewing area would be located.  The work was designed by Gutzlon Borglum, and he supervised construction until his death early in 1941.  His son oversaw the completion of the project later that year.  This monument reminds Americans of their fortitude and success in past crises:  the Founding, the Civil War, and America's industrialization.

During the 1930s powerful anti-war movies such as 'Things to Come', 'All Quiet on the Western Front', 'Lost Horizon', and, even to some extent, 'Gone with the Wind' were made.  These films actively questioned the morality and highlighted the costs of war.  Other films, comedies and romances distracted people from the dislocations of the Great Depression.

Now that war has erupted overseas, Hollywood has recognized the danger of the totalitarians. The risks of war may be necessary to protect what America holds dear.  Films like 'Waterloo Bridge', 'Sergeant York,' 'Divebomber', and 'Foreign Correspondent' are released.

Hollywood was recruited to fight the war against the Axis, too.  Documentaries, like Frank Capra's 'Why We Fight' series, explained how and why the totalitarians sought to overthrow democratic order.  Other films like 'Action in the North Atlantic', 'The Fighting Seabee's', 'Casablanca', 'Wake Island', 'North Star', 'Mrs. Miniver', 'Sahara', and 'Across the Pacific' extolled the virtues of those who fought the Axis, either with or without a rifle.  Even cartoon characters like Popeye, Bugs Bunny, and Donald Duck fought the Axis in cinemas across the land.  These movies were an important conduit for information, propaganda, and vicarious danger for people on the home front.
Don't forget to buy those war bonds, too.

Now that the USA is a war, the Republican caucus meets to determine whether they will oppose the war as 'loyal opposition' or set foreign affairs aside for the duration and work in concert with the administration.  Several noted isolationists, such as Senator Arthur Vandenberg, argue in favor of unity while others complain that this amounts to laying down Republican principals, making it easier for the Democrats to impose socialism at home.
Politics stops at the water's edge.

Now that the USA is a war, the Democratic caucus meets to determine whether they will criticize war policy as a mechanism to regain control or government or set foreign affairs aside for the duration and work in concert with the administration.  Several noted congressional leaders argue in favor of unity while others, still smarting that the Republicans manipulated scandal to take the White House complain that this amounts to letting Republicans to mislead the American public.
Politics stops at the water's edge.

Nazi sympathizers found the German-American Bund.  Ostensibly an organization to promote German-American friendship, its leadership promotes totalitarian ideas and sectarian bigotry.  Despite German funding, the US government cannot shut down its peacetime operation due to free speech guarantees.
This dam on the Columbia River was the first human structure larger by volume than the Pyramids of Egypt.  The dam provided power to eastern Washington, Oregon, and Idaho.
This dam on the Sacramento River in northern California is 183 meters high and provides hydropower to Sacramento and San Fransciso as well as irrigation for the Sacramento valley.
The Wheeler Dam across the Tennessee River in northern Alabama provides a navigable channel, water and power to the state of Alabama (Mobile).  This was a TVA (Tennessee Valley Authority) project.

The Kentucky Dam across the Tennessee River in western Kentucky provides a navigable channel, flood control, and power to the state of Kentucky (Louisville).  It is about 35 meters high and over 2 kilometers long.  This was a TVA (Tennessee Valley Authority) project.

The Parker Dam across the lower Colorado River provided water to San Bernadino, Los Angeles, and San Diego.  Its power was also sent to Southern California.  Not as large as Boulder Dam upstream, it still was of major assistance in developing the American Southwest.  It was completed in 1938.
The Fort Peck Dam across the upper Missouri River provided water and power to Great Falls, Montana.
The Pickwick Dam across the Tennessee River provides a navigable channel, flood control, and power to the state of Tennessee (Nashville).  This was a TVA (Tennessee Valley Authority) project.
The Guntersville Dam across the Tennessee River provides a navigable channel, flood control, and power to the state of Alabama (Mobile).  This was a TVA (Tennessee Valley Authority) project.
The Chickamauga Dam across the Tennessee River provides a navigable channel, flood control, and power to the state of Tennessee (Nashville).  This was a TVA (Tennessee Valley Authority) project.
The Fort Loudoun Dam across the Tennessee River provides a navigable channel, flood control, and power to the state of Tennessee (Nashville).  This was a TVA (Tennessee Valley Authority) project.

The Cherokee Dam across the Holston River provides flood control and power to the state of Tennessee (Nashville).  This was a TVA (Tennessee Valley Authority) project.  It was completed in just 18 months.
The Hiwassee Dam across the upper Tennessee Valley provides flood control and power to the state of North Carolina (Charlotte).  This was a TVA (Tennessee Valley Authority) project.
Named after the director of the TVA, this dam across the Clinch River was completed in 1936 and provided hydropower to Tennessee.
The Fontana Dam across the upper Tennessee Valley provides flood control and power to the state of North Carolina (Charlotte).  This was a TVA (Tennessee Valley Authority) project.
The Apalachia Dam across the upper Tennessee Valley provides flood control and power to the state of North Carolina (Charlotte).  This was a TVA (Tennessee Valley Authority) project.

After the fall of France, the American Navy began patrols in the western Atlantic and effectively relieved the British from escorting her merchantmen in this area.  It was virtually an act of war.  The head of OKM pressed the Fuehrer to declare war on the USA. Others counsel caution in a dangerous world.
Protest to this act to the American Ambassador
Very well, declare war on the decadent Americans

Fritz Todt, brilliant military architect, had responsibility for supervising numerous construction projects for the Reich.  While flying from one site to another, the plane upon which he was a passenger crashed, killing all aboard.
It is a sad day for Germany
US Declares War over the Reuben James
One of our submarines has sunk an American destroyer in the Atlantic.  The Americans have declared war on us in retaliation.

The American ambassador has delivered a note to the Chancellery declaring that the USA has no choice but to cancel its sale of helium to the Reich after our Anschluss with Austria.  Given last year's tragic accident on the 'Hindenburg', we will have to withdraw her sister ship, the 'Graf Zeppelin II', from service.  This is an affront to the German Volk.
America Puts Tarriffs on Our Goods
The Americans have imposed punitive tariffs on the Reich's goods to 'punish' us for Munich.
We count the insults until der Tag

The great diversity of weapons and other equipment that was developed during the interwar years greatly added to the supply burden of the logistics support organizations for all the services.  The effort to standardize on a smaller number of weapons and calibres was time-consuming but could pay dividends in the longer term by reducing supply cost.

Axis control of military bases in the Western Hemisphere constitutes a danger of invasion that cannot be ignored.  A policy decision must be made on how to react to this new threat.  Powerful factions in both Senate and Congress favour an expansion of the military, however this may cause a backlash as there is no widespread public support for war or even mobilisation.  Issuing a warning to the Axis that further expansion will not be tolerated and increasing the military budget is a reasonable 'middle of the road' choice but may be perceived as insufficiently decisive by those who oppose the current administration.  There has also been some calls for seeking closer ties with Germany to avoid any risk of war.
Increase the size of the armed forces
US reaction to Axis bases in Western Hemisphere

Axis control of military bases in the Western Hemisphere constitutes a danger of invasion that cannot be ignored.  A policy decision must be made on how to react to this new threat.  Overwhelming public opinion and strong factions in the Senate and the Congress are pushing for an immediate mobilisation, new defence contracts to procure modern war material and a strong warning to the Axis that further aggression in the Western Hemisphere will result in American intervention.  A few partisan voices have called for rapprochement with Germany and an overall re-alignment of US policy to ensure a prosperous and peaceful future.
Warn Germany and expand the Army

The Swedish scientist Arne Beurling was a professor of mathematics at the University of Uppsala and later at the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, USA. In 1940 he was given German communcations that had been encoded using the 'Sturgeon' cipher with the Geheimfernschreiber and carried out a methodical reverse engineering feat to crack the cypher in just two weeks.  He then created a device that could decypher all German teleprinter traffic passing through Sweden from Norway to Berlin and among other things gave the Swedish government advance warning of Barbarossa.
This could help the enemies of Germany

The Swedish scientist Arne Beurling was a professor of mathematics at the University of Uppsala and later at the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, USA. In 1940 he was given German communcations that had been encoded using the 'Sturgeon' cipher with the Geheimfernschreiber and carried out a methodical reverse engineering feat to crack the cypher in just two weeks.  He then created a device that could decypher all German teleprinter traffic passing through Sweden from Norway to Berlin and among other things gave the Swedish government advance warning of Barbarossa.  The Swedish government has shared plans for the decryption device with us.
The conquest of Norway has given us access to their heavy water plant.  This will aid our nuclear technology development.
We have received detailed plans for cyclotron construction from our scientific colleagues in the United Kingdom.
The conquest of France has given us access to valuable nuclear science installations.
The conquest of Belgium has given us access to valuable nuclear science installations although many of the scientists fled the country before our advancing forces.

The German advance in Belgium has caused many scientists and engineers to flee the country, including some who were working on advanced nuclear technology.  We have been able to gain access to some of the technology they were working on.

The establishment of 'Y' stations during the Great War was a direct consequence of the increased use of wireless communications.  By using multiple stations it was possible to triangulate the location of an enemy fleet, greatly improving the ability to track the enemy without being in close viusal contact.

As the use of wireless signalling became widespread it quickly became obvious that the interception of enemy communications could allow a decisive advantage.  This led to the development of vehicles that were dedicated to listening in on enemy communications from positions close to the front.

The languages of Native American tribes were almost completely unknown outside of Europe and this was recognised as an advantage as early as 1918, when during the Great War the US Army used Choctaw Code Talkers to ensure secure communications and therefore surprise in an attack against German positions in the Argonne forest.  This practise continued during the Second World War with active recruitment of Choctaws, Kiowas, Navajos, Hopis, Cherokees, Commanches, Winnebagos, Seminoles and others.

The processing and decryption of high volumes of enemy signals increasingly required a dedicated intelligence establishment.  This included institutes that provided training for intelligence analysts, auxiliary organisations that provided operators for the increasingly complex electro-mechanical devices used for and dedicated intelligence centers such as Bletchley Park and Arlington Hall where each nations most skilled cryptanalysts would work together on breaking enemy codes.

The processing and decryption of high volumes of enemy signals increasingly required a dedicated intelligence establishment.  This included institutes that provided training for intelligence analysts, auxiliary organisations that provided operators for the increasingly complex electro-mechanical devices used for and dedicated intelligence centers such as Bletchley Park and Arlignton Hall where each nations most skilled cryptanalysts would work together on breaking enemy codes.

Building on US Army experience from both the Great War and the Second World War, the US Marine Corps undertook a project to codify and refine the Code Talker practise into a real security discipline.  The Marine Corps used Navajos exclusively as it was perceived that their language was virtually unknown outside the Navajo nation, there was no written language and it's complex tonal inflections made it extremely difficult to learn as an adult.  Historically 400 Navajos and one Caucasian became part of the Marine Corps code talking program and the code was never broken.

As the mobility of modern armies increased the usefulness of fixed stations for signals interception decreased.  Mobile signals vehicles became more important and this encouraged further development of these highly specialized vehicles.

Mortars were very effective at breaking up infantry assaults and pinning troops while remaining hidden.  Research into counter-measures resulted in the GR-6 Sound Locator, a device that used three microphones to pin-point enemy mortar positions with great accuracy.  Historically this was first used by US troops in the battle for Okinawa.
Pulse code modulation was first applied to voice transmission during the effort to develop secure voice transmission over telephone lines.
In order to achieve near real time results with encryption and decryption of voice data streams it is necessary to use bandwidth compression.
Phase-shift keying is a form of modulation in which the phase of the carrier signal is shifted to represent digital data.

The first voice encryption system for telephones was the SIGSALY system developed by Bell Telephone Laboratories in 1943.  The system consisted of 40 racks of equipment and weighed 55 tons.  Initially it was installed in the Pentagon and in London to provide secure communications and by the end of the war there was twelve systems installed worldwide.  The systems was based on random noise acetate records and was generally considered to have poor voice quality but good security.  It used several new technologies, such as pulse code modulation for speech transmission, bandwidth compression and multilevel frequency shift keying.

As the size and numbers of various intelligence operations expanded far beyond what planners had envisaged it became obvious that separate army services and government ministries were duplicating efforts and sometimes compromising each others work by retransmitting information using less secure ciphers than the original transmission.  The solution was to establish single national organization to manage all cryptology research and development as well as signals intelligence interception and processing.

The British Empire could draw on vast manpower reserves from India and other regions but doing so could have long term effects on prosperity and stability.  As the situation in France became critical and Italy entered the war it became obvious that all available resources had to be mobilised to oppose the march of the Axis armies

New materials such as aluminium and gradual improvements to the drop tank design led to increased fuel capacity and reduced drag problems, allowing light aircraft unprecedented range and time over target.  This technology was crucial for allowing escorts to follow bomber formations all the way to targets deep in enemy territory.

Further improvements to the centerline drop tank design and the addition of mounting points for additional tanks on the wings of light aircraft allowed further range improvements without compromising combat performance.  Where early war fighters could cross the English Channel and fight for a few minutes only at a great risk of ditching on the return journey, late war fighters with drop tank technology could fly from England to Berlin and still have fuel left to fight effectively before returning to base.
Japan claims the Dutch East Indies

In accordance with the territorial stipulations of the Tripartite pact, Japan demands that our Dutch Allies give up the Dutch East Indies to them. The Dutch Government refuses and will only bow to force, but offer deliveries of Oil and Rubber if we support them. Japan on the other hand is likely to declare war over this matter. Shall we honour our obligations to the Japanese or the Dutch?
Honour the tripartite pact and break alliance with the Dutch!
Disonour the tripartite pact and support our Dutch allies!

Outrage! Japan has demanded our East Indian colonies and our supposed German allies claim that they are bound by the clauses of the Tripartite Pact with Japan to support them and have given us an ultimatum. Refusing the Japanese demands means war with Japan and Germany - what shall we do?
We have no choice but to accept!
NEVER! We shall fight for what is ours!

Outrage! In accordance with the stipulations of the tripartite pact, We have demanded the Dutch East Indies, and our supposed German allies claim that they are bound by their alliance with the Dutch and cannot support our claim! What shall we do?

The Dutch Government has given in to our ultimatum and surrendered the Dutch East Indies to our Japanese friends. Now the question is what to do with the Netherlands proper. We can either annex them to the Reich or install a National Socialist puppet regime.
US Reacts to Japan Gaining Saigon

Japan has recently acquired possession of Saigon.  Bases here give the Japanese bombers the ability to interdict shipping between the Philippines and Singapore, the principal British base in the Far East.  The Navy Department is alarmed.
Japan Demands Bases In Northern French Indochina

In wake of France's collapse in 1940 the Japanese demanded that Vichy grant them bases in Northern French Indochina, ostensibly to cut the flow of aid to Chiang Kai-Shek's Nationaist Chinese army. In no position to refuse, Vichy agreed to the demands
Grant Japan bases in Northern Indochina
Japan Demands control of French Indochina

In wake of France's collapse in 1940 the Japanese, as Germany's ally, feared Indochina might become an Allied base from which to challenge Japanese expansion. In no position to refuse, Vichy agreed to the demands
Cede Japan Control Of French Indochina
Grant Japan bases in Northern Indochina
Japan Demands control of French Indochina and Madagascar

In wake of France's collapse in 1940 the Japanese, as Germany's ally, feared Indochina and Madagascar might become an Allied base from which to challenge Japanese expansion. Finding Japan's demand's too much, Vichy refused to accept the demands
Cede Japan Control of French Indochina and Madagascar
Cede Japan Control Of French Indochina
Japan demands Northern French Indochina from Vichy
The collapse of France in 1940 would lead to Japan demanding military bases in Northern Indochina which Vichy accepted.
Japan demands control of French Indochina
The collapse of France in 1940 would lead to Japan demanding control of Indochina which Vichy accepted.
Creation of Independent State of Croatia

Germans have allowed us independence, realizing our people's ancient dreams. We are now free to pursue our own destiny any way we see fit, with Germany at our side. Historically, on 10th of April of 1941, the same day German army entered Zagreb, Ustashe leader in Croatia, retired Austro-Hungarian colonel Slavko Kvaternik, proclaimed Independent State of Croatia (Nezavisna Drzava Hrvatska - NDH). Until the arrival of Ante Pavelic, the exiled leader of Ustashe, he took over all the governing functions, including the post of Chief of Armed Forces. For Chief of Army he placed his close friend, also retired A-H colonel Slavko Stancer, WWI veteran without right arm, whom he promoted to general, while for Chief of Air Force he set the former captain of Yugoslav Air Force Vladimir Kern whom he promoted to Colonel. Finally, for Chief of Navy he appointed captain Djuro Jakcin whom he promoted to rear admiral.
We accepted an alliance with Japan
Recently the popularity of the television has soared.  Broadcasts of news, plays, films, and opera have captivated the nation and are bringing home strong messages of unity.

Yesterday evening was the first time that the entire nation was directly addressed via television by our leader.  He spoke eloquently of the war and the enemies we face, of how we must stand against all dangers or risk our way of life being lost forever.  The speech was a great success and was judged to have brought home the message even more effectively than radio, with a strong upsurge in the sale of war bonds and critical materiel collections.
Siam accepted an alliance with Japan
Japan Demands Access To Northern French Indochina

Engaged in its struggle with Nationalist China, Japan saw the collapse of France in 1940 as an opportunity to gain influence in Indochina, both as a stepping-stone in their goal of conquering Southeast Asia and cut the flow of supplies to Chiang Kai-Shek from outside China.
Demand Bases in Northern French Indochina
Demand Control of French Indochina and Madagascar
Japan Demands Access To Northern French Indochina

Engaged in its struggle with Nationalist China, Japan saw the collapse of France in 1940 as an opportunity to gain influence in Indochina, both as a stepping-stone in their goal of conquering Southeast Asia and cut the flow of supplies to Chiang Kai-Shek from outside China.
Demand Airbases in Northern French Indochina
Demand Control of French Indochina and Madagascar
Vichy Grants Access To Japan in Northern Indochina
Vichy France decided in the summer of 1940 to grant Japan access to bases in French Indochina
Create garrisons in Indochina and establish convoys
Stop this atrocity and bring those responsible to justice!

Technical advances and doctrinal changes based on experience led to further improvements in engineering vehicles.  This allowed faster and better construction of tank traps and defensive positions as well as clearing the rubble and craters which so often created major obstacles in urban fighting.

Niels Bohr presents a paper on fission at the same time that Otto Frisch's paper is published on nuclear fission.  The result is that scientists all over the world repeat the results in a matter of weeks.  Nuclear chain reactions can be demonstrated.

In order to boost war production and satisfy military manpower, we need to employ more of our female comrades in our war factories and enlist the male comrades in the armies of the Rodina.  This will help create our new Socialist Woman.  Long Live the Revolution!

The scientists of the proud Soviet Union have invented a wondrous new creation that transmits both sound and pictures over a distance.  It is called television.  This will better enable our people to learn the truth from our revolutionary government.

Once TV was invented, His Majesty's Government directed the BBC to begin broadcasting content for the television sets that were on the market.  The technical aspects of television broadcasting were regulated by the government.  Although the TV was a novelty invention in its first years, this medium would become the dominant medium for news and popular entertainment by the 1960s.

In order to boost war production and satisfy military manpower, we need to employ women in our war factories and enlist some of those workers.  Putting women into these non-traditional roles is going to change our society.

Once TV was invented, the government licensed the frequency spectra, and let private companies develop and broadcast on the air waves.  There were minimum standards of decency and language which were required.  There were also national standards for power, frequency assignments, registration of call signs, and inspections of equipment.  The government collected a licensing fee to cover the cost of the Federal Communications Commission activities in this sphere.  Since most of the development work in the USA was actually performed by private companies, this event rebates the development costs back to the player in supplies over and above the licensing fees.  Although the TV was something of a novelty invention in its first years, this medium would become the dominant conduit for news and popular entertainment by the 1960s.

In order to boost war production and satisfy military manpower, we need to employ women in our war factories and enlist some of those workers.  Putting women into these non-traditional roles is going to change our society.

The war has reached a desperate stage.  It is necessary to enlist every able bodied person, regardless of sex, to provide hands for the production of war material.  Japan elected to do this by dispersing small tools and hand presses into the homes.  There, elderly or female Japanese could contribute to the war effort while maintaining their households.  Trucks delivered raw materials and picked up finished goods at the homes.  This freed up manpower for enlistment into the armed forces.  It also transformed huge swathes of Japan's flammable cities into legitimate military targets.
Television broadcasting begins across Nippon.  The government is quick to arrange broadcast of news and drama to strengthen the morale of the nation.

The war has reached a desperate stage.  It is necessary to enlist every able bodied person, regardless of sex, to provide hands for the production of war material.  The women of France rally to the Republic and take industrial jobs so their men can enlist in the armed forces.  This revolutionizes the social order by making women more independent.

Television broadcasting begins across France.  The government is quick to arrange broadcast of news, plays, films, and opera to strengthen the morale of the nation. In addition, there are also private broadcast networks affiliated with the political parties which promote conservative, socialist, and communist points of view.

The Republic has passed legislation to give the franchise to women.  The distaff citizens of France now have full participation in the political life of the Republic.  Electoral politics will never be the same.

The new Abraham Lincoln Nuclear Power Plant outside Chicago has a disastrous meltdown.  Many of the firefighters, police, and civil defense workers that initially respond to the incident receive fatal doses of radiation.  Large amounts of radioactivity are released into the environment.  The prevailing westerly wind carries the radioactivity into Hammond and Gary across the Indiana border.  Thousands die, shipping docks are contaminated, and many factories become literal deathtraps due to radioactivity.  Congress convenes hearings to assess blame, which falls heavily on the current administration.

The new Karl Marx Nuclear Power Plant outside Moscow has a disastrous meltdown.  Many of the firefighters, police, and civil defense workers that initially respond to the incident receive fatal doses of radiation.  Large amounts of radioactivity are released into the environment.  The prevailing wind carries the radioactivity into across the southern part of the metropolitan area.  Thousands die, and many factories become literal deathtraps due to radioactivity.  The NKVD investigates to assess blame, which falls heavily on the surviving operators and corrupt officials who authorized substandard construction of the plant.  These men are judged enemies of the state for their negligence.

The new Alexander von Humboldt Nuclear Power Plant outside Dresden has a disastrous meltdown.  Many of the firefighters, police, and civil defense workers that initially respond to the incident receive fatal doses of radiation.  Large amounts of radioactivity are released into the environment.  The prevailing wind carries the radioactivity into across the eastern part of the metropolitan area.  Thousands die, and many factories become literal deathtraps due to radioactivity.  The Gestapo investigates to assess blame, which falls heavily on the surviving operators and corrupt officials who authorized substandard construction of the plant.  These men are judged enemies of the Reich for their negligence.
The National Basketball League is Founded

The National Basketball League is founded.  The teams largely had company backing (Firestone and Goodyear both sponsored teams) and were concentrated in the industrial northeast.  Two of the franchises which were founded included the Lakers and the Warriors.
The National Basketball Association is Founded

The National Basketball Association is founded.  This league would compete with the older National Basketball League, but had an advantage with teams in larger markets - like the Boston Celtics and the New York Knicks.
