In 1936, former world heavyweight champion Max Schmeling scored an upset win over American Joe Louis.  On 22nd June 1938, the return match led to a swift and decisive victory for Louis.  Joe Louis, a black, had refuted Nazi racist theories in the ring, confounding Nazi propagandists, who had played up the fight as an inter-racial contest.  Schmeling found himself drafted into the Wehrmacht for his refusal to fire his Jewish manager and lack of Nazi Party membership.  However, he survived the war despite front-line service as a paratrooper.
Green Bay Packers Defeat the Washington Redskins 21-6.
Washington Redskins defeat the Chicago Bears 28-21.

New York Giants Defeat the Green Bay Packers 23-17.  This was also the first year a 'Pro Bowl' was held.  In early January 1939, the Champion New York Giants defeated a team of league all-stars by a score of 13-10.

Paid season attendance for the league exceeds one million for the first time.  Green Bay Packers defeat the New York Giants 27-0. This season also featured the first televised NFL game which was broadcast on NBC.  It featured the hometown Brooklyn Dodgers versus the Philadelphia Eagles, playing at Ebbets Field.  At the time, it was estimated that there were only 1000 television receivers in the New York City metropolitan area.

Chicago Bears defeat the Washington Redskins 73-0 in the most lopsided championship game ever.  This game also marked the first live radio broadcast of an NFL championship game.  The network was the Mutual Broadcasting System, and Red Barber called the game.

This season had the first post-season play-off game as the Chicago Bears and the Greenbay Packers finished the regular season in a tie for the lead of the Western Division.  Chicago beat the Packers and went on to defeat the New York Giants 37-9.
Washington Redskins defeat the Chicago Bears 14-6.  However, numerous teams were decimated as players and coaches enlisted in the military to serve their country.

Chicago Bears defeat the Washington Redskins 41-21.  This was the first season that helmets were required equipment for players.  Also, the league instituted free substitution which evolved into the familiar offensive, defensive, and special teams of contemporary American football.
Green Bay Packers defeat the New York Giants 14-7.

Historically, this was the first post-war championship.  Of the 638 players and coaches who enlisted in the US armed forces 21 were killed in action.  The Cleveland Browns defeat the Washington Redskins 15-14.

One of the contending New York Giants star halfbacks was suspended after charges were made he had been suborned and was going to throw the game.  The Chicago Bears went on to defeat the New York Giants 24-14.
The Saint Louis Cardinals defeat the Philadelphia Eagles 28-21.
Wilbur Shaw Wins His Third Indy 500

Auto racing was a popular sport in the USA.  The biggest race in the USA during the 1930s was the Indianapolis 500 which consisted of 200 laps around a 2 1/2 mile oval at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.  The Speedway is owned by Great War American ace, Eddie Rickenbacker.  Wilbur Shaw, who had won the race in 1937 and 1939, also won in 1940 for a record third trip to Victory Lane.
As Engines Roar at the Speedway.

Air racing was a popular sport in the USA after the Great War.  Two major events were the Thompson Trophy and the National Air Races.  Organizers would set up tall towers to mark a course and pilots would have to negotiate a circuit outside the towers without exceeding a fixed altitude.  To win, pilots had to optimize aircraft for speed and maneuverability.  This led to refinements in superchargers, high octane fuel, airlerons, and other technology. These racing aircraft were essentially privately financed light fighter test beds.

Pilots and aircraft manufacturers also conducted long distance flights to demonstrate their prowess and capability.  For example, Howard Hughes and Ben Kelsey dueled for cross-country speed records.  This resulted in prototype aircraft which were long-ranged and fast, such as Hughes' Lockheed Gamma aircraft.  They were generally larger than the closed course racers in order to carry more fuel.  For all intents and purposes, these were privately financed medium range fighter test beds.
The New York Yankees won the first game 7-4, but the St. Louis Cardinals swept the rest, taking the series 4 games to one game.  This was first time the Yankees had lost a series since 1926.

The New York Yankees and Saint Louis Cardinals met in a rematch of the 1942 World Series. Both teams had lost several players to military service including Joe DiMaggio, Phil Rizzuto, Howie Pollet, and Red Ruffing.  They split the first two games, but then superb Yankee pitching held the Cardinals to just three runs in the final three games that were swept by the Yanks.  The Yankees returned to their winning form taking the series 4-1.

The American League's St. Louis Browns beat the Yankees for the American League pennant and the opportunity to challenge their cross-town rival, the St. Louis Cardinals for the World Series title.   All six games were played in Sportsman's Park.  The contestants split the first four games, then the favored Cardinals clinched the title by winning the last two games.

With the acquisition of pitcher Henry Borowy, the Chicago Cubs won the National League pennant with strong pitching.  The Detroit Tigers represented the American League.  After splitting the first four games, Detroit won the 5th game.  The sixth game went for 12 innings before Chicago tied the series, forcing a 7th game.  Despite holding the home field, Detroit exploded for 5 runs in the 1st inning and never looked back, winning the series 4-3.

The National League ended play in a tie which forced a play-off between the St. Louis Cardinals and the Brooklyn Dodgers that the Cardinals won in a best of three series.  The Cardinals then turned to face the Boston Red Sox for the World Series.  The teams were evenly matched and series went a full 7 games with the Cardinals getting a go ahead run in the bottom of the 8th Inning and holding on to hold Boston scoreless in the 9th to lock their third World Series title in five years.

This was another cross-town World Series as the New York Yankees returned to the World Series to face the Brooklyn Dodgers.  Brooklyn's roster also boasted the first black player in modern major league history, Jackie Robinson.  It was also the first World Series to be televised.  The Yankees won the hard-fought series 4-3.

Americans partake of the Olympic spirit and fine Bavarian beers as the Olympics are hosted by the Third Reich.  The government clearly intends this as a propaganda show to demonstrate that the new Reich has put Germany back as a top tier world power.  However, the eugenic theories of the Nazi's suffer a blow when black American athlete Jesse Owens wins four gold medals.  Hitler had been personally awarding the gold medals, but refused to do so for Owens because of the American's race.

Seabiscuit was an unlikely champion.  Though he counted triple crown winner Man O'War among his grandsires, he was small and fiercely temperamental.  Jockey Red Pollard helped train him into a champion.  Seabiscuit caught the imagination of the public, becoming a metaphor for the down and out everyman who simply looked for an opportunity to show his worth.  This was especially true after recovering from a leg injury so serious that most trainers would have put down the horse.  War Admiral was the dominant thoroughbred of his generation.  A son of Man o'War, he had swept the triple crown in 1937. Huge and strong, he was a thorough champion.  The two horses met in a match race on November 1, 1938.  The race was broadcast live and 40 million Americans took time from their day to listen to it on radio. Against all expectation, but not against all hope, Seabiscuit emerged triumphant in the home stretch, winning by four lengths.

In the summer of 1937, the America's Cup was again up for grabs.  This was the day of the J-class yacht.  These were enormous sloops, 120 feet or more long with a mast over 150 feet tall bearing over 7500 square feet of canvas. A crew of 40 or more worked the ship.  These vessels were the ultimate in aristocratic grace and elegance.  In the waters off Newport, Rhode Island, owner Mike Vanderbilt skippered the USA's Ranger to beat English challenger's T. O. M. Sopwith's Endeavor II in four straight races.  Ranger is notable for being the first championship yacht to have her design tuned with modeling in a tow tank to minimize drag with an optimal hull form.

This is a specialized electronic tube that can create an image.  The back side of the screen is coated with chemicals, such as zinc sulfide, which glow when struck by electrons.  An electron 'gun' is formed by arranging that electrons from the cathode will have to pass through a region of electromagnetic flux.  A signal controls the charge to the plates, adjust how many electrons will hit and excite the chemicals on the screen.  The more electrons, the greater is the brightness.

This is a specialized electronic tube that can capture black and white images.  A signal plate that is covered with an array of silver and cesium dots that has an oxide finish.  A lens focuses an image on the plate and the photo-electric effect puts charge on the dots.  An electron beam scans the dots and discharges each dot.  The discharges are picked up as electrical signals on an electrode that is separated from the dots by a mica plate.  This signal encodes the visual data from the image.

One can use the iconoscope to capture visual information and a microphone to capture the audio, then broadcast this signal via radio waves.  A receiver sorts the visual and audio signal streams, reproducing the audio via a speaker and the visual data on a cathode ray tube.  This is television. Gameplay note: this technology can trigger various events.

Punch card encoding of data was invented by Charles Babbage in the mid-19th century for his 'difference engine.'  During the 1930s 'Hollerith' encoding was picked up for the encoding of bureaucratic data by the US Social Security Administration and the Census Bureau.  It also found a home in science applications.  IBM, among others, married the type writer to the card puncher to create the 'keypunch' machine.  This let individuals with secretarial skills encode data for use in electromechanical calculating machines.
This was the first device created for data storage in electromechanical computers. This application is required for the development of improved electromechanical computers.

Many of the industrialized countries operated as though workmen operated in a 'craft' atmosphere.  They believed that a machinist or welder required years of training and experience.  However, within the discipline of industrial engineering, time and motion studies, the Taylorite breakdown of almost every industrial task into a series of simple motions and uses of the appropriate tools, meant that unskilled workers could be taught most factory jobs in a matter of a few months.  Greater industrial productivity was possible as enough people could be trained to run the factories on more of a multi-shift basis.

Most industrial jobs were held by men.  However, the increasing mechanization of many factory jobs meant that the physical requirements could be met by most women.  If a systemized training system was in place, the fairer sex provided an untapped source of workers who could release men for combat duty and expand the labor pool for closer to 7x24 (seven day/week, 24 hours/day) factory operation.  'Rosie the Riveter' was a real person.  Rose Will Monroe was a line worker at Ford's Willow Run bomber factory.  She passed away on 31st May 1997 in Clarksdale, Indiana.  The sociological effects of transforming the late-industrial family: breadwinner, spouse, and children to permit both adults to have out of the home jobs would echo for decades.

Once perfect crystals of Germanium or Silicon Germanium are available, specialized equipment to inject precisely patterned dopants into the crystals in commercial quantities and reasonable cost are necessary.  Also machines to remove the individual semiconductor 'chips' from the manufactured array and then package them so that they can electrically connect to the outside world and still remain protected from corrosion are necessary.

Once the basic technology for the fabrication and packaging of semiconductor circuits was established, engineers sought to make things smaller, faster, cheaper, and more reliable.  New equipment enabled better semiconductors that would, in turn, provide more powerful products.  Moore's Law, that semiconductors would double in capability or halve in price every 18 months, was born.

The original semiconductor transistors used a Germanium substrate.  Improved performance required a different material.  Silicon was suitable, once a method for fabricating a pure crystalline ingot from pure molten silicon.  The ingot had to then be cooled and sliced into thin wafers where the solid state semiconductor junctions could be implanted.

In 1917, a pilot in the Imperial Russian Navy, Alexander P. de Seversky, proposed increasing the range of combat aircraft by refueling them in flight. In the interwar years, air-to-air refueling was demonstrated in long duration flying records that eventually reached 27 days. World War II brought about a hiatus in aerial refueling technology development as combatants sought to develop extremely long-range aircraft with large internal fuel capacity. With the advent of jet-powered bombers that consumed far more fuel than piston-engine planes, the need for air-to-air refueling resurfaced as an operational requirement.

In the push for better aerial refueling methods, the Rigid Flying Boom System was developed, consisting of a large-diameter pipe connected to the rear of a prototype tanker and fitted with small wings at the end. The boom was lowered and 'flown' to a connector on the receiver aircraft. This allowed fuel transfers to take place at higher speeds and, more importantly, allow much more fuel to flow per minute.

Another important development in air-to-air refueling was the single-point refueling system on receiver aircraft, which allowed all of an airplane's several fuel tanks to be refilled from a single spot instead of from multiple nozzles around the airplane.

With the practical problems of air-to-air refueling solved, the deployment of the a tanker fleet is required to meet operational needs of the Air Force.  The conversion of existing bomber and transport designs provided a capable tanker fleet.  Historically, the US KB-29 and KC-97 tankers were the first generation of tankers.  However, given the scarcity of tankers, their main operational use was for strategic jet bombers.

The Royal Navy has a tradition of victory and service which extends for centuries.  Confidence, training, and superb non-commissioned officers permit the captains of the Royal Navy to get more fight per ton out of their ships.  As Rudyard Kipling wrote, 'The Navy is very old and very wise.'

This field of research allows a nation to develop nuclear theory, advanced research institutes, new weapons and highly advanced power plants. The weapons can be used against the enemy with a tremendous destructive effect.  Nuclear propulsion can be used to construct highly advanced warships and nuclear power stations can greatly increase industrial output.  However, this field of research is very costly and has some pitfalls as it explores completely new areas of research where a mistake can be fatal.

At the close of the old century, physics was entering an exciting period where the secrets of the atom were beginning to be unraveled.  Great fights were waged on whether light was a particle or a wave.  And the effects and causes of radiation were explored.  Great minds, often working alone or in the company of a select few, made vast strides in their laboratories.
Discovered in 1898 by Marie Curie from pitchblende ores found in Bohemia. One of the first radioactive elements discovered.

Isolated in 1911 by Curie and Debierne by the electrolysis of a solution of pure radium chloride employing a mercury cathode. On distillation in an atmosphere of hydrogen, this amalgam yielded the pure metal. Production would be possible with conventional electroplating technology.
Discovered in 1898 by Marie Curie. It is also found in the Bohemian pitchblendes that provide Radium. However, the concentrations are far lower (0.2% that of radium). It is also far more radioactive.
It is found in combination with Bismuth. Concentrated Polonium gives off dangerous levels of radioactivity and can ionize the air near a sample so it is surrounded by a blue glow.

Rutherford had discovered on Alpha Particles in 1899, but mistakenly took them for radiation, like x-rays. By 1903 he experimentally demonstrated that he could bend a stream of Alpha beam in strong electric and magnetic fields, demonstrating that it was a positively charged particle. Alpha particles are a helium nucleus, two protons and two neutrons and can only travel a few centimeters through the air before being stopped.
Henri Becquerel discovered Beta Particles in 1900. Beta particles are free electrons released by atomic decay or a nuclear reaction. They can travel a few meters through the air before being stopped.

Discovered by Paul Villard around the turn of the century, they were conclusively demonstrated to be photons by Lord Ernest Rutherford in 1914. Gamma Rays are caused by atomic decay or nuclear reactions, and have very high energy and short wavelengths. Gamma rays can travel interstellar distances.

Originally developed by J. J. Thompson in 1899 in the United Kingdom, this notes that as one places ionized atoms under electrical and magnetic fields in the hard vacuum of a cathode ray tube, the trajectory of the atoms will vary depending on the mass and charge of the atom. The atoms left impressions on a photographic plate and were instrumental in experimentally proving the existence of isotopes of stable, non-radioactive atoms.

The Geiger Counter was invented by Hans Geiger in 1928 and utilizes the Geiger-Mueller tube that detects ionizing radiation passing through a tube of inert gas and organic vapor. The more fragile mica window type will detect photons, alpha particles, beta particles, and gamma rays. The glass window type is sturdier, but does not detect alpha particles.

In 1913 Niels Bohr, who had been mentored by Lord Ernest Rutherford, published a theory of radiation which postulated that the atom consisted of a nucleus surrounded by electrons. There were stable energy states for the atom, and if an imbalance occurred, then radiation resulted as the atom shed the appropriate particle necessary to restore equilibrium. Bohr won the 1922 Nobel Prize in Physics for this work.

Following the Great War scientists continued to develop and amplify Bohr's Theory of Radiation.  In addition, gifted scientist/engineers began to design new tools to aid their research into atomic physics.  Science remained an international and largely European endeavour, but an increasing number of the tools were being developed in North America.
Large Van de Graaff Generator Construction

This was developed in 1929 by Robert J. Van de Graaff at Princeton University in the USA. An electrode connected to a hollow sphere is raised to a high potential and then a rapidly moving silk belt carries ionized negative charge to an electrode inside the sphere. The large potential difference between the two electrodes ionizes the air inside the sphere. Potentials of up to a million volts were possible by the early 1930s.

An associate of J. J. Thompson, Francis W. Aston of Cambridge University refined the basic mass spectrometer of Thompson and achieved an order of magnitude improvement in precision in the late teens. This led more precise study of isotopes a Nobel Prize for Aston in 1922. In 1920, Canadian-born A. J. Dempster of the University of Chicago made further refinements with directional focusing and developed a method to ionize the samples with a beam of electrons from a hot wire filament. Both innovations are still used in many modern mass spectrometers, and helped convert a scientific novelty into a useful research instrument.

Once the Mass Spectrometer was refined so it had sufficient accuracy, research into the variety of different atomic isotopes could proceed. During the 1920s there was widespread research into identifying the various isotopes of the elements.

In 1928, Walter Bothe bombarded a Beryllium target with alpha particles from Polonium. This gave off a ìhigh energy photonî which eventually was shown to be neutron. Bothe also demonstrated that you use the highly radioactive element of Polonium to bombard substances and create a reaction.

In 1932, Irene Joliet-Curie and her husband Frederic used Polonium to bombard paraffin with a Polonium source and also detected a positively charged particle in reaction. 1932, Sir James Chadwick, an associate of Lord Ernest Rutherford, repeated the Curieís work on paraffin and used a number of other targets. He was able to prove that there was a neutrally charged particle that was a consequence of the bombardment. This was the neutron, announced in a paper Chadwick authored in the 27th February issue of Nature. In 1935, Chadwick won the Nobel Prize in Physics for his discovery.

In 1932, the Irene and Frederic Joliot-Curie bombarded boron and aluminum with alpha particles and created new radioactive isotopes of nitrogen and phosphorus. This artificial radiation created a stir in the world of physics and won the husband and wife team a joint Nobel Prize in Physics in 1935.

Natural sources of radioactivity were too weak and did not produce enough radioactivity for good research. Lord Ernest Rutherford made a plea for a more powerful source of particles. Ernest Lawrence, a young researcher at the University of California, Berkeley, developed and patented the idea of the cyclotron. This used an alternating electric field to accelerate particles through a strong magnetic field. In early 1931 he built his first cyclotron and a larger model finished in the summer had a 1.1 million volt capacity. This accomplishment won Lawrence the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1939.

Enrico Fermi recognized that the neutrally charged neutron would do a better job bombarding the positively charged nucleus of the atom than the positively charged alpha particle. He embarked on a program to bombard all of the known elements with neutrons and discovered 40 radioactive isotopes of the elements. Fermi and his team also observed that bombardment of nuclei with neutrons resulted in the emission of alpha and beta particles, protons, positrons, and gamma radiation. This 1934 work on neutron bombardment resulted in a Nobel Prize in Physics for 1938.

By the mid-1930s the three basic building blocks of the atom:  the proton, neutron, and electron, had been discovered and it was known that some types of materials gave off different kinds of radiation.  The challenge was now to discover the mechanism behind the creation of radiation.

Fermiís work had produced a number of radioactive isotopes. With this raw material, scientists studied these isotopes and established that as these isotopes decayed, they gave off radiation and would shift down to stable isotopes of the element or lower atomic number elements. In some cases these lower elements were radioactive isotopes in their own right that would undergo a series of transformations until stable isotopes resulted. Although some decay products had been mapped as early as 1935, the story took some time to unfold.

Joliot-Curie had confirmed Fermiís results on the bombardment of Uranium by 1938, but believed that the by-products included transuranic isotopes of Thorium and Actinium. Ida Noddack, co-discoverer of the element Rhenium, had postulated that bombardment might result lighter elements, fission, but did not follow up on the work. Otto Hahn, Lise Meitner, and Fritz Strassman, working in Berlin, chemically separated the by-products of uranium bombardment into radium and barium, both of which were radioactive. In December 1938, they concluded that barium-like material was a bombardment by-product, but could not bring themselves to conclude fission of uranium atom into two lighter elements had occurred.

During 1939, Hahn followed up with colleague Lise Meitner who had emigrated to Sweden to escape the Naziís. Meitner worked with her nephew Otto Frisch, who had emigrated to Denmark and was working in Bohrís laboratory in Copenhagen. Following up on the work published by Hahn and Strassman, Meitner and Frisch realized that energy would be released as the two fission products separated. Their calculations indicated a value 200 MeV for uranium fission. According to the atomic weights of the uranium fission by-products, some mass was converted to energy in the act of fission. Applying Einsteinís equation e = mc2, they found that the energy and mass figures checked out. Frisch quickly returned to Copenhagen and empirically verified their calculations.

Frisch told Niels Bohr about the work he and Meitner had done on fission. They had proposed a theory that when a neutron entered the nucleus it caused the nucleus to change shape, vibrate a break apart, building on one of Bohrís own ideas. Bohr considered those observations with his own insights on the structure of the atom. Bohr built on their insights to develop a theory for fission that he shared at a conference at in Washington on 17th January 1939.

In 1934, Leo Szilard, a Hungarian expatriate physicist in Britain, filed patents for the release of nuclear energy through the transmutation of elements in a chain reaction. In 1935, Szilard amended the patent to cite Uranium and Bromine as specific elements that could be used for this purpose. In 1936, the British Admiralty accepted these patents (under British law the only way the patent could be kept secret was if a government agency itself held the patent). However, the reality of a nuclear chain reaction depended upon more neutrons being given off in a fission reaction than were required to create the fission. Bohr was arguing for experimental verification of this within days of his discussion of fission theory in Washington. Within a matter of weeks in early 1939, Szilardís theory had been empirically confirmed by Lew Kowarski at the Columbia University.

Ernest Lawrence continued to build larger and more powerful cyclotrons at the University of California, Berkeley. After Lawrence won the Nobel Prize in 1939, the Rockefeller Foundation donated $1.4 million to build a 100 MeV cyclotron at his laboratory in Berkeley. In 1940, the USA had twice as many cyclotrons in service or in construction as the rest of the world combined.

It was believed that bombardment of Uranium with alpha particles would produce elements with an atomic number beyond that of Uranium, a transuranic element. Much of the earlier experimental work leading to fission was a consequence of failed attempts to find such transuranic elements. However, another factor here was transformation of physics from table-top experiments to the need to use large cyclotrons and other tools costing hundreds of thousands if not millions of dollars. This covers upgrading the major science labs with this more elaborate and complicated equipment.
Science was being transformed by the industrialization of knowledge creation.

In the spring of 1940, Edward McMillan and Philip Abelson, working in the UC-Berkeley Rad Lab, bombarded uranium-238 with 12 MeV neutrons produced by bombarding a beryllium target with cyclotron accelerated deuterons. Based on the knowledge of how lighter radioactive isotopes decayed it was hoped that new higher atomic weight elements might be created. In fact, the experiment created U-239, which decayed into Neptunium, the first transuranic element.

Glenn Seaborg led another UC-Berkeley team to search for the next transuranic element beginning in the summer of 1940. Bombarding uranium with 16 MeV deuterons, a different isotope of Neptunium was created which decayed into Plutonium 238. The plutonium could be chemically separated from the other materials.

Science was being transformed by the industrialization of knowledge creation and the formation of R&D labs where scientists could work together on high-cost, leading edge projects was a necessity that was gradually recognized around the world. This concentration of effort streamlined not only the work itself but also the procurement of political support and funding.

Fission was only imperfectly understood.  Once again engineering was required to develop new tools to quantify the characteristics of nuclear physics.  These tools would include new materials, chemical procedures, and theoretical calculations about the basic properties of matter.  Furthermore, the complexity and cost of the tools was growing so great that the old model of a brilliant professor in his or her laboratory was giving way to new research and development establishments, sponsored by a university or government.  Finally, the possibility of creating a nuclear explosive was being explored.
In order to move into larger scale experimentation on nuclear research, significant technical enhancements in supporting technologies was necessary

In order to isolate the initial U-235 samples it was necessary to develop advanced analytical techniques which would permit the separation of this isotope of Uranium from the vastly more prevalent U-238 isotope.

Heavy water occurs when the water molecule has two deuterium atoms instead of a regular hydrogen atoms bonding to the oxygen atom. This molecule slows down neutron particles that pass through it. Heavy water was commercially available as a by-product of an ammonia factory in Norway that was built to take advantage of cheap hydro-electric power in 1934. The ammonia was used as a feedstock for artificial fertilizer

Graphite was broadly used in industry for its conductive properties, but it was also found that it would moderate neutrons, creating interest in this material as an alternative to heavy water to serve as a structural material and moderator in a controlled a nuclear chain reaction. Using this in atomic applications required purification to remove trace elements of boron and calcium from the matrix of graphite.

These machines were able to raise particles to higher and higher potentials in order to generate more energetic subatomic interactions. While still useful as experimental vehicles, the increasing precision and control of these machines also permitted accurate measurements of various sub-atomic interactions.

In order to demonstrate a controlled chain reaction and make measurements in order to validate key parts of theory, it was necessary to fabricate a nuclear pile. There were two basic types of piles developed during the 1940s, the heavy water pile and the graphite moderated pile.

This pile uses U238 as a fuel. Heavy water is used as a moderator. The bombardment of the U238 by the slow neutrons moderated by the heavy water results in creation of Plutonium which can be chemically separated from the U238. This was the approach favored by Heisenberg and his team of researchers in Germany. Their design featured alternating layers of Uranium and Paraffin which was suspended in a heavy water tank.

This approach was used by the Americans and Soviets in their research. It used uranium embedded in blocks of purified graphite with cadmium control rods that could be inserted or removed from the stack of material. The cadmium absorbed neutrons, damping the chain reaction.

Uranium had been something of a novelty element prior to 1930s. Its salts were radioactive, but there were no major industrial applications for the metal. Belgium had mines in the Congo that produced the metal.

Most uranium ores are oxides of uranium: U3O8, UO2, UO3. Concentrations of U308 vary from as much as 20% in some Canadian ores to only 0.5% in some Australian ores. The ore is mechanically ground up in ball mills and subjected to a variety of chemical processes that result in ìYellowcakeî, pure U3O8.

The yellowcake, U3O8, is dissolved in nitric acid and then subjected to a series of chemical reactions which generate a tremendous amount of toxic chemical by-products. Pure uranium metal can be obtained by reducing uranium tetrafluoride with either calcium or magnesium. However, the pure uranium will contain a mixture of both U235 and U238.

Small quantities of U235 could be extracted from the mix of U235 and U238. This permitted experimental confirmation of the reaction of U235 atoms to fast neutrons that was necessary to show that relatively small, transportable quantities of U235 could be used in an atomic reaction.

Once Plutonium had been created it was necessary to identify the chemical processes required to remove it and leave a pure metallic form. Glenn Seaborg led the team that accomplished this on 20th August 1942.

In order to calculate the amount of heat and radiation given off in a chain reaction, it was necessary to perform calculations on the size of the various atoms involved compared to the neutrons that would strike them. Furthermore, it was necessary to get some level of empirical confirmation since these numbers varied by up to four orders of magnitude (10,000 times) depending on the who did the calculations and the assumptions that they used.

The critical question for fission was the size of the nucleus compared to the atom. In the case of Beryllium, it was found that neutrons striking this atom would be reflected back out of the atom. This was historically completed in 1941.

The critical question for fission was the size of the nucleus compared to the atom. This would give an estimate for the chance that a neutron passing through the atom would strike the nucleus and create a reaction. The U238 was not as reactive as the U235 and so was identified as more suitable for a reactor fuel. This was completed by July, 1941.

The critical question for fission was the size of the nucleus compared to the atom. This would give an estimate for the chance that a neutron passing through the atom would strike the nucleus and create a reaction. The U235 was much more reactive than the U238 and calculations suggested that as little as 1 kg might be suitable to create a bomb. The actual initial bombs used about 50 kg per weapon. This was completed in July 1941 in the west, and by December 1941 in the USSR.

The critical question for fission was the size of the nucleus compared to the atom. This would give an estimate for the chance that a neutron passing through the atom would strike the nucleus and create a reaction. Plutonium was identified as a prime candidate for fission.

Finally, all the pieces are available to make a reasonable estimate on how much fissionable material is necessary to make a how big of a bang. Though science fiction speculations had been afloat for years from H. G. Wells and others, and serious scientists had speculated about this possibility since fission measurements were made, the state of the art had now reached the point that it was clear an explosive device of unprecedented potency was possible, if the engineering problems could be solved. A British committee, headed by Sir Henry Tizard, produced the MAUD Report which was approved on July 15, 1941. It concluded that a bomb with as little of 25 pounds of U-235 could explode with a force equivalent to 1800 tons of TNT.

During the spring of 1941, Enrico Fermi speculated that the heat and pressure of a nuclear explosion might create conditions for hydrogen to fuse together into helium and produce even more energy. Edward Teller studied the problem and convinced himself that the reaction would not work. However, in Japan, Hakutaro Hagiwara of the University of Kyoto gave a paper in May 1941, outlining a proposal for a bomb consisting of enriched U-235 and then igniting hydrogen for an even greater explosion

During 1941, Philip Abelson of the University of California, Berkeley, developed a practical, relatively inexpensive way to create the gas Uranium Hexafluoride. Given the international situation, he licensed the patent rights to the US government for one dollar and still never collected the dollar.
With new tools and data, it was now possible to build experimental nuclear 'piles' which could be used to test and verify theories.  Methods to separate atomic isotopes could also be developed.

Once nuclear piles were constructed, it was necessary to conduct experiments to measure and verify the amount of heat and radiation given off by chain reactions. This would permit more refined calculations of the nuclear reactions that were taking place. The worldís first self-sustained chain reaction took place during December 1942 in a pile constructed on the grounds of the University of Chicago under the direction of Enrico Fermi.

Once nuclear piles were constructed, it was necessary to conduct experiments to measure and verify the amount of heat and radiation given off by chain reactions. This would permit more refined calculations of the nuclear reactions that were taking place.

Once sufficient experiments were performed, it was possible to design a nuclear pile which would be fueled with U238, operated a period of time, and then harvested for the Plutonium that would created during the course of the fission reaction. The Plutonium would then be chemically isolated from the Uranium and used as the fissile material for a Plutonium bomb. Engineering issues associated with this included cooling, extraction of the fissile material and its byproducts, and control of the chain reaction in the pile.

Once sufficient experiments were performed it was possible to design a heavy water pile which would be fueled with U238, operated a period of time, and then harvested for the Plutonium that could be isolated from the Uranium and used as the fissile material for a Plutonium bomb. Engineering issues associated with this included cooling, extraction of the fissile material and its byproducts, and control of the chain reaction in the pile.

There are two major isotopes of Uranium. U235 and U238. Since they are chemically identical, traditional methods to separate the materials were ineffective and novel techniques relying on the different atomic weight had to be imagined. There were multiple solutions including thermal diffusion, gaseous diffusion, electromagnetic diffusion and centrifuge separation.

This method of isotope separation depended on the fact that the lighter isotope of uranium, in the gaseous form of Uranium Hexafluoride, would move more quickly through a finely perforated barrier. A sufficient number of barriers, in the thousands, would result in a much higher concentration of the U235 isotope in the gas at the end of the barriers than at the beginning. This was demonstrated at Columbia University in November 1941, but full scale engineering started in the spring of 1942. Getting an effective permeable membrane was a key piece part of this process and part of its difficulty.

The theory behind this was similar to the Gaseous Diffusion Separation but depended on the superior mobility of lighter atoms when driven by heat instead of the mobility of lighter atoms through permeable membranes. Philip Abelson was working with the US Navy to develop nuclear reactors as power sources for their submarines. He sought to improve the efficiency of the reactors with an enriched U-235 fuel. A prototype system was built at the Naval Research Laboratory in 1942 that was 36 feet tall, used steam and hot water, and whose only moving parts were the recirculating pumps.

Ernest Lawrence realized that if the uranium isotopes could be ionized, then shooting them through the strong magnetic field of a cyclotron would result in the lighter isotope being deflected less than the heavier isotope. By arranging to catch the lighter U-235 separately from the heavier U-238, one could isolate the two isotopes. The instrument to do this would be called a Calutron.

If the Uranium could be placed into solution, then the resultant solution could be centrifuged. The heavier U-238 would settle to the bottom and the lighter U-235 would be concentrated at the top. After sufficient time to achieve separation, then the U-235 would be decanted off.
The two basic applications for fission were as an explosive and as a source of heat or energy.  The conceptual work to flesh out these applications was now necessary.

The challenge was now to assemble subcritical masses of Uranium and then bring them together in such a way as to create a nuclear explosion. The solution involved designing a cannon to fire a uranium bullet at a precise velocity so it would pass through several rings of enriched U-235. As the bullet passed through the rings, a critical mass would be achieved and trigger a nuclear explosion.

The gun idea developed for a Uranium Bomb was unsuitable for a Plutonium bomb. In order to prevent a pre-detonation of the Plutonium (essentially a fizzle instead of a massive, energy-releasing chain reaction), the muzzle velocity of the bullet had to be about 1000 meters per second, which was impractical. Therefore, it was suggested that a shell of explosives around a Plutonium structure would be used to compress the Plutonium into a critical mass and start the nuclear reaction that way.

Hans Bethe and Edward Tellar returned to the idea of a fusion bomb and calculated that the heat generated by an atomic explosion could be used to trigger a fusion reaction of even greater force if the right fuel elements were available. Preliminary calculations suggested that as little as six kilograms of liquid deuterium could unleash a 1 megaton explosion.

Although water could be used to cool a reactor and generate steam, it was advisable to keep that subsequently radioactive coolant in its own loop of piping and arrange a heat exchanger to an outside loop that would be turned to steam and operate a turbine. Then the mechanical energy of the turbine could be geared down to turn a shipís propeller and/or drive an electric generator. All of this would emphasize small size and weight since submarines propulsion was immediately identified as an eventual goal for this line of research as well as conventional industrial power sources.

The production pile uses coin-shaped slugs of uranium that are inserted into hollow aluminum tubes that go through the core. After a certain period of time, the slugs are pushed through the tubes and fall into a large tank of water where the fiercely radioactive short half-life fission products decay. The reactor is reloaded and, after a safe period of time, the partially enriched uranium is removed from the tank so the Plutonium may be extracted. An unanticipated by-product of the initial design was that a Xenon isotope was one of the by-products and after a period of a few days, enough accumulated to damp the chain reaction. However, the US piles had margin to be expanded and adding about one third more uranium to the pile, created a dense enough neutron flux to overcome the dampening effect of the Xenon. Historically these piles were built at Hanford, Washington.

The production pile uses coin-shaped slugs of uranium that are inserted into multiple hollow aluminum tubes. An array of tubes is placed in the recirculating Heavy Water tank that moderates the chain reaction. Hoists move individual tubes closer or farther from the array as desired to modify the neutron flux density. After a certain period of time, the tubes are lifted out of the reactor and transferred to a ìcooling tankî where the slugs are pushed out and kept a large tank of water where the fiercely radioactive short half-life fission products decay. After a safe period of time, the partially enriched uranium is removed from the tank so the Plutonium may be extracted. An unanticipated by-product of the initial design was that a Xenon isotope was one of the by-products and after a period of a few days, enough accumulated to damp the chain reaction. The reactor needed to be redesigned for additional uranium to keep a dense enough neutron flux to overcome the dampening effect of the Xenon.

It was now clear that an atomic weapon was feasible but the necessary components had to be designed.  This involved finding a way to bring subcritical masses of fissile material in such a way that a run-away uncontrolled chain-reaction would take place.

Now the need was to realize the specific design for a uranium gun. A naval rifle was lightened and shortened since it was eventually realized that it would only need to fire once. The uranium bullet had to be designed. Also, the size of the charge had to be precisely calculated and tested since it was necessary for the uranium bullet to enter the uranium target rings with a precise velocity in order to achieve right rate of fission so the bomb would not ìfizzleî.

To make the implosion concept work, it was necessary to develop a new order of magnitude in precision for explosives. Historically, test calculations were run on a bank of new IBM computers before being experimentally verified in a program that included thousands of test explosions. A key breakthrough involved understanding that one could shape the explosives to focus the shape of the shock wave, much as a glass lens focuses light. This was the Explosive Lens concept.

Placing a thick blanket of U-238 around the critical mass would boost the yield of the explosion by reflecting some of the neutrons back into the U-235 or Plutonium core as well as by getting some fission of the U-238 by the neutrons passing through the tamper.
The details of this device are actually still classified. It involves a device that would release neutrons to start the chain reaction only at precisely the correct moment.

As part of atomic power plant development, it is necessary to design the right arrangement of shielding, control rods, moderator materials, nuclear fuel, and coolant so one can safely extract usable energy from the nuclear reactor.

Further calculations showed that Deuterium was an unsuitable fuel for a thermonuclear action. However, Tritium would do quite nicely. Furthermore, the power of a Hydrogen Bomb could be tuned by adjusting the amount of fuel placed in proximity to the triggering nuclear explosion.

Science was being transformed by the industrialization of knowledge creation and the formation of R&D labs where scientists could work together on high-cost, leading edge projects was a necessity that was gradually recognized around the world. This concentration of effort streamlined not only the work itself but also the procurement of political support and funding. For most countries R&D labs were only formed in the post-war years.
This is the creation of a entirely new industrial infrastructure dedicated to the production and extraction of useful quantities of fissile material.

This factory provided the feedstock to the Permeable Membrane Production Plants and the Magnetic Separation Plant. The first industrial plant of this type was constructed at the Clinton Engineering Works on the Oak Ridge Nuclear reservation.

This factory makes the membranes which are used to separate the U-235 from U-238 isotopes in the Gaseous Diffusion Plan. The initial Norris-Adler Barrier, developed at Columbia University, used a nickel plated mesh which worked, but was very fragile. A factory was built in Decatur, Illinois to fabricate the mesh. By late 1943, the companies that were working on the gaseous diffusion plant, Kellex and Union Carbide, had developed an alternative method that relied on a compressed nickel powder barrier. After some contentious discussions, the factory under construction was converted to the nickel powder barrier.

This is the factory which implements the gaseous diffusion separation process. Historically, the plant at Oak Ridge, Tennessee that provided this capability to the USA required 4000 stages of enrichment. The process required new materials development to resist the corrosive Uranium Hexafluoride gas (what we would come to know as Teflon) and required a complete absence of grease or any other hydrocarbons in the diffusion chambers

Once the engineering for the Thermal Separation Plant was complete, a full factory could be established. The USA actually built two. A 300 column plant was constructed in the Philadelphia Navy Yard which operated off of waste steam from the Naval Boiler and Turbine Laboratory. However, a larger 2100 column was constructed at Oak Ridge starting in June 1944. Advanced welding techniques were necessary to reliably seal the system against steam leaks.

The facility takes Uranium and accelerates the material through an electromagnetic field. Since the different isotopes have different masses, they will deposit on targets that are farther from the center of device if they have higher mass. The individual machines were named Calutrons in honor of the Berkeley Radiation Lab where cyclotrons were born. This type of facility was built at Oak Ridge, Tennessee by the US Manhattan Project.

Initially, the directors of the Manhattan Project believed that the Isotope separation processes would compete against one another and one or the other would ìwinî. However, they realized that by using all of the processes together, they could accelerate the rate at which U-235 could be concentrated. The uranium cycle at Oak Ridge involved sending using the Thermal Diffusion plant to reach about 1% concentration. Then Uranium Tetrafluoride gas went through the gaseous diffusion plant to get 50% concentration. Then the partially concentrated gas was fed to the Calutrons in the magnetic separation facility to get weapons-grade 80% U235. That was converted back to the Uranium Tetrafluoride gas and shipped to Los Alamos in sub-critical quantities. Scientists there reduced the gas to Uranium metal. With all the plants operating, enough weapons-grade Uranium could be produced to make a bomb per month compared to one bomb every six months with the Calutrons alone.

The micro-chemical processes pioneered by Glenn Seaborg were scaled up by more than a thousand fold to take the radioactive fission products from the Plutonium production piles and extract the weapons grade Plutonium. Historically, this plant was located on the Hanford Nuclear Reservation.

The necessary Tritium for the Hydrogen Bomb could be manufactured by bombarding Lithium with neutrons. This would require a production pile and refining operation, similar to those developed for Plutonium manufacture and isolation. Historically, this effort did not take place until after a nuclear arms race took off in the early years of the Cold War.

Delivery of an atomic bomb required a plane with an enormous bomb bay and good payload. Special releases, guide rails so the tail fins of the bomb would not get caught in the bomb bay, additional crew stations to carry the technicians who would arm the bomb in flight, and, in the case of the B-29, even modifying the design of the plane to extend the length of the bomb bay, had to take place.

This is a pilot nuclear power plant. The key objectives here would be to refine the reactor design and overall efficiencies of the plant so that more useful energy could be extracted from the plant than was consumed in the operation of the facility.

Weapons testing goes back centuries.  Swords and firearms routinely carried 'proof marks' that they had been built to standard and tested.  In the case of nuclear weapons, it was important that testing take place to verify the destructiveness of these unprecedented weapons.
This is the construction of test of prototype Uranium guns so serial production of the shell of the Uranium Bomb (absent the fissile material) can commence

Rather than consume the scarce U-235 in a live weapons test, Otto Frisch designed an experiment using Uranium Hydride where a mock-up of the gun and rings would be set up. Since the fission reaction in Uranium Hydride was slower than in the weapons grade U-235, dropping the bullet into the rings would result in only a burst of radioactivity instead of full explosion. Richard Feynman called it tickling the tail of a sleeping dragon and it became known as the Dragon Experiment.

This is the construction and test of working explosive implosion devices. In historical fact, this was the pacing item in completing the Plutonium Bomb that was used for the first man-made atomic explosion.

This is a test detonation of an atomic bomb. In contrast to the Uranium Bomb, where calculations suggested a range of a factor of three in the potential explosive force, the estimates for a Plutonium bomb ranged from no effect to a slight chance that it could ignite the atmosphere and end civilization as we know it. Credible calculations suggested that the explosive force could vary by a factor of 10. Historically, this was the Trinity Test at Alamagordo, New Mexico, which resulted in an 18 kiloton detonation.

This is a test detonation of an atomic bomb. In contrast to the Uranium Bomb, where calculations suggested a range of a factor of three in the potential explosive force, the estimates for a Plutonium bomb ranged from no effect to a slight chance that it could ignite the atmosphere and end civilization as we know it. Credible calculations suggested that the explosive force could vary by a factor of 10.

This develops and trains the aircrew in the mechanics of loading and delivering an atomic weapon. It also involved learning to execute a special diving turn to maximize the distance between the aircraft and the bomb by the time it would detonate.
This evaluates the initial power reactor design and establishes the changes necessary for successful industrial or naval applications.

Science was being transformed by the industrialization of knowledge creation and the formation of R&D labs where scientists could work together on high-cost, leading edge projects was a necessity that was gradually recognized around the world. This concentration of effort streamlined not only the work itself but also the procurement of political support and funding. For most countries R&D labs were only formed in the post-war years.

Once weapons were tested, it was necessary to operate and assemble the new atomic bombs.  There were multiple types of atomic weapons which were available, depending on the type of fissile material used along with the method used to accumulate the nuclear fuel.  The field also received closer attention for other applications including as a source of industrial or motive power.

After the bomb test is completed, serial production of the bomb can begin. These bombs have a yield of about 10 KT and are the same model that was dropped on Hiroshima (The Little Boy). Most of the materials are already in a production pipeline so this involves operating the bomb material industry, final assembly of the components, and transport of the actual weapons to the theater of war. The live bomb includes one additional feature. The fuse for the detonator is linked to a radar altimeter. Calculations show that the optimum blast damage will occur with a air burst at a certain altitude over the ground.

After the bomb test is completed, serial production of the bomb can begin. These bombs have a yield of about 20 Kilotons and are the same model that was dropped on Nagasaki (Fat Man). Most of the materials are already in a production pipeline so this involves operating the bomb material industry, final assembly of the components, and transport of the actual weapons to the theater of war. The live bomb includes one additional feature. The fuse for the detonator is linked to a radar altimeter. Calculations show that the optimum blast damage will occur with a air burst at a certain altitude over the ground.

After the bomb test is completed, serial production of the bomb can begin. These bombs have a yield of about 20 Kilotons and are the same model that was dropped on Nagasaki (Fat Man). Most of the materials are already in a production pipeline so this involves operating the bomb material industry, final assembly of the components, and transport of the actual weapons to the theater of war. The live bomb includes one additional feature. The fuse for the detonator is linked to a radar altimeter. Calculations show that the optimum blast damage will occur with a air burst at a certain altitude over the ground.

Practical power plants may now be built.  These plants, suitable for land-based construction, provide useful amounts of power, but require no air to burn fossil fuels and only need to be refueled at extremely infrequent intervals.  This is a full scale plant that generates power.  However, the short development time of this plant is indicative of 'crash' development.
These are shipboard nuclear reactors that can be used to replace the fossil fuel powered propulsion systems on surface ships or submarines.

Now that the first full scale atomic plant has been built, additional plants may be built across the country. These are industrial power plants that provide electricity.  Once fueled, they operate for years producing no air pollution and without requiring transport of huge quantities of fossil fuel to the plant site.  These are copies of the first plant with few modifications or improvements.

Calculation showed that mixing a small amount of tritium with a ìcocktailî of Uranium and Plutonium might create an even more powerful bomb. Older, pilot nuclear piles can create enough Tritium for these designs.
This involves the construction and test detonation of a Tritium-boosted atomic bomb. Historically, this took place in May 1951.

Reducing the theory to a practical design involved the use of electronic computers for calculations. However, there was a fundamental problem that the calculations kept showing that there was insufficient energy to push the tritium into a full-scale fusion reaction. A fundamental breakthrough was necessary to take this problem in a new direction.

A second generation of atomic plants, incorporating the lessons of the first generation are now built.  These are industrial power plants that provide electricity.  Once fueled, they operate for years, producing no air pollution and without requiring transport of huge quantities of fossil fuel to the plant site.  The longer duration for the design and construction of these plants is critical to ensure their safe operation.  Historically, these were the first civilian power plants that were turned on the late 1950s.
Improved nuclear weapons along with improved nuclear power sources are now available.  In addition, nuclear medicine, the use of radiation to fight cancers is more broadly developed.

A third generation of atomic plants, incorporating the lessons of the earlier generations. These are industrial power plants that provide electricity. Once fueled, they operate for years, producing no air pollution and without requiring transport of huge quantities of fossil fuel to the plant site. The longer development time is driven by new safety measures that have been identified as critically important.

Nuclear weapons are reduced in size and/or increased in destructive force.  In addition, nuclear power plants are engineered for improved reliability and smaller size so they can be widely used in marine applications.

A fourth generation of atomic plants, incorporating the lessons of the earlier generations. These are industrial power plants that provide electricity. Once fueled, they operate for years, producing no air pollution and without requiring transport of huge quantities of fossil fuel to the plant site. The longer development time is driven by new safety measures that have been identified as critically important.

The engineering problems for creating a thermonuclear explosion have been solved.  An atomic bomb detonates and creates a fusion reaction of tritium.  However, this device is the size of a small building and is far too heavy to deliver with a strategic bomber.  This is the device which was detonated at Eniwetok Atoll in November, 1952.

The fusion device is miniaturized so that a strategic bomber can carry it.  Unfortunately, the designers of HOI don't have the hard code for this weapon so there is no new weapon here.  Historically, these were available from the mid-1950s.
Economic growth policies enacted in the UK have encouraged investment in our country and we are seeing significant growth in key industries.

The security of South Africa is at stake and the South African government has mobilized the Homeguard

Following the loss of the major coastal ports to the Japanese, China looked for other ways of getting vital military supplies into the country.A deal was already in place to make a road from Lashio in Burma to Kunming, with work already under way.Chiang Kai-Chek negotiated with the UK to increase the capabilities of the road, and expand the project to allow for supplies to travel from Rangoon to Mandalay to Lashio to Kunming.
It is unnecessary, China will stand alone

China opened negotiations with Britain over increasing the capacity of the unfinished road between Lashio in Burma and Kunming.With the loss of the Chinese ports, this presented a valuable opportunity to Britain to maintain the China trade, and keep the Japanese occupied in China.
We agree to expand the road
We can't afford to help China too
With the agreement and assistance of Britain, the road from Kunming to Lashio and on to Mandalay and Rangoon will be expanded.
After extensive negotiations, Britain has refused to assist us by helping to expand the road between Kunming and Lashio.We are now forced to stand on our own against the Japanese invaders.
Following a massive effort, the road from Lashio to Kunming is now completed and open for transports.
With English engineering and Chinese labor, we have completed the project in a reasonable manner.We can now assist our friends in China with their war with the Japanese.
Supplies have arrived along the Burma Road
Once the Burma Road was open, regular supply shipments of various kinds began arriving in Kunming.
The Burma Road has been cut!

Following the Japanese DOW against the Allies, Imperial forces began to move through Siam and from naval landings against targets in Burma.The supply line running from Rangoon to Kunming was cut, as Japanese forces occupied most of the southern portions of the Burma Road.
The Burma Road has been cut!
Japanese Imperial troops have cut the road between Rangoon and Kunming.The supply line to China is now in enemy hands.

Following the Burma road being cut, and the US becoming an active participant, A plan was proposed to build a new supply route from Kunming to Calcutta, following the Northern Burmese and Indian borders.Work was begun in early 1942, and completed by mid 1942.

Following the Burma road being cut, and the US becoming an active participant, A plan was proposed to build a new supply route from Kunming to Calcutta, following the Northern Burmese and Indian borders.Work was begun in early 1942, and completed by mid 1942.

Following the Burma road being cut, and the US becoming an active participant, A plan was proposed to build a new supply route from Kunming to Calcutta, following the Northern Burmese and Indian borders.Work was begun in early 1942, and completed by mid 1942.
The Americans have opted not to assist us in re-establishing supply lines to China.We now face the decision alone.
The British are going to build a new road to get our supplies into Kunming, with out the assistance of the Americans.
The Americans have informed us that China is not part of their strategic plans, and will be unable to assist us.We stand alone.
The British have failed to honor their commitment to China.We now stand alone.
After several month of hard work, a new road has opened up to carry supplies from the Allied powers to China.
After several month of hard work, a new road has opened up to carry supplies from the Allied powers to China.
After several month of hard work, a new road has opened up to carry supplies from the Allied powers to China.
A shipment has arrived by the Ledo road
After several months of labor, our workers have completed the Ledo road with British assistance.
With British ingenuity and Chinese labor, we have accomplished another feat of engineering.
Advancing Japanese forces have severed the supply line running from Calcutta to Kunming!
Advancing Japanese forces have severed the supply line running from Calcutta to Kunming!
We will come up with something
Advancing Japanese forces have severed the supply line running from Calcutta to Kunming!
A shipment has arrived by the Ledo road

Following reverses in Burma, and the Burma and Ledo roads being cut, it was necessary to find an alternative means of getting supplies to China.A plan was devised to fly cargo planes over the Himalayas.It was dangerous flying even in good conditions.
With both the Burma and Ledo roads cut, there appears to be no other viable option to get supplies to China.
Supplies have arrived along the Burma Road
Once the Burma Road was open, regular supply shipments of various kinds began arriving in Kunming.
A shipment has arrived by the Ledo road

In the late summer of 1936, a devastating typhoon struck the Chinese coast.Hong Kong and nearby areas of China are badly hit.There are 11,000 deaths in Hong Kong alone.
Hong Kong recovers from the effects of the typhoon.

A massive drought struck India in 1942.The total death toll reaches 1,500,000 people by year end.Most of the mortality fell on the very young, the very old, and the ill.The empire sends aid, but in the face of the suffering it seems too little, too late to many of the people directly effected by the calamity. The scale of the disaster stirs dissent on the subcontinent that echoes empire-wide.

Immediately after the outbreak of war between Germany and Britain, William Joyce, an Anglo-Irish fascist thug traveled to Germany on a British passport via a third country.He became a naturalized German citizen and was enlisted to make propaganda broadcasts on behalf of Goebbels' Propaganda Ministry.He was known as Lord Haw Haw to the British and reviled as a traitor.
Propaganda backfires and stiffens British resolve

William Joyce, Lord Haw Haw, was captured and tried for treason after the defeat of Germany. The defense argued that since Joyce's father had not truly re-established his British citizenship upon returning from the USA, Joyce was a US citizen and not, therefore, subject to prosecution for treason against Britain.The Crown cited British law that even foreign nationals who enjoyed the protection of the crown were liable for prosecution for treason.Since Joyce used a British passport for travel that was an admission he looked to the British government for protection.Therefore, the prosecution argued, he was under British jurisdiction for his treason.
He is subject to British law - hang him
Technically he is an American citizen - release him

After the Anschluss of Austria Hitler was planning to dissolve Czechoslovakia via the problem of the Sudentenland. This meant risking a war even with the western Allied. To oppose the threat of a french invasion while the German Wehrmacht was employed in the east Hitler wanted the western defenses to be significantly enhanced. Major parts of German industry and about 400 thousand conscripted workers were put to this task. The deadline for this extensive construction phase was set on 1st October, months before it actually became the date, where the Sudetenland was ceded from Czechoslovakia without a war. The name of this huge project was 'Limesprogramm', from the Latin word for border which today is used in Germany to designate the Roman defensive line against the Teutonic tribes. Propaganda became increasingly important for the Westwall.
Employ all available forces to expand the fortifications
No decision on western fortifications at this time
The structures of this construction phase are about to be finished and become operational now.
We did what we could in that short time
When the war in the west broke out the extensive fortification works could not be kept up. The structures where left unfinished and could not be put for any practical use in the war.
We cannot keep the work going during the war

After the crisis about the Sudetenland seemed to be resolved at Munich, Hitler had new expansion plans and the defenses of the Westwall were still useful to fight off the Western Allied. Additionally more effort was put into the Propaganda.
Improve Defenses west of the river Rhine
No decision on western fortifications at this time

In spring 1939, Hitler accompanied by some military leaders and press members, visited the Westwall defenses for several days. In August, the propaganda was put into daily newspapers and a propaganda movie about the Westwall was shown in the cinemas, even in England and France. Hence creating a myth about the defenses that scared the western allied and made them unwilling to attack it.
Bring Propaganda about the Westwall to the newspapers and cinemas

After the fall of France Germany had to decide on the future of the Westwall. As long as Germany occupied France it would be of no use. It seemed far more reasonable to invest into the coastal defensive of the Atlantikwall than to keep intact fortifications far inland.
There might be future use for this defensive line
When the Westwall was attacked it showed, that its defensive powers where overestimated due to the Propaganda. Once this knowledge sat in the effect was gone.
The world is no longer afraid of our work
The line was to keep an enemy from the west back. It could not be used against an attacker from any other direction.
The fast development of new weapons brought problems for the fortifications which were build to fit in older weapons often of different sizes. But changes to concrete are difficult to make.
Turkey purchases FW190 A-3 fighters from Germany
Germany has allowed us to purchase the FW190 A-3 fighter. This fighter is better then everything we have at the moment. It could provide very useful if we by anyway got involved in this war.
With the technology bought from Germany we can build a new air wing with the FW190. Let us build this new air wing consisting of Focke-Wulf 190 A-3.
Turkey purchases Panzer III J 50mm L/60 from Germany
Germany has allowed us to purchase the Panzer III J 50mm L/60 tank. This tank is better then everything we have at the moment. It could provide very useful if we by anyway got involved in this war.
With the technology bought from Germany we can build our own armor divisions. Let us build a armor division out of Panzer III J 50mm L/60 tanks.
Turkey purchases the Hawker Hurricane II from the UK

The UK has allowed us to purchase the Hawker Hurricane II MR-fighters. This plane is better then everything we have at the moment in this class. It could provide very useful if we by anyway got involved in this war.
With the technology and planes bought from the UK we can build a new air wing with the Hawker Hurricane II. Let us build this new air wing consisting of Hawker Hurricane II MR-fighters.
Turkey wants to purchase the FW190

The Turkish government has approached us to purchase 72 Focke-Wulf 190 A-3 fighter planes. Perhaps this would be a way to strengthen the friendship between our two nations. Perhaps when Turkey is prepared to choose our side in this war the technology would greatly help the Turkish army in their fight. The Turkish government would pay us in Chromite ore and this is always needed for our industries.
Delivery of the FW190 A-3 to Turkey
We have negotiated a deal with Turkey regarding the sale of the FW190 A-3. This deal has strengthened the relationship between our two countries and has given us some valuable resources.

This could be a good way to strengthen the friendship between our two nations and when Turkey is prepared to choose our side in this war the technology would greatly help the Turkish army in their fight. The Turkish government would like to pay us in Chromite ore and this raw material is always needed for our industries.

One of the victims of Soviet terror was Andreu Nin, the political secretary of Catalunyan party P.O.U.M. (Partido Obrero de UnificaciÛn Marxista). He was arrested on 16th June, taken to the NKVD prison and tortured to death there.

The Dutch economy has been stagnating for quite a while now. Our experts have advised that we should devalue the Dutch Guilder and take it off the gold standard in order to spur our economy to new heights.

In early 1937 the navy of Nationalist Spain started with stopping and seizing control over merchant vessel, those vessel were suspected to be shipping equipment and supplies to Republican Spain. As a reaction on these recurring incidents the Dutch government send ships to the region to escort the Dutch merchant vessels on their journey through these waters.

On 18th November 1937, 7 Fokker D.XXI fighters were delivered to the Finnish Air Force. Finland also obtained a license for the production of the Fokker D.XXI in Finland. The Finnish Air Force scored 129 victories against Soviet Aircraft during the winter war. The Finnish Fokker D.XXI fighters were in service until after the end of WWII.

The Dutch government refuses to sell Fokker D.XXI fighters to the Finnish Air Force.

No, we do not want to waist our resource on fighter planes
We need a modern air force

The Finnish Air Force starts its modernization program. Finland always had a good relationship with the Dutch aircraft manufacturer Fokker. They already operated several types of Fokker planes in their air force. When the Finnish Air Force was looking for a new fighter plane Fokker was off course one of the options. The fact that the Fokker D.XXI was half the price of the German ME-109D was probably the reason the Finnish Air Force had chosen the Fokker D.XXI. The first 7 planes and a license to build 14 more were ordered on 17th November 1936. Finland would acquire a unlimited licence to build the Fokker D.XXI on 15th June 1937.

As payment for this chromite ore Germany would pay Turkey in war materials and consumer goods. Alf M. Landon became the first president to be inaugurated on the 20th January date, a change made by the 20th Amendment to the Constitution. Prior to this, presidents had been sworn into office on 4th March. It was also the first time the vice president-elect was inaugurated out-of-doors on the same platform with the president-elect.

When Belgium fell, the King Leopold ordered to all the Belgian troops to lay down their arms to the Germans. Historically, the forces in Europe followed his order, but the troops in Congo continued the fight under British command.

Troops loyal to the puppet government of Vichy are crossing our borders. Our little army has nothing to do against such unfavorable odds, but our generals suggest that maybe they could hold the enemy for some weeks or even months if they take a good defensive stance. Even if this was true, it may cause unnecessary deaths and destruction only to delay the inevitable outcome.

German intelligence reports warns us of the British intention of intervention in Syria to secure their Eastern desert flank. They are undoubtedly aware of German presence in Syria, and fear that the nazis will attack Egypt from Syria. The British military is powerful, but we are far from England, we know the terrain, and know how to defend ourselves.
