Since the very beginning of its existence, the Overseas and Colonial League was present in Brazil. It managed to send several groups of Polish settlers to various states and founding several towns and plantations. However, in November 1937 Getulio Vargas, the president of Brazil, accepted a new constitution. While strongly supporting the creation of a Brazilian nation, the new constitution strongly opposed all immigrants and especially those who wanted to stay in touch with their former countries. In 1938 the League decided to stand up in order to defend the rights of Polish emigrants to Brazil. Polish ministry of foreign affairs started talks with Brazilian government about the status of Polish minority.
We must defend our fellow countrymen

In December 1938, the Overseas and Colonial League received a letter from its envoy to Parana, Brazil. The report stated that mister Lenartowicz is being followed and that the situation of Polish minority in Brazil is getting worse with every week. The ministry of foreign affairs decided not to withdraw the League from Brazil and carry on with the talks.
End of Polish colonization of Brazil

In June 1939, bad news arrived from Brazil. Polish ambassador failed to reach a compromise with the Brazilian government. The latter declined granting Polish minority with a special status. Polish ministry of foreign affairs, worried by the growing tension on the Warsaw-Berlin line, decided to end the issue and withdraw the Overseas and Colonial League from Brazil. Polish minority there was left without any assistance from the Polish government. The press soon joined the dispute: the government was strongly criticized for leaving approx. 150 Polish families in Morska Wola village without any help and funds for a Polish school. The decision was seen as a major mistake since previously Polish propaganda had been underlining that the very existence of Polish villages in Brazil is equal to Poland having a de facto colony.

In the autumn of 1933 an unofficial envoy of Liberia came to Warsaw. Dr. Leo Sajous met with various Polish officials and with the headquarters of the Overseas and Colonial League (LMiK). Various treaties were prepared, including a declaration of will of improving economical and cultural links as well as a treaty that allowed Poland to mobilize 100,000 Liberians in case of war. The LMiK started sending envoys to Africa in order to check whether Polish colonial expansion in Liberia is possible. On 22th July 1936, Tomasz Brudzinski presented the Polish ministry of foreign affairs with a report in which he argued that both the internal and external debts of Liberia are huge and that in less than two years it would have to become dependent of a major power or pay the debts with parts of its territory. In the course of discussion it was agreed that Poland will start preparations to colonize Liberia.

When Tomasz Brudzinski was presenting a report about Polish colonial expansion in Liberia, The Weekly Mirror newspaper started an anti-Polish campaign. An article by Nn-Amdi Azikwe strongly opposed the Polish intentions of colonization and underlined that before 1918, Poland too was a colony of its neighbors. Liberian government unofficially agreed with Azikwes argumentation and revealed the, until-then secret, talks with Poland.
The love of liberty brought us here

At the end of October 1936, Liberian ambassador to France, Othon de Bogaerde, presented the Polish embassy with letters of accreditation and announced to the secretary of the Embassy, Wierusz-Kowalski, that the public opinion in Liberia is aroused by the Polish plans of colonization. The Polish government accepted the letters, but also quickened the preparations to send the first group of colonists and the purchase of land.

After Azikwes article, a real anti-Polish campaign started in Liberian media. However, the government did nothing as it argued that the liberty of speech is one of the main principles of Liberian society.
We must moderate the press and cooperate with Poland
Liberia will not end the press campaign

By the end of 1936, the Liberian ambassador presented the Polish government with a note, in which the government of Liberia apologized for the anti-Polish press campaign. The note underlined that unfortunately nothing could be done about it since the newspapers in Liberia were not state-owned. Polish ambassador Lukasiewicz declared this explanation as insufficient.
Intelligence report on Polish colonization of Liberia

Our men in Europe report that Poland is planning a big colonization campaign in Liberia. The government of that African state is facing huge economical difficulties and there is a serious risk that Liberia will sell itself to the Poles. This could result in a serious change in our sphere of influence.
Spheres of influence must be protected
American press and the Polish colonization

On 15th July 1937, the Pittsburgh Courier published an article entitled: Liberia to be swallowed by voracious Poland. The text stated that the Polish delegate to the League of Nations presented it with a plan of turning Liberia into a Mandate Territory in order to seize its resources. Polish government protested since no such proposal was ever made in Geneva and the newspaper published the dementi soon afterwards. Yet, the article brought the Polish-Liberian issue into the focus of American public opinion.
The United States will not remain neutral
American press and the Polish colonization

On 12th December 1937, the Polish ministry of foreign affairs was presented with a report on the Liberian colonization effort and international reactions. The report underlined the rising consciousness among the press in the USA and listed various rumors popular among western press, such as an alleged Polish plan to take-over the Firestone rubber plantations. Minister Beck decided that the LMiK colonization effort must be halted and all the land- sold.
Poland will not bend to scandalmongers!
The end of Polish colonization in Liberia
We decided to end all the colonization efforts in Liberia. This case will not be subject of further discussions.
The end of Polish colonization in Liberia
Poland decided to end all the colonization efforts in Liberia. This case will not be subject of further discussions. We will have to find other solutions to our problems.
The government of Liberia agreed to closer relations with Poland. It is high time we started sending the colonists.
Polish settlers set off to Liberia
By the end of April 1937, the first groups of Polish settlers set off to Liberia. The colonists, mostly peasants, are to help Polish farmers with building of rubber plantations.
By the end of April 1937, the first groups of Polish settlers set off to Liberia. The colonists, mostly peasants, are to help Polish farmers with building of rubber plantations.

By the end of April 1938, another group of Polish settlers set off to Liberia. The colonists, mostly peasants, were to settle the lands bought by the Overseas and colonial League (LMiK). Soon after their arrival they established several factories.

The government of the USA, worried by the rising Polish presence in Liberia, presented the Polish government with an ultimatum. The USA demanded that the Polish colonization of Liberia be halted and the American zone of influence be obeyed. The document warned Poland that America will not stand back and threatened with war.

The government of the USA, worried by the rising Polish presence in Liberia, presented the Polish government with an ultimatum. The USA demanded that the Polish colonization of Liberia be halted and the American zone of influence be obeyed. The document warned Poland that America will not stand back and threatened with war. Historically, Poland accepted the terms for fear of war and international pressure.
Polish government bended to our demands. Our influence over Liberia is not endangered any more.
The government of Poland rejected the terms of the ultimatum! What should we do?
We will not die for Monrovia
The president of the USA announced last night that his country is now at war with us. We are in a very difficult situation now and it might be impossible to find a solution without confrontation.
We must find a way out
Next group of Polish settlers in Liberia
Poland, unopposed by major powers, equipped yet another group of Polish settlers. It was to prepare Liberia for final take-over.
Another group of Poles reach Liberia

After securing its' interests in Liberia, Poland decided to incorporate the overseas territory. It was decided that Liberia be fully annexed as three new voivodships with limited autonomy. By-elections to the Sejm are to be held in December. At the same time Polish grain surplus started reaching Africa.

By-elections to the Sejm are to be held in December. At the same time Polish grain surplus started reaching Africa.
At least our people will not starve any more
As per the 1930s treaty, Poland was allowed to levy 100,000 Liberians into the Polish Army. The time has come to ask the Liberians for help.

Following the outbreak of the Polish-American conflict, both sides called for the League of Nations support. However, it was not clear whom to condemn and whom to help. A discussion followed, but it lead to nowhere. Various governments, including France, Italy and Australia, proposed a mediation. Seeing that no one could win the war, the Government accepted the Italian peace plan. The only condition was that the Poles withdrew from Liberia.

Following the outbreak of the Polish-American conflict, both sides called for the League of Nations support. However, it was not clear whom to condemn and whom to help. A discussion followed, but it lead to nowhere. Various governments, including France, Italy and Australia, proposed a mediation. The only condition was that the Poles withdrew from Liberia. Minister Jozef Beck, after a short talk with the Commander in Chief and the President, decided that Poland has nothing to win and much to loose. Too much, to be precise. The document was signed the following day.
They did not have much choice anyway

After the Great War Poland resented the lack of colonies. The ministry of foreign affairs argued that Poland should get 10 per cent of former German colonies just as it got 10 per cent of German mainland. The Overseas and Colonial League (Liga Morska i Kolonialna or LMiK) was founded in the 1920s to find a remedy to the overpopulation of Polish rural areas. In December 1938, senator Debski was sent to Paris to conduct unofficial talks with the French government about purchase of Southern Madagascar.
Let's send Debski and see what he can do
Colonization of Madagascar - senator Debski in Paris

After the Great War Poland resented the lack of colonies. The ministry of foreign affairs argued that Poland should get 10 per cent of former German colonies just as it got 10 per cent of German mainland. The Overseas and Colonial League (Liga Morska i Kolonialna or LMiK) was founded in the 1920s to find a remedy to the overpopulation of Polish rural areas. In December 1938, senator Debski was sent to Paris to conduct unofficial talks with the French government about purchase of Southern Madagascar. Historically France declined the Polish proposal.
Well, perhaps we could do business with Poland
Bad news. Senator Debski has just returned from Paris. It is possible that the French will not sell Madagascar to us.
Bad luck. We will find colonies elsewhere.
Colonization of Madagascar - France willing to talk
Great news! Senator Debski has just returned from Paris. He has been told that the French are willing to discuss the purchase of Madagascar.

After the initial talks the time has come to present the French government with a plan of increasing Polish influence in their colony of Madagascar. The Polish government and the Overseas and Colonial League (LMiK) plans to send Polish settlers to southern Madagascar to establish a strong Polish economical bridgehead there. Several factories are to be opened in close cooperation with the French government. The plan also assumes that the southern part of the island is to gradually become a Polish colony.
We have other priorities right now
Polish colonization of Madagascar - serious talks

After the initial talks the Poles presented us with a plan of increasing Polish influence in our colony of Madagascar. The Polish government and the Overseas and Colonial League (LMiK) plans to send Polish settlers to southern Madagascar to establish a strong Polish economical bridgehead there. Several factories are to be opened with close cooperation with the French government. The plan assumes that the southern part of the island is to gradually become a Polish colony.
Send the settlers and we'll see
Polish colonization of Madagascar - France declines
Bad news from Paris - the French have declined our proposal and decided that the Polish sovereignty over Southern Madagascar is a bad idea that should not be further discussed.
Good news - the French government agreed to our plans of colonization of Southern Madagascar. The settlers are now ready to go.
Polish settlers set off to Madagascar
By the end of February 1939, the first groups of Polish settlers set off to Madagascar. The colonists, mostly peasants, were to help Polish farmers with construction of plantations and factories.
By the end of February 1939, the first groups of Polish settlers set off to Madagascar. The colonists, mostly peasants, were to help Polish farmers with construction of plantations and factories.

In April 1939, another group of Polish settlers boarded the M/S Batory in Gdynia and set off to Madagascar. Several thousands of Polish factory workers and engineers were to further develop the industry of the island and establish several caotchouc refining factories.

In April 1939, another group of Polish settlers boarded the M/S Batory in Gdynia and set off to Madagascar. Several thousands of Polish factory workers and engineers were to further develop the industry of the island and establish several caotchouc refining factories.
The final stage of Polish colonization of Madagascar

In May 1939, the time has come for the final stage of colonization of Madagascar. A group of almost 25,000 people set off to Africa onboard several Polish and French vessels. The list of the volunteers for a trip to the tropics was several times as big, since the colonists were to receive various state grants and good money for their hard job.
The final stage of Polish colonization of Madagascar

In May 1939, the time has come for the final stage of colonization of Madagascar. A group of almost 25,000 people set off to Africa onboard several Polish, Romanian and French vessels. The list of volunteers for a trip to the tropics was several times as big, since the colonists were to receive various state grants and good money for their hard job.

In June 1939, the Polish government prepared a note demanding that the southern part of the island be sold to Poland. One of the main arguments was that the number of Poles to settle in the province of Fianarantsoa was much higher than the number of French there and that several times more than that were ready to emigrate.

In June 1939, the Polish government prepared a note demanding that the southern part of the island be sold to Poland. One of the main arguments was that the number of Poles to settle in the province of Fianarantsoa was much higher than the number of French there and that several times more than that were ready to emigrate. What is our response?
France categorically declined our demands and stated clearly that the case of Polish sovereignty over Madagascar shall not be discussed.

A great day for Poland! Our loyal allies of France have agreed to our demands and accepted Polish sovereignty over Southern Madagascar. It was decided that no border delimitation is to take place on the island prior to 1st January 1942 and that the French citizens living there are to be granted the same rights as the Poles.

Three weeks after the Czechoslovakia events, historically on 24th October 1938, Polish ambassador to Berlin Jan JÛzef Lipski had a meeting with German foreign minister Joachim von Ribbentrop. The latter stated that normalization of relations between both countries can be achieved. The price however was high: Germany demanded incorporation of Free City of Danzig, exterritorial road and railway leading through Polish Pommerania and Polish accession to the Anti-Comintern Pact. It was the first time such proposals were made officially. For Poland it was a chance of securing the western border and finding a powerful ally while Germany could win long-lost port of Danzig and a safe buffer-zone in the East. However, Polish diplomats feared that pacts with Hitler would not be worth much more than the paper they were written on.
Lets try to make a deal with Poland

Three weeks after the Czechoslovakia events, historically on 24th October 1938, Polish ambassador to Berlin Jan JÛzef Lipski had a meeting with German foreign minister Herr Joachim von Ribbentrop. The latter stated that normalization of relations between both countries can be achieved. The price however was high: Germany demanded incorporation of Free City of Danzig, exterritorial road and railway leading through Polish Pommerania and Polish accession to the Anti-Comintern Pact. It was the first time such proposals were made officially. For Poland it was a chance of securing the western border and finding a powerful ally while Germany could win long-lost port of Danzig and a safe buffer zone in the East. However, Polish diplomats feared that pacts with Hitler would not be worth much more than the paper they were written on.
Equal distance is the clue here
The true danger lies in the East
Poland decided to join Anti-Comintern Pact. We have secured our Eastern flank and it might be possible to win Poland as an ally. We also started the negotiations about the future of Danzig.

Poland decided to join Anti-Comintern Pact. We have secured our Western flank. The price was high, but Germany might prove a powerful ally against the Bolsheviks. However, our good relations with France and Great Britain might be harmed by our move and the internal opposition might grow stronger.

Shortly after Poland agreed to German demands regarding Danzig and exterritorial railway and road through the Corridor, a conference started. Polish minister of foreign affairs argued that Danzig should be incorporated into Germany, but Poland should retain some rights in the port, especially the exterritorial Military Transit Depot on Westerplatte Peninsula. Also, he demanded some compensation in technology and resources for the toll and transit fees lost due to exterritorial route to and from Eastern Prussia.

Shortly after Poland agreed to German demands regarding Danzig and exterritorial railway and road through the Corridor, a conference started. Polish minister of foreign affairs argued that Danzig should be incorporated into Germany, but Poland should retain some rights in the port, especially the exterritorial Military Transit Depot on Westerplatte Peninsula. Also, he demanded some compensation in technology and resources for the toll and transit fees lost due to exterritorial route to and from Eastern Prussia. He also stated, that without accepting those requests no further talks about the future of Danzig will be possible.

Germany accepted our demands. Westerplatte will remain in Polish hands, Poland will retain control over Polish Post office in Danzig and the rights of the Polish minority will be guaranteed. In addition, Germany agreed to deliver badly needed technologies and materials.
After long negotiations Poland accepted our demands. Westerplatte will remain in Polish hands and we'll have to pay some reparations, but Danzig can finally be reunited with the fatherland.
Germany refused our demands. Herr Hitler spoke of peace, but apparently he understands this word differently. Herr Ribbentrop spoke of compromise, but his compromise equals ultimatum.

After long negotiations Poland refused to cave into our demands. We have intercepted a report by Leon Noel, French ambassador to Warsaw: Before the partitions, the Poles called Danzig the Admiral of Poland, thus symbolizing the importance they traditionally attached to this ancient port. The Poles of the twentieth century, with their passion for the sea, and their high ideals for their reborn state, and what it should become, are not prepared to allow themselves to be despoiled in Danzig of the rights they consider essential to them. They are unanimous on this point:they will not put up with any settlement which would not, in their opinion, appear likely to safeguard them.

On 5th May 1939, Polish Minister of Foreign Affairs, colonel JÛzef Beck, issued an expose in the Polish Sejm. He said: What is the real object of it all? Is it the freedom of the German population of Danzig, which is not threatened, or is it a matter of barring Poland from the Baltic, from which Poland will not allow herself to be barred? (...) Two conditions are necessary for peace to be of real value: peaceful intentions and peaceful methods of procedure. If the Government of the Reich is really guided by those two pre-conditions, then all conversations are possible. (...) Peace is a valuable and desirable thing. Our generation, which has shed its blood in several wars, surely deserves a period of peace. But peace, like almost everything in this world, has its price, high but definable. We in Poland do not recognize the conception of peace at any price. There is only one thing in the life of men, nations and states which is without price, and that is honor.
Let us not burn all the bridges

On 9th April 1936, President Moscicki decreed the creation of National Defense Fund (FON). The fund was to raise additional funds for rearmament of the Army and military training. The basic source of income was selling of not needed military and state property and foreign credits. Soon after its' creation private donators started to pay for it as well.

Until May 1939, the National Defense Fund (FON) gathered more than 1 billion zlotys (almost 200 million 1939 dollars). Almost 40 million zlotys were gathered from private persons wishing to help the army. Most of the money was spent on airplanes, guns, rifles and other types of war materiel. Also, a submarine ORP Orzel was bought.

After the war a port in Gdynia was created and soon it became the most modern and one of the biggest sea ports at the Baltic Sea. However, most of highly-industrialized Polish areas lay in the South: in Silesia and Zaglebie regions. Toll war of 1925 with Germany, and British miners strike of 1926, proved that Polish coal could be a valuable source of income - if only its' transport costs could be lowered. A new railroad line linking Silesia with Gdynia was proposed. The first short segments were opened in the late 1920s, but it wasn't until March 1931, when the construction really started at high speed. It was finished on 1st August 1935. Soon it became highly reliable and allowed Polish mines to bring greater income. Poland became one of the main suppliers of coal in the world - and one of the cheapest.

The 4-years plan did not fill all the gaps in Poland's development. As the 1930s were slowly turning to become the 1940s, it became obvious that there is still much to be done for Poland to become able to produce enough weapons. Minister Kwiatkowski prepared a 15-years plan that was to increase country's production capabilities and diminish the unemployment. The plan consisted of 5 periods, the first of them (historically 1939-1942) focused mostly on military progress.

In the second phase of the 15-years plan the main focus was infrastructure: railways, bridges, development of land and waterways and expansion of Gdynia seaport. In addition, the state was to promote motorization, strengthen the air force and air commerce.

The third part of the 15-years plan was to be focused mostly on education and development of rural areas. The main goal was to extend school coverage to all children over 7 years of age. Also, the plan was to promote crops diversification, field irrigation and crops trade and transport improvement.

Fourth part of the 15-years plan was to be crucial in further development of Polish industry. It focused mostly on industrialization. Moreover, overpopulation of Polish rural areas was to be reduced by means of urbanization and promotion of internal migration and greater peasants mobility.

After its rebirth in 1918, Poland remained divided onto industrialized and well-developed Poland A composed of former Prussian partition and mostly rural and backward Poland B in the East. The fifth part of the 15-years plan was to erase those differences once and for all. The economical and social costs of the plan were tremendous, but it was definitely worth it: the country was finally united.

In March 1936, an occupational strike broke out in Semperit factory in Cracow. The workers, mostly women, demanded that the wages be raised by 15 percent. The police reacted harshly and a fighting occurred. The gossip had it that the workers have been massacred and many workers of other Cracow-based works went on street riots. After several days of street fights at least 10 workers were left dead and additional 20 were wounded.

On 25th March 1936, the worker protests reached their peak. Almost 30,000 men joined the protesters and the government became frightened by the scale of the strike. Finally, it was forced to withdraw from earlier decisions.
We must back down this time

After the defeat of Poland, Germany incorporated many Polish lands, among them Silesia and Zaglebie, two main industrial regions. Most of Poles opposed the new rule and brutal German policies. From the very first days sabotage became a serious issue. Moreover, German attitude towards Poles led to a drastic drop in industrial efficiency in the area.
A steel furnace opens in Silesia

In 1937, Poland started to recover itself from the Great Crisis, helped by the improvement of the world economic situation. It was then that the biggest steel furnace in Europe was being completed in Silesia, the so called
column22: X furnace. It was better than all the other furnaces in Europe at that time as to production and quality of steel.

column2: In the 1930s, the Union of Teachers of Poland (ZNP) was divided on two factions: the supporters of Sanacja government and followers of more leftist ideas. In late 1936, one of the magazines issued by ZNP, named Plomyk, started a campaign glorifying Soviet Union and communism. Historically the government decided to de-legalize the Union which sparkled a teachers' strike. Initially it started in Warsaw, but soon it spread throughout the country.
In November the teachers protests reached their peak. The government, frightened by the scale of the strike, was forced to withdraw from earlier decisions. The ZNP won that battle.
We must back down this time
Cieszyn and the Polish Coal Convention

Since the early 1920s, coal was one of the main sources of foreign currencies in Poland. During the Great Crisis, a Polish Coal Convention was established to control both the export prices and internal usage of the black gold, as it was called. To promote trade and gather money for further development of Polish industry the export prices were kept at a much lower level than in internal market. However, after the incorporation of Cieszyn Silesia the government decided that the newly-acquired coal mines did not have to obey the PKW regulations. This meant that approximately 25 per cent of Polish coal could reach the customers in Poland at a much lower price. A conflict with the PKW moguls started and soon a wave of miners protests spread throughout the country.

During a great peasants manifestation in Nowosielce (Przeworsk County) Gen. Edward Rydz-Smigly received a petition in which the peasants demanded democratization, free elections, allowing exiled politicians back and changing the foreign policies that were considered far too pro-German. The petition was not accepted and a wave of protests and riots soon started to spread throughout the country. By August 1937, the wave reached its peak when a 10 days long peasant strike was ordered by the Stronnictwo Ludowe party. During the strike that took place in almost every village in Poland the farmers denied any food shipment to cities, blocked railway lines and roads. The government decided not to intervene, but in several counties the riots were brutally pacified by the police and the army. It is estimated that more than 42 protesters were killed and several hundreds were injured. Approximately 4000 peasants were arrested.
End of the Customs War with Germany

Following the end of WWI the trade relations between Poland and Germany were constantly deteriorating. In 1926, a Customs War started - both countries raised the taxation so much that it almost halted all trade activity. On 1st April 1938, both countries signed an agreement formally ending the conflict. The agreement was to be valid until 1st March 1940. During the first six months Poland exported more than 250,000 tons of coal.
End of the Customs War with Poland

Following the end of WWI the trade relations between Poland and Germany were constantly deteriorating. In 1926, a Customs War started - both countries raised the taxation so much that it almost halted all trade activity. On 1st April 1938, both countries signed an agreement formally ending the conflict. The agreement was to be valid until 1st March 1940. During the first six months Poland exported more than 250,000 tons of coal.
The cooperation started in 1938, proved itself quite fruitful. Now the time has come for re-negotiation of our treaties and signing a new trade agreement.
We can send the coal elsewhere
The cooperation with Poland started in 1938 proved itself quite fruitful. Now the time has come for re-negotiation of our treaties and signing a new trade agreement.
Poland declined the coal trade agreement

When we started the Customs War with Poland in the 1920s, we were in much better position since Poland had practically no way of exporting her coal abroad and we had more than enough of our own coal and steel. However, our industry needs more and more of coal and steel with every year while Poland found other markets for their production. This time this will hurt us more than it will hurt them.

After the great crisis Poland's economy was hit severely. It was not until 1937, when the market finally got out from depression. The government, having passed the four-years plan, started to invest in the poorer regions of Poland. However, the private investors were somewhat anxious. In December 1936, the Ludwikow Steel Mill (Huta Ludwikow) bought the Suchedniow Steel Factory near Kielce. Soon it was decided that the latter factory is to be turned into a motorcycles factory. The SHL motorcycle (named after the town of SuchedniÛw and Huta LudwikÛw company) turned out to be a huge success. Simple, yet powerful (powered by licensed Villiers engine), paved the way for other private companies to invest their money in less-developed parts of Poland.
Afrika Korps in the BledÛw Desert

Located midway between KrakÛw and Czestochowa in the northern part of Polish Silesia, the BledÛw Desert is the only true desert in Europe. It consists of 20 sq. mi. of shifting sands, dunes, deflation fields and oasis-like vegetation (only along the Biala Przemsza River that cuts through the desert), and even mirages on hot summer days. In 1941, the OKW prepared a plan of building there a replica of Libyan town in order to establish a military training camp for the Afrika Korps. Historically, the village was built and the Rommel forces were training there before setting off to Africa. Also, all pieces of German desert equipment were tested there.
We came here for the waters

In early 1938, Polish HQ bought two Renault R-35 tanks from France for testing purposes. After the tests were carried out it was decided that the tanks are completely unreliable and do not fit the General Staff designations and needs. However, when the crisis over Czechoslovakia started it became obvious that the war is getting closer and Polish TP-7 tank factories could not produce enough tanks to quickly modernize the army. French military credit to Poland allowed the purchase of French tanks. Poland asked for Somua S-35 and Hotchkiss H-35, but France denied. Since the credit could be spent only on French equipment, Poland was left with no choice and 100 R-35 infantry support tanks were bought.
We must strengthen our armored units
We do not need this crap

After the Munich conference it became apparent that it wouldn't be long before Czechoslovakia is fully annexed by Germany. Many soldiers who wanted to fight for their country defected to Poland on their own. Some of them brought their own equipment with them while the others were simply demobilized and crossed the border with Poland. Most of them applied to join the Polish army and were waiting near the Czechoslovakian consulates for a Czechoslovak unit in Poland to be created.

After the Munich conference it became apparent that it wouldn't be long before Czechoslovakia is fully annexed by Germany. Many soldiers who wanted to fight for their country defected to Poland on their own. In April 1939, Major Joseph Bartik was sent to Poland with a proposition from Colonel Frantisek Moravec, chief of Czech intelligence, that a Czechoslovak Legion be created in Poland in exchange for intelligence information.
We do not need an army in exile

After the Munich conference it became apparent that it wouldn't be long before Czechoslovakia is fully annexed by Germany. Many soldiers who wanted to fight for their country defected to Poland on their own. In April 1939, Major Joseph Bartik was sent to Poland with a proposition from Colonel Frantisek Moravec, chief of Czech intelligence, that a Czechoslovak Legion be created in Poland in exchange for intelligence information. Soon a legion of 3000 men was created in KrakÛw which was to become a core of the future Czechoslovak army in exile.
We do not need any Czechoslovak spies
Handover of southern Serbia to Bulgarians

NDH had seven governments during its existence. The fifth lasted from 11th October 1943, until 1st February 1944. Number of ministers has reached 17, an unusually large number of ministers for such a small country.
NDH had seven governments during its existence. The sixth lasted from 1st February 1944, until 30th August 1944.

Commander Djuro Jakcin has passed away suddenly of natural causes. Historically, Djuro Jakcin was commander of all NDH naval forces (riverine and sea-faring) from April 1941, until late 1943. With the Italian veto on a Croatian navy in the Adriatic, he served as the Military AttachÈ in Berlin till November 1942. He served as chief liaison officer with the Waffen SS
column22: X Division till September 1943. His last post was as the head of the diplomatic representation of the NDH in Sofia, Bulgaria till February 1944, when he suddenly died of natural causes.

column2: A section of UNS (Ustasha control service) in charge of spying on Germany has reported that Germans have full knowledge of the planned Vokic - Lorkovic coup d'Ètat. Even though we were aware of this development, and intended to fully use it at some point, our hands have been forced by the Germans. We must move quickly and arrest all conspirators, putting blame on Ante Vokic and Mladen Lorkovic.
NDH had seven governments during its existence. The seventh lasted from 30th August 1944, until the bitter end.

Increased enemy air activity over the Balkan area, especially bomber raids, are hampering our war effort and destabilizing our allies, such as Croatia. We are in position to send some captured Czech AA guns to Croatia to bolster their anti-air defenses. Such a move will help keep them in the war and could gain us some influence with the Croatian government. However, the AA guns might prove necessary to the defense of the Reich. What shall we do?

We have an opportunity to send one of our officers, Djuro Dragicevic, to Germany, to help negotiate armament shipments from the Germans. Germany has been considering assisting us with a shipment of flak guns. It is possible that Dragicevic might be able to win some concessions that we requested but have been unable to obtain so far. Historically, Djuro Dragicevic was sent to Berlin in early 1944, where he stayed until the final days of the war. He was then captured by the Soviets.

Concerned about the increasing number of enemy air attacks on targets in the Balkans, Germany has sent us the equipment for several flak units. Historically, increasing attacks by USAF 12th and 15th Air Force and RAF Balkan AF on targets in Croatia, Austria, Hungary, Serbia, and particularly Ploiesti oilfields in Romania encouraged Germany to bolster flak defenses in Croatia with captured Czech-made AA guns.

Concerned about the increasing number of enemy air attacks on targets in the Balkans, Germany has sent us the equipment for several flak units. Dragicevic, our envoy in Berlin, was able to negotiate some concessions and this has given us a much larger then anticipated number of flak guns. Historically, increasing attacks by USAF 12th and 15th Air Force and RAF Balkan AF on targets in Croatia, Hungary, Serbia, and particularly Ploiesti oilfields in Romania encouraged Germany to bolster flak defenses in Croatia with captured Czech-made AA guns.

With the approaching Red Army, our general staff is arguing for a massive expansion and reorganization of our armed forces. Croatian Home Defense (Domobranstvo) and Ustasha army (Ustaska vojnica) are to be integrated into Croatian Armed Forces (HOS) with numerous Home Defense officers retired and Ustasha officers to be placed in there positions. This controversial reorganization will not be popular, but the general staff consider it necessary.
There is no need for harsh measures

With the approaching Red Army, our general staff is asking for a massive expansion and reorganization of the armed forces. This would be a deeply unpopular move, but our staff feels it is required if we are to resist the Reds. Historically, the mobilization in March 1944, increased the Croatian now armed forces to their peak size of 258,100 members.

The recent reorganization of our armed forces and the merging of regular Home Defense and Ustasha army troops has given us an opportunity to get rid of some suspected traitors. A number of officers are suspected of having participated in the Vokic-Lorkovic conspiracy, and some are known for their anti-ustasha attitudes. Shall we dispose of the treasonous elements in our army? Historically, many forcefully retired officers of Croatian Armed Forces later joined growing Tito's partisans, by now called NOVJ or People's Liberation Army of Yugoslavia which was in desperate need for capable staff officers.

The recent reorganization of our armed forces and the merging of regular Home Defense and Ustasha army troops has given us an opportunity to get rid of some suspected traitors. A number of officers are suspected of having participated in the Vokic-Lorkovic conspiracy, and some are known for their anti-ustasha attitudes. Shall we dispose of the treasonous elements in our army? Historically, many forcefully retired officers of Croatian Armed Forces later joined growing Tito's partisans, by now called NOVJ or People's Liberation Army of Yugoslavia which was in desperate need for capable staff officers.

War has been going badly, and we must be prepared to make our last stand. Our generals are demanding that we attempt one last mobilization, to secure troops needed for defense. What shall we do? Historically, the last Croatian mobilization of the war recruited only 10,000 men.

General Zorn has not been seen in several days, and we have reasons to suspect that foul play is involved. Some rumors claim that Zorn was killed by a partisan strike, while others claim that traitor Zorn fled to avoid capture by our enemies. It seems rats are starting to flee a sinking ship. Historically, General Zorn disappeared in late April 1945. His fate is unknown to this day.

With fall of Berlin, and the general defeat of our German allies, the war is drawing to a close. Our defeat seems certain, in the face of the invincible Allies and the Red Army. Historically, the fall of Berlin and death of Adolf Hitler led to massive retreat of remaining German and NDH troops. The troops fled towards Austria and Italy in hope of reaching western Allies to surrender to them instead of soldiers of Yugoslav army, thirsty for revenge, or the approaching Red Army. Poglavnik Ante Pavelic and most of the Ustashe leadership fled Zagreb and attempted to hide in South America but were eventually found and brought to justice in the newly formed Federal Democratic Republic of Yugoslavia. Sir, what is your last command?
The President orders Gen. MacArthurís evacuation

Orders for Gen. MacArthurís evacuation from the Philippines had reached his headquarters, placing the General in a real dilemma. He thought of resigning his commission, reenlisting as a private, and fighting with the Philippine guerrillas. The temptation to disobey this order was strong. MacArthur had a deep affection for the Philippines--he had spent much of the inter-war period on different assignments in the Philippines, However, he had no choice but to obey and leave. MacArthur arranged for himself, his family and a small military entourage to escape on four PT boats of Lt. John Bulkeley's Motor Torpedo Boat Squadron 3, and then by B-17 to Australia. Some Naval Officers gave the plan only a 1 in 5 chance of success.
The evacuation succeeds, and MacArthur vows: I shall return
His PT Boat is sunk, and America's most famous General dies
The US President orders Gen. MacArthurís evacuation

Orders for Gen. MacArthurís evacuation from the Philippines had reached his headquarters, placing the General in a real dilemma. He thought of resigning his commission, reenlisting as a private, and fighting with the Philippine guerrillas. The temptation to disobey this order was strong. MacArthur had a deep affection for the Philippines--he had spent much of the inter-war period on different assignments in the Philippines, However, he had no choice but to obey and leave.
The Philippine guerrillas will carry on

General MacArthur had retired from the US Army in 1935, to organize the Philippine Army. The development of the Philippine Army was slow. Major problems, with the funding requirement for the Armyís creation, expansion, basing and equipment being one of the most intractable challenges. 1936 had been devoted to the building of camps, organization of cadres, and the special training of instructors. The first group of men was called up on 1st January 1937. However, the vast majority of the Army would be reservists.

The President, by executive order, called into the service of the U.S. for the all organized military forces of the Philippine Commonwealth. The War Department immediately followed up the President's action by establishing, that same day, a new command in the Philippines, with headquarters in Manila. This command, to be called U.S. Army Forces in the Far East (USAFFE), would consist of the Philippine Department, those military forces of the Commonwealth ordered into active service, and such other forces as might be assigned. At the same time, Gen. MacArthur was recalled to active duty and put in command of U.S. Army Forces in the Far East. The recall of Gen. MacArthur to active duty at the age of 61 brought back into the US Army one of its most able and experienced senior officers.

The first official War Department program for a large-scale reinforcement of the Philippines was proposed by Gen. Gerow. In a memorandum for the Chief of Staff, Gen. Gerow argued that those reasons which had limited the size of the Philippine garrison--lack of funds, personnel, and equipment, plus the inability of the Navy to support a large force--were no longer entirely valid. With its present strength, he pointed out, there was a real doubt in the Philippine garrison could resist an attack. To strengthen the garrison and increase its chances of holding Luzon and especially Manila Bay, Gen. Gerow recommended that the Philippines be reinforced by antiaircraft artillery, modern combat planes, and tanks.
Do nothing and accept great loss of influence
The US Army Air Force deploys aircraft to the Philippines.

US Army General Marshall summarized for the US Secretary of War the air reinforcements already shipped or scheduled for shipment to the Philippines. He noted, there were 35 B-17s already in the Islands. Soon the Philippines should have a total of 200 aircraft of various types of bombers and fighters.
The US sends a mixed group of bombers and fighters

The US War Department plan for a large-scale reinforcement of the Philippines was proposed by Gen. Gerow. In a memorandum for the Chief of Staff, Gen. Gerow argued that those reasons which had limited the size of the Philippine garrison--lack of funds, personnel, and equipment, plus the inability of the Navy to support a large force--were no longer valid. With the present strength Philippine garrison, he pointed out, there was a real doubt in the Philippine garrison could resist an attack. To strengthen the garrison and increase its chances of holding Luzon and especially Manila Bay, the Philippines will be reinforced by antiaircraft artillery, modern combat planes, and tanks.

In February 1943, as wartime Commander of the U.S. European Theater of Operations, General Frank Andrews launched the American strategic air campaign against Germany. Before he was killed in an air crash along the Icelandic coast, he had the central role in directing operations intended to achieve victory in Europe. His outstanding knowledge of every phase of airpower was an invaluable asset to the Allies in the early stages of planning and executing the combined British and American 'round-the-clock' bombing offensive against Germany. It is difficult to speculate about how great a role General Andrews would have played during World War II and later, if he had lived. His significance, however, does not depend on what 'might have been.' Instead, it rests on the unique contributions he actually made in his lifetime.

The Chief of the Air Corps General Oscar Westover lost his life in an airplane accident near the Lockheed plant at Burbank, California, when his plane burst into flames on landing. Historically, he was replaced by Gen. 'Hap' Arnold.
The Retirement of General Gen. Henry 'Hap' Arnold
Gen. 'Hap' Arnold retires after suffering a heart-attack. Historically, he was replaced by Gen. Carl Spaatz.
General George Patton suffers a neck injury in an automobile accident on 9th December 1945. He later dies from an embolism on at the 130th Station Hospital.
The Retirement of General Gen. Henry 'Hap' Arnold
Gen. 'Hap' Arnold retires after suffering a heart-attack. Historically, he was replaced by Gen. Carl Spaatz. However, if Gen. Andrews had survived the war, he would have been a very strong candidate.
The Retirement of General Malin Craig

Gen. Malin Craig received his promotion to general in 1935, and was the Army Chief of Staff from 2nd October 1935 to 31st August 1939. As Chief of Staff, Gen. Craig pointed out the Army's lack of manpower and materiel, focused on Army planning, and prepared for World War II as best as he could given governmental restraint. He retired from active duty in 1939. He was replaced by Gen. George C. Marshall.
The Retirement of General George C. Marshall

Gen. Marshall retires and the next day the President calls him back to duty an Ambassador, begriming his diplomatic career. Marshall had been superb in his duties as the Commander of all U.S. military forces. His influence and respect from Congress were instrumental with an extension of the draft as well as periodic requests for enormous appropriations to fund the military. Even with his busy schedule interacting with Congress and planning strategy with the top military brass, the Chief of Staff made constant visits to his troops and made sure their needs were met.
Appoint Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower & Gen. Omar N. Bradley
The Retirement of Admiral William H. Standley

Before being retired at his own request on 1st January 1937, Admiral Standley frequently performed the duties of Acting Secretary of the Navy, due to the declining health of Secretary of the Navy Claude A. Swanson. During his tenure as Chief of Naval Operations, Standley initiated the Vinson-Trammell Naval Bill that provided for establishing, building, and maintaining the United States Navy.
The Retirement of Admiral William D. Leahy

In January 1937, Admiral Leahy had became Chief of Naval Operations, serving for more than two years during a period marked by increasing tensions in the Far East and Europe and by a gradual expansion of the Navy. During this time he frequently had additional duty as Acting Secretary of the Navy.
The Appointment of Admiral Ernest King
Admiral Admiral Ernest King had been appointed as Commander in Chief, U.S. Fleet in December 1941. He also became Chief of Naval Operations in March 1942, holding both positions.
The Retirement of Admiral Ernest King

As a member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, he was instrumental in obtaining sufficient resources to begin and sustain offensive operations. King had been promoted to the new rank of Fleet Admiral in December 1944. Later, with the Second World War was won on all fronts, he left his wartime offices.
The conquest of Czechoslovakia was a boon to German war technology. The Czechs were definite leaders in effective medium tanks and their 38(t) tank was considered one of the best in the world.
Inner Mongolia stands apart from Japan in the Far East
Manchukuo stands apart from Japan in the Far East
Unity in the face of external enemies
The Zheng-Feng: Mao's rectification of style

The British public is outraged over German aggression

The restoration of Syria to French authority
The restoration of Lebanon to French authority

The Armee du Levant remains loyal to France
The death of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk (1881-1938)
The Inonu regime cracks down on far right wing parties
Turkey passes the citizens tax: the Varlik Vergisi
Britain re-establishes Free French control in Lebanon
Britain re-establishes Free French control in Lebanon

The peace treaty Yugoslavia signed with Britain ensured Yugoslav sovereignty and self-determination.
Britain offered a peace agreement to the leaders of the victorious rebellion in Yugoslavia. The treaty respected Yugoslav sovereignty and self-determination.

The Yugoslav monarchy had been too decadent for a long time. Regent Pavle did not have the support of certain sectors of the Army, and was not popular amongst the general population. When he buckled to German pressure and signed the Tripartite Pact to join the Axis, the group of nationalist officers headed by General Simovic knew that it was time to make their move. Few rebellions were executed with less complications. The Prime Minister was arrested by police and forced to resign. Regent Pavle was forced to sign his abdication, and the same night went to exile in Greece. The public was ecstatic: the streets in Belgrade were full of people singing and waving English and French flags everywhere. The German minister in Belgrade was publicly insulted

Massive demonstrations against our signature of the 'Pact of Steel', entry into the Axis, led by a wide coalition of opposition parties, have shaken the government. Hundreds of thousands of protesters have taken to the streets, chanting 'Better War Then Pact', 'Rather Grave Than Slave', and 'Out With The Government'. With the help of British diplomats, generals of the Air Force Borivoje Mirkovic and Dusan Simovic have accomplished a coup d'Ètat against the current government. Teenage King Petar II has been named head of state, while general Simovic has named himself Prime Minister. The people are rejoicing on the streets, while the German ambassador has been spit on and was seen leaving Belgrade. The new government will attempt to placate the Germans with trade concessions and further negotiations about military access. Yugoslavia, a country until then poorly governed, had shouted its heroic, but temporary, defiance at the most powerful conqueror of the modern era.

As the China incident escalated into full-scale war the internal Chinese rivalries were gradually put aside.  Although the warlords of China continued to be at odds and corruption remained a great problem, there was also many political moves to defeat a common enemy.  Throughout the war, Muslim fighters from Sinkiang fought alongside the KMT forces and gained a reputation for being among the best forces in China.

Many Koreans had fought for the Communist forces during the decades of conflict in China.  As war erupted in their homeland these veterans returned to North Korea, still with Chinese army equipment and ready to fight for the Communist cause.  In total, this force numbered more than 30,000 men.
The Chinese sent much material and 30,000 veterans of the Chinese Civil War to fight for North Korea.
The Soviet Union sent much material and many military advisors to Korea.

The joint trusteeship ultimately failed to defuse the international and domestic pressures in Korea.  The country was destined to be torn apart and ravaged once more as war broke out between North Korea and South Korea.
Many countries sent naval taskforces and army units to fight in Korea.

The joint trusteeship ultimately failed to defuse the international and domestic pressures in Korea.  The country was destined to be torn apart and ravaged once more as war broke out between North Korea and South Korea.

As all major powers agreed to joint trusteeship, the future of Korea was decided.  The North came under the influence of Communism while the South became a Capitalist outpost on the Asian continent.  The decision was vastly unpopular with the Korean people and once more popular unrest swept across the country.

As foreign governments moved in and established their rule over the Korean people the KPR government was destroyed and many expected a return to the days of colonial rule.  Massive unrest followed despite investment in rebuilding by the occupying power.
The ravages of war had displaced much of Korea's population and destroyed local industry.  The rebuilding was slow and often hampered by banditry and lack of materials.

After more than 30 years of colonial rule, Korea won their liberty when Japan conceded defeat.  Gradually local governments started forming and rebuilding from the chaos of the war began.  This became known as the KPR government.
The imperialist Japanese forces are no match for our forces. We have destroyed an enemy column and seized much equipment from them, learning much in the process.
In a daring surprise attack our brave soldiers have acquired much equipment from the corrupt warlord forces! We have learned much from this.

During the long struggle with the corrupt warlord forces, we have learned much about warfare. Now that there is a pause in the conflict we should strive to improve our defensive position, to implement the changes proposed by our German advisers and also to reform our military.

In 1940, Mao came up with a new political program in his 'New Democracy'. It was a flexible regime based on an alliance between the working class, peasantry, lower middle-class and the 'national capitalists'. The program stimulated the proliferation of small industry and handicraft production (through industrial cooperatives, or 'Induscos'), and improved the economic situation of the peasantry. At the same time, Mao instituted a severe auto-critique on Communist China. It took the form of the Zheng-Feng, or rectification of style, and tried to substitute 'abstract and empty Marxism' for a 'Marxism deeply informed of Chinese characteristics'. During this time, the Communist Party was involved with the peasantry and knew how to lead the people in the direction of nationalism hostile to Japan.

Nationalist Chinese garrisons were established in the cities but the countryside was ruled by the Communists who would kill landowners and let the peasants rule themselves. This drew new recruits to the Communist cause.

Japanese garrisons were established in the cities but the countryside was ruled by the Communists who would kill landowners and let the peasants rule themselves. This drew new recruits to the Communist cause.

When Japan forged a peace agreement with China, the Nationalists regained most of their territory but also became a puppet state under Japanese control. Mao Tse Tung, the leader of Communist China remarked, 'The Chinese people will forever be slaves to the Japanese overlords unless they join the People's Liberation Army and take their fate back into their own hands!'

Germany did not attempt any attacks on neutral countries after Czechoslovakia because of the risk of war with the Allies. This attitude changed when the German High Command made up their minds to attack the Allies regardless. As a result, the French population clamored for something to be done against German aggression on the European continent.

Germany did not attempt any attacks on neutral countries after Czechoslovakia because of the risk of war with the Allies. This attitude changed when the German High Command made up their minds to attack the Allies regardless. As a result, the British population clamored for something to be done against German aggression on the European continent.
German authorities have seized the French-Spanish border territories of Montpelier and Tarbes
Republican Spain renounces the involvement of Fascist forces during the Spanish rebellion and pledges to uphold the cause of Socialism on the continent
German aggression against the Balkans without prior arrangement with the Soviet Union would have resulted in very serious consequences for German-Soviet relations up to and including war.
German aggression against the Baltics without prior arrangement with the Soviet Union would have resulted in very serious consequences for German-Soviet relations, perhaps even including war.

The British government had well developed plans to move in the event of enemy control of the London area. Plans included either a temporary move to the Midlands or Scotland, or a move to Canada if Britain became untenable. The government would then come back to London once England was again secure.

In the summer of 1940, the situation appeared rather grim for Britain. They had been driven off the continent, and had lost most of their heavy equipment. Additionally, the presence of U-Boats in the Atlantic threatened their mercantile lifelines. In response, Churchill pleaded with Roosevelt for some assistance. He warned that if the Germans were able to force a political settlement with Britain (which had been discussed in the British Cabinet in the dark days of late May and early June), it would seal German control of Western Europe, and permanently alter the political situation of the world. Roosevelt, hamstrung by the U.S. Neutrality Acts, found a way to get around the intent of the law

Added to this bad situation, the threat of U-Boats in the Atlantic threatened the very lifelines of Britain.
