The Treaty stated that no German military forces were allowed on the western side of the Rhine. When Hitler had troops march ostentatiously into this area, many nations were shocked. Some, such as France, Belgium, and the Netherlands, were forced to decide on a new policy to deal with this aggressive behavior. The Netherlands had to decide whether to align with the German movement, or to remain with its traditional allies.

In 1936, Germany violated stipulations of the treaty of Versailles set down at the end of the First World War. The Treaty stated that no German military forces were allowed on the western side of the Rhine. When Hitler had troops march ostentatiously into this area, many nations were shocked. Some, such as France, Belgium, and the Netherlands, were forced to decide on a new policy to deal with this aggressive behavior. Belgium decided to secure its border with Germany.

In 1936, Germany violated stipulations of the treaty of Versailles set down at the end of the First World War. The Treaty stated that no German military forces were allowed on the western side of the Rhine. When Hitler had troops march ostentatiously into this area, many nations were shocked. Some, such as France, Belgium, and the Netherlands, were forced to decide on a new policy to deal with this aggressive behavior.
Following the re-militarization of the Rhineland by Germany, Belgium canceled the defensive treaty of 1920 with France, and instead embraced a policy of strict neutrality.
Romanian oil was crucial to the pre-war economies of both Germany and Italy.
UK finds the German alliance with Franco too aggressive on Hitler's part, and thus have decided to aid us. What should we do?

The Spanish civil war is developing to a struggle between ideologies, and Germany consider us in need of assistance. What should we do? A German direct military intervention could outrage England and France and end up in an invasion through the Pyrenees, Gibraltar or the beaches and that would leave us in an extremely difficult situation. Germany is too far away from our borders to help soon enough if the Allies decide to attack us. On the other hand, Germany would be a powerful ally, with a strong Army and modern weapons. The decision is critical.

We have to crush the Moor's rebellion! We did not fight against the separatists in the Moroccan war in the 1920s, to suffer this humiliation. For Franco, Mill·n Astray, and the rest of the veterans of that war, this is a personal issue. Also, an important part of our troops are composed of African Regulares, and if this lasts too long, it may have a dramatic effect in their loyalty. We have no option but to exterminate the revolutionists.
After the hard times of the civil war, now is the moment to establish a solid government for our newly born country.
After the hard times of the civil war, now is the moment to establish a solid government for our newly born country.

We have received a generous amount of material and money from the Soviet government to help to rebuild our devastated cities. Our country is exhausted and everybody is in need of help. What should we do with it?

After Spanish civil war Mussolini sent aid to Spain to rebuild the country. It was officially given to help the Church of Spain, so it was a good diplomatic move that pleased the Vatican and the rest of Europe. It was very useful to Italy to keep Spain as friendly and close as possible because of the obvious strategic advantages of having a possible ally in the Mediterranean. Even as a non-belligerent, the idea of having bases in Spanish territory was very seductive for Mussolini. Historically, Franco used that help from Italy to rebuild the Spanish Church, as intended, but also to build the huge 'Valle de los Caidos', a spectacular and monumental mausoleum for the national, Italian and German soldiers killed during the war. It was also where Franco was to be buried after his death.
Instability in the region has required us to mobilize our reserves.

The British and Portuguese governments reaffirmed their ancient alliance. This agreement secured Britain's strategic sea lanes to Africa and the Mediterranean. The Portuguese also demonstrated their desire to work with both the Western and Fascist powers.

Following the Nationalist victory in the Spanish Civil War the U.S. administration realized that the only way they would be able to influence the new Spanish government was to formally recognize Franco's government as the official government of Spain.
Pope Pius IX, in response to the anti-clericalism of the Republican government, supported General Francisco Franco and formally recognized the Nationalist government in Spain.

In August 1943, Portugal granted the Allies the right to establish air and naval bases in the Azores. This had a significant effect on the ability of the Allies to provide cover for the Atlantic convoys.
Despite a desire to avoid alienating Germany, Portugal nevertheless entered into negotiations to lease basing rights in the Azores to the Allies.

Although the Portuguese dictator Salazar was ideologically sympathetic to the Axis powers, his country also had considerable historical ties to Britain. Salazar walked a careful line between alienating either side and managed to keep his country out of the war. Portugal declared its neutrality on 1st September 1939, immediately after the German invasion of Poland.
The refusal to blockade Germany has driven the Allies to declare war on us. We should ask for the Axis' assistance.
Our compliance with the Allies' demands for an embargo has led the Axis to declare war on us. It's time for the Allies to keep their word and protect us from German retaliation.
The British government insists that all trade between Portugal and the Axis should cease immediately. Failure to comply could have the direst consequences.

The Allies wanted to strangle the German economy through any means at their disposal. After instituting several measures to limit trading between neutral countries and the Axis, the Allies finally decided to block all of Germany's foreign trade. Portugal was considered by the Allies as an adjacent neutral, and as such subject to severe trade restrictions. Imports of critical supplies were limited to pre-war values, to avoid creating stockpiles that could be exported to the Axis. Meanwhile, the trade deals for tungsten and other Portuguese products the government kept making with Germany were making the Allies very displeased with Portugal. By 1944, patience had all but ran out, and the Allies demanded the complete cessation of trading between Portugal and Germany. Finally, in June 1944, Portugal stopped all trade with the Axis.

Hearing the news of our great revolution, the Portuguese government vows to help us anyway they can. They have started by giving us permission to use their territory for military operations, and Portuguese volunteers have massed to help us fight the evil communists.

The army of Spain has risen against the leftist Republican government. We should help those fine fellows fight the growing communist threat! Our great Head of Government, Prof. Oliveira Salazar vows to do all that is in Portugal's power to help them. With the survival of the Spanish Republic and the Iberian federalist AzaÒa's government, Portugal's independence is at stake!
Germany is still unable to supply itself anywhere else, and asks that we make another trade agreement.
Germany is still unable to supply itself anywhere else, and asks that we make another trade agreement.

During the war the amount of Portuguese exports to Germany grew. Germany needed minerals like tungsten, chrome and zinc, which Portugal extracted. The German people also needed fruit and fish. Germany found itself paying high prices for it's raw materials and foodstuffs. One example is tungsten. Tungsten (or wolfram) was very important in the production of hardened steel for armor plating, ammunitions and industrial machinery. After declaring war on the Soviet Union, Germany was cut off from the main production center of China, where it had supplied itself, and had to turn to Portugal and Spain for help. The Allies competed for the Iberian production, and the price of the ore rose quickly, going from $639/ton in 1939 to over $27,000/ton in 1942. In 1941, Germany managed to strike a deal with Portugal, in which Portugal guaranteed a stable price for tungsten. In exchange, German exports to Portugal would be made at 1938 prices.

In 1940, as war raged in Europe, Portugal commemorated what Salazar's government called the double centennial. This represented the 800 years since Portugal's independence from Leon, and the anniversary of the 1640 revolution. As part of these celebrations, the government organized a great exhibition in Lisbon, where the whole Portuguese speaking world was to be represented. Most Portuguese artists participated in this effort, and the exhibition was seen throughout the country as a great feat.

When the Spanish Civil War broke out, Salazar was startled to hear Portugal was very close to being unable to defend it's borders. He decided therefore to start a rearmament program for the Portuguese military. In August 1939, the United Kingdom promised to provide some assistance in carrying out those plans. The start of the war came in the way, however, and the program was only completed in September 1943.

When the Spanish Civil War broke out, Salazar was startled to hear Portugal was very close to being unable to defend it's borders. He decided therefore to start a rearmament program for the Portuguese military. In August 1939, the United Kingdom promised to provide some assistance in carrying out those plans. The start of the war came in the way, however, and the program was only completed in September 1943.

In April 1939, Germany, Italy, Spain and Japan signed a pact to stand together against international communism. The Italian ambassador in Lisbon tried to get Portugal to sign it too, but Salazar refused.

On 17th March 1939, as Franco got ready to take Madrid, an agreement was signed between the Portuguese government and the Spanish Nationalists. This agreement was called the Iberian Pact and assured that Portugal and Spain would stand together against any threat. When war broke out in Europe, the Portuguese and Spanish governments made a joint statement of neutrality. Franco later changed Spain's status from neutral to non-belligerent.

On 4th July 1937, an attempt was made on the life of Salazar. A bomb went off in a street as his car passed, but he was unharmed. The Portuguese secret police (PVDE) claimed the attack was the work of five members of the Red Legion group. Demonstrations of popular rejoicing were held in Lisbon. Both Hitler and Mussolini congratulated Salazar on his survival.
Our representatives have met with the mutinous soldiers, who've decided to listen to reason. All is well again in the Portuguese navy.
Our negotiations with the mutineers have failed! They insist on their attempt to defect to Republican Spain. What should we do now?

In September 1936, there was an attempted mutiny in the Portuguese fleet. Communist sailors took control of two ships (Afonso de Albuquerque and Dao) and tried to leave Lisbon. They intended to join the Spanish Republican navy and fight the Nationalists. The secret police got wind of this and warned the government. The Navy Minister ordered the shore batteries to stop the ships before they could leave the harbor. After taking 18 hits, the ships surrendered. The convicted sailors were sent to the Tarrafal prison camp in Cape Verde, which became known as the Camp of Slow Death

Under pressure from the Roosevelt administration, the Spanish government agreed to restrict the shipment of raw materials to Germany and to limit the activities of Axis agents in Spain. In return, the U.S. government ended its embargo of oil shipments to Spain.
The Nationalist Spanish government informed the League of Nations that Spain was withdrawing from the League of Nations.

With nearly half the army and the majority of officers corps on the side of rebellion, the Madrid government was paralyzed and unable to organize an effective resistance. When the last desperate attempt at compromise was refused by General Mola, the government gave in to the requests of the anarchist and socialist labor unions and agreed to provide them with arms. By this time workers had already begun seizing arms from barracks, armories and ships, taking to the streets to resist the uprising. The militias succeeded in defeating the insurgents in many areas, often followed by bloody purges of anyone considered sympathetic to the Nationalists.

The Republican government was approached by a delegation of Moroccan nationalists, offering to raise a rebellion against us in return for a guarantee of Moroccan independence. The republicans have accepted and now they are helping the Moroccans that initiated the uprising against our troops!
Fulfilling our agreement, we will cede our Moroccan colonies to France
France agrees to provide Spain with arms in return for territorial concessions in North Africa.

The Republican government was approached by a delegation of Moroccan nationalists, offering to raise a rebellion against Franco in return for a guarantee of Moroccan independence. This proposal was advocated by some Anarchists and Communists, who argued that a successful insurrection would cause dissent among Franco's Moroccan divisions and divert troops away from the front in Spain. However, there was little support for Moroccan independence among Republican politicians, fearing the French reaction if the revolt spread into neighboring French Africa. Instead, Morocco was used as a bargaining chip in an attempt to gain the support of the western democracies.

Franco received nearly 2 million tons of oil on credit from the Texas Oil Company during the civil war. Other aid to the Nationalists was provided by American companies such as Ford, Studebaker, Standard Oil, and General Motors, including over 12,000 American trucks, more than twice the number received from both Germany and Italy.

In April 1936, President Alcal·-Zamora was deposed by the Cortes on the grounds that he had exceeded his constitutional authority by calling general elections in February. The same parties that had come to power in the election used it as the pretext to remove Zamora and replace him with Manuel AzaÒa. When moderate Socialist Indalecio Prieto failed to gain the support of the Left to form a government, an all Republican cabinet was formed by Santiago Casares Quiroga.

When a crisis in government arose in late 1935, President Niceto Alcal·-Zamora appointed a caretaker Prime Minister and scheduled elections for February 1936. The electorate was polarized after the uprising of October 1934, and Zamora feared another revolt if the right wing came to power again. The Right was opposed in the elections by the Popular Front coalition, including left republicans, socialists, Catalan autonomists, and communists.

The Pope gave a speech denouncing the atrocities against Catholics in Republican Spain, in which he distinguished between the Christian heroism of the Nationalists and the savage barbarism of the Republic. The Pope gave his blessing to 'those who have assumed the difficult and dangerous task of defending and restoring the rights and honor of Church and religion.' The support of the Vatican helped to unify the different factions within the Nationalist zone. The Civil War was portrayed as a crusade to defend Catholicism against Atheism and Communism.

General Emilio Mola, who laid the initial plans for the July 1936 uprising, died less than a year later when his plane crashed in bad weather. His death cemented Franco's position as Nationalist Spain's supreme leader.

On 1st October 1936, General Francisco Franco settled all leadership disputes within the Nationalist forces and was proclaimed Commander in Chief of the Nationalist Army and Head of the Spanish State. Franco assumed the rank of Generalissimo and the title el Caudillo (the leader).

As the great fascist and communist powers took sides in the Spanish Civil War, the conflict came to symbolize for many the struggle between the two ideologies. While democratic nations followed a policy of appeasement and non-intervention, anti-fascist idealists from many nations went to Spain as volunteers. Mainly recruited and organized by the Communist International, over 30,000 volunteers were formed into what became known as the International Brigades.

General Jose Sanjurjo was returning from exile in Portugal to assume command of the military uprising when his plane crashed shortly after takeoff. Senior General Cabanellas was named Chairman of the National Junta of Defense, but his presidency was only a symbolic one. In reality, Nationalist forces were commanded by General Mola in the north, Franco in Morocco and the Canaries, and Quiepo de Llano in Andalusia.

The uprising reached Barcelona the morning of 19th July 1936, when General Fern·ndez Burriel seized key areas of the city in preparation for the arrival of General Goded from Majorca to take command of rebel forces in Catalonia. Throughout the day there was bloody fighting in the streets of Barcelona, with the resistance led by militias of the CNT (anarchist labor union), together with police forces still loyal to the government. By the evening of the 19th the attempted coup had failed, the remaining pockets of resistance finally surrendered in the morning of 20th July 1936. Goded was forced to announce over the radio that he had fallen prisoner and that further fighting was useless. The leaders of the Barcelona uprising were executed.

On 12th July 1936, Lieutenant JosÈ Castillo was shot and killed by right wing militants outside his home in Madrid. Castillo had led the police force that repressed a violent Monarchist demonstration earlier in the year and had collaborated in training Socialist militias. In retaliation for the killing, friends of Castillo in the Assault Guards assassinated JosÈ Calvo Sotelo, leader of the Monarchist opposition in parliament. These events shocked the public, and prompted the army to take action against the civilian government which had allowed the country to fall into such disorder.

One of the main objectives of the rebellion against the Republic was to crush the nationalist movements in Spanish territory. The ultra-conservative sectors in Spain saw the 'Estatuto de AutonomÌa' given to CataluÒa as a treason to Spanish history, and they thought that this kind of self-government in provinces could lead to disaster and ultimately cause the disintegration of Spain. In National-held provinces it was forbidden to use local idioms (such as Catalan, Euskera or Galego), or show regionalist flags or symbols. Failing to obey those orders would mean imprisonment or even execution. National forces fought fiercely against local nationalist militias and took terrible reprisals against nationalist politicians and supporters. Just the same as communists and anarchists, they were seen as 'the enemies of Spain'.

The differences and confrontations between Central Government and the Generalitat (Catalan Autonomic Government) have reached their most critical point. Separatist militias supporting the Generalitat have attacked and seized several Central Government facilities in Barcelona and Lleida. They have control of telephonic services, train stations and several weapons and supply depots. The Generalitat has declared that they effectively control all services and institutions in the region and that from now, Catalonia will continue fighting in the war as an independent state allied with the Republic of Spain against a common enemy.

One of the main objectives of the rebellion against the Republic was to crush the nationalist movements in Spanish territory. The ultra-conservative sectors in Spain saw the 'Estatuto de AutonomÌa' given to CataluÒa as a treason to Spanish history, and they thought that this kind of self-government in provinces could lead to disaster and ultimately cause the disintegration of Spain. In National-held provinces it was forbidden to use local idioms (such as Catalan, Euskera or Galego), or show regionalist flags or symbols. Failing to obey those orders would mean imprisonment or even execution. National forces fought fiercely against local nationalist militias and took terrible reprisals against nationalist politicians and supporters. Just the same as communists and anarchists, they were seen as 'the enemies of Spain'.

The majority party in the Basque Parliament, PNV (Basque Nationalist Party) announced yesterday that their ministers and counselors would leave their seats in Central and Autonomic Governments. They said that they took this decision because the Central Government had forgotten about Euskadi, leaving it isolated and helpless after the fascist aggression. The demise of those counselors caused a big commotion, as it left the Autonomic Government useless due to PNV's majority in the chamber. This morning, the PNV, backed by nationalist militias (gudaris), dissolved the Autonomic Government and installed a new independent government declaring Euskadi an independent state that would continue the war against fascism with their own means.

Despite the fact that Poland pronounced full neutrality in Spanish Civil War and banned any arms export and volunteer emigration to any of the belligerent sides, polish state-owned factories sold several hundred thousands carbines and rifles to the Republicans. Most were of old 'Kbk wz. 1898' type, but some 8000 were modern 'Kbk wz. 1929'.

In 1937, the Catalan government approved a special economical plan, known as 'Tarradellas plan'. Josep Tarradellas was then the minister of economy of the Catalan government. The plan tried to solve the problems that the war had created. It gave great powers to the minister of economy for enforcing laws for war effort, for reorganizing the administrative and economical staff in Catalonia, for imposing new taxes and for helping in the collectivization of factories. The economical measures tried to progressively change a capitalist production mode to a more socialist one. The plan had considerable success in these areas, especially for war industries. But the powerful anarchist and communist organizations didn't always like the enforcement of the Catalan government.
Insubordinate forces under the command of Francisco Franco began the civil war in Spain.
The Republican forces won the Spanish Civil War against Nationalist forces.
The Nationalist forces, under the control of Franco, won the Spanish Civil War against Republican forces.
Insubordinate forces under the command of Francisco Franco began the civil war in Spain.

On 23rd October 1940, a historic meeting between Franco and Hitler took place in the French city of Hendaya, near the Spanish border. The purpose of the encounter, held in a armored wagon in the city train station, was to negotiate Spanish participation in World War Two alongside the Axis powers. Spain had previously solicited the rights to Gibraltar and all Moroccan territories, along with enormous industrial and economic help from Germany as payment for its participation. The final agreement ended up being only that Germany would receive the Spanish Blue Division, and to take control of some mines and weapon factories: Spain would otherwise stand apart from the war.

The discussion on the intervention of Spain was long and tense. Hitler wanted Spain to participate more actively in the war, but Franco knew that his country was not prepared to fight another war so soon after the end of the Spanish Civil War, so he demanded major economical, technological and military help from Hitler, along with rights to Gibraltar and Moroccan territories, in exchange for Spain to fully join the Axis cause. Hitler tried hard to negotiate around the Spanish conditions, but Franco did not give in. In the end, Spain chose to stand apart, and only sent the Blue Division to Germany and gave them control of some mines.

The discussion on the intervention of Spain was long and tense. Hitler wanted Spain to participate more actively in the war, but Franco knew that his country was not prepared to fight another war so soon after the end of the Spanish Civil War, so he demanded major economical, technological and military help from Hitler, along with rights to Gibraltar and Moroccan territories, in exchange for Spain to fully join the Axis cause.

On 23rd October 1940, a historic meeting between Franco and Hitler took place in the French city of Hendaya, near the Spanish border. The purpose of the encounter, held in a armored wagon in the city train station, was to negotiate Spanish participation in World War Two alongside the Axis powers. Spain had previously solicited the rights to Gibraltar and all Moroccan territories, along with enormous industrial and economic help from Germany as payment for its participation. The final agreement ended up being only that Germany would receive the Spanish Blue Division, and to take control of some mines and weapon factories: Spain would otherwise stand apart from the war.

During the Civil War, the Communist movement was very important to Republican Spain: International Brigades were created by the Comintern, and many militia forces were raised and commanded by communist leaders. Also, the Soviet Union sent a lot of aid to the Republic. This undoubtedly created an important pro-soviet feeling in postwar Spain. If the Republicans had won the war, this may have been a determinant factor in the political future of Spain.

During the Spanish Civil War, some French commanders were cooperating with the Republicans. This sharing of knowledge on modern strategy, when combined with Spanish commander's experience, helped to develop new strategic Army doctrine. Also, tons of French weaponry were shipped to Spain, along with the means to manufacture them.

The Spanish Civil War was a war against fascism. Although Britain did not agree with Republican ideology, it was at least a democratic nation fighting against tyranny. During the Spanish Civil War, some British commanders co-operated with the Republicans. This sharing of knowledge on modern strategy, when combined with Spanish commander's experience, helped to develop new strategic Army doctrine. Also, tons of British weaponry were shipped to Spain, along with the means to manufacture them.

During the Spanish Civil War, some Russian commanders were cooperating with the Republicans. This sharing of knowledge on modern strategy, when combined with Spanish commander's experience, helped to develop new strategic Army doctrine. Also, tons of Russian weaponry were shipped to Spain, along with the means to manufacture them. Mosin-Nagant rifles were widely used, and if the Republic had won the war, the Mosin-Nagant probably would have become the regulation rifle instead of the Mauser.

During the Spanish Civil War, some Italian commanders were cooperating with rebels. This sharing of knowledge on modern strategy, when combined with Spanish commander's experience, helped to develop new strategic Army doctrine. Also, tons of Italian weaponry were shipped to Spain, along with the means to manufacture them. If Germany had not shipped its weapons to Spain, Franco would have been forced to rely on Italian weaponry to win the war, and instead of the Mauser, rebel troops probably would have been armed with Mannlicher rifles.

During the Spanish Civil War, some German commanders were cooperating with rebels. This sharing of knowledge on modern strategy, when combined with Spanish commanders' experience, helped to develop new strategic Army doctrine. Also, tons of German weaponry were shipped to Spain, along with the means to manufacture them. Thus, many German Mauser Kar98 rifles, known as el m·user to Spanish soldiers, were produced and extensively used by Nationalist forces. The Mauser Kar98 became the regulation rifle of National Army and Guardia Civil for many years.

On 22nd October 1936, the philosopher, writer, and poet Miguel de Unamuno, Rector of the University of Salamanca, and one of the most influential intellectual figures in Spain, pronounced a very critical speech about franquist project during an academic lecture. Unamuno finished the speech with the phrase: you may win, but you will not convince. The reprisal was immediate. General M. Astray replied with a threat, saying: Hail to death, death to intelligence! A few days later, Unamuno was forced into poverty. Other cultural figures suffered worse fates: Federico GarcÌa Lorca was assassinated, Miguel Hern·ndez was imprisoned, and Antonio Machado went into exile.

The Spanish Civil War resulted in more than 500,000 deaths, not only on the battlefield. The Fascists, with a extermination policy imposed by the High Command, executed approximately 90,000 people. Cruelty, however, was present on both sides. Though the government asked its troops not to take reprisals, many angry militants took justice into their own hands.  7000 clerics were killed, and many falangists and enemy soldiers were executed. The land that was left for those who won the war was a land full of hunger, poverty, and dead bodies in ditches.

During, and after the war, thousands of people fled to the mountains to avoid the Franquist repression. Many of these refugees joined together, creating a guerrilla network in many Spanish territories. The guerillas attacked targets such as infrastructure, mines, falangist housing, but their primary objective was to survive. With the outbreak of war in Europe, the guerillas thought the Allies would bring their war against fascism to Spain, and therefore decided to help the Allies. This help came mainly in the form of information, but not exclusively: the mugularis, or passeurs, helped approximately 7000 Jews, spies, resistance members, and British pilots to escape from German-occupied France. Although the guerillas were never a serious danger to Franco, he was forced to commit a lot of resources and men to exterminate them.

Although no democratic country sent military help to the Spanish Republic, the pressure of public opinion, and the impact of the press showing the cruelty of the war, motivated some countries to sent humanitarian help. The Republic received ambulances, food, medicine, and medical personnel, as well as Red Cross volunteers.
We have received guns for our fortifications from the USA. This unexpected success is emboldening our people, and we can now stand up to fascist aggressors.
As we expected USA has refused our offer and we will have to obtain the heavy guns needed for our fortifications elsewhere. Many in our government are very disappointed with this turn of events.

Yugoslavia built fortifications along the Italian frontier and later along old Austrian, now German border but these fortifications lacked heavy artillery pieces to be effective. With Czechoslovakia and France gone, and UK under threat of invasion, the only neutral place left to buy artillery were United States of America. Historically, Yugoslavia offered its surplus of cement production to USA in exchange for guns but USA refused, failing to realize an opportunity to ensure neutrality of smaller nations in Europe.

We have received a large shipment of powerful German tanks, including their assault guns, armored, cars, howitzers, anti-tank guns, and other miscellaneous equipment. This will significantly increase the power of our armored formations. Historically, in July 1943, Germany finally agreed to modernize Bulgarian armored force (the 1st Armored Brigade) and supplied it with 46 PzKpfw IV, 10 PzKpfW III, 25 Stug III assault guns and 20 Sd Kfz 222 armored cars plus necessary howitzers, anti-tank guns etc. In the end tanks ended up fighting its builder instead of the Red Army since Bulgaria switched sides in 1944.

Germany has sent us 36 of their Pz Kpfw 35(t) tanks. This gift will significantly enhance our knowledge of tank technology. Many in our military feel that an alliance with Germany might be worth pursuing.

We have obtained permission from France to purchase a large quantity of their excellent R-35 tanks, to improve and upgrade our armor units. Our old Renault FT-17 and M.28 tankettes are considered obsolete, and many officers clamor for their replacement. Historically, in 1939, 54 R-35 tanks were bought from France, arriving to Yugoslavia in April 1940. They replaced the old Renault FT-17 and Renault-Kegresse M.28 (Char de Combat Muni du Propulseur Kegresse-Hinstin M.27/28) tanks in the 1st Armored vehicles battalion (1. Bataljon bornih kola).

We are in negotiations with the government of Italy for the purchase of the SIAI Savoia Marchatti SM-79-I heavy bomber designs. Our general staff recommends that we purchase the design to give us some long-range bombing capability. Our Foreign Minister reports that this sale could also improve the relations between our country and Italy. Historically, Yugoslavia purchased SIAI Savoia Marchetti SM-79-I designs from Italy in 1938.

The government of United Kingdom has provisionally approved a purchase of some Hawker Hurricane Mk. I fighter aircraft for our Air Force, as well as a purchase of the designs and a manufacturing license. These fighters have received favorable reviews by the RAF, and some of our officers believe they could significantly improve our short-range fighter defenses.

The Germans have sent us enough Bf-109 E-3 fighters, supplies, and spare parts to equip two entire new squadrons. Training has started to teach our pilots how to use these new machines. Historically, negotiations which began as early as January 1938 finally came to a conclusion in 5th April 1939, with the initial contract to supply Yugoslavia with 50 Bf-109 E-3 and 25 spare DB 601 A engines. This was followed by another contract for a further 50 Bf-109 E-3 in June 1939, in exchange for the iron, chrome and copper ore, which was of vital importance to German industry. Deliveries had begun in autumn of 1939 but only 73 airplanes were actually delivered and the lack of spare parts grounded many of those.

The Germans have sent us enough Bf-109 E-3 fighters, supplies, and spare parts to equip an entire new squadron. Training has started to teach our pilots how to use these new machines. Historically, negotiations which began as early as January 1938 finally came to a conclusion in 5th April 1939, with the initial contract to supply Yugoslavia with 50 Bf-109 E-3 and 25 spare DB 601 A engines. This was followed by another contract for a further 50 Bf-109 E-3 in June 1939, in exchange for the iron, chrome and copper ore, which was of vital importance to German industry. Deliveries had begun in autumn of 1939 but only 73 airplanes were actually delivered and the lack of spare parts grounded many of those.

Our military demands that we request this beautiful aircraft from Germans, even blackmailing them with canceling our regular ore shipments. While some are concerned that this could bring us closer to Germany, others are afraid of provoking the Germans with blackmail. Regardless, the Messerschmitt Bf-109 E-3 is certainly one of the most advanced designs in the world, and our Air Force would be very pleased to have some of those aircraft in its ranks.

We have purchased the designs and the license for the Dornier Do-17K tactical bomber aircraft from Germany. These new aircraft should boost our tactical bombing capability significantly. Historically, two 1000 hp Daimler-Benz DB 600 A engines were replaced with two 960 hp Gnome-Rhone 14N1/2 engines. Yugoslavia built Dornier Do-17K bomber aircraft at the State Aircraft Factory (Drzavna Fabrika Aviona) in three versions: Do-17 Kb-1 tactical bomber, and the Do-17 Ka-2 and Do-17 Ka-3 reconnaissance aircraft with secondary bombing and attack capability.

We are in a position to negotiate a purchase of a small number of Bristol Bleheim Mk I bomber aircraft from United Kingdom, our traditional allies. These bomber aircraft are needed to modernize our aging air squadrons, replacing the old Breguet 19 and Potez 25 in role of tactical bombers. We are also negotiating to purchase the license to build some more in our country, as well as designs themselves. Some officers, however, are against this purchase, calling it unnecessary. Historically, in 1936 Yugoslavia purchased 22 Bristol Blenheim Mk I tactical bombers from United Kingdom with a further 16 being built under license by Zmaj Factory at Zemun. They replaced the old Breguet 19 and Potez 25 biplanes in the tactical bomber role.

Historically, in 1936, Yugoslavia purchased a number of Hawker Fury Mk II airplanes from the UK. Some were also license-built by Zmaj at Zemun and Ikarus. They remained in service with 5th Fighter Wing until the April war and claimed three Bf-109s and one Bf-110 for the loss of eleven Furies in aerial dogfighting.

We are in a position to negotiate a purchase of a small number of Hawker Fury Mk II fighter aircraft from United Kingdom, our traditional allies. These fighter aircraft are needed to modernize our aging fighter squadrons, to enable us to compete with the new designs coming into service in other countries. We are also negotiating to purchase the license to built some more in our country, as well as designs themselves. Some officers, however, are against this purchase, calling it unnecessary.

NDH had seven governments during its existence. The fourth lasted from 1st April 1943, until 11th October 1943. Milan Budak was named Foreign Minister, while Andrija Artukovic became Minister of Security.

Following the capitulation of Italy, Germany has transferred control of former Italian possessions on the Adriatic coast to our government. All of Dalmatia is once again part of Independent State of Croatia. The people are rejoicing at this fortunate event.

Former Italian conquests in the Balkans have reverted to our control. Croatians, our staunch allies, are clamoring for the return of Dalmatia and Adriatic coast, their claimed provinces. Returning these lands will remove the burden of their occupation from our hands, and increase our influence with the Croatian government. What shall we do?

Italy has capitulated, and we are free from their domination. Poglavnik Ante Pavelic has proclaimed that we are free from Italian control, and that he will be taking personal control of the government and the country while Nikola Mandic will take over the post of the Prime Minister. We are currently hoping that Germany will take over former Italian territories in Dalmatia, so that we might commence negotiation on return of Dalmatia and the coast to Croatia.

Croatian national Parliament, Hrvatski Sabor, was reconstituted today. The representatives were formed from the still living representatives taken from the last Hrvatski Sabor in 1918, Croatian national MPs from the Yugoslav Parliament, and from distinguished political activists in the Croatian national movement. This moves Croatia a step closer to international recognition and respectability. Historically, the Hrvatski Sabor was reconstituted on 23rd February 1942, and had about 200 representatives. Even though its role in the governing of Independent State of Croatia was limited, it did serve to legitimize the country in the eyes of the Western democracies.

The newly-made oil wells in Croatia are now producing up to their full production capacity. It appears as if the sceptics were wrong and the oil reserves in this part of Croatia are in fact significant. Historically, oil produced in Medjimurje and other parts of continental Croatia was a significant source of oil for the German war machine in the later parts of the war.

The newly-made oil wells in Croatia are now producing up to their full production capacity. It appears as if the sceptics were wrong and the oil reserves in this part of Croatia are in fact significant. Historically, oil produced in Medjimurje and other parts of continental Croatia was a significant source of oil for the German war machine in the later parts of the war.

The newly-made oil wells in Croatia are now producing up to their full production capacity. It appears as if the sceptics were wrong and the oil reserves in this part of Croatia are in fact significant. Historically, oil produced in Medjimurje and other parts of continental Croatia was a significant source of oil for the German war machine in the later parts of the war.

The newly-made oil wells in Croatia are starting to gear up to their full production capacity. It appears as if the sceptics were wrong and the oil reserves in this part of Croatia are in fact significant. Next year's production should be even better. Historically, oil produced in Medjimurje and other parts of continental Croatia was a significant source of oil for the German war machine in the later parts of the war.

The newly-made oil wells in Croatia have started producing some oil, but our experts now state that additional resources are needed to complete the production facilities and to finish the geological surveys. Oil production figures so far do not support these additional requests for material. However, there are still some hopes that a major oil deposit will be found and production increased by a large factor.

We have an opportunity to explore alternative sources of oil, a crucial resource for our industry. Some small oil wells have already been found in the Medjimurje area near Croatian capital, Zagreb. It is possible that these wells are merely the tip of the iceberg and that further exploration for oil will reveal large reserves. This move would, however, entail investing considerable effort in upgrading the province infrastructure and creating new oil drilling platforms. What shall we do?
NDH had seven governments during its existence. The third lasted from 10th October 1943, until 1st April 1943. Vilko Begic was put in charge of armaments industry.

Croatians refused to send volunteers for our campaign against the Soviets, and they are now trying to make up for their cowardice by additional ore shipments. They seem only willing to support our struggle from afar, without shedding blood in the process. We shall see...

Since we didn't send any troops, we need to show our good faith to Germany in another way. Germans have requested additional shipments of our iron ore, and we are pleased to comply. Our government hopes that this will clear any bad will between us and the Germans.

We have an opportunity to show off the courage of our troops to Germany. We can send a number of volunteers to join a German Army division in Germany, to be used against the Bolsheviks on the Eastern Front. What should we do? Historically, in 1942, a group of 'volunteers' was sent to Germany where 369th Infantry Regiment was formed and added to 100th Jager Division on the Eastern Front. The unit fought in several campaigns, before being destroyed at Stalingrad.
With the opening of a new front against the Soviet Union, many volunteers are joining our glorious armed forces in the fight against bolshevism.

Hungary sent its own negotiators to Rome to discuss the newly created Independent State of Croatia and its borders. Hungarians demanded and received Medjimurje and Baranja areas, small provinces on the north-western and north-eastern tips of Croatia, respectively.

We have a chance to destroy the remnants of old Yugoslav apologists and their hired help. For decades they cooperated with Belgrade to keep us down. We can finally strike back. Historically, Croatian Peasant's Party (HSS) represented Croatian interests in Kingdom of Yugoslavia. It's platform was based on cooperation and coexistence with Serbs in a federal state. Ustashe leaders were at best contemptuous of HSS and wanted to be rid of it's politicians and supporters. To cement their hold on the newly created Croatian state, they banned HSS on 11th June 1941, and seized the assets of their members.

Ustashe terrorists have received assistance from a foreign government, both in money and training. This raises a possibility of further terrorist strikes against our country in the future. Historically, Italy, Hungary, and Bulgaria assisted the Ustashe, while Italy and Hungary provided for their training camps in late 1930s.
Having managed to assure Soviet leadership of our sincerity, we have been granted independence once again. We shall now fight alongside our Russian comrades as allies and equals.

After the disastrous performance of Croatian army in late 1942 and early 1943, during anti-partisan offensives, Germany has sent us equipment and advisors necessary to reorganize our infantry divisions into more mobile brigade formations better suited for mountain warfare, which the partisans excel in.

Soviet leadership has agreed to an alliance with us. We are making final arrangements for a cease fire with the Red Army and a peace agreement with the Allies has been arranged. Our troops are retreating from all our occupied territories, and we have promised to return to our pre-war borders. We can only hope that Soviets will choose to keep us as allies instead of purging non-communists from the country.

After the disastrous performance of Croatian army in late 1942 and early 1943, during anti-partisan offensives, many in our government feel that we should lend a hand to our incompetent Croatian allies. Our advisors suggest that Croatian forces be reorganized and given the equipment for mountain terrain, where most of the partisans are located. Also, the unwieldy Croatian infantry divisions should be disbanded and reorganized into more mobile mountain brigades. Shall we assist our Croatian allies?

The Red Army is here! Our position has grown increasingly untenable. Our strategists do not expect our army to be able to repulse the Soviet onslaught. Germans are either unwilling or unable to assist us. As grave as our situation is, there is still hope. A part of our leadership believes Soviet Union might be open to peace negotiations, provided we offer to switch sides. What shall we do? Historically, with Soviet troops arriving at its borders on 9th September 1944, Bulgaria decided to change sides and join the winning team.

During recent fighting with Greece, German troops seized the province of Thessaloniki. We have long staked our claim on the province and its port, a significant transport and naval center. Germans have shown reluctance to administer the area directly, and have handed over control to our troops. In return, we have established access rights for their troops and their ships.

Slavko Kvaternik was an Austrian-Hungarian colonel in WW I. He declared the formation of Independent State of Croatia on 10th April 1941. However, at the moment, he is becoming somewhat of a liability because of his public arguments with the leadership of the Ustasha movement. What shall we do with him? Historically, Slavko Kvaternik formally withdrew from his political and military positions on 4th January 1943, due to a conflict with Poglavnik Ante Pavelic. He then retired to Austria. Later, he was forced to emigrate to Slovakia together with his son Eugen Dido Kvaternik because of problems with the Ustasha movement. He was arrested post-war and extradited to Yugoslavia where he was sentenced and shot in 1947.

Vladimir Laxa was second in command of the ground forces of the NDH in April 1941. He was also the commander of all our ground forces since June 1941. In October 1941, he was transferred to the High Command of the Croatian Armed Forces. Laxa has fallen out of favor with our leadership, and is considered somewhat of a loose cannon. What shall we do with him? Historically, he remained serving with the High Command of Croatian Armed Forces till August 1942, when he was removed by order of Marshall Slavko Kvaternik and forcibly retired.

In 1941, Jure Francetic, together with Rafael Boban, organized the 1st Ustasha Regiment, the infamous Black Legion, and became its first commander. Historically, as colonel (highest active Ustasha rank) he was sent on 22th December 1942, to take command of Lika operational area. During flight his aircraft had engine failure and was forced to land near village Mocilo near Slunja - area held by partisans. He died presumably on 27th December 1942, from wounds he received during landing and capturing. He was posthumously promoted to Ustasha krilnik (highest Ustasha rank, also held by Slavko Kvaternik).

Mihajlo Lukic was the commander of the Osijek Divisional Area, later Inspector-General of the Infantry. He was also the Liaison officer to the Italian II Corpo d'Armata for a short period of time. In December 1941, he was named the commander of the 3rd Sarajevo Military Area, but remained in this position for a very short period of time. Lukic is very outspoken with his opposition to sending volunteers to Germany for the Eastern Front. His public opposition is becoming an embarrassment for the government. What shall we do with him? Historically, Lukic was forcibly retired in February 1942, due to his boisterous resistance to the government allowing Croatians to volunteer for German units on the Eastern Front.

On 14th September 1941, the most successful sabotage to date was carried out by communist resistance. Organized by Rade Koncar and Vojo Kovacevic and carried out by Slavko Markon, Joze Culjat, Blaz Mesaric, Nada Holjevac and Vilim Galjer, a large bomb was placed at the Zagreb post office, destroying the central telephone exchange and cutting many phone lines. C-in-C of Wehrmacht, South-East sector, reported to Berlin that the only phone line from Zagreb to Berlin had to be directed across Budapest.

On 4th August 1941, Slavko Komar, together with six other comrades, attacked an Ustashe student company with bombs near the Botanic garden, leaving 28 wounded Ustashe. This attack demonstrated that the resistance against the rule of Ustashe was significant.

In early July 1941, Milan and Dragica Dvorscak burned 60,000 meters of parachute silk at Buzan street in the capital of Zagreb. Not only did this act of sabotage destroy a significant quantity of important war material, but the act itself encouraged resistance against the regime.
NDH had seven governments, the second of which was in power from 1st July 1941 to 10th October 1942. It had 13 ministers.

Negotiations in Rome with the representatives of the newly-formed Independent State of Croatia have gone well. Croatia has agreed to secede Dalmatia to us, fulfilling our territorial demands, while also agreeing to allow Duke Sapoleto to become King of Croatia, Tomislav II. We are now effectively in control of Croatia, while having also resolved a festering territorial problem. Hungary was also involved, receiving Medjimurje and Baranja from Croatia.

Once created, the biggest problem Croatia faced was determining its border with Italy, who wanted another Italian Greater Albania. Negotiations were opened in Rome to determine the fate of NDH and to establish territorial borders between Croatia and Italy. Hungary is also involved as it has a claim on the north-western tip of Croatian territory. Historically, NDH kept some minimal independence by becoming an Italian puppet with Duke of Sapoleto becoming King of Croatia, Tomislav II. Croatia also surrendered Dalmatia to Italy, fulfilling Italian territorial demands, and promised not to create a navy of any kind. Hungarians received Medjimurje and Baranja, which they asked for.

NDH had seven governments during its existence. The first one lasted from the arrival of Poglavnik Ante Pavelic to Zagreb on 15th April 1941, until 1st July 1941. Foreign Minister was Pavelic himself in the beginning, later to be replaced with Mladen Lorkovic.

Croats welcomed their glorious leader Poglavnik Ante Pavelic, who returned from exile today. Pavelic has led the Ustashe organization for many years now, and is considered the most popular of Croatian nationalist leaders. He has promised Croatia progress and prosperity in the foreseeable future under his government.

On the same day NDH was established, brother of Slavko Kvaternik attempted to take over rule in Crikvenica. The commander of Northern Costal Defense Sector of Yugoslav Navy, captain Mirko Pleiweiss, reacted quickly and with a small naval detachment arrested the conspirators. Few minutes later a brief firefight took place leaving most conspirators dead (including Petar Kvaternik) and wounding several Yugoslav Navy sailors. Captain Mirko Pleiweiss then successfully completed the evacuation or sinking of ships of the Yugoslav Navy from Northern Sector preventing their capture by Italian forces.

In August 1941, the situation in Serbia become critical, as after German attack on Soviet Union a communist lead uprising put most of the countryside ablaze. Germans quickly established a much stronger government under former Yugoslav army minister general Milan Nedic and provided armament for expansion of existing police units.

Constant rise in partisan activities and capitulation of Italy are raising concern in our government that a large army is needed to combat the enemy. However, the people are resentful of constant fighting, and forcing another mobilization will have a negative impact on morale. What shall we do?

Germany has refused to acknowledge our protestations regarding the 'Pact of Steel' and our recent government change. Enraged by recent events, Germans have decided to declare war upon us, creating panic in our government and population. Our longtime allies, United Kingdom and France, have offered us assistance in combating the German menace. Any assistance would be greatly welcomed, as our General Staff claims we cannot hold against Germany alone.

Governments of France and Italy have sent us about 250 of known Ustashe terrorists and sympathizers, who were hiding out in Western Europe. Finally we have a chance to destroy the leadership of the movement and prevent a serious political crisis before it develops. The Prime Minister believes that a series of public trials and incarcerations of those criminals will dishearten other potential recruits and disrupt their terrorist network.

The accursed Croatian Ustashe nationalists have struck again, planting bombs, assassinating public figures, and fomenting armed rebellion against the government. Their campaign has diverted resources toward repairing the damage, and has caused much political chaos. Concern has been raised abroad about our stability.

The accursed Croatian Ustashe nationalists have struck again, planting bombs, assassinating public figures, and fomenting armed rebellion against the government. Their campaign has diverted resources toward repairing the damage, and has caused much political chaos. Concern has been raised abroad about our stability.

The accursed Croatian Ustashe nationalists have struck again, planting bombs, assassinating public figures, and fomenting armed rebellion against the government. Their campaign has diverted resources toward repairing the damage, and has caused much political chaos. Concern has been raised abroad about our stability.

The accursed Croatian Ustashe nationalists have struck again, planting bombs, assassinating public figures, and fomenting armed rebellion against the government. Their campaign has diverted resources toward repairing the damage, and has caused much political chaos. Concern has been raised abroad about our stability.

The accursed Croatian Ustashe nationalists have struck again, planting bombs, assassinating public figures, and fomenting armed rebellion against the government. Their campaign has diverted resources toward repairing the damage, and has caused much political chaos. Concern has been raised abroad about our stability.

The accursed Croatian Ustashe nationalists have struck again, planting bombs, assassinating public figures, and fomenting armed rebellion against the government. Their campaign has diverted resources toward repairing the damage, and has caused much political chaos. Concern has been raised abroad about our stability.

The accursed Croatian Ustashe nationalists have struck again, planting bombs, assassinating public figures, and fomenting armed rebellion against the government. Their campaign has diverted resources toward repairing the damage, and has caused much political chaos. Concern has been raised abroad about our stability.

An agreement on matters of government policy and cooperation was reached today between representatives of the Peasant Democratic Coalition, a Serbian government coalition, and Serbian United Opposition, the opposition party. The agreement hopes to create a unified government, confirm the principles of centralized development, unitary state, and sovereignty of Karadjordjevic royal dynasty, and guarantee political and civil liberties.

We've signed a non-aggression pact with Italy. This treaty also involves a political and an economic agreement. We have undertaken to respect our common frontiers on land and on the Adriatic Sea. This diplomatic coup has shown to other nations that we are capable of resolving our differences peacefully. Historically, Count Gian Galeazzo Ciano of Italy and Premier Milan Stojadinovic of Yugoslavia signed the pact on 26th March 1937, in Belgrade.

With the failure to reach an agreement and solve the Croatian question, riots have broken out in cities of the Banovina Hrvatska, a proposed semi-independent Croatian administrative entity within Yugoslavia. Angry citizens and supporters of Vlatko Macek and his Croatian Peasants Party are demonstrating en masse in Zagreb, Osijek, Split, Rijeka, and other cities. Croats are refusing to enlist in the military, causing a shortage of new recruits.

The political crisis has finally been resolved today through the signing of the Cvetkovic-Macek Accords, which provide for the creation of the semi-independent Banovina Hrvatska on Croatian national territory. This new division of government will have autonomous powers over agriculture, commerce and industry, social and health policy, education, and internal security over its territory. Ivan Subasic is to head the new government of Banovina Hrvatska. Both sides hailed the agreement as the beginning of a new era in inter-ethnical relations in Yugoslavia. Historically, the Accords merely delayed the onset of violent ethnic conflict, which erupted during WWII.

Vlatko Macek has been selected by the Croatian Peasants Party, and the newly assembled Croatian Parliament, to negotiate with the Cvetkovic government about the Croatian status in Yugoslavia. Cvetkovic government has declared that its intention is to seek agreement with the Croatians about full equality in state and government affairs.

Alarmed by the increasing turmoil in the country and its political crisis, Regent Pavle Karadjordjevic is considering intervening and removing Milan Stojadinovic and his cabinet. Dragisa Cvetkovic, Regent's confidant and trusted follower, will be named as the new Prime Minister, and he will select his new cabinet, should we decide to remove Stojadinovic. Historically, Regent Pavle removed Stojadinovic and replaced him with Cvetkovic, whom he believed capable of salvaging the public trust in the government.

All the newly elected Croatian deputies to the Yugoslav parliament demanded in a resolution that the great powers intervene in Yugoslavia to assure the Croats 'liberty of choice and destiny'. Even though the resolution did not pass as the majority government deputies did not support it, it generated a lot of publicity both home and abroad.

Flinging accusations of electoral fraud, and demanding the democratic right to self-government, parliamentary deputies of Croatian Peasants Party refuse to take part in the parliament, creating a government crisis. Public pressure is mounting that something be done.

The government has finally called for a general election, and the main contenders are the current governmental coalition, Yugoslav Radical Community, headed by Milan Stojadinovic, and the opposition coalition, United Opposition, centered around Croatian Peasant's Party headed by Vlatko Macek. The mood in the nation is mixed, without any clear direction. Historically, in a very close election, radicals got 54 percent, United Opposition won 44 percent, and Stojadinovic government remained in power.

The government has deemed the current Chief of Staff to be insufficient to deal with the war effort. Therefore, they have selected General Danilo Kalafatovic to be new Chief of Staff and coordinate the army efforts. We hope that General Kalafatovic will lead the army ably and courageously.

Following our unconditional surrender, German government has decided to annex our country directly to the Third Reich. We have no choice but to comply. This is our last official act as the government of Yugoslavia.

Soviet Union has signed a Treaty of Friendship and Non-aggression with us. This will help allay fears created in our public by Germany's belligerent actions. However, even though we had asked for a clause allowing for military assistance in case of an attack, Soviet Union has refrained from such a treaty at this time. We hope to further improve our relations toward a full military alliance in the future.
Germany has acknowledged the power of Serbian people and contribution they can give in the fight against bolshevism. We are now free to join in their fight.

Following our unconditional surrender, German government has decided to create two new states out of our remaining territories: Independent State of Croatia, and Serbia. We have no choice but to comply. This is our last official act as the government of Yugoslavia.

The civil war in Yugoslavia, started over a government crisis about signing of the 'Pact of Steel', is over. Yugoslav loyalists have finally surrendered, and our continued independence is assured. It is now time to take our rightful place in world affairs.

Ravaged by a brutal war, dismembered by German attack, and disillusioned by Allied support (or lack thereof), Yugoslavia capitulated. Germany dictated the peace terms, being the most powerful among the belligerents. Historically, seeing an opportunity to demonstrate the power of the Third Reich, and reward its allies and sympathizers, Germany decided to divide Yugoslavia among its neighbors. Central parts of the country were given to Croatia, a staunch German ally. The Dalmatian coast was handed over to Italians, while the extreme south of the country was awarded to Bulgarians. Hungarians received Vojvodina, a small northern province, while the remainder of the country was occupied by Germans themselves. Germany also annexed Slovenia directly, while deciding to create a puppet state out of the remains of Serbia.

The Serbian-led government majority has decided to defy Regent Pavle and enter into a state of open rebellion against him and his decision to sign the 'Pact of Steel'. Using a moment of weakness in the kingdom, Ustashe leader Slavko Kvaternik has used the moment to proclaim the Independent State of Croatia (Nezavisna Drzava Hrvatska). Croatian people are elated, as they feel independence at last, after centuries under foreign rule. Sabotages and clashes prior and after the proclamation have destabilized the Yugoslav government and the army. Some of the Army units have even decided to join with us. Numerous volunteers are flocking to the ranks of Domobrani, our newly-established defense force. The upcoming conflict with Yugoslav loyalists has inspired our masses. Our government is also negotiating with Germany, in order to ask for their aid against the Yugoslav loyalists, who dared defy the Third Reich.

Emboldened by massive demonstrations in the capital against our entry into Axis, various rebel factions have started an armed insurrection against the lawful government. The Croatian nationalist faction supports our alliance with the Germans, and has formed the Independent State of Croatia. Serbian nationalists and the majority of the armed forces have taken over the capital and are preparing to retake the rest of the country, hopefully assisted by the Allies. Chaos and strife are spreading around the country as brothers take arms against brothers, and neighbors fight with neighbors. The grand experiment called Yugoslavia, the land of the South Slavs, has ended in strife and violence.

While massive demonstrations against our entry into the Axis have rocked the government, two Air Force generals, Borivoje Mirkovic and Dusan Simovic, have attempted to coup the current government. Fortunately, forces loyal to the government have prevented their coup attempt and placed the conspirators under arrest, while the gendarmerie has quelled the protests in streets.

Massive demonstrations against our entry into the Axis, led by a wide coalition of opposition parties, have shaken the government. Hundreds of thousands of protesters have taken to the streets, chanting 'Better War Then Pact', 'Rather Grave Than Slave', and 'Out With The Government'. With the help of British diplomats, generals of the air force Borivoje Mirkovic and Dusan Simovic have accomplished a coup d'Ètat against the current government. Teenage King Petar II has been named head of state, while general Simovic has named himself Prime Minister. The people are rejoicing on the streets, while the German ambassador has been spit on and was seen leaving Belgrade. The new government will attempt to place the Germans with trade concessions and further negotiations about military access. Yugoslavia, a country until then poorly governed, had shouted its heroic, but temporary, defiance at the most powerful conqueror of the modern era.

The government of Yugoslavia stands on the brink of disaster. The recently signed entry into the Tripartite Pact is opposed by the majority of the population. Many within the ruling circles question the wisdom in signing on with the Germans. The news of this event will reach the population within days: their response could prove critical to the future of the Kingdom.

While massive demonstrations against our signature of the 'Pact of Steel' have rocked the government, two Air Force generals, Borivoje Mirkovic and Dusan Simovic, have attempted to coup the current government. Fortunately, forces loyal to the government have prevented their coup attempt and placed the conspirators under arrest, while the gendarmerie has quelled the protests in streets.

Massive demonstrations against our signature of the 'Pact of Steel', led by a wide coalition of opposition parties, have shaken the government. Hundreds of thousands of protesters have taken to the streets, chanting 'Better War Then Pact', 'Rather Grave Than Slave', and 'Out With The Government'. With the help of British diplomats, generals of the air force Borivoje Mirkovic and Dusan Simovic have accomplished a coup d'Ètat against the current government. Teenage King Petar II has been named head of state, while general Simovic has named himself Prime Minister. The people are rejoicing on the streets, while the German ambassador has been spit on and was seen leaving Belgrade. The new government will attempt to placate the Germans with trade concessions and further negotiations about military access. Yugoslavia, a country until then poorly governed, had shouted its heroic, but temporary, defiance at the most powerful conqueror of the modern era.

The government of Yugoslavia stands on the brink of disaster. The recently signed entry into the 'Pact of Steel' is opposed by the majority of the population. Many within the ruling circles question the wisdom in signing on with the Germans. The news of this event will reach the population within days: their response could prove critical to the future of the Kingdom.

We have been offered entry into the Tripartite Pact, either through alliance with Germany, or through allowing their military safe passage over our soil ('Pact of Steel'). Our Minister of Foreign Affairs reports that the Germans are very keen on our signature of the treaty. Signing the treaty, in either version, will remove the threat of invasion, for which we are not ready. However, we risk alienating our population and our traditional ally, England. On the other hand, should we refuse, we face the imminent threat of an attack from Germany and her allies.

Bulgaria, our eastern neighbor, has allied with Germany. Given their unreasonable claims on the south of our country, and their belligerent behavior during the last round of Balkan wars, we suspect they have pretensions on our soil. Our intelligence has determined that German Army units have been spotted moving through Bulgaria. Recent world events are giving rise to fears that perhaps an attack on our country from several directions is being prepared. The government is preparing contingency plans and readying supply stockpiles.

We have signed a treaty of peace and perpetual friendship with Hungary, hoping to discourage their government from attacking our country. Even though the treaty promises peace and good relations, tensions still remain given Hungary's ties to Germany.

Fighting in Greece has led us to believe that some sort of relief is necessary, or else the Greeks might collapse. Our general staff has proposed that we ask France to send an expeditionary force to Thessaloniki, as they did in the Great War, to assist the Greeks and take the pressure off our southern flank. The Foreign Ministry, however, is unsure that such a move is wise at this time, due to the situation on the western front.

The great Zenica Steelworks have finally been completed and are ready for production. Historically, the Steelworks opened in mid-1937, and were the largest such plant in Eastern Europe at the time. The plant helped Yugoslav steel export industry, made possible the production of modern armament, and employed thousands of workers.

In March 1936, Krupp's concern received contract to turn Zenica iron foundry into a modern steel mill capable of armament production using advanced metallurgical technology. The granting of the contract was favored by portions of the military, and led to closer connections between Yugoslavia and Germany. The completed Zenica Steelworks became one of the largest steel mills in Eastern Europe.

In only nine months, shipping tycoon Bozo Banac built an aluminum factory in Lozovac, which became the first producer of aluminum in this part of Europe. The factory was later confiscated by Italians after their occupation of Dalmatia. After capitulation of Italy the factory was plundered and anything of value was taken to Italy. It was rebuilt in 1945, and confiscated again in 1946, by the new Yugoslav communist government. The new factory was recently returned to the only heir, Marko Ivanovic, whose family also owned a large part of Yugoslav oil industry.

We have an opportunity to export some of our stockpile of oil, bauxite, chrome and copper ore to Germany, who needs it. If we can spare the resources, the sales would boost our treasury considerably, allowing us to increase government salaries and reduce dissent. On the other hand, our industrial sector might need the materials in the near future for its own production.

We have an opportunity to export some of our stockpile of oil, bauxite, chrome and copper ore to Germany, who needs it. If we can spare the resources, the sales would boost our treasury considerably, allowing us to increase government salaries and reduce dissent. On the other hand, our industrial sector might need the materials in the near future for its own production.

We have an opportunity to export some of our stockpile of oil, bauxite, chrome and copper ore to Germany, who needs it. If we can spare the resources, the sales would boost our treasury considerably, allowing us to increase government salaries and reduce dissent. On the other hand, our industrial sector might need the materials in the near future for its own production.

If we can spare the resources, the sales would boost our treasury considerably, allowing us to increase government salaries and reduce dissent. On the other hand, our industrial sector might need the materials in the near future for its own production.
