If we can spare the resources, the sales would boost our treasury considerably, allowing us to increase government salaries and reduce dissent. On the other hand, our industrial sector might need the materials in the near future for its own production.

We have an opportunity to export some of our stockpile of oil, bauxite, chrome and copper ore to Germany, who needs it. If we can spare the resources, the sales would boost our treasury considerably, allowing us to increase government salaries and reduce dissent. On the other hand, our industrial sector might need the materials in the near future for its own production.

Germans have transferred control over the area surrounding Nis to us. Our military is sending troops for occupation duties, to pacify the notoriously unstable region. Many in Bulgaria are pleased to see our proper territories restored, lost since the Balkan Wars at the beginning of the century.

We have an opportunity to export some of our stockpile of oil, bauxite, chrome and copper ore to Germany, who needs it. If we can spare the resources, the sales would boost our treasury considerably, allowing us to increase government salaries and reduce dissent. On the other hand, our industrial sector might need the materials in the near future for its own production.

Partisan activity and resulting unrest in central Serbia have proved a continued drain on German manpower. With the war with Soviet Union, Germans feel they need the occupation forces stationed there on the front. Therefore they have transferred control of central Serbia, covering the Valjevo, Kraljevo, and Novi Pazar areas, to their Bulgarian allies. We have little choice but to accept.

Our Foreign Ministry has hammered out an export deal for various foodstuffs with the government of Germany. We were able to offer low prices and beat the competition in terms of delivery. The added income should keep the peasants happy.

Germans have transferred control over the area surrounding Nis to us. Our military is sending troops for occupation duties, to pacify the notoriously unstable region. Many in Bulgaria are pleased to see our proper territories restored, lost since the Balkan Wars at the beginning of the century.

Our Foreign Ministry has hammered out an export deal for various foodstuffs with the government of Germany. We were able to offer low prices and beat the competition in terms of delivery. The added income should keep the peasants happy.

Unrest in southern Serbia has proved a continued drain on German manpower. With the war with Soviet Union, Germans feel they need the occupation forces stationed there on the front. Therefore they have transferred control of southern Serbia, particularly the area around Nis, to their Bulgarian allies. Bulgarians have long claimed those areas due to a small Bulgar minority living there. We have little choice but to accept.

Our Foreign Ministry has hammered out an export deal for various foodstuffs with the government of Germany. We were able to offer low prices and beat the competition in terms of delivery. The added income should keep the peasants happy.

Our Foreign Ministry has completed a deal to import various foodstuffs from Yugoslavia at very good prices. The received food is of fair to good quality, and will definitely further our stockpile of various war materials. Hopefully we shall be able to secure a similar agreement next year.

Our Foreign Ministry has hammered out an export deal for various foodstuffs with the government of Germany. We were able to offer low prices and beat the competition in terms of delivery. The added income should keep the peasants happy.

Faced with the fall of the capital and most of mainland, Greek government has transferred control of the island of Crete to us. In return, we have promised to hold their government-in-exile and assist them in liberating their country when the tides of war change in our favor.

Our Foreign Ministry has hammered out an export deal for various foodstuffs with the government of Germany. We were able to offer low prices and beat the competition in terms of delivery. The added income should keep the peasants happy.

Athinai has fallen into enemy hands, and the enemy is overrunning our defenses. We are preparing for our last stand at Crete, where the government has taken refuge. However, the government of Britain is offering to take over Crete as their territory and to shelter a government-in-exile. Additionally, they are offering to garrison Crete with their units and bolster its defenses. Should we accept, we have been given guarantees that when the war shifts back to our side, that Greece will be liberated from its occupiers. Alternatively, we can attempt to hold Crete against all opposition on our own. What shall we do? Historically, Greece reluctantly handed Crete over to Britain when it became obvious that mainland had fallen and that the country was as well as gone, in late April 1940. British rule over Crete was short-lived, however, because a daring aerial invasion of the island by Luftwaffe paratroopers expelled the British expeditionary force after two weeks of bitter fighting.

Our Foreign Ministry has hammered out an export deal for various foodstuffs with the government of Germany. We were able to offer low prices and beat the competition in terms of delivery. The added income should keep the peasants happy.

We have received an influx of foreign investment, particularly in the northern part of the country. New factories are being built to utilize our abundant natural resources. The resulting employment and flow of money to treasury should stabilize the country a little. Historically, Yugoslavia was an under-developed country prior to WWII, and Western European nations invested heavily in its industries and infrastructure.

The banned Communist Party activists have been disseminating anti-government literature, organizing committees, and weakening the regime. They are also infiltrating student, worker, and women's organizations, making them very hard to root out. Their constant propaganda is mobilizing the masses against the government.

After Milan Gorkic, the previous leader of the Communist Party in Yugoslavia, is recalled to Moscow in June, the Communists choose Josip Broz, called Tito, to take over the leadership of the party. This young man has already been noted as valuable member of the Communist Party and a stout revolutionary.
We must call up the reserves to defend our country.

In February 1941, General Metaxas, dictator of Greece suffered a massive heart attack and died. The strains of leading the country since 1936, and the struggle against first the Italians, and now the Germans took its toll on the venerable leader, and he passed away.
The United Kingdom has sent us the promised aid to fight the Italians.

Upon the commencement of hostilities with Italy, General Metaxas made overtures to London for aid in his fight.  Building on the stated declaration of a guarantee of Greek independence, Metaxas argued his case forcefully.  Britain, and her Commonwealth allies, sent arms, munitions, and additional forces to Greece.  Though in a losing cause, Britain increased her standing in Greece by these actions.

When the Italian leader Benito Mussolini issued his ultimatum to the Greek government in October 1940, the response was swift and clear.  General Metaxas, the Greek dictator, issued a one word reply to the Italian demands: OXI!  Oxi, or Ochi, simply means no.  Following that reply, the Italians launched an invasion of Greece on 28th October 1940, from their holdings in Albania, and met stiff resistance.

After banning all political parties except his Monarchist Party, General Metaxas pursued other means of stifling opposition to his rule.  In the wake of the 1936 general strike, and the farmer's agitation, Metaxas made further opposition to his rule effectively illegal.  As a consequence, almost all of the active political opponents of Metaxas were exiled, with many fleeing to Cyprus, Crete, Lebanon, France, and Britain.

In the aftermath of the labor unrest the previous year, and in an attempt to boost his own support, General Metaxas initiated a plan to ease the burden on Greek farmers.  The plan called for price raises for agricultural products, and the government in Athens assuming most of the farmer's monetary debts.  Metaxas did all this, yet failed to win any popular support, but some dissent was alleviated by his measures.

With the unrest of the May strike, and continued challenges to his authority, General Metaxas forced through legislation banning all political parties in Greece.  The legislation was a mere rubber stamp on his fiat which had the effect of forcing all opposition parties underground.  Only Metaxas' Monarchist party remained legal.

Following the electoral problems in April, the various unions and trade guilds staged a general strike beginning in May 1936.  General Metaxas, the Prime Minister, instituted a state of emergency, and cracked down on the strikers, and the unions.  He used the state of emergency to further enhance his own powers, becoming a more identifiable dictator.

In March 1936, the Greek elections produced a split result, with Panagis Tsaldaris and Themistoklis Sophoulis locked in a heated battle.  As neither candidate was acceptable to the King, Ionnes Metaxas was appointed Prime Minister on 4th April 1936.  While not particularly popular, Metaxas held the confidence of the King, and soon made moves to establish himself as the virtual dictator of Greece.
The Turkish government has sent us a proposal for a non-aggression pact.
The King requests that we mobilize our nation to defend our borders.
We must call up the reserves to defend our country from hostile aggressors.
With the fall of Yugoslavia, Italy is now in possession of several disputed territories and has given us the province of Skopje.
With the fall of Yugoslavia, Italy is now in possession of several disputed territories and has given us the province of Pristina.
In light of our struggle against the Axis invasion the USSR has sent us 134 fighter planes.

Marxist-oriented Muslim radicals are rapidly gaining popular support against the feudal rule of King Zog I.  The insurrection is strong with backing from both disloyal elements of the Army and foreign powers.  King Zog is fleeing into exile and a new government is being formed.

Germans have invited us to a state visit to their country. This is an opportunity to gain assurances from German government about their intentions in the Balkans, especially concerning our country. What shall we do? Historically, Prince Paul, the Regent of Yugoslavia, paid a state visit to Berlin where Chancellor Adolf Hitler guaranteed the inviolability of Yugoslavia's borders in a state toast. Such guarantees were historically proven false less then two years later when Wehrmacht invaded and conquered Yugoslavia, in a campaign lasting less then two weeks.
Groups of liberal reformers and Marxist-oriented Muslim radicals are rising up against the feudal rule of King Zog I.  The insurrection seems poorly planned and is unlikely to pose any real threat.

The British and French governments extended their mutual assistance pacts to the Greek and Romanian governments in an attempt to bolster a united front against Germany and Italy in the Balkans. The Italian annexation of Albania placed Greece in direct danger of invasion, while the Germans placed pressure on the Romanians.

With the signing of the Greco-Bulgarian agreement, the British and French governments provided a $10 million loan to the Bulgarian government to pay for the kingdom's rearmament program. The British and French sought to incorporate the Bulgarians in the Balkan Entente. The Bulgarian government, however, pushed more insistently for a revision of the World War I peace treaties, which led to tensions with Romania over the future of Dobrudja.

The Bulgarian and Greek governments (the latter acting on behalf of the Balkan Entente) signed an agreement recognizing Bulgaria's right to rearm. The agreement also abolished the demilitarized zones between the two states. By this time, the Bulgarian government had made significant headway in terms of remilitarizing, in violation of the World War I peace treaties. The Bulgarian government purchased most of their military equipment from Germany, but the Bulgarian regime did not support National Socialism.

The Bulgarian and Greek governments (the latter acting on behalf of the Balkan Entente) signed an agreement recognizing Bulgaria's right to rearm. The agreement also abolished the demilitarized zones between the two states. By this time, the Bulgarian government had made significant headway in terms of remilitarizing, in violation of the World War I peace treaties. The Bulgarian government purchased most of their military equipment from Germany, but the Bulgarian regime did not support National Socialism.
Political dissatisfaction led to a revolt on the island of Crete. The Greek government took immediate action to suppress the rebellion.
The Bulgarian government disbanded the National Socialist Party in Bulgaria in an attempt to control fascist elements in the kingdom.
The Greek and Turkish governments signed a Treaty of Friendship designed to promote security in the eastern Mediterranean.

The Bulgarian and Yugoslav governments have signed a Treaty of Friendship and Perpetual Peace which ends a long period of antagonism between the two kingdoms. This pact opened the door for the Bulgarians to establish closer relations with the other Balkan powers as well as resulting in greater sense of security in Yugoslavia.

The Bulgarian and Yugoslav governments have signed a Treaty of Friendship and Perpetual Peace which ends a long period of antagonism between the two kingdoms. This pact opened the door for the Bulgarians to establish closer relations with the other Balkan powers as well as resulting in greater sense of security in Yugoslavia.

Under the Versailles Treaty, major German rivers and canals came under international control. Chancellor Adolf Hitler has announced that the German government will resume control over the waterways in Germany. We have to respond to this violation of the Versailles Treaty.

The Germans have sent us a proposal promising industrial machinery if we sell them steel. In light of the significant decline in trade with Italy as the result of Yugoslavia's imposition of economic sanctions during the Ethiopian crisis we should seriously consider signing this agreement. Our people might not like it but our economy could really use the boost.
The Albanian and Italian governments have signed a new series of agreements on financial and trade relations, which provided the Italians with even greater control over Albania.
With the fall of Yugoslavia, Italy is now in possession of several disputed territories and has given us the province of Skopje.
Following the defeat of Czechoslovakia by Germany and Hungary, the agreement signed made prior to the war divides the captured areas between the two countries.
Representatives of the Austrian, Hungarian, and Italian governments reaffirmed the protocols between the three states to maintain the status quo in Danubian region.

To prevent the expansion of ideas regarding fascism and dictatorship, communists suggested an alliance between the communist, peasant, legitimist, conservative and Christian parties. However, communists were too weak, and the other parties couldn't agree with each other.
War has broken out between Germany and Czechoslovakia. The German ambassador has asked us to step up to our promises regarding the attack on Czechoslovakia.

The prime and the foreign minister traveled to Germany to discuss foreign policy affairs. The Hungarian Prime Minister and Foreign Minister understood that the Anschluss was inevitable, however they were opposed to the German ideas about Hungary attacking Slovakia. They wanted to revise the borders peacefully.

Several fascist organizations united to form the Hungarian National Socialist Party, under the leadership of Ferenc Sz·lasi. This new political party strongly supported the Hungarian regent, Admiral MiklÛs Horthy, and called for his candidacy to the throne. Admiral Horthy rejected these efforts.
The police confiscated the pamphlet of the Hungarian Social-Democratic Party containing the concepts of Hungarian social democracy.
The minister of interior directed that the antifascist participants of the Spanish Civil War be registered and constantly observed by the police.
In a speech to the Hungarian assembly, Prime Minister K·lm·n Dar·nyi announced that he rejects the idea of dictatorship.

Vienna Conference representatives of the Danubian Protocol States (Austria, Hungary, and Italy) met in Vienna to discuss European tensions. The conference marked the gradual consolidation of Italian power in the Danubian Basin.
The attempts made between the countries in the Danubian region to create a counterpart to the German interest have failed
The minister of the interior banned the Kasz·skeresztes P·rt (Hungarian National Socialist Party) led by Zolt·n BˆszˆrmÈnyi claiming it to be dangerous to the order and the public safety.

Italy, Austria and Hungary signed an anti-Nazi mutual defense treaty in Rome. At the time when Italy was losing its power in the region of Danube, the leaders of Hungary tried to make approaches to Germany. However, Germany and Hungary barely had common points in their foreign policy conceptions so Hungary decided to strengthen its bonds with Italy, despite of their increasing alienation. This pact was to prevent the Anschluss, although Gyula Gˆmbˆs thought it to be inevitable.
Gyula Gˆmbˆs died on 6th October 1936. On 12th a new government formed with K·lm·n Dar·nyi in charge. His objective was to counter Hungary's rightist deviation.

General Gustaw Orlicz Dreszer was one of the best Polish officers. Freedom fighter, member of the Polish Legions during WWI, he fought bravely against the Bolshevik menace in 1920. After the peace treaty he became inspector of all cavalry units in the Polish Army. Brilliant staff officer, he became the author of several defense plans. During the 1926 he became the C-i-C of all forces loyal to Pilsudski. As the commander of the Colonial League he was the main air force and navy proponent in Poland. He died in a plane crash over Gdansk Bay on 16th July 1936. His RWD-9 crashed into the sea after Orlicz-Dreszer wanted to greet his wife on her route home onboard 'M/S Pilsudski' ocean liner. His funeral in Gdynia became a huge patriotic manifestation.

We have managed to negotiate a purchase of the design and a manufacturing license for the Landsverk L-60B light tank from Sweden. This new design has many advantages over the old tanks, including excellent speed and handling, as well as a good armor design and high-quality optical sights. The new tank will be named Toldi I, after a XIV century Hungarian national hero. Large-scale production will be organized as soon as the new design is ready.
Italians have delivered the promised CV 35 tankettes and we can now form an armored unit using these tanks.

Our government has negotiated a purchase of a number of Italian CV 35 tankettes, enough to equip one armored unit. We have also agreed on the purchase of production license and technology transfer. Historically, in March 1938, Hungary purchased 104 CV 35 tankettes from Italy. A few tankettes were lost in a brief two-day border war with Slovakia in March 1940. These tankettes were soon to be surpassed by basic light tanks, and did not see much use.

In 1938 Hungary began production of Landsverk L-60B Swedish light tank under license. The tank was named after a famous Hungarian hero from the XIV century. Historically, the Toldi I tank was used in Operation Barbarossa, the German attack on Soviet Union. However, it's minimal main gun (20mm) proved inadequate against heavy armor of Soviet tanks. Toldi I ended up being used mostly in a scouting role due to its great speed and excellent suspension.

Leaders of the Croatian nationalist Ustashe movement have asked us for financial support in establishing training camps for their paramilitary forces. Giving them aid will strengthen them and their campaign will likely destabilize Yugoslavia and please parts of our public. On the other hand, the ensuing diplomatic mess will be costly to clear up, and ignoring these malcontents might give us some influence with the Yugoslav government. Historically, Italy, Hungary, and Bulgaria assisted the Ustashe, while Italy and Hungary provided for their training camps in late 1930s.

Ludomil Rayski was a chief of Polish Air Force since 1926. He was very popular, not only among his soldiers, but also among the society. He was an excellent pilot, but also a great organizer. With the limited funds he had at his disposal, Rayski managed to create a relatively modern air force with excellently trained crews. However, as the war was nearing the Polish Air Force needed modernization. This process encountered many problems. The main issues were lack of home-made aviation engines, German sabotage and lack of understanding of modern warfare among the politicians. Moreover, France and Great Britain were reluctant to fulfil the credits granted to Poland. In February 1939, Rayski resigned his post as a protest to constant quarrels about funds for the modernization.

Wincenty Witos was one of the most important politicians in the inter-bellum. As a member of Austro-Hungarian parliament he opted for a complete independence of Poland. After WWI he was a MP and Prime Minister and created Polish agrarian movement (Polish Peoples Party). Ousted by Pilsudskis coup d'Ètat, sentenced to 1.5 year of prison, he emigrated to Czechoslovakia. He returned to Poland in 1939, and lead the agrarian party until his death.

In the 1930s, the economical crisis touched all social groups, but the most impoverished were the farmers. Most governments after Pilsudski's coup d'Ètat either ignored peasant parties or did nothing to change the fate of the farmers. Polish agrarian movement had always been mostly democratic, but second half of the 1930s, saw increasing radicalization among peasant politicians and leaders. In August 1937, Wincenty Witos organized a huge peasant strike in central and southern Poland. For ten days, most of Polish farmers refused any food shipment in order to force Slawoj-Skladkowski's government to start democratization and let the exiled opposition leaders return to Poland. In certain areas a peaceful strike turned into battles with the police, in which almost 50 people were killed.

Roman Dmowski was one of the greatest and most controversial statesmen in Polish history. He represented Poland in Russian Duma. He was the main opponent of Pilsudski's plan of a big, multi-national country in the early days of polish independence. His idea was to create a small but nationally pure Poland that would assimilate all the minorities. After the WWI, Dmowski represented Poland at the Versailles conference and was the main ideologist of the national-democratic movement. Contrary to what most people think the two creators of Poland, Dmowski and Pilsudski, met personally only once - by accident on the street in Tokio.

Roman Dmowski was one of the greatest and most controversial statesmen in Polish history. He represented Poland in Russian Duma. He was the main opponent of Pilsudski's plan of a big, multi-national country in the early days of polish independence. His idea was to create a small but nationally pure Poland that would assimilate all the minorities. After the WWI, Dmowski represented Poland at the Versailles conference and was the main ideologist of the national-democratic movement. Contrary to what most people think the two creators of Poland, Dmowski and Pilsudski, met personally only once - by accident on the street in Tokio.

Wojciech Korfanty was one of the greatest Polish politicians before and after the First World War. He fought for Poland in Reichstag and Prussian Landtag. After WWI he became a civil commissar of Silesia and prevented third Silesian Uprising from spreading into a full-scale war. He was a member of several parliaments, one of the leaders of Christian Democrats and a man of great valor. It's a great loss to our country.

Sikorski's coalition government turned out to be a relatively good cabinet. It managed to bring some political stability and relative prosperity. It also managed to win several Ukrainian groups to the idea of a multi-national state by granting them more rights and preparing a plan of an Ukrainian canton in southeast Poland. Kwiatkowskis 6-year plan, although not as radical as it could be, finally diminished the unemployment and opened a new period in which the differences between industrialized western voivodships and the rural and backward eastern voivodships were to disappear. Last but not least, it ended antagonisms between two main factions in Polish politics created by Pilsudski's coup d'Ètat in 1926. However, the clouds were gathering in the west and war was not impossible anymore.

Slawoj-Skladkowski's government turned out to be one of the best cabinets the Republic had. The minorities at last gained some influence and the government managed to bring back some political stability. Kwiatkowski successfully ended the economical crisis, diminished the level of unemployment and started a chain of necessary reforms. Although the voting laws were not entirely democratic and parts of the opposition declared a boycott of 1938 elections, more than 67 percent of Poles took part in the voting. This gave the government necessary support, as the official government party (Alliance of National Unity - OZoN) gained 57 percent of seats in newly-elected Sejm. However, the clouds were gathering in the west and war was not impossible anymore.

In 1936 the crisis after Pilsudski's death was over. All three major factions inside of Sanacja movement agreed that a new government must be elected to fight against the communist agitation and growing unrest in the country. The most important problem was still the economical crisis after the 1929 Wall Street disaster.

The Polish government, exposed to German eastward expansion, sought closer relations with the Soviet Union by renewing the Soviet-Polish Non-Aggression Pact. The Polish government made efforts to build up a barrier of Baltic and Balkan states to help maintain the status quo in Eastern Europe.
Our only chance to gain back the territory that is rightfully ours is by the strength of our military.
Due to international instability we must call up the reserves and mobilize the nation.

In a speech in the Reichstag, Chancellor Adolf Hitler officially renounced the Anglo-German Naval Treaty of 1935, which had restricted the German navy to one-third the size of the Royal Navy, as well as the German-Polish Non-Aggression Pact of 1934, accusing the British and Polish governments of attempting to encircle Germany. Chancellor Hitler also renewed his demands on Poland regarding Posen and Danzig and offered bilateral non-aggression pacts to the Scandinavian and Baltic states. In response, the Polish government gave up its demand of a proposed guarantee from Russia and now supported British efforts to attract the Soviet government into a new peace front.
The Hungarian government announced that it had withdrawn from the League of Nations, a decision which reflected German influence on Hungary.

Colonel Adam Koc organized the Camp of National Unity, an all-embracing coalition of political organizations which supported the Polish government. The organization's goals included maintenance of the 1935 constitution, popular support for the army to protect the republic, anti-Communism, land reform for the peasants, and Polonization of minority groups. In response to this effort, workers and peasants formed the Workers, Peasants and Intellectual's Group, opposed to Koc's nationalist goals. Peasant strikes spread across the country and the government responded with bloodshed.

Following the peace terms from the first World War, the city of Danzig and the surrounding areas had been declared a free state protectorate under the League of Nations. As Hitler's power in Germany grew he started terror and propaganda campaigns in both Austria, Czechoslovakia, and Danzig in order to gain the support of the local German populations. The increasing pressure from the German minority in Danzig forces us to try and make an agreement with them to stop the violence in the streets and keep it from spreading into the rest of Poland. Such an agreement will greatly increase the influence of the nationalists in Danzig and diminish the power of the League of Nations in the region. This is what the nationalists want but we need the harbor of Danzig in order to keep our sea trade going.
With the fall of Yugoslavia, Italy is now in possession of several disputed territories and has given us the province of Novi Sad.
The Soviet government has announced that it will not renew the non-aggression pact it had with us.
Today the Romanian government officially severed the Anglo-French guarantee of territorial integrity in the Balkans and sought to improve relations with the German government.

The Romanian government announced that in light of the current situation it no longer saw any reason in continuing as a member of the League of Nations and therefore decided to withdraw from the organization.

The British and French governments extended their mutual assistance pacts to the Greek and Romanian governments in an attempt to bolster a united front against Germany and Italy in the Balkans. The Italian annexation of Albania placed Greece in direct danger of invasion, while the Germans placed pressure on the Romanians.

In an effort to win broader political support, the Romanian government introduced a new nationalities statute which gave minorities equal rights with Romanians in terms of language, religion, and race. Under a new administrative plan, introduced on 13th August, Romania's old racial divisions became void and a new political system divided into ten provinces went into effect.

The German government offered bilateral, non-aggression pacts to the Scandinavian and Baltic states. The Finnish, Norwegian, and Swedish governments rejected the proposal, basing their decisions on a policy of strict neutrality. The Danish, Estonian, and Latvian governments accepted the German proposal.
The USSR has decided to renew its non-aggression pact with us.

The Hungarian regent, Admiral Nicolas Horthy, conducted a state visit to Germany, where he was received by the German government with great ceremony. During the visit the diplomats from both countries discussed common issues such as Sudetenland and came to a greater understanding on several issues.
Lithuania has refused to open up for normal diplomatic relations. What should we do now?
Lithuania has given in to our ultimatum and has opened up for normal diplomatic relations.

In the years 1920-1939, Lithuania and Poland were not conducting normal diplomatic contacts. This quasi-war state happened partially due to the Polish refusal to return Wilno (Vilnius) to Lithuania and partially due to the fact that Lithuanian national integrity was based on the opposing Poland as an external enemy. All this changed when on 17th March 1938, a Polish soldier was killed in a border skirmish. Polish government used this incident to normalize Polish-Lithuanian affairs and in ultimatum delivered to Kaunas (Kowno) demanded from Lithuania that normal diplomatic contacts be restored. Historically, Lithuania accepted this demand, and later developed normal contacts with Poland. Most European countries saw that as Lithuanian recognition of Polish sovereignty over Wilno.

In the years 1920-1939, Lithuania and Poland were not conducting normal diplomatic contacts. This quasi-war state happened partially due to the Polish refusal to return Wilno (Vilnius) to Lithuania and partially due to the fact that Lithuanian national integrity was based on the opposing Poland. All this changed when on 17th March 1938, a Polish soldier was killed in a border accident. Polish government used this incident to normalize Lithuanian-Polish affairs and in ultimatum delivered to Kaunas (Kowno) demanded from Lithuania that normal diplomatic contacts be restored. Historically, Lithuania accepted this demand, and later developed normal contacts with Poland.

Our intelligence service has discovered the plans for a coup against us by the National Socialist Party. We have to act fast but be aware that the National Socialists have strong support in the population due to their plans for land reforms and relief for our hard pressed agriculture.
The governments of Austria, Hungary, and Italy agreed to extend their defensive treaty until 30th June 1938, as a means to deter German expansion in central Europe.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1943 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. This year's laureate is George de Hevesy (Hungary), for his work in the use of isotopes as tracers in the study of chemical processes.

Historically, Hungary signed the Tripartite Pact on 20th November 1940. With this Pact, Hungary's claims in Europe are recognized. Germany and Hungary also agree a mutual exchange of weapons and technology.

After the Versailles Treaty and four uprisings (three in Silesia and one in Grand Poland), a border between Poland and Germany was set up. German minority (4%) never accepted Poland as their motherland and, as Nazi Germany was increasing its pressure on Poland, sabotage became a real problem. Planes were being destroyed on the airfields, coal mines were set in flames and railroads damaged.

In the 1930s, Polish foreign politics involved the idea of 'Equal distance to both Berlin and Moscow'. Most of Polish politicians shared the fears of Pilsudski, who was afraid that allying with either side would result in Poland becoming a puppet of one of its stronger neighbors. If Poland allied itself to the Soviets and allowed the Red Army to enter, it would probably never leave. Similarly if Poland became allied to Germany, it would be constantly threatened with political pressure and German involvement in Polish internal affairs would increase too much. Pilsudski himself said shortly before his death in 1935 that 'Poland is currently sitting on two chairs at the same time. If we lean on one of the sides, we fall'.

In the 1930s, Polish foreign politics involved the idea of 'Equal distance to both Berlin and Moscow'. Most of Polish politicians shared the fears of Pilsudski, who was afraid that allying with either side would result in Poland becoming a puppet of one of its stronger neighbors. If Poland allied itself to the Soviets and allowed the Red Army to enter, it would probably never leave. Similarly if Poland became allied to Germany, it would be constantly threatened with political pressure and German involvement in polish internal affairs would rise too much. Pilsudski himself said shortly before his death in 1935 that 'Poland is currently sitting on two chairs at the same time. If we lean on one of the sides, we fall'.
Red Army units started supporting us with weapons and government-in-exile in London confirms that USSR re-established diplomatic contacts with them. We can now treat Soviets as potential allies.
Red Army units have started supporting us with weapons.

The start of Warsaw uprising was sudden, but anticipated by the British High Command. Much earlier Polish and UK governments decided that to support expected national uprising. UK will train and support some special forces units. Ultimately these units took the shape of some small diversion groups and one large unit, 1st Paradrop Brigade, lead by General Sosabowski.

The start of Warsaw uprising was sudden, but anticipated by the British High Command. At the start the British government hoped that Warsaw would quickly be relieved by advancing Soviet forces, but Stalin's lack of support to the Polish Home Army (AK) action complicated the whole situation. The only way to support the AK was air drops. Historically Allied strategic bombers starting from bases in Italy and North Africa delivered huge caches of AT weapons, equipment and medicines to Warsaw, but due to the chaotic nature of urban fighting more than half of these were captured by German units.

The start of Warsaw uprising was sudden, but anticipated by the British High Command. At the start the British government hoped that Warsaw would quickly be relieved by advancing Soviet forces, but Stalin's lack of support to the Polish Home Army (AK) action complicated the whole situation. The only way to support AK was air drops. Historically Allied strategic bombers starting from bases in Italy and North Africa delivered huge caches of AT weapons, equipment and medicines to Warsaw, but due to the chaotic nature of urban fighting over half of these were captured by German units.

The start of Warsaw uprising was sudden, but anticipated by the British High Command. At the start British government hoped that Warsaw would quickly be relieved by advancing Soviet forces, but Stalin's lack of support to the Polish Home Army (AK) action complicated the whole situation. The only way to support AK was air drops. Historically Allied strategic bombers starting from bases in Italy and North Africa delivered huge caches of AT weapons, equipment and medicines to Warsaw, but due to the chaotic nature of urban fighting over half of these were captured by German units.

The start of Warsaw uprising was sudden, but anticipated by the British High Command. At the start the British government hoped that Warsaw would quickly be relieved by advancing Soviet forces, but Stalin's lack of support to the Polish Home Army (AK) action complicated the whole situation. The only way to support AK was air drops. Historically Allied strategic bombers starting from bases in Italy and North Africa delivered huge caches of AT weapons, equipment and medicines to Warsaw, but due to the chaotic nature of urban fighting over half of these were captured by German units.

Polish Home Army (AK), however strong in numbers had a significant weakness - lack of weapons. At first arms were mostly from 1939 campaign. Later weapons were either captured, manufactured or even traded from defecting Axis soldiers. Due to the long and dangerous air routes, AK was supported by Allies much less than Yugoslav or French partisans. As a result, Warsaw uprising started with few well equipped assault units and many more trained people waiting for weapons. During the initial strike AK units were able to capture large caches of police and garrison weapons, thus arming new groups of fighters.

Polish Home Army (AK), however strong in numbers had a significant weakness - lack of weapons. At first arms were mostly from 1939 campaign. Later weapons were either captured, manufactured or even traded from defecting Axis soldiers. Due to the long and dangerous air routes, AK was supported by Allies much less than Yugoslav or French partisans. In result, Warsaw uprising started with few well equipped assault units and many more trained people waiting for weapons. During the initial strike AK units were able to capture large caches of police and garrison weapons, thus arming new groups of fighters.

Polish Home Army (AK), however strong in numbers had a significant weakness - lack of weapons. At first arms were mostly from 1939 campaign. Later weapons were either captured, manufactured or even traded from defecting Axis soldiers. Due to the long and dangerous air routes, AK was supported by Allies much less than Yugoslav or French partisans. As a result, Warsaw uprising started with few well equipped assault units and many more trained people waiting for weapons. During the initial strike AK units were able to capture large caches of police and garrison weapons, thus arming new groups of fighters.

As the Red Army was advancing from the east, the German occupying forces were perceived to be on the defensive in Poland. Polish Home Army (AK), directed by the Polish Government-in-Exile in London, was eager to prove that Poland still had an army and a legal government. It was extremely important to counter Soviet attempts to install puppet governments as well as gain support of UK and USA for post-war period. Warsaw Uprising was part of the plan 'Burza' (Storm) - large operation of partisan units supporting advancing Red Army and installing local administration cells on liberated territories. At that point Germans had a comparatively small military presence in the Polish capital. The decision was based on the assumption that the Red Army was so close to Warsaw that it would be able to join AK any day.

Historically, Polish arms exports in the 1930s were one of the main sources of foreign currency for the Polish army. Every two planes sold abroad could cover the expenses for buying one for the army. We have made another fair deal with Spain recently.

Polish arms exports in the 1930s were one of the main sources of foreign currency for the Polish army. Every two planes sold abroad could cover the expenses for buying one for the army. We have made another fair deal with Spain recently.

Despite the fact that the Polish government pronounced full neutrality in the Spanish Civil War and banned any arms export and volunteer emigration to any of the belligerent states, Polish state-owned factories sold several hundred thousand carbines and rifles, most of which went to the Republicans. Most of the arms shipments went through Romania and Southern America to hide them from foreign intelligence services.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1937 Nobel Prize in Medicine. This year's laureate is Albert von Szent-Gyˆrgyi Nagyrapolt (Hungary), for his discoveries in connection with the biological combustion processes, with special reference to vitamin C and the catalysis of fumaric acid.

Ukrainian National-Democrat Union (UNDO) was the main Ukrainian political party in Poland. From the beginning of its existence it was clearly anti-Soviet, but in the early 1930s, it also became strongly anti-Polish. It maintained relations with Ukrainian underground organizations, including the terrorist Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists (OUN). However later in the 1930s, UNDO made it to the Sejm and started to seek some sort of a modus vivendi with the government in Warsaw. An agreement was signed (historically in late 1936) in which UNDO promised not to continue the anti-government propaganda while the government stopped all repressions aimed at Ukrainians. This agreement became the beginning of a new era in Polish-Ukrainian relations.

After the battle of Warsaw in 1920, Poland looked ready to march on Moscow but Lenin sued for peace and the Allies pressured Pilsudski to stop his troops. At this moment two main ideas on Polish eastern borders emerged: the one proposed by Roman Dmowski and the one proposed by JÛzef Pilsudski. Dmowski wanted a state as large as possible without any national minorities while Pilsudski opted for a federation of nations in the pre-partition style of Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth. The borders established at the treaty of Riga were a compromise between these concepts, and Poland after 1921 had around 30% of national minorities. At times the earlier concept gained the upper hand in certain areas and lead to major strikes and riots, especially among the Ukrainians as such politics were clearly aimed against their national aspirations.

One of the main issues of Polish internal politics in the 1930s was the case of the Ukrainian university. Both sides saw the need to create such a facility, but Polish government feared that setting it up in LwÛw would drastically change the national stability in the city and proposed a smaller city like StanislawÛw or Tarnopol instead. Ukrainians however feared that such localization would help the authorities to marginalize its role. Historically discussions never ended and no Ukrainian university was created before the war broke out.

Historically, after series of tests in 1936, the Department of Armaments decided to start a licence production of 'Pegassus XX' engines. They entered the service as 'PZL Pegaz XX A' and 'PZL Pegaz XX B' soon afterwards.

After series of tests in 1936 the Department of Armaments decided to start a licence production of 'Pegassus XX' engines. They entered the service as 'PZL Pegaz XX A' and 'PZL Pegaz XX B' soon afterwards.

Polish bomber PZL P-37 'Los' (Elk) was one of the best medium bombers of the late 1930s. It was very fast, reliable, safe and had an enormous bomb load of almost 2600 kg. Unfortunately, Polish industry could not provide it with a decent engine. After a series of tests in 1936, the Department of Armaments decided to start a licence production of 'Bristol Pegasus XX' engines.

After Poland regained independence in 1918, the boundaries between the former occupants were still clearly visible. Poland was informally divided onto industrialized and developed 'Poland A' and the rural and poor 'Poland B' which was on former outskirts of the Russian Empire. In February 1937, the government started to build the Central Industrial Zone (COP) between the Vistula and San rivers. The purpose was to develop the 'Poland B' sector, give a boost to the war industry and reduce unemployment. By 1939 a huge steel mill in Stalowa Wola, munitions factory in Sanok, carbines and handguns factory in Radom, aircraft works in Mielec and RzeszÛw and several other factories were constructed.

In 1936, an increased demand for grain enabled the Polish economy to fully recover from the Great Crisis. However the unemployment was still rising and government was forced to seek new solutions. In June 1936, Eugeniusz Kwiatkowski, the minister of economy, prepared a plan of government investments for the next four years. According to this plan hundreds of thousands of people were to be hired for construction of heavy industry and infrastructure improvements. Until 1940 more than 1.8 billion zlotys (almost 350 million 1939 dollars) were spent for that purpose.

In 1936, polish government prepared a series of sanitary regulations. Many of the Jewish MPs were afraid that the new law will allow the police to impose severe restrictions on kosher butchers and started a propaganda campaign in which they described the new law as 'anti-Semitic' and 'brutal'.

Before WWII Poland was a country with the largest Jewish minority in the world (more than 3,5 million people). Many of them were interested in the ideas of Zionism. By 1937, more than 160,000 Jews emigrated to Palestine

In August 1937, the secretary general of the Polish Communist Party (KPP), Lenski-Leszczynski, was called off to Moscow and shot. In the following months most of the communist leaders shared his fate. In the spring of 1938, the Central Committee of Komintern decided to dissolve the KPP on the pretext of KPP being an agent of Polish intelligence. The reason why Stalin made such a decision is still unknown.

Polish modification of an excellent Bofors 37mm AT gun, the 'Armata pp. wz.36' was one of the best constructions of its times. Not only was it more reliable than its' original, but also it was significantly cheaper (approximately 1000 UK pounds in 1937). In 1938, Poland sold several hundred of these together with a license to Great Britain, where they remained in active service until early 1950s, under the name of 'Ordnance QF 37mm Mk.1'.

Tsar Boris III (1884-1943) was an important figure during the World Wars. Historically he followed Germany, mainly to regain territory lost in the Treaty of Neuilly. He did however manage to save the Bulgarian Jewish population and never declared war on the USSR. When Hitler summoned Boris to Germany it was agreed he would declare war on the USA and the UK, but not the USSR. Shortly after his return to Sofia, he died of an apparent heart failure. He was succeeded by his infant son Simeon II.

Tsar Boris III (1884-1943) was an important figure during the World Wars. Historically he followed Germany, mainly to regain territory lost in the Treaty of Neuilly. He did however manage to save the Bulgarian Jewish population and never declared war on the USSR. When Hitler summoned Boris to Germany it was agreed he would declare war on the USA and the UK, but not the USSR. Shortly after his return to Sofia, he died of an apparent heart failure, though many in Bulgaria felt it was a Nazi conspiracy to put a more pro-Nazi government in power. He was succeeded by his infant son Simeon II.

Soon after joining Allies, Poland asked UK and France for help in modernization of its air force. Historically, both countries decided to give Poland special credits for military equipment. From UK Poland acquired 100 Fairey Battle bombers.

Soon after joining Allies, Poland asked Britain and France for help in modernization of its Air Force. Both countries decided to give Poland special credit to purchase military equipment. From Britain, Poland acquired modern plane engines and a contract for 100 Fairey Battle bombers.
Due to the crisis on German border, the Polish government asked the Romanian government for free passage of French arms transport through Konstanca harbor.

Soon after joining Allies, Poland asked Britain and France for help in modernization of its Air Force. Both countries decided to give Poland special credit to purchase military equipment. From France, Poland acquired a contract for 100 MS-406 fighters.

During the 1930s, Polish military intelligence accomplished many feats in operations against the German Abwehr. Perhaps the most important was the creation of a copy of the Enigma encryption device by a small group of Polish math scientists: M. Rejewski, J. Rozycki and H. Zygalski. Their works provided valuable experience for the further development of decryption devices during World War Two.

After the fall of Poland, according to Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact, Stalin had a free hand in the Baltic states to do as he pleased. Interested in gaining full control over all the Baltic countries, he was interested in creating an illusion of friendly USSR. The ceding of Vilnius (Wilno), the historical capital of Lithuania and one of more important cities for Polish culture, was a good example of Stalin's politics. Vilnius was returned to Lithuania in 1939.
Germany offered help to support the Romanian government against the Iron Guard during the rebellion.

The conflict between Antonescu and Horia Sima reached its climax with The Legionary rebellion of 21st January 1941, which raged for three days. Implementing predetermined strategies, hordes of Legionnaires staged pogroms in many cities and villages. Looting, torture and killing swept through the country. Eventually, the rebellion was suppressed by the army. In a telephone conversation on 22nd January 1941, Hitler offered Antonescu the support of German troops in crushing the rebellion, but Antonescu declined. After the rebellion was quelled, German troops helped smuggle a number of Legionnaires (including Horia Sima) out of the country.

The fall of King Carol occurred on 6th September 1940. The populace considered him responsible for the loss of the territory of Transylvania, and for increased violence due to political infighting in the country. Carol abdicated in favor of King Mihai. Ion Antonescu became head of government.
The Iron Guard under Codreanu's command attempted to seize power in Romania. The coup was unsuccessful and Codreanu and his Iron Guard commanders were severely punished.

Codreanu's Legionary movement (aka the Iron Guard) killed 2 prime ministers in an attempt to intimidate the government and gain power and support. King Carol outlawed all the political parties and established a personal dictatorship to quell the growing unrest in the country.

Many Polish forces escaped from the Germans and Soviets through Hungarian territory. They made the attempt to escape through Hungary and tried to regroup with their comrades in the Western nations of France and Britain.

Many Polish forces also escaped from the Germans and Soviets through Hungarian territory. They made the attempt to escape through Hungary and tried to regroup with their comrades in the Western nations of France and Britain.

On 17th September 1939, Soviet tanks and motorized units crossed Polish borders. According to a USSR diplomatic note: 'Poland has fallen and the USSR has begun liberation of Western Byelorussia and Ukraine from both Polish and German oppressors'. In this way, Stalin tried to secure the claims negotiated for the USSR in the Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact. Meanwhile, the Polish government and High Command desperately tried to prepare their last line of defense in the southeastern part of the country. The Soviet attack rendered these plans obsolete - the government and all available military forces were forced to cross the Romanian border to avoid capture by Soviet troops. Between the 17th and 20th of September, over 40,000 troops, as well as most of the Polish Air Force, crossed the border into Romania. After disarming the troops, the Romanian government helped the Poles reach France and the UK - effectively recreating the Polish Army in the West.

Some Polish forces escaping from the Germans entered Romanian territory. They asked the Romanian government for support to reach Britain or France. The Romanians obliged, relieving the Polish forces of their weapons and equipment in the process.
Realizing the strong threat of the Soviets, the Romanian government made several purchases of tanks and military technology from Germany.
Realizing the strong threat of the Soviets, the Romanian government made several purchases of tanks and military technology from Germany.
Realizing the strong threat of the Soviets, the Romanian government made several purchases of tanks and military technology from Germany.
To strengthen their relationship, Hitler had some military equipment, stolen from the Czechs, sent to Hungary.
Realizing the strong threat of the Soviets, the Hungarian government made several purchases of tanks and military technology from Germany.
Realizing the strong threat of the Soviets, the Hungarian government made several purchases of tanks and military technology from Germany.
To strengthen their relationship, Hitler had some military equipment, stolen from the Czechs, sent to Hungary.
Italy also sold a lot of its unneeded, surplus, or obsolete military equipment to European Axis satellite nations like Hungary. This was, in part, to support these nations against the Soviets.
Germany also sold a lot of its unneeded, surplus, or obsolete military equipment to European Axis satellite nations like Bulgaria. This was, in part, to support these nations against the Soviets.
Germany sold much of the equipment it captured during the defeat of France. Most of the equipment went to European Axis satellite nations like Bulgaria.

We have signed a treaty of peace and perpetual friendship with Yugoslavia, hoping to discourage their government from any rash and unfortunate moves. Even though the treaty promises peace and good relations, tensions still remain given Yugoslavia's recent political instability and historical pretensions.
Germany demanded the province of Sevastopol from the Ukraine in return for supporting their independence politically, and with supplies, materiel, and resources.
Germany sent resources to help the Ukrainians in their fight against their former oppressors.
Germany sent supplies to help the Ukrainians in their fight against their former oppressors.
The Ukrainians declared their independence and established a new government.

Vienna Conference representatives of the Danubian Protocol States (Austria, Hungary, and Italy) met in Vienna to discuss European tensions. The conference marked the gradual consolidation of Italian power in the Danubian Basin.
Representatives of the Austrian, Hungarian, and Italian governments reaffirmed the protocols between the three states to maintain the status quo in Danubian region.
The attempts made between the countries in the Danubian region to create a counterpart to the German interest have failed

Italy, Austria and Hungary signed an anti-Nazi mutual defense treaty in Rome. Austria signed the agreement, because the increasing German propaganda made it obvious that if Austria wished to remain neutral it would have to find strong allies in order to repel any German requests for Anschluss.

Slovakia's involvement in Fall Weiss, while a proud moment for Slovaks supporting National Socialism and Hitler's Reich, was but a minor contribution to the offensive. Still, Slovakia did provide pressure upon the Polish army in southern Poland. After the fall of Poland, however, Slovakia was expected to dutifully cede control of any conquered territory to its greater German ally.

Eastern Poland was apportioned to the Soviet Union by means of the recent Molotov-Ribbentrop pact. Slovakia, as a German ally, would return any Polish territory she conquered during Fall Weiss to Soviet control.
Access through Slovakia was of prime interest to Germany and a implied part of the German-Slovak alliance.

The Germans have sent us enough Bf-109 E-3 fighters, supplies, and spare parts to equip an entire new squadron. Training has started to teach our pilots how to use these new machines. Historically, in 1938 Switzerland purchased 90 Bf-109 fighters from Germany. Later, when the fighters were needed desperately for the German war effort, the Swiss refused to sell them back, despite many German requests to have the fighters returned. The Swiss continued to resist increasing German pressure and desperation, and, using the very same fighters, even got into dogfights with the Germans over violations of airspace.

We have successfully negotiated a sales deal with Switzerland, exchanging our Messerschmitt Bf-109 fighter technology for a good price. Our delegation has also impressed the Swiss Air Force officers, hopefully bringing our two countries closer together.

Our military demands that we purchase this beautiful aircraft from Germans. The fighter airplane in question is certainly one of the most advanced designs in the world, and our Air Force would be very pleased to have some of those aircraft in its ranks. Germans have offered fairly good prices for a large number of planes.

Swiss government has approached us offering to purchase a large number of Messerschmitt BF-109 E-3 fighter aircraft. While we would normally be cautious with the sale of such advanced technology to potential enemies, the Swiss are offering a good price in return for our aircraft. Also, this could be an excellent way to foster a friendship between our two countries. Should we proceed with negotiations?
Only forces loyal to the new Slovakian Government may remain mobilized, which resulted in a massive demobilization of former Czech forces.
Due to the loss of the Sudetenland we can no longer support the divisions whose soldiers were drafted from the lost provinces.
We must call up the reserves to defend our country.

Political demonstrations in support of the National Socialists broke out in Graz and soon spread across Styria, resulting in a state of revolution. The Austrian government proved incapable of dealing with the revolution for fear of offending the Germans. Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg was unable to negotiate a reconciliation with the Socialist working classes to ease the political crisis.

The Schuschnigg government has announced plans for a general amnesty for National Socialists who had participated in an attempted coup against the government. The Austrian government offered amnesty to improve relations with the German government.

Although the Soviet Navy has been primarily a defensive tool, Stalin has decided that he would like the ability to project power with naval forces built around modern battleships and large cruisers. As a part of this change in policy, the Soviet ambassador has approached the Foreign Ministry with a request to acquire the necessary technical knowledge from Swiss corporations. If we agree to this measure, it would allow Swiss engineers to work with their Soviet counterparts on designing modern steam turbines and boilers necessary for building modern warships.
The governments of Austria, Hungary, and Italy agreed to extend their defensive treaty until 30th June 1938, as a means to deter German expansion in central Europe.

In response to the political tensions following the suppression of a Sudete German Party meeting, the Czechoslovak government postponed national elections and forbid political meetings. The situation developed into crisis proportions between the German and Czechoslovak governments.
Former Czechoslovak president Thomas Masaryk has died, which led to a period of national mourning. He was considered the father of the Czechoslovak republic.

Although the Swiss government partially participated in the economic sanctions against Italy in response to the Ethiopian crisis, the government decided to recognize the Italian conquest. Fascist aspirations for incorporation of the Italian-speaking cantons of Switzerland into Italy, the conclusion of the Rome-Berlin Axis, and the collapse of the League of Nation's collective security system persuaded the Swiss to avoid tensions with the Italians.

Under the Versailles Treaty, major German rivers and canals came under international control. Chancellor Adolf Hitler has announced that the German government will resume control over the waterways in Germany. We have to respond to this violation of the Versailles Treaty.
The Swiss government has taken new steps to repress Communism in Switzerland and several cantons wish to make the Communist Party illegal.
Our economy has been stagnating for quite a while now. Our experts have advised that we should devalue the Swiss Franc and take it off the gold standard in order to spur our economy to new heights

Austrian Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg forced Prince Ernest Stahremberg, commander of the Heimwehr, to resign as Vice Chancellor and leader of the Fatherland Front. This move eliminated Chancellor Schuschnigg's only real rival for power.

The Czechoslovak prime minister, Milan Hodza, conducted an official state visit to Vienna. The meeting reflected a rapprochement between the two countries in the face of growing German power. The Austrians feared German designs and were uncertain of Italian resolve, while the Czechoslovaks, with French support, hoped to bring Austria, and perhaps Hungary, in association with the Little Entente to form a stronger coalition against Germany. One result of Czechoslovak Prime Minister Hodza's visit to Vienna was the signing of a trade agreement as a means to promote cooperation between the two states.

The Czechoslovak prime minister, Milan Hodza, conducted an official state visit to Vienna. The meeting reflected a rapprochement between the two countries in the face of growing German power. The Austrians feared German designs and were uncertain of Italian resolve, while the Czechoslovaks, with French support, hoped to bring Austria, and perhaps Hungary, in association with the Little Entente to form a stronger coalition against Germany. One result of Czechoslovak Prime Minister Hodza's visit to Vienna was the signing of a trade agreement as a means to promote cooperation between the two states.

A Jewish assassin has murdered the leader of the Swiss National Socialists. He was killed while visiting Davos and during the following days the Swiss government decided to disband the National Socialists as a national organization.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1946 Nobel Prize in Literature. This year's laureate is Hermann Hesse (Switzerland), for his inspired writings which, while growing in boldness and penetration, exemplify the classical humanitarian ideals and high quality of style.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1944 Nobel Peace Prize. This year's laureate is the International Committee of the Red Cross, for their continuing effort to relieve the suffering of the civilians of war and other conflicts.
The Nobel Foundation has named the laureates for the 1939 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. This year's laureates are Adolf Friedrich Johann Butenandt (Germany), for his work regarding sex hormones

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1938 Nobel Peace Prize. This year's laureate is the Nansen International Office for Refugees, for their continuing effort to relieve the suffering of refugees of war, famine, and other disasters.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureates for the 1937 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. This year's laureates are Walter Norman Haworth (United Kingdom), for his investigations on carbohydrates and Vitamin C

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1945 Nobel Prize in Physics. This year's laureate is Wolfgang Pauli (Austria), for the discovery of the Exclusion Principle, also called the Pauli Principle.
The Nobel Foundation has named the laureates for the 1936 Nobel Prize in Physics. This year's laureates are Victor Franz Hess (Austria), for his discovery of cosmic relation

Slovak Nationalists in 1936 demanded that Czechoslovakia enter an alliance with Hitler and Mussolini. Czechoslovakia, however, had strong ties with her pro-allied Balkan neighbors and had a strong distrust of Hungary.
Just after Germany's Anschluss of Austria, the German Agrarian Party and Sudetendeutsche Partei (SdP) united to form a stronger front.

After the Great War homecoming, soldiers in Austria were not disarmed. Many joined the paramilitary forces of different political parties. In the mid-1930s, this led to violent clashes and forced the Chancellor to prohibit weapons within the general population. It also lead to the introduction of mandatory army service for every male between the ages 18 to 35.

On 11th July 1936, German and Austrian officials met to hammer out an agreement. Germany publicly stated that it would honor Austrian sovereignty, and this showed a strong friendship between the Austrian and German governments. This served to ease some fears that an increasingly confident Germany would not respect international law or the sovereignty of other nations. However, the Agreement also had a secret agenda: to provide amnesty for Austrian Nazis, lift censorship on Nazi media, allow the resumption of political activities by Austrian Nazis, and ensure the appointment of men friendly to the Nazis in the Austrian Schuschnigg Cabinet.

At the end of 1936, Edvard Benes, president of the Republic of Czechoslovakia, discovered that important information was being exchanged between the German government and several prominent members of the Soviet embassy in Prague. Benes suspected this was a conspiracy by the Russian military and old-guard Communists to depose Stalin and install a new regime closer to the German political line. Benes desired this information to be communicated to the Soviets through the Czech police, so that it would be presented to Stalin from a friendly foreign source. Benes' service to the Soviet leader earned him the gratitude of Stalin, but also pitted him against Germany.

In 1938, Switzerland purchased 90 Me-109 fighters from Germany. Later, when the fighters were needed desperately for the German war effort, the Swiss refused to sell them back, despite many German requests to have the fighters returned. The Swiss continued to resist increasing German pressure and desperation, and, using the very same fighters, even got into dogfights with the Germans over violations of airspace.

During April and May 1939, Swiss envoys pleaded with the United States to support them with supplies in the event of a war in Europe. At first the Americans denied these requests, but eventually ended up agreeing to ship the materiel. By the time war broke out in September 1939, American supplies were reaching Switzerland.

After the German Anschluss with Austria, Switzerland took numerous measures to prepare against an invasion from Germany. A new division was created to guard the border with the former nation of Austria.

Throughout 1936, Minger, the Swiss minister of defense, gained approval from governmental authorities for the rearmament of the Swiss army. These approvals allowed for the creation of new weapons, and the arming of large amounts of the Swiss population in the event of an emergency. Although the Swiss economy was not really in the shape to pay for such an expensive action, the government none the less went ahead with the programs, as fears of a German takeover became widespread.
A government loyal to Britain and Germany has been installed in Bhutan.
A government loyal to Britain and Germany has been installed in Nepal.
A government loyal to Britain and Germany has been installed in Yemen.

With Britain defeated, the Germans have decided to sign a definitive peace treaty with the United Kingdom and Vichy France. As a part of this agreement, they are turning over occupied France to the Vichy Government. The new Fascist British Government has asked us to cease hostilities with the Germans. Shall we comply? Refusing means war with Britain, as they have aligned themselves with Germany now.

The British zone will consist of the L‰nder, Schleswig-Holstein, Lower Saxony, and North Rhine-Westphalia. In addition the British will occupy the southwestern third of Austria. The occupation zone of the United States consisted of Hesse, Baden-W¸rttemberg, Bavaria, the L‰nder of Rhineland-Palatinate, the Saarland, and the north-central areas of former Austria, including Salzburg.

The British zone will consist of the L‰nder of Schleswig-Holstein, Lower Saxony, and North Rhine-Westphalia. In addition the British will occupy the southwestern third of Austria. The British zone will consist of the L‰nder of Schleswig-Holstein, Lower Saxony, North Rhine-Westphalia and the southern quarter of Austria. The occupation zone of the United States consisted of the Land of Hesse, the northern half of the present-day Land of Baden-W¸rttemberg, Bavaria, and the north-central areas of former Austria, including Salzburg. The occupation zone of the United States consisted of the Land of Hesse, Baden-W¸rttemberg, Bavaria, the L‰nder of Rhineland-Palatinate, the Saarland, and the north-central areas of former Austria, including Salzburg.
