With Britain defeated, the Germans have decided to sign a definitive peace treaty with their French and British collaborator regimes. As a part of this agreement, they are turning over occupied France to PÈtain. This has greatly increased the legitimacy of the collaborator government in the eyes of the French people.

With Britain soundly defeated, it is time to replace the provisional peace with France with a more permanent European New Order. The Foreign Ministry has prepared a treaty in which Germany will keep Elsass and Lothringen and regain the colonies lost in the Great War, as well as some new colonial land. Iraq will become a Reich Protectorate. Italy will gain Malta, Cyprus, British and French Somaliland and Egypt as a puppet, while Spain will get Gibraltar. Occupied France will be returned to the Vichy Government and a puppet regime will be set up in London under Oswald Mosely. Ireland and Argentina will be offered the Ulster and the Falklands respectively, hopefully bringing them closer to Germany. Do you want to institute this New Order now?

The threat of the Soviet Union was always a major factor in Japanese planning.  Recent events have forced a re-evaluation of defenses on some of the northern island chains and it's been proposed to send several labor battalions to begin construction of AA emplacements, coastal artillery bunkers and other defenses to improve the ability of the Army to hold these outposts.

With the developing threat in the Pacific theatre the Army has requested resources for construction projects on several islands and atolls.  New airstrips, improved harbors, coast artillery and bunker complexes will ensure our ability to protect our bases and project power in the Pacific.  The Navy has raised some objections to this plan, stating that only a few new harbor facilities are required and that the resources should instead be used on expanding the navy.
As Japan went to war against the Allies the population of the Bonin islands (some 7700 people) were evacuated to the Home Isles to protect them from bombing or other hardships in the coming war.

The inability of the Imperial Army in controlling the guerilla movements in China has finally reached a critical level and a major popular uprising is taking place in China.  Partisan units in several provinces have declared their loyalty to a single Warlord and he's called every man and woman to raise arms against the Japanese to win freedom once again from the 'foreign devils'.  Local garrisons in several provinces have been completely overrun and there's some reports indicating that the Chinese forces are receiving direct aid from Allied commando units.

The Japanese policy of maintaining only minimal garrisons in key cities gave the KMT and Communists a free hand in inciting villagers and townspeople in thousands of settlements against the Japanese occupation forces.  This quickly grew into a major resistance organization with significant clandestine aid from foreign powers and attacks on Japanese forces became a regular occurrence.  While some resistance groups operated in reinforced company strength and sometimes coordinated attacks within a province, there was no cohesive organization for forming units on the divisional scale or truly wresting control of entire provinces from the Japanese force.

Strong Japanese garrisons both in the cities and the countryside exerted a good level of control over the local populace, although inevitably there were some incidents every year where trouble flared up and required additional resources to quell.  The source of the trouble was usually Communist agitators in the countryside while in the cities it was KMT supporters seeking to return to power.

The Japanese policy of maintaining strong control only in the major cities gave the KMT and Communists a relatively free hand in inciting villagers and townspeople in thousands of settlements against the Japanese occupation force.  This would often result in strikes, attacks on police stations or other forms of resistance and as time passed insurgents sought to engage Japanese forces even within the largest cities with mortar attacks on barracks or sudden attacks on soldiers traveling alone.  The response from the occupation forces was often swift and violent, yet the resistance was not quelled.

The Japanese policy of maintaining strong control only in the major cities gave the KMT and Communists a relatively free hand in inciting villagers and townspeople in thousands of settlements against the Japanese occupation force.  This would often result in strikes, attacks on police stations or other forms of resistance and as time passed insurgents sought to engage Japanese forces even within the largest cities with mortar attacks on barracks or sudden attacks on soldiers traveling alone.  The response from the occupation forces was often swift and violent, yet the resistance was not quelled.

When the China incident first began few would have thought that Japan would one day extend control over all of China, yet this has now come to pass and our influence in Asia is growing as other governments acknowledge our strength.  The KMT has been reduced to nothing more than roving bandits and Japanese garrisons are being established all over the Chinese mainland.  It's critical that sufficient troops are maintained in China to prevent the KMT or Communist leadership from reforming and organizing mass uprisings against the occupation forces.
The Allied invasion of Indochina led to Japan's demand for full control of Indochina to secure its position

The decision to make Tokyo the final battleground changed the face of the city forever.  Buildings were demolished to clear lanes of fire, barricades blocked every road and all open areas were turned into minefields.  Hundreds of thousands of civilians were armed with assorted small arms, explosives or even bamboo spears.  As the militia units formed up the factories were shut down or more often converted into impromptu fortresses.
All but the most critical factories are shut down as the workers form into militia units and are issued with their weapons.  The orders are simple: stand and fight to the last man!

As enemy forces threatened the Japanese Home Islands, desperate plans were made for a vast citizen's militia to be mobilized for defense all over the nation.  While poorly equipped the numeric strength and desperate tactics of such a militia would take a heavy toll on any invader, especially when fighting from prepared positions in the cities.
Allied landings in French Indochina would have severely disrupted Japan's Southern Strategy, forcing Japan to intervene directly in French Indochina
Fearing conflict in Indochina would derail its own plans for Southeast Asia, Japan intervened in the Franco-Siamese war, forcing the two sides to a settlement that was in Siam's favor
In the summer of 1941, Japan forced the Vichy administration in Indochina to grant the Japanese bases in the Mekong Delta
In the summer of 1941, Japan forced the Vichy administration in Indochina to grant the Japanese bases in the Mekong Delta, in spite of American protests
We are at war with a major power, mobilize the entire nation.
We are at war on two fronts, we must fully mobilize.
We are at war with China and will partially mobilize the country.

Shortly after war was declared, Japanese forces captured the American Zone in Shanghai from the USMC 4th Marine Regiment.  The Marines put up a ferocious battle and inflicted severe casualties on the over-confident Japanese forces.
Shortly after war was declared, Japanese forces captured the ships of the US Yangtze Patrol near Shanghai, China.
Shortly after war was declared, Japanese forces captured the U.S. 15th Infantry Regiment, which was deployed protecting the U.S. Treaty Port in Tianjin, China.

The USA and their Philippine lackeys have joined China in alliance and are in a state of war against the Empire.  China is receiving massive aid from their new ally.  We must teach the Americans never to meddle in Asia again.

The American weaklings in the government cannot decide between peace or war, but the isolationist faction in the USA is our unwitting ally in staying the hand of the American colossus.  The current government will aid China and do its most to strengthen the USA against us.  This will hurt our influence.  We must quickly wrap up our campaign in China before the threat of war with USA saps our morale at home even more.
The American quail at the prospect of war.  They withdraw all of their garrisons from China in humiliation.  Our people are ecstatic.  The prestige of the Chrysanthemum Throne has never been higher.

The Americans are sending aid to the Chinese.  They are enraged at the Empire.  Our embassy reports that Congress is ready to vote money for new battleships in their navy.  The foreign ministry urges concessions and recall of Prince Asaka, but the General Staff recommends a hard line.

The Americans have recalled their ambassador and our embassy reports that the Americans are greatly incensed at the Empire.  American newsmen on the Panay filmed the entire attack, and every cinema shows our pilots killing Americans in the newsreel.  It is too soon for war.  We will recall General Nakajima from the front.  Prince Asaka loses a great deal of face.

As Imperial forces advanced on Nanjing, Westerners fled the city like rats.  At Central China Army HQ, a member of Prince Yasuhiko Asaka's staff determines that the time has come for a demarche against the West.  Japan will show them that they are in China only with our sufferance.  Over two dozen aircraft attack and sink the USS Panay, an American gunboat on the Yangtze near Nanjing.  The US oil tankers nearby are also set ablaze and sunk.  An army gunboat approaches the sinking American naval vessel and rakes it repeatedly with machine gun fire.  The Foreign Office in Tokyo is aghast when they hear the news.

After the outbreak of the Chinese incident there was a gradual increase of U.S. economic and political pressure on Japan. The 'Hull note' that Japan received on 26th November, was regarded as an ultimatum that Japan could not accept and following a number of cabinet meetings, a strategy for war against Britain and the U.S. was agreed upon. Plans called for the conquest of the Philippines within 53 days, Malaya after 100 days and the East Indies within 150 days.  The neutralization of British and U.S. bases in the area was also a high priority.

After several days of battles involving more than 30,000 Soviet and Japanese troops, the fighting has now died down to a stalemate.  It appears the Red Army can be defeated in a battle of attrition although Army reports indicate that the Red Army artillery and tanks are very numerous and powerful.  Most of our 2500 casualties came from enemy artillery fire.

Commanders of the Kwangtung Army are reporting minor border clashes with Outer Mongolian cavalry troops along the Manchukuo border.  They recommend a higher readiness for local garrisons and request additional air support.  It appears that the Soviet troops did not learn from the Changkufeng battle last year.

All the way up until the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor there was extensive trade between the USA and Japan. With the increase in Japanese aggression in the Pacific the USA tried to put bans on exports of certain goods through legislation, but Japan countered this by buying through third party countries.
With the continued aggression by Japan in the Pacific the U.S. government wanted to stop all exports to Japan.  This time they did not listen to the lobbyists.

All the way up until the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor there was extensive trade between the USA and Japan. With the increase in Japanese aggression in the Pacific the USA tried to put bans on exports of certain goods through legislation, but Japan countered this by re-import through third party countries.
After cracking the main Dutch defenses on Java the Dutch are at our mercy.

While Japan originally faced few problems in occupying parts of China and Indochina they would gradually come under pressure from guerilla attacks.  Attacks on outposts, sabotage against supply lines and attacks on Japanese garrison units became common in the occupied territories.  In China, the irregular warfare was primarily by the Communist forces controlled by Mao Zedong while in Indochina it was the Viet Minh (who would later fight the French).  Due to the inability of Japanese forces to secure the vast territories conquered, the guerillas could always find a weakly defended target and their attacks were often quite successful.

With the new Chinese government taking orders from Tokyo, the time has come to fully assert Japanese control over the Chinese army.  Officers will be assigned to every Chinese formation to ensure discipline and control.  Chinese equipment will be replaced with superior Japanese technology and supplies, but as payment the Japanese governors will take control over Chinese industry and many industries will be moved to Japan.  Some ministers are arguing that a reduced program, limiting both tech transfer and industry relocation, will be less costly in the short term and less likely to cause dissent in China.

In June 1937, the Hayashi government fell and Konoe Funimaro came to power.  While he initially tried to balance the growing influence of the military, after the Marco Polo Bridge he became increasingly militaristic.  It was his cabinet that handed the conduct of the China Incident to the military, with no government oversight.  Konoe Funimaro would later conclude alliance agreements with Germany, issue the National Mobilization Law, establish the Shin Taisei and Taisei Yokusankai.

Ultimately the government of Konoe Funimaro failed to resolve the diplomatic conflict with the United States.  As tensions increased, Konoe Funimaro once more resigned and Tojo Hideki took over as Prime Minister.

As the diplomatic situation with the United States became increasingly tense, the former Prime Minister Konoe Funimaro was asked to return.  He was seen as the only man who could guide Japan through a very difficult situation.
The failure to bring the Chinese incident to a close led to the resignation of the Prime Minister Konoe Funimaro in 1939.

After the 2-2-6 incident, there were 3 candidates for the post of Prime Minister.  Konoe Funimaro was chosen but refused because he sympathized with the coup attempt.  Historically, Hirota Koki was chosen instead.

Hamada was opposed to the growing influence of the military and the expansion programs.  When he gave his Harakiri speech it led to the resignation of the Minister of War, Terauchi Hisaichi, and eventually the fall of the Hirota cabinet.

Despite many calls for clemency, the government took a hard line with the conspirators and coup-makers of the 2-2-6 Incident.  Most of them were executed without trial, but ultimately this policy failed to stop the growing power of Kodoha-influenced officers in the Japanese government.

On 26th February 1936, Kodoha junior officers from units in the Tokyo area staged a coup d'Ètat.  In the early morning, 1400 officers and men embarked on missions to eliminate the political leaders of Japan.  Their victims included Lord Keeper of the Privy Seal Saito Makoto, Finance Minister Takahashi Korekiyo and Army Inspector General Watanabe Jotaro.  Intended victims who escaped included Prime Minister Okada Keisuke, Grand Chamberlain Suzuki Kantaro, Prince Saionji Kinmochi and Count Makino Nobuaki.  The Kodoha forces seized control of key communications and administrative facilities and for several days the outcome hung in the balance.

The Kodoha (Imperial Way Faction) was a right wing association of junior and field grade Imperial Army officers.  They worked to dismantle the influence of political parties in Japan and to restore the Showa Emperor as an absolute ruler with the Army as his main instrument of policy.  The organization was influenced by political writers like Kira Ikki, Gondo Seikei and Okawa Shumei as well as the ideology of the Kokyrukai (Amur River Society).  Many of the Kodoha officers had little regard for democratic process and were prepared to use violence to bring the Emperor to power.

In April 1942, the National Finance Control Board was established under the Financial Control Organization Order.  The Board operated under the Bank of Japan and worked to strengthen government control over funding as well to establish central clearing systems for domestic exchanges.  They also brought more aggressive government involvement into the business operations of all financial institutions.

In February 1942, with the war against the USA underway, laws were passed to establish the Wartime Finance Bank and the Southern Development Bank.  Both institutions raised funds through bond issues and loaned it to military industries and various ventures such as hydro-electric generators, electrical power companies, shipbuilders and the petroleum industry.  The Southern Development Bank notes were generally used as military scrip and by the end of the war they had issued loans of 13 billion yen.

With the outbreak of war in Europe inflation levels started increasing throughout the world.  Increases in the levels of speculative investing using operational funds forced the introduction of the Banking Management Order.  This used the provisions of the National Mobilization Law to place all financial-institution lending activities under government control, including loans of operating funds that had previously been exempted from the Temporary Funding Adjustment Law.

With the outbreak of war in China, the Japanese government increasingly depended on bond issues.  From 1936 to end of 1937, the outstanding bonds increased from 685 million yen to 2,230 million yen.  This led to inflation and forced the government to impose stricter control on banks, foreign exchange and every other aspect of the Japanese financial systems.  In September 1937, the Temporary Funding Adjustment Law brought in even more controls, allowed for more bond issues at preferential rates and diverted funding and private sector savings into arms industries.
In order to ensure supplies and manpower for the military-industrial complex, the government today passed the Wartime special ordinance Act.

Japanese archaeologists today announced a major discovery, referred to as the Toro Site.  This is a late Yayoi period (BC 300 to AD 300) site and features pit houses, raised storehouses, paddy fields and an irrigation system.  The site covers an area of 33,000 square meters.
News have just come through that there has been a major derailment accident in the Ishigami station yard.

After great expense and long labor, the railway tunnel under the Kammon Strait is now complete.  This links southwestern Honshu with northern Kyushu and as part of the project there has been major infrastructure upgrades that will benefit local industry.

Tokyo police has arrested Ozaki and Sorge, the latter a German journalist, for espionage.  According to the police statement, the men were spying for the Soviet Union.  After three years in prison, the men were executed in 1944.
Today it was announced that Kokumin Gakko, a compulsory school system to train the loyal subjects of the Emperor, will be implemented throughout the country.
Today saw massive celebrations across the entire country as Japan marked the 2600th anniversary of it's founding as a sovereign nation.
Massive investments in infrastructure and industry finally paid off today as the Hitachi works in Katsuta were opened.  This will provide a great boost to the war effort.

The Japanese government abolished all political parties and replaced them with the Taisei Yokusankai (Imperial Rule Assistance Association) in a move that spelled the end of democracy in Japan and soon saw the rise of Tojo Hideki to absolute power.

In an effort to ensure adequate supply of labor in strategic industries, the government today passed the National Service Ordinance.  This will allow them to relocate people as needed to work in coal mines, armament industries etc.

In an effort to boost the war effort the government has passed the National Mobilization Law.  This will provide subsidies for war production and give control over the corporations, newspapers and labor organizations.  It will also limit consumer commodities and introduce price and contract controls.  Ultimately, this law will allow the government to use all the resources and manpower of the country to prosecute the war.

In a passionate speech today, the minister Araki Sadao called for a spiritual mobilization and consolidation of public moral support of the war.  The minister called for people to unite under slogans such as 'One hundred million hearts beating as one' (ichioku isshin) and 'The eight corners of the world under one roof' (hakkoo ichiu)
During 1938 and 1939, ten professors at the University of Tokyo were ousted from their positions due to their political stance.

The Japanese Prime Minister, Konoe Funimaro, today announced a new policy of non-recognition of the KMT leadership in China and called for a new order to be established in East Asia.  Additional forces were mobilized to enforce this new policy.
In 1937, Seiranso, a new sanatorium for tuberculosis, opened in the Muramatsu district.
During 1937 and 1938, some 400 liberals and leftists were arrested as the Japanese government cracked down on various political groups.

When the Japanese military learned of the British and American unwillingness to allow force parity they were outraged.  Japan withdrew from the treaty rather than accept limitations that would not allow them a sufficient navy to defend their country.

On 11th November 1940, Schiff 16 (the raider ship Atlantis) encountered the British cargo ship Automedon.  Shelling destroyed the bridge and killed the officers on the British ship, allowing the Germans to board and capture Top Secret mail for the High Command (Far East), new code tables, and a War Cabinet report on British forces, defenses of Singapore, information regarding Australia and New Zealand, and an appraisal of Japanese intentions. The documents, along with 10,000 tons of aviation fuel, were sent to Japan. Some believe these documents influenced the Japanese decision to go to war against the Allies.

A vote has passed in the League of Nations condemning our legitimate insertions into China. It cannot be avoided that this may have some impact on our ability to convince others that our policy is legitimate.

The Australian and Japanese governments negotiated a textile trade agreement in response to the Australian tariff increase. The Australian government agreed to import as many Japanese textile products up to the 1934 level, while the Japanese pledged to purchase a specified amount of Australian wool. This agreement also helped to defuse some of the tension developing in Japan.

In response to increased competition on the Asian markets the Australian government imposed a new and higher tariff rate policy which replaced the more modest tariff rates of 1932. This move is having a serious impact on our textile exports.

In an early morning radio broadcast, the Japanese government announced the decision to cease all military resistance and lay down arms.  All military units were instructed to return to base and await the arrival of occupation forces for disarmament and processing prior to being sent home.

As invading forces controlled all the Japanese Home Isles the Emperor and the government faced a difficult choice.  Japanese forces in overseas holdings could fight on to the bitter end as honor demanded, but victory did not seem likely and the loss of life would be enormous.  To avoid crippling Japan the choice of surrender had to be considered.

As invading forces controlled all the Japanese Home Isles the Emperor and the government faced a difficult choice.  Japanese forces in overseas holdings could fight on to the bitter end as honor demanded, but victory did not seem likely and the loss of life would be enormous.  To avoid crippling Japan the choice of surrender had to be considered.
The tides of war shift and change, lending us another opportunity to review the treaty status with the USSR.

While the Soviet Union battled the advancing German army on the steppes of Russia, Japan was busy pushing back the Chinese army in mainland China: neither country could afford a second war front.  Japan initialized a neutrality treaty with the USSR that maintained a separate peace between the two countries, even though Japan was one of the Big Three and formally a member of the Axis.
Mexico has sent us a proposal for a trade deal. They would like to buy supplies from us in exchange for military supplies.

The Chinese leadership showed that they fully understood the concept of total war when they destroyed the Huayuankow Dike, causing a massive flood in the Yellow River area. Thousands of Japanese soldiers drowned and all military operations came to an abrupt halt, but the civilian destruction was immense.  Eleven cities and four thousand villages were destroyed, causing several hundred thousand civilian deaths and making millions homeless.  Years later, the people of the flooded provinces would remember the ruthlessness of the KMT and be among the first to rise up against the KMT when the Chinese civil war resumed.

As the China incident continued to escalate and Japan landed additional troops in north China, the Chinese army moved against the Japanese SNLF garrison in Shanghai. Fierce battles raged in the streets and the Japanese faced the choice between executing a hurried amphibious landing operation to relieve the beleaguered garrison or to evacuate Japanese citizens from the city.  Due to the size of the Japanese population in Shanghai an evacuation would be an expensive and difficult operation, with a high risk for civilian casualties.

As the China incident escalated to full warfare in northern China, Japanese authorities were no longer able to protect Japanese citizens in Tsing-tao against the anger of the Chinese people. In the face of increasing numbers of violent attacks on Japanese property and citizens, the authorities ordered a full evacuation.

Japanese garrison troops in Feng-Tai, southwest of Peiping, clashed with Chinese forces at the Marco Polo Bridge. The battle was only a local incident and negotiations quickly restored order, but the terms of the settlement were later violated by Chinese troops. There were incidents again at the bridge, as well as at Kwang-an-men and Lang-Fang.
Japanese garrison troops in Feng-Tai, southwest of Peiping, clashed with Chinese forces at the Marco Polo Bridge. The battle was only a local incident and hurried negotiations quickly restored order.

The Tripartite Pact divided the world into spheres of influence. The former German colonies in the Pacific clearly fell into the Japanese sphere. Now that France, Great Britain and Australia are defeated, Germany had to cede Kaiser-Wilhelm-Land, the Mariane Islands, Marshall Islands and the Samoas to her ally Japan.

Germany put considerable weight into negotiations with Japan over the recognition of Manchukuo. The Japanese government offered considerable trade concessions, including strategic materials critical to German industry. Signing of the agreement meant the end to German trade with China. Following the German recognition of Manchukuo, Japan committed to shipping strategic materials for use in Germany industry to make up for shortfalls from the cessation of Chinese shipments but historically the shipments were never made.

Germany put considerable weight into negotiations with Japan over the recognition of Manchukuo. The Japanese government offered considerable trade concessions, including strategic materials critical to German industry. Signing of the agreement meant the end to German trade with China. Following the German recognition of Manchukuo, Japan committed to shipping strategic materials for use in Germany industry to make up for shortfalls from the cessation of Chinese shipments but historically these shipments were never made.

The Germans provision of extensive military support to the Chinese did not go unnoticed. The Japanese believed that this interference by a European power was unacceptable, leading them to lodge strong protests with the German ambassador, even going so far as to demand the immediate recall of the German mission from China.
This is a major change in Japan's policy.
The Japanese claims in northern China must be recognized. The Imperial Army will enforce our will on the Chinese bandits.
With the final surrender of Dutch forces, Japan has gained control over the rich colonies in the Dutch East Indies.
With this Pact, Japan's claims in Asia are recognized. Germany will rule northern Europe and Italy shall control the Mediterranean lands.
In a move to contain the destabilizing influence of the Comintern, Germany is offering to sign a five year Anti-Comintern Pact with Japan.
After long negotiations, the Nationalist Chinese have agreed to recognize Japan as their overlords in return for most Chinese territory.
The Nationalists have rejected our peace offers. We can continue this battle to the end or create a new puppet state and let them fight this war for us.

The Chinese incident has gone too far and our army will be overstretched if we continue to advance and fight the Nationalists. We must seek peace with Chiang Kai-Shek to allow new focus in more important theaters of operations.
As Japanese forces advanced on Nanjing the diplomats from western countries were evacuated. Several U.S. diplomatic staff were on the gunboat 'Panay' when it was attacked by Japanese aircraft.
This is our opportunity to strike at Vladivostok and the Siberian resources! We must join the Axis forces.

The victorious armed forces of Japan seek new direction for expansion. There are great resources to be found in Soviet-held Siberia, but also among the colonial areas of south east Asia and the Pacific region.
Japanese forces have defeated the USSR and are now free to fight in other theatres.

Kwantung Army commanders report that a Soviet counter-attack with more than 300 tanks and hundreds of armored cars has been stopped by the defenders of Hill 721.  This is an enormous defeat for the Soviet forces and it has seriously compromised their position and influence in the Far East.  Signal intercept reports that the enemy commander, General Zhukov, has been relieved of his command and placed under arrest.

Kwantung Army commanders report enemy counter-attacked with more than 300 tanks and hundreds of armored cars.  Our position on Hill 721 has been lost after days of hard fighting and our remaining forces are being pushed east of Nomonhan village.  We must seek terms at once or face the collapse of our front!

After several weeks of fighting and heavy losses on both sides, the Soviet leadership has accepted our terms and withdrawn their troops from Nomonhan village and Halha River.  This has proven that the Imperial Army is superior to the Red Army.

The earlier border clashes have escalated and our troops are being hard pressed by several Soviet brigades.  The Kwangtung Army commander is requesting immediate reinforcements and air support in order to be able to retake the initiative.  An offensive is planned to take Nomonhan village and drive on the west bank of the Halha.

With the invasion of the Soviet Union, the fascist regime in Italy was able to whip up a frenzy of support for the Axis, even, and especially, from the Catholic Church which blessed soldiers as they left for the 'Crusade Against the Godless East'. Even after sending an entire Army Corps as an expeditionary force to help the Germans, still thousands of Italians volunteered to join the Heer while Italy's own Armed Forces drastically needed the manpower.

The Austrian government has announced that it does not wish to sign the II. Roman Protocols. This brings the idea of co-operation in the Danubian area to counter the German interests in the region to an end.

The Hungarian government has announced that it does not wish to sign the II. Roman Protocols. This brings the idea of co-operation in the Danubian area to counter the German interests in the region to an end.

Vienna Conference representatives of the Danubian Protocol States (Austria, Hungary, and Italy) met in Vienna to discuss European tensions. The conference marked the gradual consolidation of Italian power in the Danubian Basin.
During the Budapest Conference, Hungarian officials have announced that they no longer wish to maintain the Danubian Protocols.
During the Budapest Conference, Hungarian officials have announced that they no longer wish to maintain the Danubian Protocols.
During the Budapest Conference Austrian officials have confirmed their interest in maintaining the Danubian Protocols.
During the Budapest Conference Hungarian officials have confirmed their interest in maintaining the Danubian Protocols.
Representatives of the Austrian, Hungarian, and Italian governments reaffirmed the protocols between the three states to maintain the status quo in Danubian region.
The attempts made between the countries in the Danubian region to create a counterpart to the German interest have failed
The Austrian Government has decided to sign the II. Roman Protocols and thereby create a counterpart to the German interests in the Danubian region.
The Hungarian Government has decided to sign the II. Roman Protocols and thereby create a counterpart to the German interests in the Danubian region.

The Austrian government has announced that it does not wish to renew the Danubian Pact. This brings the idea of co-operation in the Danubian area to counter the German interests in the region to an end.

The Hungarian government has announced that it does not wish to renew the Danubian Pact. This brings the idea of co-operation in the Danubian area to counter the German interests in the region to an end.

Italy, Austria and Hungary signed an anti-Nazi mutual defense treaty in Rome. In the time Italy was losing its power in the region of Danube, the leaders of Hungary tried to make approaches to Germany. However, Germany and Hungary barely had common points in their foreign policy conceptions so Hungary decided to strengthen its bounds with Italy, despite of their increasing alienation.

Yugoslavia has decided to purchase SIAI Savoia Marchetti SM-79-I heavy bomber designs from us. This has increased our international prestige, and given us leverage in future dealings with the Yugoslav government.

Yugoslavia has approached our government with the possibility of purchasing the designs for our heavy bomber aircraft, SIAI Savoia Marchetti SM-79-I. This represents an excellent opportunity to demonstrate our technical prowess to the world, as well as gain some influence with the Yugoslav government.

Hungarian government has approached with the intent to buy a number of our CV 35 tankettes from us, including the designs. This could be a chance for us to improve relations between our two countries and showcase our military industry in the international arena.

Following the declaration of Croatian independence, the provinces comprising the mainland Banovina Hrvatska, a Croatian administrative entity, have been turned over to Croatia without a fight. As Banovina Hrvatska was in many ways a sovereign administrative body, controlled by a Croatian national majority, this arrangement will suit us greatly for the moment.

Negotiations in Rome with the representatives of the newly-formed Independent State of Croatia have gone well. Croatia has agreed to secede Dalmatia to us, fulfilling our territorial demands, while also agreeing to allow Duke Sapoleto to become King of Croatia, Tomislav II. We are now effectively in control of Croatia, while having also resolved a festering territorial problem.

We have an opportunity to return the Croatian nationalist Ustashe activists wanted for terrorism to Yugoslavia. They have used our country as a base for their political activity for a while, and now Yugoslav government is demanding that they be deported back to their country for processing.

Leaders of the Croatian nationalist Ustashe movement have asked us for financial support in establishing training camps for their paramilitary forces. Giving them aid will strengthen them and their campaign will likely destabilize Yugoslavia and please parts of our public. On the other hand, the ensuing diplomatic mess will be costly to clear up, and ignoring these malcontents might give us some influence with the Yugoslav government. Historically, Italy, Hungary, and Bulgaria assisted the Ustashe, while Italy and Hungary provided for their training camps in late 1930s.

We've signed a non-aggression pact with Yugoslavia. This treaty also involves a political and an economic agreement. We have undertaken to respect our common frontiers on land and on the Adriatic Sea. This diplomatic coup has shown to other nations that we are capable of resolving our differences peacefully. Historically, Count Gian Galeazzo Ciano of Italy and Premier Milan Stojadinovic of Yugoslavia signed the pact in Belgrade on 26th March 1937.

After Spanish civil war Mussolini sent aid to Spain to rebuild the country. It was officially given to help the Church of Spain, so it was a good diplomatic move that pleased the Vatican and the rest of Europe. It was very useful to Italy to keep Spain as friendly and close as possible because of the obvious strategic advantages of having a possible ally in the Mediterranean. Even as a non-belligerent, the idea of having bases in Spanish territory was very seductive for Mussolini. Historically, Franco used that help from Italy to rebuild the Spanish Church, as intended, but also to build the huge 'Valle de los Caidos', a spectacular and monumental mausoleum for the national, Italian and German soldiers killed during the war. It was also where Franco was to be buried after his death.

After Italy invaded Europe, England started on a major campaign in the League of Nations to have international sanctions imposed on Italy.  This behavior came across as extremely hypocritical to the Italian public

After Italy's surrender in 1943, there remained pro-fascist Italian troops willing to continue the struggle on the side of Germany. Some 15,000 Italian volunteers spent a period of time training in the south of Germany, returning as the SS Legion Italia. Originally used in anti-partisan operations in February 1944, Himmler was reluctant to grant the unit full Waffen-SS status. But in 1944, when troops of the SS Legiona Italia distinguished themselves in action against the Allied landings at Anzio, Himmler proclaimed them full units of the SS. Later, the SS Legion Italia was granted full divisional status. Elements of the division lasted to the last days of the war, when having run out of ammunition, they unwisely surrendered to the partisans, who massacred the survivors to a man.
The Albanian and Italian governments have signed a new series of agreements on financial and trade relations, which provided the Italians with even greater control over Albania.
Following the refusal of the Greeks to submit to our reasonable demands, we are left with no choice but to take by force what is rightfully ours.
The Mexican government has approached us suggesting that they would buy consumer goods from us and pay for them with oil.
War has broken out and we are must completely mobilize our nation.
In 1938, the Italian army underwent a major military reform which drastically increased the size of the army.

The Italian government sent a diplomatic note to the French indicating that the Franco-Italian Agreement of 1935 was invalid because the two states had not exchanged ratifications. The French government rejected this position.
The French government recognized the Italian conquest of Ethiopia in an effort to gain Italian support against German expansion.
Pope Pius IX, in response to the anti-clericalism of the Republican government, supported General Francisco Franco and formally recognized the Nationalist government in Spain.

American aviator Amelia Earhart arrived in Massawa in Eritrea with her navigator Fred Noonan today. This stop is part of her flight to circumnavigate the globe. She will flying down to Assab down on the coast tomorrow and then will fly across the Arabian Sea to Karachi, India. From there, she will continue across India, Siam, British Malaya, and the Dutch East Indies on her way to Australia. From there she will fly north to Honolulu and then to her goal of Oakland, California.

Adolf Hitler outdid himself on Mussolini's state visit to Germany in September 1937. Sensing the Duce's frustration over Italy's treatment by England and feeling an actual kinship with the Italian Dictator, Hitler treated Mussolini to five days of parades, rallies, and official visits. Hitler would even grant a request of Mussolini's to view the ultra secret armament factories of Krupp Steel. Even downpours and guffaws by the German military wouldn't sour Mussolini's mood. In the largest international media event of the time, millions around the world would hear Mussolini and Hitler surprisingly declare that Fascism and National Socialism were equal political movements in the Olympic Stadium. While the international community knew the day would come for a fascist alliance, the magnitude of the event hung a cloud of inevitability of war over Europe. For morale purposes, England would not transmit the event.

Benito Mussolini threatened to go to war with Germany if it proceeded with the imminent annexation of Austria in 1934. Strangely, this marked a major turning point in Italian politics that would come to Germany's advantage. France and England both failed to make good on their promises to support Italy and were seemingly willing to toss Italy to the wolves. Hitler backed down, and as the dust settled the Fascist Administration in Italy began to wonder why it was risking war for the seemingly impotent and scheming Western Powers. By 1937, Italy's international relations had done a 180 degree turn and German-Italian relations were at an all time high. Hitler took advantage of this by offering Mussolini a National Tour of his Third Reich

In 1938, Benito Mussolini sent his loyal minion Riccardo Federici to the United Colonies of Eritrea, Somalia, and Ethiopia (known as the Africa Orientale Italiana) to report on the progress of the Viceroy of Ethiopia (then Emilio De Bono) in civilizing (i.e. industrializing) the colony for Italy's use. In a scathing report, he made it quite clear that there was a yawning gap between the promise of the empire and the actions of the men who had arrived at the colony. Incidences of corruption, exploitation, and infighting in the Fascist Administration were rampant.  Ordinary Italian settlers and soldiers were reduced to living in huts with the populace whilst money was squandered. Historically, Mussolini replaced Emilio De Bono with Pietro Badoglio as Viceroy

The New Roman Empire is born! We have achieved our goals in north Africa and the Middle East, expanding both our territories and puppet key states throughout the region. May the New Roman Empire last a thousand years!

The British are suing for peace! They are willing to hand over all north African holdings (including all Egyptian claimed provinces) and territories to expand our Ethiopian colony. All Mediterranean bases (except Gibraltar) will now be under our control and our claim on Saudi Arabia will be recognized. Jerusalem and Amman are also to be seceded to Italy. Egypt, Iraq, and Syria are to be reconstituted and their independence recognized by both Italy and England. Syria is to secede Rawah, Iraq is to secede Mosul and At Turayg, and Egypt is to secede all holdings west of the Nile except Al Minyah and Sawhaj. Shall we accept the peace proposal?

Italy faces two problems: the alienation of the western nations and a new Independent State of Croatia forming between its new territories. Italy may be able to restore relations with the western nations by a partition of the remaining Yugoslav provinces with Italy's new neighbors. There are three disputed provinces currently under Italy's control: Pristina, Novi Sad, and Skopje. With regards to Croatia, the new country is still in its elemental state.
The Italian army marches through the streets of Belgrade.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1938 Nobel Prize in Physics. This year's laureate is Enrico Fermi (Italy), for his demonstrations of the existence of new radioactive elements produced by neutron irradiation, and for his related discovery of nuclear reactions brought about by slow neutrons.

The College of Cardinals elected Engenio Pacelli as the new pope, Pius XII. He had served for several years as the papal secretary of state and chief advisor to Pope Pius XI. The new pope had a reputation for a strong will, an astute character, and diplomatic skill. Pius XII immediately set out to avoid a general war in Europe, but his efforts did not reflect a change in policy from Pius XI.

Pope Pius IX died at the height of European tensions between fascism, communism, and democracy. Pius IX gained an international reputation for standing firm against any regime which threatened religion or the rights of the individual. As a result, his policies often challenged the Communists and the Fascists.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Foreign Secretary Lord Halifax conducted an official visit to Rome to confer with Italian Premier Benito Mussolini. The British leaders hoped to find some leverage with the Italians to maintain the status quo in the Mediterranean.

The Italian government issued a series of demands for French colonies (especially Tunisia and Corsica) and other concessions. In response, the French government took an uncompromising attitude towards the cessation of any colonies to the Italians.
The Italian government issued a series of demands for French colonies (especially Tunisia and Corsica) and other concessions.

The British and Italian governments agreed to mutually respect each other's interests and rights in the Mediterranean and the maintenance of Spanish independence and integrity. The British government hoped to end tensions in the Mediterranean region as Germany was emerging as a greater threat to European security than Italy. Despite this treaty, the Italians continued to support the Nationalists in the Spanish Civil War and the British were unable to prevent military supplies from reaching the belligerents. The British sought to use the non-intervention agreements as a means to prevent the expansion of the Spanish Civil War into a general war, but the Italians flagrantly violated this principle.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler conducted an official state visit to Rome. Premier Benito Mussolini provided an impressive state reception to demonstrate the solidarity of the Rome-Berlin Axis.

In light of the recently attempted oil embargo against Italy by the League of Nations as well as Mussolini's revisionist foreign policy the Italian government has announced its withdrawal from the League of Nations.
Austria decided to sign the renewal of the Danubian pact. This should make us stronger against Germany.
Hungary decided to sign the renewal of the Danubian pact. This should make us stronger against Germany.
The governments of Austria, Hungary, and Italy agreed to extend their defensive treaty until 30th June 1938, as a means to deter German expansion in central Europe.
The Yemeni Imam has refused to sign a renewal of the Italian-Yemeni treaty for the next 25 years.
The Yemeni Imam has signed a renewal of the Italian-Yemeni treaty for the next 25 years.

The Italian and Yemeni governments agreed to renew their 1926 treaty for a period of 25 years. The Imam of Yemen occupied a strategic point in the Red Sea and strove to maintain his independence between Saudi Arabia, Britain, France, and Italy.

Although the Swiss government partially participated in the economic sanctions against Italy in response to the Ethiopian crisis, the government decided to recognize the Italian conquest. Fascist aspirations for incorporation of the Italian-speaking cantons of Switzerland, the conclusion of the Rome-Berlin Axis, and the collapse of the League of Nations collective security system persuaded the Swiss to avoid tensions with the Italians.
Pope Pius IX again condemned Communism in a papal encyclical aimed primarily at the Soviets and their campaign against religion.

Premier Benito Mussolini conducted an official visit to the Italian colony of Libya where he declared his interest and friendship for Muslims around the world. He permitted the Arabs to hail him as the protector of Islam and accepted the sword of Islam. This announcement challenged Anglo-French dominance over the Arab states and they accused the Italians of passing subversive propaganda in North Africa, Egypt, Palestine, and Syria.

While the import restrictions imposed on Italy by the League of Nations had only little effect on Italy's ability to purchase the needed goods, the bad publicity gained by the Italian campaign in Ethiopia had a great impact on Italian exports. This forces the Italian government into a dilemma. They can either try and boost the economy by devaluating the Lire or watch as companies go out of business. The Italian people felt that they were becoming increasingly isolated by the democratic powers in Europe and that strength could only be regained by drawing closer to Germany.

Despite the government line, the Italian Army was completely unprepared to wage a large scale modern war due to a multitude of logistical and organizational problems. However, as long as Italy was able to concentrate on only one front these problems did not manifest strongly, as shown by successes of the Italian Army in Ethiopia. As Italy found itself declaring war on more and more countries and opening up additional fronts in Yugoslavia, Greece, Africa and Russia, the problems began to manifest themselves with disastrous consequences.
We have just received word that German customs have stopped the supplies that we sent to for Finland. The trucks had to return to the supply depot.
With all those countries wanting to help Finland it might help us internationally if we send some aid as well. Should we send them some supplies?

The Vatican has decided that it can no longer overlook the atrocities committed in Finland. Today Pope Pius XII sent a formal condemnation to the Soviet government on behalf of the many Catholics that suffer unnecessarily because of the Soviet attack on Finland.

After Haile Selassie fled to London, the Italians discovered that it would not be an easy task to pacify Ethiopia. A few local Rases continued to resist and launch guerilla attacks on their conquerors. A few submitted, but as long as Italy did not have the Ethiopian nobility on her side there would be no peace in Africa Orientale Italiana. Mussolini tried to bribe the exiled Emperor with 1 million pounds and nominal sovereignty in order to satisfy the Ethiopian people's desire to be led by their Emperor.

After Haile Selassie fled to London, the Italians discovered that it would not be an easy task to pacify Ethiopia. A few local Rases continued to resist and launch guerilla attacks on their conquerors. A few submitted, but as long as Italy did not have the Ethiopian nobility on her side there would be no peace in Africa Orientale Italiana. Mussolini tried to bribe the exiled Emperor with 1 million pounds and nominal sovereignty in order to satisfy the Ethiopian people's desire to be led by their Emperor.

After stunning German success in France, Italy joined Axis and began aggressive moves in the Balkans and Africa. Mussolini's dream of new 'Roman Empire' was visibly at hand. As a part of this plan, Italy issued an ultimatum to the Greek dictator General Metaxas, demanding that he secede several strategic provinces in Greece, or face war (historically on 28th October 1940).
Our military industry is highly dependent on coal imports from Germany with 6 to 12 million tons imported every year.

After Haile Selassie fled to London, the Italians discovered that it would not be an easy task to pacify Ethiopia. A few local Rases continued to resist and launch guerilla attacks on their conquerors. A few submitted, but as long as Italy did not have the Ethiopian nobility on her side there would be no peace in Africa Orientale Italiana. Mussolini tried to bribe the exiled Emperor with 1 million pounds and nominal sovereignty in order to satisfy the Ethiopian people's desire to be led by their Emperor.

In the years preceding the Second World War, many countries exported modern technologies to the USSR, thus contributing to the rapid industrialization of the Soviet Union. Even countries whose ideology was in extreme opposition to communism often decided to take the opportunity to earn money and influence from Soviet industrial development. Italy was one of these countries: their naval technology was vital to the development of the large Soviet Navy.

The German annexation of Austria posed a potentially great threat to Italian borders, despite the creation of the Rome-Berlin Axis. Mussolini's dilemma was whether to follow the demands of his people, who wanted to remain friends with the UK and France, or those of his fellow fascist dictator, Adolf Hitler, and the third Reich.

At the outbreak of the Spanish Civil War, Mussolini sent some commanders as military advisors or leaders of specific units to Spain. In contrast with Germany, Italy didn't take as much advantage of the experience gained during the war, possibly because its intervention was much less of a decisive factor in the war. Tons of Italian weaponry were shipped to Spain, along with the means to manufacture them. If Germany had not shipped its weapons to Spain, Franco would have been forced to rely on Italian weaponry to win the war, and instead of the Mauser, Rebel troops probably would have been armed with Mannlicher rifles.

When the Italian armistice with the Allies was signed, the Germans established the Repubblica Sociale Italiana with the objective of continuing the fighting in Italy. German troops in the Balkans prepared to take control of Axis-occupied provinces. Most Italian forces in the region received the news of the armistice with optimism, wishing to receive orders to go home. Instead they were caught by surprise by the Germans. They were forced to turn their weapons over to Wehrmacht and SS units, and then were taken prisoner. Some units thought this was a dishonor to the Italian army and chose to fight against the Germans. Though a few soldiers and officers were able to escape and return home before being captured, most of the Italian Forces in the Balkans were imprisoned or executed.

On the night of 8th September 1943, as Field Marshal Badoglio, the new Italian prime minister, was signing a peace treaty with the Allies, German forces surrounded Rome and took over most of the northern provinces. Badoglio and the Royal family quickly fled to Allied territory while the Germans established a new puppet government in the controlled provinces. This was the Repubblica Sociale Italiana, under the nominal command of Mussolini, who was rescued from his imprisonment by German paratroopers. After that, half of Italy stood under the control of Germany and the new fascist regime, and the other half was in Allied hands. The situation dictated that Allied Italy would have to fight alongside Allied forces to retake its lost territory.

The desperation of Mussolini was an evident sign that fascist Italy was about to crumble and seek a separate peace with the Allies. Since the very first signs, the German High Command prepared plans to mobilize their troops in Italy to prevent the country from surrendering and to re-establish a fascist puppet government. On the night of 8th September 1943, as Field Marshal Badoglio, the new Italian prime minister, was signing a peace treaty with the Allies, German forces surrounded Rome and took over most of the northern provinces. Badoglio and the Royal family quickly fled to Allied territory while the Germans established a new puppet government in the controlled provinces. This was the Repubblica Sociale Italiana, under the nominal command of Mussolini, who was rescued from his imprisonment by German paratroopers.
After the capitulation of Italy, England took control of most parts of Italy to prepare for the advance on mainland Europe.
After the capitulation of Italy, United States took control of most parts of Italy to prepare for the advance on mainland Europe.

The secret negotiations between Badoglio and the Allies eventually developed into an Allied final offer. The terms were harsh, but Italy was exhausted and had little choice. The treaty stipulated that Italy leave the Axis and sign peace with the Allies and the Soviet Union, return the prisoners on Italian soil, surrender all military arsenal weapons, and grant the Allies control over most of the country, establishing a military government. Obviously, Hitler was furious when Italy left the Axis, and the German troops on Italian soil, stationed in Rome and other important cities, tried to take over the country, but the defensive situation was desperate even for German forces. Finally, Badoglio signed the armistice on 8th September 1943, as Allied troops advanced deeper into Italian territory.

After the change of government in Italy, Field Marshal Badoglio immediately initiated secret contacts with the Allied powers in order to abandon the war and seek a separate peace. The Allies offered Italy a two-part surrender agreement

After Italy had lost all its African colonies and the Allies were landing in Sicily, it was clear that the country could not continue the war. The Italian population was sick of it, the armed forces were demoralized and humiliated, and the economy was close to ruin. The long series of military disasters and defeats had ruined the credibility and popularity of Mussolini as a politician and as a leader. On 24th July 1943, the Great Fascist Council met and voted to retire Mussolini from the government. Following the Dino Grandi proposal, King Victor Emmanuel was restored to authority, bringing the fascist regime to its end. The proposal was seconded even by Ciano, Mussolini's son-in-law. The King assigned Field Marshal Badoglio to form a new government, Mussolini was arrested, and the first necessary measures to negotiate with the invading Allied forces were initiated.
Italo Balbo was an Italian pilot and politician. He served as officer in the Italian Army the during the First World War.
The Ethiopians refused the Italian offer of Mogadishu and Obbia in exchange for peace.
Italy agreed to a peace treaty with Ethiopia in exchange for Mogadishu and Obbia.
The Ethiopians refused the Italian offer of Asmara in exchange for peace.
Italy agreed to a peace treaty with Ethiopia in exchange for Asmara.

The war against Ethiopia was not as easy as the Italian government thought it would be. The hard climatic conditions as well as the rough terrain were often decisive factors that the Ethiopians took good advantage of. Italy suffered a humiliating defeat by being expelled out of Africa by a poor, third-world country.  The Italian army appeared unprepared to fight a serious war. The Ethiopians demanded Italian dominions in East Africa in exchange for a peace agreement.
Unrest in Ethiopia has grown out of control.  Native warriors are forming into large war bands and taking up arms against the Italian garrisons.

When Benito Mussolini took power in Italy, one of his first objectives was to resume plans to expand Italian influence in Ethiopia, thereby taking revenge for the humiliating defeat of the Italian army in 1896. The League of Nations voiced its disgust with this new war in Abyssinia, but did not take any serious measures to try to stop it. Addis Abeba was in Italian hands by May 1936. The Duce proclaimed King Vittorio Emmanuel the new Emperor of Ethiopia, annexing it into the emerging Italian Empire.

The once proud Italian colonies of Libya tumbled down after feeling the power of the Allied offensive in North Africa. Italian citizens in North Africa desperately tried to return to Italy, but many were captured by the Allies. Some of them even were killed by the furious Libyan people. The Italian army on the African continent was in very bad shape, and morale was very low. With the fall of Libya, Italy increased conscription to prepare for the potential invasion of Southern Europe by the Allies.

The Italian nation made extensive preparations for war. The instability in Europe had once again lead to turbulent international troubles, and it was only a matter of time until the war expanded to include the involvement of Italy. Italian leadership realized the time to take measures to make the young men obey the call of duty.
With the final surrender of Dutch forces, Japanese troops take over the Dutch East Indies as this area falls into their sphere of interest.

With Paris in German hands it became clear that a new world order was emerging. In 1940, the Tripartite Pact divided the world into German, Italian and Japanese spheres of interest. Germany would rule northern Europe, and Italy would control the Mediterranean lands. Since Japan refused to sign, their claims in Asia would be disregarded.

With Paris in German hands it became clear that a new world order was emerging. In 1940, the Tripartite Pact divided the world into German, Italian and Japanese spheres of interest. Germany would rule northern Europe, Italy would control the Mediterranean lands, and Japan would control Asia.
In a move to contain the destabilizing influence of the Comintern, Germany consulted with Italy to expand the Anti-Comintern Pact.

The government of Yugoslavia has decided to purchase our R-35 tanks in large quantities. We have made useful contacts in their officer cadre and have improved the relations between our two countries. With the dark clouds looming over the Old Continent once again, we shall rest easier knowing we can rely on our old allies to assist us in the upcoming struggles.

The Italian government sent a diplomatic note to the French indicating that the Franco-Italian Agreement of 1935 was invalid because the two states had not exchanged ratifications. The French government rejected this position.

The French and German governments signed an agreement by which both states guaranteed the inviolability of the current frontiers and provided for mutual consultation to settle all disputes peacefully.

After the French government implemented a series of decrees aimed at improving the French economy at the expense of labor, the Confederation of Labor planned for a 24-hour general strike. To preempt the strike, the government militarized railway workers and requisitioned other services and threatened to deal harshly with any strikers. As a result, only a few workers went on strike, but many labor leaders were arrested. The government used national defense as the rationale to take sterner action against organized labor.

The French government finally passed a bill which devalued the value of the franc, although the legislation did not fix the franc's new gold content. Since the implementation of the new social policies under the Popular Front, production costs greatly increased in France and prices rose steadily. At the same time, capital fled the republic which undermined the value of the franc.

The government of Yugoslavia has showed an interest in purchasing large numbers of our R-35 tanks for their own use, as well as obtaining the necessary technology and licenses to produce them in Yugoslavia. Many of our officers still remember the aid Serbia gave us in the Great War, and are more then willing to assist our old allies with rearming themselves. This sale could also bring our two countries closer together.
We are at war and must mobilize the Republic.
German aggression in Czechoslovakia shows that diplomacy has failed, we must prepare for war and mobilize territorial forces.
Successful landings by the Allies in Southern France in 1944 led to the rapid collapse of the Vichy Regime, with the Axis forces putting up minor resistance.

The collapse of Vichy control in Algeria following the Allied invasions of Operation Torch led the Germans to violate the armistice with Vichy and send German troops into Vichy France without prior notification of Vichy authorities.
With the defeat of Gaullist elements in Beirut Vichy control over Lebanon was reasserted.
Allied landings in French Indochina would have led to Japan's seizure of control in all of Indochina.
In the summer of 1940, the Siamese government demanded that Vichy cede provinces in Indochina that the Siamese had been forced to give up to the French in the 1890s.
With Thai forces moving deep into Cambodia and Laos, Vichy faced expulsion from the Mekong Valley when Japan offered a settlement to the conflict.
In the summer of 1940, the Siamese government demanded that Vichy cede provinces in Indochina that the Siamese had been forced to give up to the French in the 1890s.
In the summer of 1941, the Japanese demanded an expansion of their military bases to Southern Indochina.

To meet German demands for labor collaboration between Vichy France and Germany, the Vichy French government established compulsory labor for men between the ages of 18 and 65, and for unmarried women between the ages of 20 and 35.
With the Allied takeover of Madagascar, demands for restoring the colony to Free French control would lead to its transfer to DeGaulle's control.

After disputes with the Allies over who should lead Free French forces in Algeria, the assassination of Darlan s his leadership by establishing his movement's center in Dakar, the administrative center of French West Africa
The successful Allied landings at Oran and Algiers would lead to the transfer of Algeria to DeGaulle's control.
The successful Allied landings at Casablanca would lead to the transfer of Morocco to DeGaulle's control.
The successful Allied landings at Algiers and Oran would have led Gaullists in Morocco to seize power.
The conquest of Algeria would have cut French Equatorial Africa from Vichy, leading to a change of sides by colonial administrators.
The conquest of Algeria would have cut French West Africa from Vichy, leading to a change of sides by colonial administrators.
Fearing DeGaulle's appeal would lead to a loss of control over France's colonial empire, pro-Vichy groups organized to defend their control of the Empire.
The elimination of Vichy control in French West Africa would have led to successful seizures of power by DeGaulle sympathizers in French Equatorial Africa.
With the capture of Dakar by the Allies, DeGaulle solidifies his leadership by establishing his movement's center in Dakar, the administrative center of French West Africa.
Dakar was the political center of French West Africa and the center of Vichy power. Its successful capture by the Allies would lead to French West Africa's rally to DeGaulle.
With the clearing of East Africa of Axis Forces and the British takeover of Djibouti, demands for restoring the colony to Free French control would lead to its transfer to DeGaulle's control.
The decision of the Allies to seize French Guiana to prevent the Axis a base in South America would lead to calls by DeGaulle to restore it to his authority.

Because the USA and Vichy were not at war, the USA was reluctant to interfere in the French colonies in the Caribbean, where the political leadership remained loyal to Vichy while much of the population was Gaullist. By 1943 the fear of German use of French Caribbean ports for their submarines and growing instability lead to U.S. demands for the French governors to switch to DeGaulle's side. On 2nd June 1943, a Gaullist coup in Guadeloupe failed, leading to a series of Gaullist riots on Martinique and, within a couple weeks, Guadeloupe again. On 30th June 1943, the Vichy governor resigned and was given U.S. protection to return to Vichy while a Free French regime was established on the islands, leaving Indochina as the only colony remaining under nominal Vichy control.

Because the USA and Vichy were not at war, the USA was reluctant to interfere in the French colonies in the Caribbean, where the political leadership remained loyal to Vichy while much of the population was Gaullist. By 1943 the fear of German use of French Caribbean ports for their submarines and growing instability lead to U.S. demands for the French governors to switch to DeGaulle's side. On 16th March 1943, Gaullist riots broke out in Cayenne, and after tense negotiations the governor resigned and a Free French regime established.

Although most of East Africa had been cleared of Axis forces by the end of 1941, French Somaliland, with its excellent port of Djibouti, remained loyal to Vichy. Negotiations with Vichy forces in November 1942, failed to convince the pro-Vichy governor to switch sides, leading to a Free French invasion, on 26th December 1942, that would overthrow the governor two days later, securing French Somaliland for the Free French.

The seizure of Madagascar by the Allies in November 1942, led to the dispatch of a ship to Reunion to demand the colony's adherence to Free France, thus ending the Vichy presence in the Indian Ocean basin.
In 1940 pro-Vichy officials in French West Africa successfully foiled attempts to rally the region to DeGaulle, culminating in the failed Anglo-Free French raid on Dakar in September 1940.

Japan's rapid expansion after Pearl Harbor into SE Asia led to fears Vichy would allow the Japanese to establish bases on Madagascar, potentially cutting Allied shipping routes via the Cape of Good Hope. In June 1942, the British seized the port of Diego-Suarez on the Northern tip of the island and began negotiations with the pro-Vichy regime to surrender control to DeGaulle. In September 1942, the negotiations broke down, leading to a British intervention that ended with the Vichy governor surrendering control on 5th November 1942.

When the rest of Equatorial Africa rallied to Free France in August 1940, pro-Vichy officials in Gabon prevented the colony's defection. After solidifying control in Brazzaville, DeGaulle made Gabon his first priority and on 12th November 1940, after a week of fighting, the pro-Vichy forces were ejected from Gabon.
The rise of Vichy was seen as a betrayal to the cause of France in many French colonies. On 2nd September 1940, French Polynesia defected to the Free French cause.
With much of Equatorial Africa rallying to Free France, DeGaulle solidified his leadership by establishing his movement's center in Brazzaville, capital of the Middle Congo colony.
Two days after the defection of Chad, the governors of Middle Congo, Ubangi-Chari and Cameroun declared their adherence to Free France.

The rise of Vichy was seen as a betrayal to the cause of France in many French colonies. On 26th August 1940, Governor Felix Eboue, an Afro-Caribbean from Guiana and the only non-white French colonial governor in the Empire, declared his adherence to Free France.
The rise of Vichy was seen as a betrayal to the cause of France in many French colonies. On 18th July 1940, New Caledonia became the second colony to rally to the Free French cause.

As the Vichy regime established itself, some Frenchmen refused to bow to the New Order in Europe. They would find their leader in Charles DeGaulle, who on 18th June 1940, delivered his call to the French nation to resist fascism and liberate France.

American aviator Amelia Earhart has arrived in Dakar after a two day layover up the coast at Saint-Louis. She ended up there after a minor navigational error after her transatlantic flight from Natal, Brazil. She will be flying to Fort Lamy and then continue across northern Africa to Massawa in Italian Eritrea. From there she will be crossing India, Siam, British Malaya, and the Dutch East Indies on her way to Australia before the final two legs of her flight to Oakland, California.
The French government announced its withdrawal from the League of Nations as the League had completely lost its influence.
The Romanian government officially severed the Anglo-French guarantee of territorial integrity and sought to improve relations with the German government.
Despite the growing influence of Germany on the Balkan countries and the otherwise good relations between France and Turkey, Turkey refused to sign a mutual aid agreement with the France.

In light of the growing threat of increased German influence in the Balkans, and the good relations between Turkey and France on other issues Turkey decided to sign a mutual aid agreement with France.

The French and Turkish governments concluded a mutual assistance treaty, based on the earlier Anglo-Turkish Treaty. Under the Franco-Turkish pact, the French gave up all claims to the Republic of Hatay, which became a part of Turkey. In return, the Turkish government promised to extend mutual aid to France in the case of aggression. With the acquisition of Hatay, the Turkish government stood squarely behind the Western powers.

Premier Eduoard Daladier of France conducted an official visit to Corsica and Tunisia to demonstrate France's claims on these territories in the face of Italian demands. The warm Tunisian reception for the French premier demonstrated that the Arabs had little enthusiasm to exchange French rule for Italian colonization. Tensions between the French and Italian governments remained high as the French refused to discuss any cessation of French territory to the Italians.

The Italian government issued a series of demands for French colonies (especially Tunisia and Corsica) and other concessions. In response, the French government took an uncompromising attitude towards the cessation of any colonies to the Italians.

The French government recognized the Italian conquest of Ethiopia in an effort to gain Italian support against German expansion, and thereby increase the sense of security in France by reducing the threat of Italian invasion in the south of France.
King George VI and Queen Elizabeth conducted an official state visit to Paris. This visit was conducted to highlight Anglo-French solidarity and as a counter-demonstration to Hitler's visit to Rome.

The French government uncovered a plot by the Cagoulards (Hooded Ones) to overthrow the French republic and to restore the monarchy. The Cagoulards were a terrorist group associated with a larger revolutionary (fascist) organization. The government discovered secret plans, fortified dugouts, and caches of weapons and ammunition.

After a nationalist uprising began in French Morocco, the French government immediately rushed in troops and aircraft to the protectorate and wiped out the rebellion. The French arrested a number of nationalist leaders. The government also appointed Albert Sarrault, a leading colonial administrator, to lead a new Commission of Coordination for North Africa

Under the Versailles Treaty, major German rivers and canals came under international control. Chancellor Adolf Hitler has announced that the German government will resume control over the waterways in Germany. We have to respond to this violation of the Versailles Treaty.
To meet the demands of French labor, the Blum ministry nationalized the republic's munitions industry.
As part of the Popular Front's social program, the Blum ministry reorganized, and eventually nationalized, the Bank of France.

We have asked United Kingdom for reassurance that they will intervene on our behalf of us in case of a future war with Germany. In light of the recent German occupation of the Rhineland this threat has moved closer. The British have failed to reply on our request.

We have asked United Kingdom for reassurance that they will intervene on our behalf of us in case of a future war with Germany. In light of the recent German occupation of the Rhineland this threat has moved closer. England has reassured us that they will respond immediately should any such action become necessary.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1947 Nobel Prize in Literature. This year's laureate is AndrÈ Paul Guilaume Gide (France), for his comprehensive and artistically significant writings, in which human problems and conditions have been presented with a fearless love of the truth and keen psychological insight.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1937 Nobel Prize in Literature. This year's laureate is Roger Martin du Gard (France), for the artistic power and truth with which he has depicted human conflict as well as some fundamental aspects of contemporary life in his novel-cycle 'Les Thibault'.

Revolts and more revolts are all over the place in French Morocco, the situation is desperate. Moroccan insurgents are controlling all the government buildings. We cannot control them anymore, it is time to give them their freedom.
The new colonial policy of Republican Spain in Morocco has initiated some revolts in our lands in search of their desired freedom...
Spain asks for military aid, in return they offer us control of their colonies in North Africa once the Nationalists are defeated.

The Finnish army fighting the Soviets was heavily outnumbered both in men and material and therefore the Finnish government sent a telegraph to its embassy's in London and Paris requesting much needed supplies and military advisors.
The streets of Paris are filled with angry students. They are protesting against the inactivity of the Allies in the atrocities committed by the Soviet army upon the Finnish people.

The War Guilt trial of Riom found several ex-ministers of France guilty of treason.  They were all sentenced to life imprisonment and moved to German prisons scattered throughout the occupied territories.
On 24th September 1941, the Vichy government reduced tobacco rations in Paris to only four cigarettes per day for men and zero for women.
On 29th June 1941, after being forced by the German regime, Vichy France broke off all diplomatic ties with the Soviet Union.

On 19th May 1941, Vichy France announced the release and repatriation of 100,000 French POWs.  As a result, the French population under PÈtain had their spirits lifted to see the return of their loved ones home. Because of this, industrial output grew slightly.
On 14th December 1940, the Vichy government limited wine consumption to two liters per person per week.  The population grumbled, but surprisingly did not rebel. Industrial output fell, however.

On 6th December 1940, the Vichy government ordered the arrest and indictment of ex-ministers and government leaders of the previous French state. The French people immediately demonstrated against the persecution of their former leaders, and the Vichy regime was faced with a decision. Placate the people by withdrawing from all military co-operation with the Axis, or suppressing the voices of discontent. This infuriated the German government, and many prominent leaders called for the immediate annexation of Vichy territory.
Due to poor past performance, PÈtain, the Head of State of Vichy France, dismissed Prime Minister Laval from his duties.  Jean-Francois Darlan was appointed as his replacement.
