Later in 1940, new rations began arriving in Vichy France from the colonies.  Weekly rations per person were increased to: 350 grams of bread, 300 grams of sugar, 50 grams of cheese, 360 grams of meat per day and 100 grams of fat per week.

Due to the ongoing conflict the government in Vichy had to decide whether to redistribute supplies to cover the shortfall in food or to lower weekly rations.  They lowered rations, setting the new volumes to 4 ounces of sugar, 6 ounces of spaghetti, 1.5 ounces of rice and 3 ounces of margarine per person.

After the defeat of France and Britain, the puppet governments could not deny Germany the return of her former colonies. Deutsch-Ostafrika, Kamerun and Togo were restored to German control. Benin and French Equatorial Africa also were added to the African possessions of Germany in order to form a land bridge between Togo and East Africa.
On 30th January 1939, Hitler demanded the return of all former German colonies. Kamerun and Togo had been given to France by the treaty of Versailles.

Soon after joining Allies, Poland asked Britain and France for help in modernization of its Air Force. Both countries decided to give Poland special credit to purchase military equipment. From France, Poland acquired a contract for 100 MS-406 fighters.

To ensure Lebanon remained in the French sphere of influence, the 1936 Franco-Lebanese treaty included a clause that would have France send troops for its protection in case Lebanon was attacked by a third party.
Having driven Vichy out of Syria, Britain returned control to Free France.
Having driven Vichy out of Lebanon, Britain returned control to Free France.

We have an opportunity to return the Croatian nationalist Ustashe activists wanted for terrorism to Yugoslavia. They have used our country as a base for their political activity for a while, and now Yugoslav government is demanding that they be deported back to their country for processing.

After Vichy France refused to be bullied by Britain into giving up its colonial control of Lebanon and Syria, Britain invaded those two countries. Vichy France was left to decide to relinquish control or fight to defend its acquisitions.

Yugoslav government has asked us to land a force in Thessaloniki in northern Greece and open a new southern front in the war as soon as possible. Yugoslav Regent Pavle is hoping that the history will repeat itself and that the south front might draw enough enemy resources there to provide victory for the Allies. A member of our staff, General Weygand, believes a swift intervention there might prove decisive.

After the British made demands for the withdrawal of Vichy France from Lebanon and Syria, the resulting collapse of Vichy colonial influence allowed the Free French to restore their control of these two countries.

The political situation in Syria is growing more and more difficult. We have to make a decision. Either we outlaw the Nationalist Party who is responsible for this situation or we risk losing influence on our colonies.

Fearing that Germany would gain access to military bases in the Levant from Vichy, the British decided that Vichy influence in Lebanon and Syria had to be returned to be under the control of Free France.

To ensure Syria remained in the French sphere of influence, the 1936 Franco-Syrian treaty included a clause that would have France send troops for its protection in case Syria was attacked by a third party.
As the Second World war wound to a close in Europe, Lebanese nationalists began demanding complete independence from French colonialism.
As the Second World war wound to a close in Europe, Lebanese nationalists began demanding complete independence from French colonialism.
As the Allies pushed forward into Europe, Syrian nationalists demanded an end to direct French rule. They were supported in their demands by the British.
As the Allies pushed forward into Europe, Lebanese nationalists demanded an end to direct French rule. They were supported in their demands by the British.

To ensure Lebanon remained in the French sphere of influence, the 1936 Franco-Lebanese treaty included a clause that would have France send troops for its protection in case Lebanon was attacked by a third party.

To ensure Syria remained in the French sphere of influence, the 1936 Franco-Syrian treaty included a clause that would have France send troops for its protection in case Syria was attacked by a third party.

After the fall of France to the Germans, and the corresponding emplacement of a more Fascist-aligned government, Vichy France moved quickly to reassert its claims on the French position in the Levant.

France demanded an immediate German withdrawal after it reoccupied the Rhineland in 1936. France also threatened war if Germany refused to retreat. The predictable German refusal left France in the position to back up words with actions, while it had unwittingly estranged itself from its more cautious Allies.
Due to German reoccupation of the Rhineland in 1936, France opted to extend the Maginot Line along the Belgian border as a safety measure.

In 1936, Germany violated stipulations of the treaty of Versailles set down at the end of the First World War. The Treaty stated that no German military forces were allowed on the western side of the Rhine. When Hitler has troops march ostentatiously into this area, many nations were shocked. Some, such as France, Belgium, and the Netherlands, were forced to decide on a new policy to deal with this aggressive behavior.
Believing France needed to protect its Levantine interests, the French Chamber refused to ratify the 1936 Treaty that granted Lebanon internal independence.

Many Syrian nationalists believed that Lebanon, separated from Syria in 1924, should be restored to Syrian control. The French would have directly opposed any such attempt by Syria to achieve that goal.

Shortly after the fall of France, the somewhat dubious question of Vichy France staying out of the war with the Allies arose. Of course, it was highly unlikely that Germany, recent victors in France, would allow this to happen.

During the 1930s, Polish military intelligence accomplished many feats in operations against the German Abwehr. Perhaps the most important was the creation of a copy of the Enigma encryption device by a small group of Polish math scientists: M. Rejewski, J. Rozycki and H. Zygalski. Their works provided valuable experience for the further development of decryption devices during World War II. In August 1939, Polish intelligence invited a group of Allied scientists to Kabaty Palace, a secret decryption research center, and handed over to them a copy of the German Enigma machine.

The victory of Franco and Nationalist Spain showed the world the horrors of Civil War without reconciliation. About 500,000 Republican Spaniards fled to different countries to escape reprisal. These reprisals were extremely cruel during the war: the Fascists had already executed over 90,000 people. Most of the exiled arrived at the border with France and were sent to immense camps for refugees. Extreme-right wing party members Maurras and Daudet criticized the decision to give shelter, and caused trouble with the negotiations. Fortunately, there were also people who sympathized with the refugees: pressure from public opinion and left-wing intellectuals made the French government decide to give shelter and food to civilian refugees, while militants could continue in the camps until they found a job or enlisted with either the LegiÛn …trangËre or Compagnies de Travailleurs …trangers.

The Spanish Civil War became a war against fascism. Although France did not quite agree with Republican ideology, it was at least a democratic nation fighting against tyranny. A safe way for France to get more involved was to send military advisors and the technological means to produce weapons to Republican Spain.

After losing the war with Germany, Polish territory was divided between Germany and USSR as set out in the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact. Meanwhile, the Polish government in exile declared they were creating an army to fight on the Western Front alongside France and Great Britain. Survivors from the Polish army, who had crossed Romanian and Hungarian borders, tried to reach France and Britain to join newly formed units.

After losing the war with Germany, Polish territory was divided between Germany and USSR as set out in the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact. Meanwhile, the Polish government in exile declared they were creating an army to fight on the Western Front alongside France and Great Britain. Survivors from the Polish army, who had crossed Romanian and Hungarian borders, tried to reach France and Britain to join newly formed units.

The threat of an attack on the Aleutians prompted the USA and Canada to improve air and land routes to Alaska.  Alaska Highway was designed for one primary purpose, and that was to facilitate the building of the airfields and serve as a guide path for flyers. Whether that purpose was essential to the defense of the continent is another question, one that should not obscure the fact that the highway and the staging route amply fulfilled their principal role.

The B.C.A.T.P. was one of the most ambitious pilot training programs ever developed.  It gave the Commonwealth a safe region in which to train large numbers of pilots quickly, but used up a large number of Canadian resources.
British Prime Minister Winston Churchill traveled to Ottawa to speak before the Canadian Parliament and reaffirm the war effort against the Axis powers.

King George VI and Queen Elizabeth arrived in Canada to begin an official state visit to the dominion. This was the first time a British monarch visited Canada and the Canadian welcome reinforced Anglo-Canadian ties.

The British, Canadian, and American governments signed a major trade agreement, which the three countries had negotiated for a considerable period of time. Each state agreed to considerable trade concessions, a position which marked growing cooperation between the English-speaking countries.

A series of strikes led by the CIO spread across the United States in the automobile and steel industries in 1937. The CIO demanded that General Motors plant in Oshawa, Ontario recognize the local branch of N.A.W.A., an affiliate of the CIO. When General Motors refused, the workers commenced a sit-down strike. On 23rd April 1937, the prime minister of Ontario intervened, denounced the CIO, and announced a wage and working conditions agreement with auto workers but withheld recognition of the N.A.W.A.

The British parliament was required by Commonwealth law to consult member states on matters concerning the Commonwealth as a whole.  As such, when the issue of Edward VIII's decision to marry arose as a matter of public debate, London sent three proposals to all the Commonwealth members: force Edward to abdicate if he wished to marry Wallis Simpson, accept the marriage with Simpson as consort, or accept the marriage and Simpson as Queen. London chose to ignore the stated opinions of the Commonwealth in favor of appeasing radical elements in England.  Domestic response was harsh against the Parliament in London.

The British parliament was required by Commonwealth law to consult member states on matters concerning the Commonwealth as a whole.  As such, when the issue of Edward VIII's decision to marry arose as a matter of public debate, London sent three proposals to all the Commonwealth members: force Edward to abdicate if he wished to marry Wallis Simpson, accept the marriage with Simpson as consort, or accept the marriage and Simpson as Queen. When the consultations ended, and after several private conversations, the general consensus was to allow Edward to marry, and recognize Mrs. Simpson as his consort.  Some domestic unhappiness was inevitable, but stability had to be maintained.

The British parliament was required by Commonwealth law to consult member states on matters concerning the Commonwealth as a whole.  As such, when the issue of Edward VIII's decision to marry arose as a matter of public debate, London sent three proposals to all the Commonwealth members: force Edward to abdicate if he wished to marry Wallis Simpson, accept the marriage with Simpson as consort, or accept the marriage and Simpson as Queen. After consulting with the members of the Commonwealth, London accepted the majority decision, and forced Edward to abdicate the throne.  Edward's brother, Albert, was installed as King George VI.  Respectability and stability were thereby restored to the monarchy.

The British parliament was required by Commonwealth law to consult member states on matters concerning the Commonwealth as a whole.  As such, when the issue of Edward VIII's decision to marry arose as a matter of public debate, London sent three proposals to all the Commonwealth members: force Edward to abdicate if he wished to marry Wallis Simpson, accept the marriage with Simpson as consort, or accept the marriage and Simpson as Queen.

When Finnish foreign minister Ryti announced that Finland would accept foreign volunteers into their military personnel, Canadians flocked to Toronto to sign up for a new volunteer division. The provincial government in Toronto was willing to help, but decided to ask the Canadian government about to the legality of the matter first.

When Finnish foreign minister Ryti announced that Finland would accept foreign volunteers into their military personnel, Canadians flocked to Toronto to sign up for a new volunteer division. The provincial government in Toronto was willing to help, but decided to ask the Canadian government about to the legality of the matter first.
9.2 inch and 6 inch guns from the obsolete ships HMCS Niobe and HMCS Rainbow were used to reinforce both Eastern and Western coastal defenses.
Igor Gouzenko defected to Canada from the Soviet Union. He provided important details of the Soviet spy ring to the RCMP.
McNaughton was recalled to Canada and forced to resign over his persistence in keeping Canadian fighting units together. James Ralston was his replacement.

The War Measures Act suspended some basic civilian rights for the duration of the war in order to retain internal stability.  This caused some unrest within the general population.  With this Act, fascist and communist groups were also banned.

After the onset of the Second World War, President Roosevelt gave public assurance to the people of Canada by saying: 'I can give assurance to you that the people of the United States will not stand idly by if domination of Canadian soil is threatened by any other empire'.
Surviving British Duncan Class, Exmouth Class, Faulknor Class, Grenville Class and Hardy Class Destroyers were transferred to the Royal Canadian Navy.

The National Resources Mobilization Act introduced military conscription, primarily for the defense of Canada.  It was a very unpopular Act amongst civilians, but it was necessary to increase the available manpower in the Canadian Armed Forces.
The fall of Paris inspired many Canadian civilians to volunteer for the armed forces.
After the outbreak of the Second World War, thousands of civilians volunteered to join the Canadian Armed forces.
The German government has issued a strong protest against the prohibition of foreign political activity in southwest Africa.
The Union of South Africa government issued a decree prohibiting political activity by foreigners, including non-naturalized German residents, in southwest Africa.

American aviator Amelia Earhart has arrived at Darwin as a part of her circumnavigation of the globe. Her arrival was delayed by mechanical difficulties while flying through the Dutch East Indies. She will be continuing on to the United States after stops at Lae on Papua New Guinea, Howland Island, and Honolulu Hawaii.

The South African parliament finally clarified the role of natives in the government. Natives retained the right to register as voters in the Cape Province, but this right was not extended to the other three provinces. Instead, native voters signed up on separate electoral rolls and could elect three Europeans to represent their interests in the Union Parliament. The act also established a native representative council (composed of 22 members of which twelve were elected), but the council was limited to an advisory role.

Japan has decided to sign the proposed trade agreement. Event though we have to accept more Japanese textiles into our country then we would have liked it gives us an opportunity to influence the political situation in Japan.
The Japanese have decided to decline our generous offer. They will have to find a different place to sell their textiles. Unfortunately we also lost our chance to influence them politically.

The Australian and Japanese governments negotiated a textile trade agreement in response to the Australian tariff increase. The Australian government agreed to import as many Japanese textile products up to the 1934 level, while the Japanese pledged to purchase a specified amount of Australian wool. This agreement also helped to defuse some of the tension developing in Japan.
In response to increased competition on the Asian markets the Australian government imposed a new and higher tariff rate policy which replaced the more modest tariff rates of 1932.

London has chosen to ignore the stated opinions of the Commonwealth in favor of appeasing radical elements in England.  Domestic response has been harsh against the parliament in London, but we have done our duty.

With consultations ended, and several private conversations, the general consensus has been to allow Edward to marry, and recognize Mrs. Simpson as his consort.  Some domestic unhappiness is inevitable, but stability must be maintained.

After consulting with the members of the Commonwealth, London has accepted the majority decision, and forced Edward to abdicate the throne.  Edward's brother, Albert, has been installed as King George VI.  Respectability and stability have been restored to the monarchy.

As such, when the issue of Edward VIII's decision to marry arose as a matter of public debate, London sent three proposals to all the Commonwealth members: force Edward to abdicate if he wished to marry Wallis Simpson, accept Simpson as consort or accept Simpson as Queen.

As such, when the issue of Edward VIII's decision to marry arose as a matter of public debate, London sent three proposals to all the Commonwealth members: force Edward to abdicate if he wished to marry Wallis Simpson, accept Simpson as consort or accept Simpson as Queen.

As such, when the issue of Edward VIII's decision to marry arose as a matter of public debate, London sent three proposals to all the Commonwealth members: force Edward to abdicate if he wished to marry Wallis Simpson, accept Simpson as consort or accept Simpson as Queen.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureates for the 1945 Nobel Prize in Medicine. This year's laureates are Sir Alexander Fleming and Ernst Boris Chain (United Kingdom) and Sir Howard Walter Florey (Australia), for the discovery of Penicillin and its curative effect in various infectious diseases.

The South African farmers would like to do their part in helping Finland through their difficult time. A total of 14,000 liters of wine and 7000 liters of spirits have been gathered and are ready to be shipped to Finland.
After the defeat of Australia, the government was forced to return the former German colonies of Kaiser-Wilhelm-Land to Germany.
On 30th January 1939, Hitler demanded the return of all former German colonies. The Treaty of Versailles divided the Pacific colonies of Germany between Australia and Japan.
After the defeat of South Africa, the former German colony of Deutsch-S¸dwestafrika was returned to Germany.
On 30th January 1939, Hitler demanded the return of all former German colonies. Southwest Africa had been given to South Africa by the Treaty of Versailles.
John Curtin died in office, leading to the appointing of a new cabinet by Ben Chifley.

After months of internal turmoil, independent voters support the Labour Party, ousting Robert G. Menzies. John Curtin formed the new government. Three ministers, Street, Gullet, and Fairbairn, were also killed in an airplane crash.
Robert G. Menzies appointed a new cabinet after the death of Joseph A. Lyons.
Australia changed conscription and mobilization laws to make up for a lack of manpower overseas, caused by losses to infantry in heavy fighting. Conscripts could now be sent overseas.
Australia introduced conscription and went to full mobilization upon the entry of Japan into the war. Conscripts were not required to fight overseas.
Some of those who were unwilling to join the Allied cause in Australia changed their minds after the fall of Paris.
Many Australians rushed to defend the British empire in its time of need. More civilians then expected actually signed up.
After the outbreak of the Second World War, thousands of civilians volunteered to join the New Zealand Armed forces.
Out of all the Commonwealth nations, South Africa was the most likely not to join the Allies in a war against Germany, regardless of historical ties.
Historically the ruling elite of South Africa did not allow Africans to join the South African Military for fears of arming the African population.
After the outbreak of the Second World War, thousands of civilians volunteered to join the South African Armed forces.

The fascist Italian government has proven to the rest of the world that it is not a peace-loving regime. The continuous attempts by Italy to recreate an empire ruled from Rome demand our immediate attention. We must intervene and once and for all stop the Italian warmongers.

The threat of an attack on the Aleutians prompted the USA and Canada to improve air and land routes to Alaska.  Alaska Highway was designed for one primary purpose, and that was to facilitate the building of the airfields and serve as a guide path for flyers. Whether that purpose was essential to the defense of the continent is another question, one that should not obscure the fact that the highway and the staging route amply fulfilled their principal role.

Yugoslavia built fortifications along the Italian frontier and later along old Austrian now German border but these fortifications lacked heavy artillery pieces to be effective. With Czechoslovakia and France gone, and UK under threat of invasion, the only neutral place left to buy artillery were United States of America. Historically, Yugoslavia offered its surplus of cement production to USA in exchange for guns but USA refused, failing to realize an opportunity to ensure neutrality of smaller nations in Europe.
In response to Albert Einstein's A-Bomb Letter, the President approved only $6000 to buy graphite and uranium for experiments proposed by Leo Szilard, who drafted the letter for Einstein.

A Navy rescue team commanded by Charles 'Swede' Momsen, aboard the salvage ship USS Falcon, brought all 33 survivors of the Squalus to the surface on 25th May 1939.  Thirty-nine terrible hours had elapsed since the sinking.  Momson's team used the McCann Diving Bell, which Momsen and Rear Admiral Allan R. McCann developed. Along with Rear Admiral McCann, Momsen received a commendation from the President for his efforts in the rescue of the sailors from the USS Squalus.

During operational trials, the US Navy submarine Squalus sank with a crew of 59: five officers, 51 enlisted men and three civilian inspectors.  Soon after the sinking, a telephone buoy was released and surfaced. Rockets were fired from time to time, the sixth launched after four hours on the bottom. By chance, a lookout on the sister submarine USS Sculpin saw its smoke. Once the Sculpin made its way over the sunken Squalus, it found the phone buoy. However, soon after the two-way conversation began, the phone cable broke.

During the 1936 campaign, FDR lashed out at 'economic royalists' and generally scapegoat businesses for the Depression.  One measure put through Congress to deal with 'this new industrial dictatorship' was a nearly confiscatory retained profits tax.  However, this dried up the principal source of capital for small business and raised the cost of capital for large business.  This reduced the incentive for expansion or entrepreneurial activity and the country remained mired in Depression.  Consequently, the people failed to benefit even as business was punished.
The IAM wins the strike.  The UBC sues the IAM, Anhueser-Busch, and the contractors in court.  Industry returns to normal.
The UBC wins the strike.  The IAM sues the UBC, Anhueser-Busch, and the contractors in court.  Industry returns to normal.

Anheuser-Busch was in the process of reconstructing some of its breweries in 1939.  Anheuser-Busch agreed that union workers would perform the work.  Both the United Brotherhood of Carpenters (UBC) and the International Association of Machinists (IAM) wanted the projects.  The IAM won.  Then the UBC called a nation-wide strike against Anheuser-Busch and the construction contractors.  The case went all the way to the Supreme Court and in U.S. vs. Hutcheson (3rd February 1941) the court ruled for the UBC and declared that the Sherman Antitrust Act did not apply to union activity.

After six years of failure in curing the Great Depression, Congress finally decided that it was time to curtail waging economic warfare on business.  This bill featured a flat 18% corporate income tax and no extension of the undistributed profits tax, effectively repealing that 1936 law.  The House passed the bill by 357-1.  If the president vetoes this he will certainly lose.

It was believed that higher wages would give workers more money to pump into the economy.  The Roosevelt Administration pushed this bill into law as part of the Second New Deal.  With a minimum wage of $0.40/hour and a guarantee of time and half wage for time over 40 hours per week.  About 750,000 workers saw legally mandated raises.  However, within two weeks of coming into effect and in the south alone, the U.S. Labor Department reported that 30,000 to 50,000 workers were fired as employers concluded they couldn't afford the extra cost.  By raising the cost of employment, the act discouraged hiring and aggravated the unemployment rate.  The U.S. economy remained mired in the Depression.

This dam on the Columbia River provided over 518,000 kilowatts of hydroelectric generating capacity.  It was 60 meters high and 820 meters long.  It included both salmon ladders and shipping locks.  The project was directed by industrialist Henry J. Kaiser.  This provided cheap power throughout the Northwest.

On 22nd June 1944, President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed the 'Servicemen's Readjustment Act of 1944', better known as the 'GI Bill of Rights'. At first the subject of intense debate and parliamentary maneuvering, the famed legislation for veterans of World War II has since been recognized as one of the most important acts of Congress. During the past six decades, the law has made possible the investment of billions of dollars in education and training for millions of veterans, and the nation has in return earned many times its investment in increased taxes and a dramatically changed society.

The Pentagon, headquarters of the Department of War, is the world's largest office building. It has three times the floor space of the Empire State Building in New York. The National Capitol could fit into any one of the five wedge-shaped sections. Despite 17.5 miles of corridors it takes only seven minutes to walk between any two points in the building. The building is completed at an approximate cost of $83 million. It consolidated 17 buildings of the War Department and returned its investment within seven years.
A new headquarters for the Department of War is proposed.  It will be the world's largest office building and will consolidate 17 buildings of the War Department.

After missing the World Series last year, the Yankees were back to their championship ways.  The Yankees won their fifth championship in six years by beating those bums from Brooklyn in five games.  The only game that the Dodgers were able to win was game 2.  All of the games were very close with four of the five games being decided by two runs or less.

For the first time in four years the New York Yankees did not get to the World Series.  It was also the first time in four years that the World Series went the full seven games to decide the winner.  The Cincinnati Reds managed to knock off the Detroit Tigers to win their first championship since they won in the controversial 1919 World Series which was tainted by the Black Sox scandal.  The Tigers were within one game of winning after winning game 5, but the Reds came back to take the next two and win it all.

The Hindenburg was coming in for a landing at the naval air station in Lakehurst New Jersey.  Hindenburg was a thrilling sight as she approached the landing site.  She was almost three football fields long and with luxurious dining salons and staterooms.  A tongue of flame appeared at the stern of the airship and spread forward destroying the airship in only 32 seconds.  Broadcaster Herb Morrison found himself reporting the biggest story of his career.  His smooth delivery became a jumble of impressions as the emotions of the unfolding disaster took hold.  The crowd stood mesmerized by the flames consuming the airship until the flames destroyed the scarlet letters of the airship's name.  36 people died in the crash including the Hindenburg's captain Ernst Lehmann.

'War of the Worlds' was a radio play written by Orson Wells and broadcast across the nation. When it unfolded dance music was interrupted a number of times by fake news bulletins reporting that a 'huge flaming object' had dropped on a farm near New Jersey. As the audience sat on the edge of their seats, actors playing news announcers, officials and other roles one would expect to hear in a news report, described the landing of an invasion force from Mars and the destruction of the United States. The broadcast also contained a number of explanations that it was all a radio play, but if members of the audience missed a brief explanation at the beginning, the next one didn't arrive until 40 minutes into the program. People packed the roads, hid in cellars, loaded guns, even wrapped their heads in wet towels as protection from Martian poison gas, in an attempt to defend themselves against aliens, oblivious to the fact that they were acting out the role of the panic-stricken public that actually belonged in a radio play.

This movie starring Humphrey Boggart and Ingrid Bergman opened in theaters across the United States today.  The movie is the story of an American in French Morocco during the late 1930s.  It is story about a French resistance leader Victor Laslo (played by Paul Henreid) and his wife (played by Ingrid Bergman) attempting to escape Nazi controlled France.  Boggart plays Rick Blaine, the owner of Rick's Place, the bar where most of these transactions in travel visas takes place.  The focus of the movie is the tension between Bergman and Bogart because of their past relationship.  It will go on to become an American classic.

The Cincinnati Reds were the New York Yankees' victim on the way to the Yankees' unprecedented fourth consecutive World Series title.  The Reds were swept in four straight games only able to score eight runs off the Yankee pitching.

The Yankees have won their third straight world series.  This time they swept the Chicago Cubs to gain the championship.  This is the first time that a team has won three straight Major League baseball championships.  Yankee shortstop Frankie Crosetti and second baseman Joe Gordon were the offensive and defensive stars of the series.  Pitcher Red Ruffing won two of the games for the Yankees pitching two complete games and only giving up three runs over the two games.

The New York Giants again fell to the New York Yankees in the world series losing to the Yankees four games to one.  The Yankees won the first three games of the series by at least four runs each game.  Carl Hubbell got the game 1 start again this year, but this time the Yankees jumped on him scoring seven runs in five innings.  The Giants did manage to win game 4 before the Yankees clinched the series in game 5.

The New York Yankees have won the World Series by defeating the New York Giants in 6 games.  The Giants took the first game behind an impressive pitching performance by Carl Hubbell but the Yankees came back to win game 2, crushing the Giants 18-4.  The Yankees would win the next two before dropping game 5 in extra innings.  The Yankees clinched the series in game 6, scoring seven runs in the ninth.

The President addresses a joint session of Congress.  He denounces the capture of U.S. servicemen by Japan, calling it 'a barbarous act'.  He cites the Japanese atrocities in China in chilling detail, including the loss of the Panay, and concludes that America must keep the Open Door in China by force of arms.  He calls for Congress to approve alliance with China, which will result in a war with Japan.

The President addresses the nation by radio.  He denounces the capture of U.S. servicemen by Japan, calling it 'a barbarous act'.  He calls for severing all favorable trade relations with Japan and strictest enforcement of the Neutrality Acts with Japan.  He calls for abrogation of the Washington Naval Treaties and a huge supplemental appropriation for the Navy.  He calls for massive aid to Nationalist China.  He calls for enrollment of a 'China Legion' to fight against the Japanese, with funding from Congress.  All Americans must be released safe and unharmed or the Japanese Empire's leaders will be held accountable.

Overwhelming Japanese forces have interned two regiments of U.S. forces in mainland China.  They have also interned the Yangtze Patrol.  There are American dead and wounded suffered in resistance prior to the internment.  War is a serious possibility.  Isolationist sentiment in the USA is very vocal even as more Americans appear to feel that 'enough is enough' and are willing to support forceful action.

After the USA escalated their concern by recalling their ambassador, the Japanese recalled General Kesago Nakajima over his role in the Panay Incident.  The General is rumored to have committed seppuku, ritual suicide.  His immediate superior, Central Front Commander, Prince Yasuhiko Asaka, the Emperor's uncle, has lost immense face and embarrassed the Imperial family.  The U.S. also collects sizable reparations. This is a clear American diplomatic victory.

Albert Einstein explained to the President that recent discoveries about Uranium indicate the promise of bombs that create a nuclear-chain reaction. He suggested the creation of a taskforce to keep track of and expedite developments of uranium-based bombs.  This letter led to the Manhattan Project.

Piloted by U.S. Air Force Capt. Charles E. 'Chuck' Yeager the Bell X-1 became the first airplane to fly faster than the speed of sound [historically on 14th October 1947]. The X-1 reached a speed of 1127 kilometers (700 miles) per hour, Mach 1.06, at an altitude of 13,000 meters (43,000 feet). Yeager named the airplane 'Glamorous Glennis' in tribute to his wife. Air-launched at an altitude of 7000 meters (23,000 feet) from the bomb bay of a Boeing B-29, the X-1 used its rocket engine to climb to its test altitude.

The world was changed forever when the first atomic bomb was tested today [historically on Monday morning 16th July 1945, in an isolated area of the New Mexico desert on the Alamagordo Bombing and Gunnery Range]. Conducted by the top-secret Manhattan Engineer District, this test was code named Trinity.  J. Robert Oppenheimer quoted a line from a sacred Hindu text, the Bhagavad-Gita: 'I am become death, the shatterer of worlds'.

As Japanese forces advanced on Nanjing, citizens from Western countries were evacuated. Several diplomats, their families, foreign correspondents and other civilians were on the gunboat USS Panay 27 miles upriver from Nanjing when it was attacked and sunk by Japanese aircraft. Three Standard Oil Company tankers that were in the company of the Panay were also sunk.  Two U.S. sailors, the captain of one of the tankers, and an Italian foreign correspondent were killed.  The entire attack was captured on newsreel film by correspondents aboard the doomed Panay.  The Japanese demand U.S. withdrawal from China.

As Japanese forces advanced on Nanjing, citizens from Western countries were evacuated. Several diplomats, their families, foreign correspondents and other civilians were on the gunboat USS Panay 27 miles upriver from Nanjing when it was attacked and sunk by Japanese aircraft. Three nearby Standard Oil Company tankers were also sunk.  Two US sailors, the captain of one of the tankers, and an Italian foreign correspondent were killed.  The entire attack was captured on newsreel film by correspondents aboard the doomed Panay.  The Japanese have apologized for the 'mistake', offered reparations, and will discipline the squadron commander.

The USMC 4th Marine Regiment had been deployed in Shanghai to protect the American Zone in the foreign concession there.  The rising tensions in the Pacific made their continued occupation of that portion of the city untenable so they were transferred to the Philippines to join U.S. forces there.

The U.S. Navy Yangtze Patrol, which operated on that Chinese river to assure the safe passage of American citizens and commerce, has been disbanded.  With the rising tensions in the Pacific those sailors are merely hostages to U.S. good behavior.  The surviving gunboats will sail for the Philippines and join the U.S. Asiatic Fleet.
The 15th Infantry Regiment, on independent deployment in Tianjin, China, has been withdrawn and will join its parent unit, the 3rd Infantry, 'Rock of the Marine' Division.

Soviet Foreign Minister arrived in Washington for a conference with the U.S. President and other high ranking American officials. The meeting focused on the supply of Lend-Lease supplies and equipment for the Soviet Union, which resulted in the Master Lend-Lease Agreement in June.
The Mexican government has launched trade negotiations with other countries to try and sell the oil confiscated earlier from U.S. companies in Mexico.

Following the Nationalist victory in the Spanish civil war the U.S. administration realized that the only way they would be able to influence the new Spanish government was to formally recognize Franco's government as the official government of Spain.

The search for Amelia Earhart has not found the missing aircraft or her crew. The battleship Colorado, and the aircraft carrier Lexington were the largest ships in the armada that was carrying out the search. The fleet used aircraft to search the seas and islands around Howland in the effort. There were no promising leads about the fate of the crew and the aircraft, but there are theories running through the press and through gossip across the country. These theories include the idea the flight was a spy mission authorized by the president that was shot down by the Japanese, but many believe that she was lost at sea and drowned.

Female aviator Amelia Earhart and her navigator Fred Noonan have failed to arrive at Howland Island for a fueling stop. The captain of the Coast Guard Cutter Itasca reported that the last message from Earhart was received at 0842 local time in which she reported that she is running a line of 157∞/337∞ searching for Howland Island. Itasca was detailed to refuel the plane when it arrived at Howland and also provide homing signals for Earhart. The captain has started his search towards the northwest in hopes of finding the missing plane. Unfortunately, the search turned up empty. The Commander of the Pacific Fleet has sent units to search for Earhart's plane both to the northwest and southeast of Howland Island.

Female aviator Amelia Earhart made an unexpected landing at Soerabaja in the Dutch East Indies. After temporary repairs, she will fly back to Bandoeng for permanent repairs by KLM Dutch East Indies technicians. In a phone conversation with her husband, Earhart was confident that she would still be back in Oakland, California before the Fourth of July. From Java, she is going to fly to Darwin, Australia before continuing on to the United States. She will be making a stop at Howland Island, near the Gilbert Islands, for fuel and rest on the flight to Honolulu. From there, she will be flying back to the mainland.

Aviator Amelia Earhart has left Miami with her navigator Fred Noonan. She is en route to Caripito, Venezuela via San Juan, Puerto Rico on the first leg of her second attempt to become the first female pilot to circumnavigate the globe. She will continue down to Natal Brazil where she will cross the Atlantic Ocean. She will cross northern Africa to Italian Eritrea. From there, her journey will take her across India, British Malaya, and the Dutch East Indies to Darwin, Australia. She will return to Oakland, California after a stop in Honolulu.  She is expected to complete her journey by the Fourth of July.

Amelia Earhart's attempt to fly around the world has ended in failure. She suffered a blowout in one of her landing gear tires that forced her plane off the runway. Fortunately, there was no fire, but the accident did a lot of damage to the bottom of the plane. This will end her around the world flight bid.

Amelia Earhart, the female aviator famous for being the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean, left Oakland en route to Honolulu on the first leg of her around the world flight. She will head to Australia from Honolulu and then will continue on through Southeast Asia, across Africa, then cross the Atlantic to South America. This will be the first time someone has flown around the world near the equator.
The Dutch government in exile has asked us to protect their interests in Duth Guyana. This is a request that we cannot refuse.

In his annual speech to congress today president Roosevelt proclaimed that every individual in the world should have access to the four basic freedoms. Freedom of speech and expression, freedom of worship, freedom from want, and freedom from fear.

All the way up until the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor there was extensive trade between the USA and Japan. With the increase in Japanese aggression in the Pacific the USA tried to put bans on exports of certain goods through legislation, but Japan countered this by buying through third party countries.

With the continued aggression by Japan in the Pacific the US government wanted to stop oil exports to Japan.  This was heavily opposed by the lobbyists from the oil industry and a compromise was forged putting a maximum limit on the trade but not completely banning it.

All the way up until the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor there was extensive trade between the USA and Japan. With the increase in Japanese aggression in the Pacific the USA tried to put bans on exports of certain goods through legislation, but Japan countered this by re-import through third countries.

After the Japanese declaration of war against Nationalist and Communist China the U.S. government passed an executive order banning all export of military equipment to Japan. This piece of legislation had almost no effect since Japan was nearly self-sufficient in military gear and only imported raw materials from the US.

All the way up until the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor there was extensive trade between the USA and Japan. With the increase in Japanese aggression in the Pacific the USA tried to put bans on exports of certain goods through legislation, but Japan countered this by re-import through third countries.

All the way up until the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor there was extensive trade between the USA and Japan. With the increase in Japanese aggression in the Pacific the USA tried to put bans on exports of certain goods through legislation, but Japan countered this by re-import through third countries.

After a stunning final victory over the German Wehrmacht, the Soviet Army continued pressing westwards. The Soviet Army at once started creating communist administrations and blocked efforts to bring legal governments-in-exile back to power. This was a major diplomatic insult to the Allies and all other democratic countries. Requisitions, confiscation of private property, and brutal enforcement of the new Soviet order were common. The Soviet actions shocked the peoples of all democratic countries.
As conflict broke out between North Korea and South Korea, American forces were quickly moved to intervene and support the South Korean armed forces.

With growing problems in Korea and several major powers taking an interest in the fate of Korea it became obvious that a joint solution was needed.  The major powers met at the Moscow Conference to settle the fate of Korea once and for all.  Negotiations quickly showed that the only acceptable solution would be joint trusteeship for the four powers - USA, USSR, UK and China.  The way forward seemed clear until this morning when the Soviet delegates presented demands for full control over the Korean peninsula.  Suddenly the negotiations are collapsing and it looks like this could mean war.

With growing problems in Korea and several major powers taking an interest in the fate of Korea it became obvious that a joint solution was needed.  The major powers met at the Moscow Conference to settle the fate of Korea once and for all.  Negotiations quickly showed that the only acceptable solution would be joint trusteeship for the four powers - USA, USSR, UK and China.

Shortly after the defeat of Japan, the USA established a military government in Korea to oversee the rebuilding of the country and counter any communist influence.  Their arrival meant the end of many of the local KPR governments and created further social upheaval.

The Panamanian government has raised a number of issues regarding the sovereignty of the Panama canal and surrounding areas that are currently under our control. We could offer a few concessions as well as raise our investments in Panama in order to secure the continued cooperation of the Panamanian government, or we could apply some extensive pressure to ensure that the Canal remains under our control.

The U.S. Congress has proposed the Pitman Act which permitting the United States Treasury to exchange Chinese silver dollars for American gold. This exchange will provide the Chinese government with greater access to foreign credit which will allow the Chinese army to purchase critical military supplies.

Although the Soviet Navy has been primarily a defensive tool, Stalin has decided that he would like the ability to project power with naval forces built around modern battleships and large cruisers.  As a part of this change in policy, the Soviet ambassador has approached the State Department with a request to acquire the technical knowledge from an American company.  If we agree to this measure it would allow the naval architecture firm of Gibbs and Cox to share design work about modern shipbuilding practices and modern dual purpose secondary battery mounts with their Soviet counterparts.
The Spanish government has informed us that they will not be dictated on who they can trade with. We cannot let this continue.
The Spanish government wisely decided to cease its trade activities with Germany.

President Franklin Roosevelt declared that Nazi-Fascist influence was growing in Argentina and that the Argentine government had failed to fulfill its obligations under the inter-American agreements. As a result, the U.S. government refused to allow American ships to call at Argentinean ports.
The Argentinean government has informed us that they will not be dictated to.
The Argentinean government has decided to cooperate with the Allies. A wise decision.
The Roosevelt administration froze Argentina's gold assets in the U.S. as the Argentinean government failed to cooperate fully in the war against the Axis powers.

Under pressure from the Roosevelt administration, the Spanish government agreed to restrict the shipment of raw materials to Germany and to limit the activities of Axis agents in Spain. In return, the U.S. government ended its embargo of oil shipments to Spain.

Following a coup in Bolivia the new government wished to open up diplomatic channels with the USA. Historically the U.S. refused to recognize the Bolivian government because it was more radical than the previous one.

The President of the USA conducted a state visit to Mexico to meet with the Mexican President. The two leaders expressed the good relations which existed between the two American republics as an example of the good neighbor policy.

The President of the USA conducted a state visit to Brazil to meet with the Brazilian President. The two leaders met on board a U.S. destroyer off Natal, Brazil and announced their joint determination to safeguard the sea lanes of the Atlantic Ocean.
Ecuador has denied us access to their bases.
The Ecuadorian government agreed to allow the U.S. government to build naval bases in the Galapagos Islands and the Santa Elena Peninsula.
The U.S. government requested permission to use air and naval bases on Ecuadorian territory.
Guatemala has denied us access to their bases.
The U.S. administration announced the establishment of U.S. air bases in Guatemala to help protect the Panama Canal.
The U.S. government requested permission to use air and naval bases on Guatemalan territory.
To reduce mounting inflation in China, the British government extended 50 million pounds and the U.S. government provided $500 million in credits to the Nationalist Chinese government.

For the first time, the reigning British monarchs, King George VI and Queen Elizabeth, visited the United States. The state visit was designed to bolster Anglo-Saxon relations in response to the increasing tensions in Europe.
The U.S. administration recalled the U.S. ambassador to Berlin in response to Germans violation of the Munich Agreement and the occupation of Bohemia and Moravia.
The U.S. administration and the Brazilian government concluded a series of agreements, through which the Brazilians received financial aid and general economic development assistance.

The British, Canadian, and American governments signed a major trade agreement, which the three countries had negotiated for a considerable period of time. Each state agreed to considerable trade concessions, a position which marked growing cooperation between the English-speaking countries.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureates for the 1947 Nobel Prize in Medicine. This year's laureates are Carl Ferdinand Cori and Gerty Theresa Cori (nÈe Radnitz) of USA, for their discovery of the course of the catalytic conversion of glycogen

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1946 years Nobel Prize in Medicine. This year's laureate is Herman Joseph Muller (USA), for the discovery of the production of mutations by means of X-ray irradiation.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1946 Nobel Prize in Physics. This year's laureate is Percy Williams Bridgman (USA), for the invention of an apparatus to produce extremely high pressures, and for the discoveries he made therewith in the field of high pressure physics.
The Nobel Foundation has named the laureates for the 1946 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. This year's laureates are James Batchelleer Sumner (USA), for his discovery that enzymes can be crystallized
The Nobel Foundation has named the laureates for the 1946 Nobel Peace Prize. This year's laureates are Emily Greene Balch (USA), as president of the international League for Peace and Freedom
The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1945 Nobel Peace Prize. This year's laureate is Cordell Hull (USA), for his prominent participation in the origination of the United Nations.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureates for the 1944 Nobel Prize in Medicine. This year's laureates are Joseph Erlanger and Herbert Spencer Gasser (USA), for their discoveries relating to the highly differentiated functions of single nerve fibres.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1944 Nobel Prize in Physics. This year's laureate is Isidor Isaac Rabi (USA), for his resonance method for recording the magnetic properties of atomic nuclei.
The Nobel Foundation has named the laureates for the 1943 Nobel Prize in Medicine. This year's laureates are Henrik Carl Peter Dam (Denmark), for the discovery of vitamin K.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1943 Nobel Prize in Physics. This year's laureate is Otto Stern (USA), for his contribution to the development of the molecular ray method and his discovery of the magnetic moment of the proton.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1939 Nobel Prize in Physics. This year's laureate is Ernest Orlando Lawrence (USA), for the invention and development of the cyclotron and for results obtained with it, particularly with regard to artificial radioactive elements.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1937 Nobel Prize in Literature. This year's laureate is Pearl Buck (pen-name of Pearl Walsh, nÈe Sydenstricker) of USA, for her rich and truly epic descriptions of peasant life in China and for her biographical masterpieces.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1936 Nobel Prize in Literature. This year's laureate is Eugene Gladstone O'neill (USA), for the power, honesty and deep-felt emotions of his dramatic works, which embody an original concept of tragedy.
The Nobel Foundation has named the laureates for the 1936 Nobel Prize in Physics. This year's laureates are Victor Franz Hess (Austria), for his discovery of cosmic relation

When the Spanish Civil War broke out in July 1936, Texas Oil Company president Thorkild Rieber ordered oil tankers bound for Spain to be redirected to the insurgents. Although the U.S. policy was one of non-intervention, oil was not listed as a war material under the Neutrality Act. Texas Oil supplied Franco with $6 million in oil on credit during the civil war, and was fined only $22,000 for falsely declaring the shipments were going to France and not Spain. Additional supplies including over 12,000 trucks were sold to the Nationalists by American companies including Ford, Studebaker, Standard Oil, and General Motors.
Despite the war in Finland throughout the first months of the war USA continued to sell military equipment to the USSR. This amounted to almost $32 million worth of military equipment.

Today the American president made an announcement regarding the U.S. policy on U.S. citizens participating in foreign wars. He repeated that any American citizen who participates on any side of a non-U.S. conflict will loose his American citizenship. Americans participating in the Finnish-Soviet war however would not lose their citizenship, since there had never been a formal Declaration of War from the Soviets.

The American Congress decided today that whereas further support could not be given to the Finnish military it could still be deemed appropriate to issue money in support of the civilian population in Finland. As a consequence of this policy Finland was granted a total of $600,000 in help to the civilian population.

Shortly after the outbreak of war the Finnish ambassador in Washington, ProcopÈ relayed a request by the Finnish Prime minister Ryti that a loan of $60 million be given to Finland. The money is needed to buy necessary supplies for the Finnish army.
With the events in Europe intensifying, the U.S. weighed options on whether to stay and continue searching for oil or to leave.

In the mid 1930s, the Afghans were seeking contracts with people to attempt to find oil. The primary choice of the Afghan government was the U.S., in hopes of establishing a legation. The Afghans refused to give it the Russians or British, the French showed no interest, and there would surely be protests for giving contracts to Germany and Japan.

Bolivia was one of the most important producers of tin. In 1942, the Bolivian government decided to sell the tin to the U.S.A. at incredibly cheap prices. In exchange, the American-sponsored Bohan mission helped Bolivia in developing the more remote lands and in improving industry and infrastructures.
Niels Bohr is captured by the Germans and is probably working for them now. We should intensify our own research.
Niels Bohr escaped from Denmark and soon joined the top secret Manhattan Project.

After a stunning final victory over the German Wehrmacht, the Soviet Army continued pressing westwards. The Soviet Army at once started creating communist administrations and blocked efforts to bring legal governments-in-exile back to power. This was a major diplomatic insult to the Allies and all other democratic countries. Requisitions, confiscation of private property, and brutal enforcement of the new Soviet order were common. The Soviet actions shocked the peoples of all democratic countries.

Hit twice as hard by the Great Depression and almost completely ignored by the New Deal, African Americans hoped to benefit from the high paying boom in war industry as America became the 'Arsenal of Democracy' during the 1940s. Unfortunately, 75% of all war industries refused to hire blacks for any position, and another 15% only hired janitors and menial laborers. Frustrated by this, the NAACP demanded action from the Federal government. A. Phillip Randolph, leader of the Union of Black Porters, organized a mass protest and march on Washington to involve 100,000 African Americans. Alarmed by this threat to national image and the crusade for his 'Four Freedoms', Roosevelt met with Randolph and other civil rights leaders two weeks before the scheduled date of the protest. When Roosevelt asked what could be done to stop the march, Randolph demanded an Executive Order outlawing discrimination of any kind in war industry hiring practices.

In 1942, after rejecting the British requests for the Treaty Ports, Eire decided to offer the use of the ports instead to the U.S. Navy.  Under the new proposal, the ports would fall to U.S. Navy administration, and no combat troops would be placed on Irish soil.  American officials initially jumped at the offer, only to reject it later when the Royal Navy stated that the ports were no longer crucial to the war effort.
China has presented its case to the League of Nations and it is clear that Japan is the aggressor. They are in violation of the Kellogg Peace Act and we should issue a protest note to them.

Stalin never forgot his enemies, no matter how long ago they opposed him, or how far away they were from the Kremlin. One of Stalin's most important enemies was Leon Trotsky, former creator and first commander of the Red Army, second in command under Lenin, and a founding figure of the Bolshevist movement. After losing the struggle for power after Lenin's demise, Trotsky was exiled from the USSR. He relocated from country to country, constantly tracked by Stalin's spies and assassins. Finally, in August 1940, he was killed by NKVD operatives in Mexico. Stalin's brutal action shocked public opinion both in Mexico and in the USA.

The East Coast of the United States was devastated by one of the worst natural disasters on record, when a major hurricane, with steady winds up to 121mph and waves as high as 50 feet, smashed across Long Island, leaving a swath of ruin across large parts of New York and New England. By the time it was finished, 700 people had been killed, 8900 homes were destroyed, and around 63,000 people were made homeless. In all, over 2 billion trees were lost. The hurricane incited massive fear in a nervous economy, by incurring $6.2 million in damage losses ($15 billion 1998 dollars).

During the 1930s, while the Great Depression raged, the situation for the southern plains of the United States was made even worse by the disastrous Dust Bowl. Years of drought and deep plowing had exposed the top soil of the fertile plains to high winds. Dust storms blanketed the states of the region, devastating farms and wreaking havoc on communities. The Dust Bowl brought further hardship to an already strained economy. By 1938, the conditions had eased somewhat, and the worst of the storms had passed. The United States breathed a little easier.

After the successful German invasion and occupation of the British Isles, the United States was faced with the choice of intervening. They had to choose whether or not to deliver an ultimatum to Hitler, demanding an immediate ceasefire on the British front and a German withdrawal from the British Isles. Bureaucratic elements had steadily lost support for the isolationist policy in the United States after the Battle of Britain, and popular opinion on the sovereignty and independence of the United Kingdom effectively forced the American government to issue the ultimatum to Hitler. Germany ignored the ultimatum and continued to fight in the United Kingdom. German diplomats, however, were interested in delaying conflict with the U.S.A.

After the successful German invasion and occupation of the British Isles, the United States was faced with the choice of intervening. They had to choose whether or not to deliver an ultimatum to Hitler, demanding an immediate ceasefire on the British front and a German withdrawal from the British Isles. Bureaucratic elements had steadily lost support for the isolationist policy in the United States after the Battle of Britain, and popular opinion on the sovereignty and independence of the United Kingdom effectively forced the American government to issue the ultimatum to Hitler.

The mid-term elections were a good way for the government to gauge public reaction to the President's policies in his first two years of the term. The elections also signaled a realignment in the balance of power in the legislative branch. Voters turned out in droves to the polls to grade the President.

In 1936, the Supreme Court declared many of Roosevelt's New Deal programs unconstitutional. Fearing the total collapse of his reforms, Roosevelt embarked on a plan to influence the makeup of the Supreme Court. Proposed in early 1937, the Court-Packing Plan was designed to expand the number of judges from 9 to 15, as well as to encourage retirement of justices by age 70 by granting them full pay.

Icelandic bases were strategically critical to the Battle of the Atlantic. With Denmark quickly falling to German aggression, Britain was forced to act swiftly to control the Icelandic region, or risk defeat in the Atlantic. British Marines landed in Reykjavik and seized strategic control of Iceland and Greenland. This was a serious setback for Germany in the Atlantic. Some months after British marines landed in Iceland, control was handed over to U.S. forces.

During April and May 1939, Swiss envoys pleaded with the United States (who were neutral at this time) to support them with supplies in the event of a war in Europe. At first the U.S. denied these requests, but eventually did agree, and by the time war broke out in September 1939, American supplies were reaching Switzerland.

During April and May 1939, Swiss envoys pleaded with the United States (who were neutral at this time) to support them with supplies in the event of a war in Europe. At first the U.S. denied these requests, but eventually did agree, and by the time war broke out in September 1939, American supplies were reaching Switzerland.

Under the brutal rule of Trujillo, almost all of the progress made by the previous administration was erased. Now rumors began to trickle in that Trujillo was killing Haitians by the thousands. Haiti was prepared for a war. However, the USA wanted to intervene to negotiate peace between the two.

One of the largest and most ambitious projects ever attempted in engineering, the Golden Gate Bridge linked Oakland to San Francisco. On 27th May 1937, the bridge was finally completed. Like the Boulder dam, it served to bring thousands of jobs to the West Coast, and gave people valuable work experience.

Part of President Franklin Delano Roosevelt's Five year plan, the Boulder dam was a mammoth project that increased electrical availability to isolated areas in the interior of the USA.  Construction of the dam employed a significant amount of workers. It was a real sign that Roosevelt's plan could work well.

Throughout his term as President, Alfred Smith found it difficult to pass the programs of social reform and military increases he had proposed. A strong Republican Congress kept him from bringing back any of the New Deal programs of Roosevelt, and his foreign policy was increasingly mocked in government circles. To counteract this rise in isolationism, Smith gave a notable speech in March 1941, where he called on Americans to dream big, and use America's prosperity to provide 'Guns For Liberty' for the Allies overseas.

History recorded President Wilkie as a reluctant interventionist. Originally supportive of foreign involvement, Wendell Wilkie had used isolationism to get elected. As war broke out overseas, he found himself returning to form and seeing a need for some US involvement. Heavy isolationist opposition made this almost impossible, and the issue came to a head in March 1941, when Wilkie gave his famous speech calling on Americans to ëopen their minds and hearts to the troubles of this world, and become the true Armory of Freedomí. It was a speech designed to minimize the backlash his programs of foreign aid would create.

The growing wars overseas frightened many Americans into calling for increased foreign aid and involvement. Fearing the Democrats would take advantage of the growing interventionist sentiment, President Landon gave his famous speech of March 1941, speaking out about the horrors of war and how America would prosper by staying out of it. To rousing cheers, Landon concluded with his famous line, ëLet the fools die, for our boys will stay home'.

The growing conflict in Europe convinced President Roosevelt that America had to get involved and bring its industrial power over to the side of the Allies. He explained these concepts in his speech in March 1941, referring to America as the 'Arsenal of Democracy'. Through force of will and gradual persuasion, Roosevelt increased American aid to Allied belligerents and slowly convinced more and more of the folks at home that war was inevitable.

The failure of government policies in the late 1930s increased social dissent and kept America firmly out of any foreign involvement. Emboldened by this growth of isolationist sentiment, the Republicans turned to Robert Taft as their presidential candidate in 1940. Condemning the mistakes of the past and of the New Deal, Taft sought to restore public confidence and wealth by going after corrupt businessmen and magnates, who he said 'were a blot on the American landscape'. Swept into office on a tide of public enthusiasm, Taft immediately went to work, proposed his first round of legislation, dubbed the 'Prosperity for the People' program, which was a series of laws criminalizing bad business behavior. The program was coupled with high protective tariffs and bans on arms exports.

World events of the late 1930s made many Americans question the wisdom of isolationism and the policies of President Landon. The mediocre successes of his Just and Fair Deal led many to wish for a return of the progressive Democratic legislation of the early 1930s. Campaigning in favor of an increased American role in world affairs, and bringing back some of the New Deal programs, Alfred Smith succeeded in winning a major electoral victory in 1940, defeating Alf Landon and bringing the Democrats back to power. The major part of President Smith's foreign policy was the reformation of the restrictive Neutrality Acts, passed in the early 1930s.

During the election campaign of 1940, Wendell Wilkie supported foreign policies that many critics pointed out were not much different than Rooseveltís. To distance himself from his opponent, Wilkie became increasingly critical of Roosevelt as a 'warmonger', portraying him as someone trying to get America into war as soon as possible. The success of this strategy prompted Wilkie to adopt increasingly isolationist positions as his lead in the polls increase. He adopted the famous slogan ëRepeal Rooseveltí, promising to restore the restrictive Neutrality Acts of the 1930s. Wilkie was elected by a large margin and had to consider fulfilling his promise.

Pleased by his repeal of the New Deal programs in the late 1930ís, isolationists rallied around Alf Landon, leading to a huge re-election victory over his Democratic opponents in 1940. Flush with success, Landon embarked on a new program designed to curb the power of the munitions companies, who were calling for loosening of the restrictive Neutrality Acts. With war looming in Europe, Republicans wanted to keep America out, and arms exports were seen as a dangerous way of getting involved in unwanted conflict. To prevent this, Landon proposed the Homeland Act, a program of restrictions designed to tighten, if not eliminate, arms exports outside of the country.

Roosevelt spent his second term in office revising the restrictive Neutrality Acts of the early 1930s, trying to slowly prepare American business for the conflicts that were looming in Europe and Asia. The adjustments to the neutrality laws permitted some forms of munitions exports, albeit less than what Roosevelt had hoped for. In the end, munitions manufacturers were satisfied with an opportunity to increase their profits by shipping more arms overseas. Roosevelt's re-election victory in 1940 made this transition complete.

After their electoral victory in 1936, the Republicans were eager to dismantle Roosevelt's social legislation. Fearing public backlash, they chose their course with care, debating between the gradual removal of each provision of the New Deal, or to eliminate the entire package in one bill of repeal. Pundits dubbed it the 'Just and Proper Deal', and it spelled the end of Rooseveltís legacy. Nervous investors watched carefully to see what the economic implications would be. President Alf Landon proposed the first of the bills in early 1937.

Although its legislation was passed in 1935, it was not until Roosevelt's election victory in 1936 that his 'Second New Deal' was considered permanent. It included such bills as: the Works Progress Administration Act, National Labor Relations Act, and the Social Security Act, and was designed to boost industrial production and put the great unemployed masses to work. The Second New Deal was economically a mixed success, but it did help restore the confidence of the American public as they eased their way out of the Great Depression.

After the rapid defeat of France by the mighty forces of Germany, the United States was faced with a choice. Although isolationist policies still dominated the political scene, many felt sympathetic to the victims of the Nazi juggernaut.

'There is no chance of reconciliation?'.'No, we fight for Spain. They fight against Spain. We've decided to proceed at any cost'.'But you'll have to kill half of the Spanish population!'.'I've said: at any cost!'. This is an excerpt of an interview with Franco by an American reporter a few months after the start of the war. The North American press was the main body responsible for showing the world the atrocities committed by both sides: the extermination policy of the Fascist side, and vigilante justice by Republican militias. Literary figures such as Capa or Hemingway, arrived in Spain, gaining much inspiration for their works. It was after observing the war that Hemingway wrote his famous novel: 'For whom the bell tolls'.
Millions of civilians volunteered or were conscripted for military service once the United States were dragged into the war.
Millions of American men registered for military service at the introduction of the Selective Service Act.

After the onset of the Second World War, President Roosevelt gave public assurance to the people of Canada by saying: 'I can give assurance to you that the people of the United States will not stand idly by if domination of Canadian soil is threatened by any other empire.'

After the onset of the Second World War, President Roosevelt gave public assurance to the people of Canada by saying: 'I can give assurance to you that the people of the United States will not stand idly by if domination of Canadian soil is threatened by any other empire.'

As Japanese forces advanced on Nanjing, diplomats from western countries were evacuated. Several U.S. diplomatic staff were on the gunboat 'Panay' when it was attacked by Japanese aircraft. It was destroyed just offshore from Nanjing while evacuating. The Japanese foreign minister did not immediately apologize, and those responsible went unpunished. Japan used the incident to state that U.S. forces were no longer welcome in Asia.

As Japanese forces advanced on Nanjing, diplomats from western countries were evacuated. Several U.S. diplomatic staff were on the gunboat 'Panay' when it was attacked by Japanese aircraft. It was destroyed just offshore from Nanjing while evacuating. The Japanese foreign minister immediately apologized, and those responsible were brought to justice.

The industrial stimulation program enacted last year has not achieved it's objectives.  Authorities report only limited growth in a number of industries, citing labor unrest and delivery delays as primary causes for failure.
The industrial stimulation program enacted last year has been successful and local authorities report significant growth in a number of industries.

The industrial stimulation program enacted last year has not achieved it's objectives.  Authorities report only limited growth in a number of industries, citing labor unrest and delivery delays as primary causes for failure.

During the mid and late 1930s Great Britain was seeking prosperity and stability while protecting the status quo of the Empire.  The wealth of colonies around the world was flowing back to the Home Isles and helping industrial growth as well as funding massive government investment.  While Great Britain remains at peace you will be able to influence which areas will gain the majority of government funding each year.

While Great Britain remains at peace you will be able to influence which areas will gain the majority of government funding each year.

The fascist Italian government has proven to the rest of the world that it is not a peace-loving regime. The continuous attempts by Italy to recreate an empire ruled from Rome, demand our immediate attention. We must intervene and once and for all stop the Italian warmongers.

Cypriots are volunteering to fight against the Axis even though there was no organized effort to recruit them into our army. This volunteer force will certainly come to good use in our fight against the enemy. Historically, over 30,000 Cypriots volunteered to fight the Axis powers during the course of World War II.

Cypriots are volunteering to fight against the Axis even though there was no organized effort to recruit them into our army. This volunteer force will certainly come to good use in our fight against the enemy. Historically, over 30,000 Cypriots volunteered to fight the Axis powers during the course of World War II.

With the opening of hostilities between the Axis powers and Greece, Cypriots are volunteering to fight against the enemy in their homeland of Greece, even though there was no organized effort to recruit them into our army. This volunteer force will certainly come to good use in the upcoming Greek campaign. Historically, over 6000 Cypriots volunteered to fight Germans and Italians on mainland Greece during the spring of 1941.
The Republicans have declined our proposal, and thus, the Nationalists are bound to win.
The Republicans has accepted our alliance offer, and thus another world war has broken out. Germany is going to be stopped, once and for all.

Hitler has once again shown aggression and this time it is dangerous, and might lead to another world war. Germany has already broken the Neutrality Pact regarding Spanish Civil War by sending supplies and advisors to the Nationalists' army, but this is going to far. In addition, having a country allied with Germany threatening France's south flank could be very too dangerous in the times to come. On the other hand, a direct intervention of the Allies in the Spanish war could cause another horrible war in all of Europe. What should we do?

Yugoslav government has approved the purchase of a number of Hawker Hurricane Mk. I fighter aircraft from us. This has had a favorable effect on our prestige as an aircraft manufacturer, as well as giving us some influence with the Yugoslav government. Historically, in 1938 Yugoslavia purchased 24 Hawker Hurricane Mk. I from the United Kingdom, while a further 20 planes were built under license by Zmaj at Zemun in Yugoslavia.

The government of Yugoslavia is considering a purchase of a small number of Hawker Hurricane Mk. I fighter aircraft. They might also be interesting in purchasing the designs and a license to manufacture some more in their own country. Many members of our government favor assisting the Yugoslav government, the successor to Serbia, as acknowledgement of their assistance against the Austro-Hungarian Empire in the Great War.

Yugoslavia has purchased a small number of Bristol Blenheim Mk I tactical bombers as well as the designs and a manufacturing license. This will show to the world that British aircraft are still the technologically most advanced models. Historically, in 1936 Yugoslavia purchased 22 Bristol Blenheim Mk I tactical bombers from United Kingdom with a further 16 being built under license by Zmaj Factory at Zemun. They replaced the old Breguet 19 and Potez 25 biplanes in the tactical bomber role.

When situation in France became critical, UK hastily created volunteer units (LDV) to secure defense of Home Islands. On 23rd August 1940, Winston Churchill changed the name of the LDV to the Home Guard. The government was expecting 150,000 men to volunteer for the Home Guard. Within the first month, 750,000 men had volunteered, and by the end of June 1940, the total number of volunteers was over one million. The number of men in the Home Guard did not fall below one million until they were stood down in December 1944. This effort allowed Royal Army to reform and regain strength after the Dunkirk catastrophe.

With the Italian invasion of Greece under way, General Metaxas, Prime Minister of Greece has requested aid from Britain. In conjunction with the stated guarantees of Greek independence, and the familial relationship between our monarchs, aid is certainly a possibility.  Historically, the UK and the Commonwealth sent arms, munitions, and troops to Greece, ending in the mass evacuation from Crete of British, Greek, and New Zealand forces to Egypt.
We are at war and must mobilize what is left of the Empire.
We are at war and must mobilize the Empire.
German aggression in Czechoslovakia shows that diplomacy has failed, we must prepare for war and mobilize territorial forces.
