In a speech in the Reichstag, Chancellor Adolf Hitler officially renounced the Anglo-German Naval Treaty of 1935, which had restricted the German navy to one-third the size of the Royal Navy, as well as the German-Polish Non-Aggression Pact of 1934, accusing the British and Polish governments of attempting to encircle Germany. Chancellor Hitler also renewed his demands on Poland regarding Posen and Danzig and offered bilateral non-aggression pacts to the Scandinavian and Baltic states. In response, the Polish government gave up its demand of a proposed guarantee from Russia and now supported British efforts to attract the Soviet government into a new peace front.

The British government took major steps in addressing the country's woeful state of military preparedness, by introducing a national register for war service. This program was voluntary, but the British government, in light of the Munich Crisis, began a major effort to modernize the kingdom's military forces. This included the purchase of large numbers of American aircraft.

American aviator Amelia Earhart has become the first woman to fly from the Horn of Africa across the Arabian Sea to Karachi. She landed there with her navigator Fred Noonan today after the historic flight. She will be laying over there for a day to have some maintenance done on her plane before flying to Calcutta. From Calcutta, she will be crossing Siam and Malaya on her way to the Dutch East Indies and Australia. She will continue on to the United States from there.

After Italy invaded Ethiopia, England started on a major campaign in the League of Nations to have international sanctions imposed on Italy.  This behavior came across as extremely hypocritical to the Italian public.

Italy has agreed to our peace proposal. England is to secede to Italy all north African holdings (including all Egyptian claimed provinces) and territories to expand their Ethiopian colony.  All Mediterranean bases (except Gibraltar) will now be under their control and an Italian claim on Saudi Arabia will be recognized. Jerusalem and Amman are also to be seceded to Italy. Egypt, Iraq, and Syria are to be reconstituted and their independence recognized by both Italy and England. Syria is to secede Rawah, Iraq is to secede Mosul and At Turayg, and Egypt is to secede all holdings west of the Nile except Al Minyah and Sawhaj.

Northern Africa and Egypt have fallen to the Italians and we have no remaining allies in the Middle East. We have been unable to press the siege of their Ethiopian colony and their armies have opened up a corridor to get supplies in through the mountains. Our ports in the Mediterranean are gone, as well as our principal submarine base, Malta. Can we afford to continue the fight against the Germans and the Italians together? Perhaps we should send a peace envoy to Mussolini? Unalterable conditions will include: The reconstitution of all allies in the region in some form (except Lebanon), access to the Suez canal through independent Egypt, and Britain will retain Kuwait, Gibraltar, and control over Yemen and Oman.

After a stunning final victory over the German Wehrmacht, the Soviet Army continued pressing westwards. The Soviet Army at once started creating communist administrations and blocked efforts to bring legal governments-in-exile back to power. This was a major diplomatic insult to the Allies and all other democratic countries. Requisitions, confiscation of private property, and brutal enforcement of the new Soviet order were common. The Soviet actions shocked the peoples of all democratic countries.
As conflict broke out between North Korea and South Korea, American forces were quickly moved to intervene and support the South Korean armed forces.

With growing problems in Korea and several major powers taking an interest in the fate of Korea it became obvious that a joint solution was needed.  The major powers met at the Moscow Conference to settle the fate of Korea once and for all.  Negotiations quickly showed that the only acceptable solution would be joint trusteeship for the four powers - USA, USSR, UK and China.  The way forward seemed clear until this morning when the Soviet delegates presented demands for full control over the Korean peninsula.  Suddenly the negotiations are collapsing and it looks like this could mean war.

With growing problems in Korea and several major powers taking an interest in the fate of Korea it became obvious that a joint solution was needed.  The major powers met at the Moscow Conference to settle the fate of Korea once and for all.  Negotiations quickly showed that the only acceptable solution would be joint trusteeship for the four powers - USA, USSR, UK and China.
Even after another warning, Portugal will not embargo the Axis.
Despite continued demands, Portugal refuses to embargo Germany. It's trading is supplying the Nazis with much needed tungsten, canned food, tin and wool products.

Starting in the early 1930s, Portugal began a rearmament program to bring their forces up to date. This process, which started slowly, was accelerated with the start of the Spanish Civil War. The British government, trying to influence Portugal away from Germany, offered it's help.

Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, resigned his office in protest against Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's determination to reach an agreement with the Italian government before the settlement of the Spanish Civil War. Secretary Eden was a champion of the League of Nations and the collective security system. He was replaced by Lord Halifax.
Finland has requested the full support of the Allies in their struggle against the Soviets. Now is the time when we live up to our word or lose a lot of the influence that we have around the world.
We have asked for military access from Norway to ease our troops' travel to Finland should the need arise. Norway has denied our request.
We have asked for military access from Norway to ease our troops' travel to Finland should the need arise. Norway has accepted our request and we now have military access to Norway.

During late 1944 the Danish resistance movement was feeling pressured by the Gestapo. Several resistance leaders had been captured and they had been imprisoned at the Shell-House, the Gestapo headquarters in Denmark, and the evidence was being collected there as well. A desperate telegram was sent to London begging for an attack on the Shell-House: the RAF had to attack at all cost. On the 21st March 1945, 20 mosquito bombers with escorts launched the attack in 3 waves. The outcome was both a success and a disaster. A success because 16 out of 24 prisoners survived and most of the evidence was destroyed. A disaster because one of the bombers in the first wave hit a lighting pole during flight and crashed into a school. Some of the 2nd wave and all of the 3rd wave mistook the fire at the school as the target and dropped their bombs on the school. 123 civilians, 87 of them children were killed when the school burned down.
To reduce mounting inflation in China, the British government extended 50 million pounds and the U.S. government provided $500 million in credits to the Nationalist Chinese government.
British Prime Minister Winston Churchill traveled to Ottawa to speak before the Canadian Parliament and reaffirm the war effort against the Axis powers.
The Romanian government officially severed the Anglo-French guarantee of territorial integrity and sought to improve relations with the German government.

For the first time, the reigning British monarchs, King George VI and Queen Elizabeth, visited the United States. The state visit was designed to bolster Anglo-Saxon relations in response to the increasing tensions in Europe.
Portugal has refused our proposed agreement.
Portugal has decided to sign the agreement with us.

The British and Portuguese governments reaffirmed their ancient alliance. This agreement secured Britain's strategic sea lanes to Africa and the Mediterranean. The Portuguese also demonstrated their desire to work with both the Western and Fascist powers.

King George VI and Queen Elizabeth arrived in Canada to begin an official state visit to the dominion. This was the first time a British monarch visited Canada and the Canadian welcome reinforced Anglo-Canadian ties.
Despite the growing influence of Germany on the Balkan countries, Turkey refused to sign a mutual aid agreement with the UK.
In light of the growing threat of increased German influence in the Balkans, Turkey decided to sign a mutual aid agreement with UK.

The British and Turkish governments announced a mutual aid agreement in the event of aggression or war, which marked the expansion of military assistance treaties in Eastern Europe to the Middle East. In spite of close economic ties with Germany, the Turkish government supported a British bloc to check German expansion into the Balkans.

The British government introduced military conscription for all men aged 20-21 in an effort to increase the kingdom's military forces by 300,000 men. The Chamberlain government also increased military expenditures to $3 billion for one year.
In fear that such an agreement may move Rumania even closer to a conflict with Germany, the Rumanian government has decided to refuse our offer of a mutual aid agreement.
In light of the growing from Germany, the Rumanian government has decided to enter into a mutual aid agreement with UK and France.
In fear that such an agreement may move Greece even closer to a conflict with Italy, the Greek government has decided to refuse our offer of a mutual aid agreement.
In light of the growing fear of an Italian invasion of Greece through Albania, the Greek government has decided to enter into a mutual aid agreement with UK and France.

The British and French governments extended their mutual assistance pacts to the Greek and Rumanian governments in an attempt to bolster a united front against Germany and Italy in the Balkans. The Italian annexation of Albania placed Greece in direct danger of invasion, while the Germans placed pressure on the Romanians.

The British and French governments extended their mutual assistance pacts to the Greek and Romanian governments in an attempt to bolster a united front against Germany and Italy in the Balkans. The Italian annexation of Albania placed Greece in direct danger of invasion, while the Germans placed pressure on the Romanians.
Chamberlain has managed to find substantial leverage regarding the future stability in the Mediterranean during his visit to Italy.
Chamberlain's visit to Italy has only brought very small gains in regards to stability in the Mediterranean.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Foreign Secretary Lord Halifax conducted an official visit to Rome to confer with Italian Premier Benito Mussolini. The British leaders hoped to find some leverage with the Italians to maintain the status quo in the Mediterranean.

The British, Canadian, and American governments signed a major trade agreement, which the three countries had negotiated for a considerable period of time. Each state agreed to considerable trade concessions, a position which marked growing cooperation between the English-speaking countries.

In response to German military maneuvers, the British government announced the mobilization of the Royal Navy with plans to concentrate most of the fleet by early September. The Chamberlain government warned that the British would not back down from the crisis in Czechoslovakia.

With the signing of the Greco-Bulgarian agreement, the British and French governments provided a $10 million loan to the Bulgarian government to pay for the kingdom's rearmament program. The British and French sought to incorporate the Bulgarians in the Balkan Entente.

The British government sent Lord Runciman to Prague to investigate the condition of the German Sudetens. Lord Runciman's report supported the German claims. The fact that he made his base at one of his acquaintances in the area who was also a German Count is said to have had quite a bit of influence on his report.
King George VI and Queen Elizabeth conducted an official state visit to Paris. This visit was conducted to highlight Anglo-French solidarity and as a counter-demonstration to Hitler's visit to Rome.
Italy has rejected our generous offer.

The British and Italian governments agreed to mutually respect each other's interests and rights in the Mediterranean and the maintenance of Spanish independence and integrity. The British government hoped to end tensions in the Mediterranean region as Germany was emerging as a greater threat to European security than Italy. Despite this treaty, the Italians continued to support the Nationalists in the Spanish Civil War and the British were unable to prevent military supplies from reaching the belligerents. The British sought to use the non-intervention agreements as a means to prevent the expansion of the Spanish Civil War into a general war, but the Italians flagrantly violated this principle.

The British and Italian governments agreed to mutually respect each other's interests and rights in the Mediterranean and the maintenance of Spanish independence and integrity. The British government hoped to end tensions in the Mediterranean region as Germany was emerging as a greater threat to European security than Italy.

The Italians are becoming an increasing threat in the Mediterranean area. One way on countering this could be through sending military advisors to Egypt and thereby increasing our own security in the area.
As the Fascist powers became increasingly aggressive in the Balkans, the United Kingdom extended a guarantee of independence for Greece to deter any further expansion.

In light of the recent German re-occupation of the Rhineland the governments of Belgium and France have asked us to reaffirm our determination to intervene should any of the two nations enter a state of war with Germany any time in the future.

The British parliament announced the marriage of Edward VIII and Wallis Simpson.  Mrs. Simpson is to be coroneted as queen to King Edward.  This is an obvious attempt to pander to right wing and pro-colonial elements in Britain, which does not bode well for the future.

Following consultations by London, the British parliament has decided that Edward can marry, but Mrs. Simpson will only be his consort.  It is obvious that Mr. de Valera's considered opinion was heeded not only by London, but across the Commonwealth as well.  The Irish government respects the decision of London.

Following various consultations, London has forced King Edward VIII to abdicate the throne in favor of his brother.  In true Irish fashion, de Valera delayed officially accepting the abdication for over a week, leaving Edward as King of Ireland for that period.  Taking advantage, de Valera passed several pieces of legislation, weakening the ties between Ireland and the Commonwealth.

On 10th December 1936, parliament made it known to King Edward VIII, that if he wanted to marry Wallis Simpson, he would be forced to sign an act of abdication, renouncing any claims he, or his heirs would have to the throne.  Edward signed the act, abdicating the throne in favor of his brother Albert (George VI).  Edward married Simpson, was made the Duke of Windsor, and moved to France, later moving to Portugal, before being made Governor of the Bahamas.

The British parliament was required by Commonwealth law to consult member states on matters concerning the Commonwealth as a whole.  As such, when the issue of Edward VIII's decision to marry arose as a matter of public debate, London sent three proposals to all the Commonwealth members: force Edward to abdicate if he wished to marry Wallis Simpson, accept Simpson as consort or accept Simpson as Queen.

As the situation revolving around Edward's decision to marry grew more and more intense, the British parliament was forced to act.  A decision was made, first by the cabinet, then by parliament as a whole, to find an acceptable solution, and restore stability to the monarchy as well as to the government.  As such, three options were put forward: force Edward to abdicate if he wished to marry Wallis Simpson, accept Simpson as consort or accept Simpson as Queen.

As time went on, it became quite apparent that Edward intended to marry Wallis Simpson, the American divorcee.  The King made it clear to the Prime Minister, and the Privy Council, that he will marry Mrs. Simpson, with or with out the approval of Parliament.  Edward's assertions on this matter have become public knowledge, and the MP's are clamoring for an inquiry.

The private life of Edward VIII was the subject of much speculation, and the fodder for many Fleet Street tabloids.  His repeated affairs and liaisons of dubious natures, gave the scandal reading public much to ponder.  One such affair was with the American Wallis Simpson, who obtained her divorce in mid 1936, with the intention of marrying Edward.
In January 1936, King George V of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland died.  The beloved monarch was succeeded by his eldest son, Edward.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1947 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. This year's laureate is Sir Robert Robinson (United Kingdom), for his investigations on plant products of biological importance, especially the alkaloids.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1947 Nobel Prize in Physics. This year's laureate is Sir Edward Victor Appleton (United Kingdom), for his investigations of the physics of the upper atmosphere - especially for the discovery of the so-called Appleton layer.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureates for the 1945 Nobel Prize in Medicine. This year's laureates are Sir Alexander Fleming and Ernst Boris Chain (United Kingdom) and Sir Howard Walter Florey (Australia), for the discovery of Penicillin and its curative effect in various infectious diseases.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1937 Nobel Peace Prize. This year's laureate is Cecil of Chelwood, Viscount (Lord Edgar Algernon Robert Gascoyne Cecil) of United Kingdom, for the foundation and presidency of the International Peace Campaign.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureates for the 1937 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. This year's laureates are Walter Norman Haworth (United Kingdom), for his investigations on carbohydrates and Vitamin C.

Start of Warsaw uprising was sudden, but rather expected by UK. Much earlier Polish and UK governments decided that to support expected national uprising UK will train and support some special forces units. Ultimately these units took shape of some small diversion groups and one large unit, 1st Paradrop Brigade, lead by General Sosabowski. When uprising started, this unit was left in Britain due to high risk of air drop so far from Isles. Later Polish paratroopers joined 1st Airborne Army in Operation Market-Garden.

The start of the Warsaw uprising was sudden, but rather expected by UK. At the start British government hoped that Warsaw will be fast relieved by advancing Soviet forces, but Stalin's lack of support to the Polish Home Army (AK) action complicated the whole situation. The only way to support AK were air drops. Historically allied strategic bombers starting from bases in Italy and North Africa delivered huge caches of AT weapons, equipment and medicines to Warsaw, but due to the chaotic nature of city fighting over half of these were captured by German units.

As the Red Army was advancing from the east, the German occupying forces were perceived to be on the defensive in Poland. Polish Home Army (AK), directed by the Polish Government-in-Exile in London, was eager to prove that Poland still got it's army and legal government. It was extremely important to counter Soviet attempts to install puppet governments, as well as gain support of UK and USA for post-war period. Warsaw Uprising was part of the plan 'Burza' (Storm) - large operation of partisan units supporting advancing Red Army and installing local administration cells on liberated territories. At that point Germans had a comparatively small military presence in the Polish capital. The decision was based on assumption that Red Army is so close to Warsaw, that it will be able to join AK any day.
We have asked for military access from Sweden to ease our troops' travel to Finland should the need arise. Sweden has denied our request.
We have asked for military access from Sweden to ease our troops' travel to Finland should the need arise. Sweden has accepted our request and we now have military access to Sweden.

If Finland decides to make a formal request for help from the Allies then we need to have plans ready for deployment of our troops. If we have to make landing in the USSR it will make it very difficult for us. If we can get military access from Norway or Sweden we could deploy our troops very close to the front.

The situation in Finland is getting increasingly desperate. Can we really sit and watch as Finland gets overrun by the communists? We have units being assembled and getting ready to depart. We could make assurances to Finland that we will aid them if they make a formal request.

The situation in Finland is becoming more and more difficult. Maybe now is the time when we should step in and send assurances to our democratic friends in Finland and while we are at it send some bombers as well to aid them in their dire situation.
A change was declared today in UK policy on foreign volunteers. It was stated that all men age 27 or older may leave for military service in Finland.

The provincial government continues to press for an answer as to the legality of sending the volunteers that have assembled in Toronto to fight for Finland. We can no longer delay. We have to give them an answer.
The parliament has to decide whether to take more direct measures to aid Finland's struggle against USSR. We could send them some guns and ammunition.

The Finnish Winter War has resulted in massive donations to Finland by private people as well as business. These donations have amounted to more then 150,000 pounds and could make a real impact on the war.

The Finnish army fighting the Soviets was heavily outnumbered both in men and material and therefore the Finnish government sent a telegraph to its embassies in London and Paris requesting much needed supplies and military advisors.

Polish bomber PZL P-37 'Los' (Elk) was one of the best medium bombers of the late 1930s. It was very fast, reliable, safe and had an enormous bomb load of almost 2600 kg. Unfortunately, Polish industry could not provide it with a decent engine. After series of tests in 1936, the Department of Armaments decided to start a licence production of 'Bristol Pegasus XX' engines.

Historically, Polish modification of an excellent Bofors 37mm AT gun, the 'Armata pp. wz.36' was one of the best constructions of its times. Not only was it more reliable than the original, but also it was significantly cheaper (approximately 1000 UK pounds in 1937). In 1938 Poland sold several hundred of these together with a license to Great Britain, where they remained in active service until early 1950s, under the name of 'Ordnance QF 37mm Mk.1'.

Polish modification of an excellent Bofors 37mm AT gun, the 'Armata pp. wz.36' was one of the best constructions of its times. Not only was it more reliable than the original, but also it was significantly cheaper (approximately 1000 UK pounds in 1937). In 1938, Poland sold several hundred of these together with a license to Great Britain, where they remained in active service until early 1950s, under the name of 'Ordnance QF 37mm Mk.1'.

In the late 1930s, the British army started rearming. One of the main issues was lack of a decent AT weapon. Polish modification of an excellent Bofors 37mm AT gun, the 'Armata pp. wz.36' was one of the best constructions of its times. Not only was it more reliable than the original, but also it was significantly cheaper (approximately 1000 UK pounds in 1937). In 1938, Poland sold several hundred of these together with a license to United Kingdom, where they remained in active service until early 1950s, under the name of 'Ordnance QF 37mm Mk.1'.

Immediately after the regime change in Italy, Field Marshal Badoglio, the new Italian Prime Minister, started the secret contacts to sign an armistice with the Allies. After some intense negotiations, it was evident that Italy was in a desperate situation and accepted the hard terms: leave the Axis and sign peace with the Allies and the Soviet Union, return the prisoners on Italian soil, surrender the arsenal and give the Allies control over most of the country, establishing a military government, shared between UK and the USA. At the same time that the armistice was signed, the German troops in Italian soil took over most of the northern provinces and established a new Italian fascist government, the 'Repubblica Sociale Italiana', ruled by Mussolini, who was rescued from his prison by German paratroopers.

In 1943, new technology allowed British forces to contemplate a raid on the river dams of the Mohne and the Eder. The mission would be difficult, using a form of bouncing bomb to destroy the dams during a night raid against a well defended target, but the impact on German industry would be high.

After a stunning final victory over the German Wehrmacht, the Soviet Army continued pressing westwards. The Soviet Army at once started creating communist administrations and blocked efforts to bring legal governments-in-exile back to power. This was a major diplomatic insult to the Allies and all other democratic countries. Requisitions, confiscation of private property, and brutal enforcement of the new Soviet order were common. The Soviet actions shocked the peoples of all democratic countries.

After a stunning final victory over the German Wehrmacht, the Soviet Army continued pressing westwards. One victim of the Red Tide was Paris, the capital of France. The Soviet Army at once started creating communist administrations and blocked efforts to bring legal governments-in-exile back to power. This was a major diplomatic insult to the Allies and all other democratic countries.

After a stunning final victory over the German Wehrmacht, the Soviet Army continued pressing westwards. One victim of the Red Tide was Brussels, the capital of Belgium. The Soviet Army at once started creating communist administrations and blocked efforts to bring legal governments-in-exile back to power. This was a major diplomatic insult to the Allies and all other democratic countries.

After a stunning final victory over the German Wehrmacht, the Soviet Army continued pressing westwards. One victim of the Red Tide was Amsterdam, the capital of the Netherlands. The Soviet Army at once started creating communist administrations and blocked efforts to bring legal governments-in-exile back to power. This was a major diplomatic insult to the Allies and all other democratic countries.

After a stunning final victory over the German Wehrmacht, the Soviet Army continued pressing westwards. One victim of the Red Tide was Oslo, the capital of Norway. The Soviet Army at once started creating communist administrations and blocked efforts to bring legal governments-in-exile back to power. This was a major diplomatic insult to the Allies and all other democratic countries.

After a stunning final victory over the German Wehrmacht, the Soviet Army continued pressing westwards. One victim of the Red Tide was Copenhagen, the capital of Denmark. The Soviet Army at once started creating communist administrations and blocked efforts to bring legal governments-in-exile back to power. This was a major diplomatic insult to the Allies and all other democratic countries.

After Haile Selassie's flight to London the Italians found out that it would not be an easy task to pacify Ethiopia. A few local Rases were still resisting and launching guerilla attacks on the conquerors. A few submitted but as long as Italy did not have the Ethiopian nobility on her side there would be no peace in Africa Orientale Italiana. Mussolini tried to bribe the exiled Emperor with 1 million pounds and nominal sovereignty to satisfy the Ethiopian people's desire to be led by their Emperor, while keeping the actual power for Italy. Historically Haile Selassie I. declined. The Lion of Judah returned to power in 1942 invading his own country with the help of British forces from the Sudan. The world is watching, giving in to Fascist demands will reduce our standing and ensure Italian hegemony in Ethiopia. Defying the Fascists will increase our influence as we will be seen as upholding the rights of independent nations

On 14th August 1936, The Irish Free State established its own national airline, Aer Lingus.  As part of de Valera's plans to further weaken Ireland's dependence on England, Aer Lingus was to be the new commercial connection between Ireland and the world.  This led to the creation of Dublin International Airport, and eventually to the creation of Shannon International Airport.  Trans-Atlantic service begins later in 1937, Dublin to New York.

As Ireland grew more confident in her independence, and in Eammon de Valera, it gradually moved further away from the Anglo-Irish Treaty that had established the Irish Free state.  After serving a term as Chairman of the League of Nations, de Valera began a more rigorous diplomatic program for Ireland, culminating in the External Relations Act (1936). Passed in the wake of the abdication of Edward VIII, it removed the British monarch from having any say in Irish external affairs, except for the accreditation of its diplomats.  By the end of the year, Irish embassies were present in several nations, and no longer dependant on the graces of the Commonwealth.

On the 14th June 1937, Irish voters approved a new constitution put forth the previous year by Taoisiech Eammon de Valera. Following on the heels of the External Relations Act and the abdication of Edward VIII in Britain, de Valera moved Ireland away from the Commonwealth and the Anglo-Irish Treaty of 1921.  The new state no longer acknowledged the King of England as the head of state (except for accreditation of diplomats), and instead instituted a new office, President.  Douglas Hyde was elected the first President of Eire in 1938.

With Britain at war against Germany, and the Blitz full on, many in Eire decided to seek work in Britain to support the effort against Fascism.  In total some 12,000 men and women went to work in Ulster and mainland Britain during the war years.

In the spring of 1941, with America sitting on the sidelines, the Royal Navy wanted the use of the Irish ports more than ever.  After several cabinet meetings, Prime Minister Churchill opted to do what had previously been unthinkable, offer the Ulster province in exchange for the Irish ports and full alliance between Eire and Britain.  Despite the offer, Eire rejected the request.

Since 1916, the Irish Republican Army (IRA) had been a thorn in the side of British authorities.  Even with the end of the Anglo-Irish War in 1922, the IRA continued to actively campaign in the Northern counties.  Raids on police stations, army barracks, and government buildings continued apace right up until the Blitz began in 1940, despite efforts by both the Irish Free State and Britain.

Beginning in January 1939, the Irish Republican Army (IRA), began a series of bombings not only in Ulster, but in mainland Britain as well.  An IRA bomb in Coventry killed 5 and wounded 70 in August 1939.  The campaign's highlight was the raid on the Magazine Fort in Phoenix Park which netted the IRA several crates of ammunition and guns, as well as provided a spectacular explosion.  The campaign came to an end in March 1940, as the German Blitz heated up, and bombs began to fall not only on Britain, but on Ireland as well.
The U.S. Navy, with official backing of their government, have accepted the Irish offer to use the Treaty Ports in their war against fascism.

In early 1942, U.S. officials approached the British government and Admiralty with an offer they had received from the government in Eire.  The Irish were offering the use of the Treaty Ports, but only if the U.S. Navy was in charge, no combat troops passed through Ireland (or Ulster), and no British troops or navy personnel landed on Irish soil.  The Admiralty told the Americans that the ports were no longer necessary, and to reject the offer.

After rejecting the British requests for the Treaty Ports, Eire decided to offer the use of the ports to the U.S. Navy in 1942.  Under the proposal, the ports would be under U.S. Navy administration, and no combat troops would be placed on Irish soil. U.S. officials jumped at the offer, only to reject it when the Royal Navy said they were no longer necessary to the war effort.

Though having been drawn into the European war, Ireland was at last united under a democratic and Irish government.  The return of Ulster soothed many of the old antagonisms between Britain and Ireland.  The disruptions of the Unionists will be smoothed over, and they will be placated eventually.

The government of Eire accepted the final British offer for the use of the Treaty Ports.  As part of that agreement, His Majesty's government transferred control of the Ulster province to the Dublin administration, over the objections of pro-Union politicians in Ulster.

With Eire having rejected all offers and requests, the question was put to the British cabinet.  Take the ports by force, or struggle on with out them. Churchill and his ministers opted to move on, as getting involved in another conflict in Ireland was undesirable.
With Britain again in control of Dublin, the inevitable is apparent. Eire submits to Britain.

Facing the overwhelming British presence, Eire was left with little choice. Bringing another devastating war to Ireland, or a peace that preserved something of what had been gained. They opted for peace.
In a final flurry of diplomatic efforts, Britain made a final, almost unbearable demand upon Eire over the crisis.  Even up to the last minute, the Irish response was in doubt.
The de Valera government has agreed to talk.  Emergency discussions are now taking place.
Having brought Ireland and Britain back to war, the British government has offered terms for peace before war has truly begun.
Once again into the breech, British soldiers are off to fight in Ireland.
Following the refusal of the use of the Treaty ports, Britain decided to take them by force.  Irishmen responded to the renewed threat from England, and rallied to the Dublin government.

Fearing the rampant conquests of Germany, the Irish government decided that it had best make a decision regarding its safety.  In accordance with that, they accepted the Royal Navy's request for the Treaty Ports, in the hope that should Ireland be attacked, Britain and the other western Allies would come to their aid.

The immediacy of the situation in Britain led Churchill and his government to do what had been unthinkable.  Mainly, giving up the Ulster province to Eire in exchange for the Treaty Ports.  Despite the offer, and the achievement of a major Irish goal, de Valera refused the offer, unwilling to be drawn in to the conflict, and just as unwilling to help save Churchill.

The effects of the Anglo-Irish relationship since 1916, had long reaching effects.  Eire refused to allow the Royal Navy access to the Treaty Ports, citing her neutrality, and their desire to not be subject to any degree of British authority.  Especially as long as the six counties of Ulster remained under British dominion.

In 1940, the British government requested the use of the Treaty ports, 3 ports in Eire that had been under the control of the Royal Navy until 1938.  Eammon de Valera, Taoiseach of Eire, steadfastly wanted to remain neutral in the European conflict between Britain, France, and Germany.  Fearing that granting the British request would be seen as a hostile move by the Germans, and not wishing to give up what had been gained in Ireland, de Valera refused the request.

Begining in 1940, as the German U-Boats began to put a stranglehold on British shipping, some in the Royal Navy and government believed that by gaining the use of the former Treaty Ports in Ireland, they could break the Kreigsmarine in short order.  Churchill authorized contact be made with Dublin in regards to the ports at Cobh, Bantry Bay, and Lough Swilly.  The British cabinet held several options open regarding the ports, including taking them by force.  This was dubbed 'Plan W' by the Ministry of Defense, and envisioned quickly seizing Dublin and forcing a favorable response.

Having refused the agreement reached by the Plenipotentiaries, Ireland opted to continue their economic policy of sanctions against British goods and business.  All further negotiations were suspended.

When Eammon de Valera took office as Prime Minister of the Irish Free State in 1932, he began a program of protectionism and trade tariffs against Britain.  The British responded in kind, and so began the 'Economic War' between Ireland and Britain.  In 1937, negotiations began to end the disputes, and covered a myriad assortment of topics.  On 25th April 1938, an agreement was reached between the two nations.  The agreement dealt with issues of trade, tariffs, and ended British control of the Treaty Ports.

When Eammon de Valera took office as Prime Minister of the Irish Free State in 1932, he began a program of protectionism and trade tariffs against Britain.  The British responded in kind, and so began the 'Economic War' between Ireland and Britain.  In 1937, negotiations began to end the disputes, and covered a myriad assortment of topics.  On 25th April 1938, an agreement was reached between the two nations.  The agreement dealt with issues of trade, tariffs, and ended British control of the Treaty Ports.

On 2nd September 1939, a day after the War in Europe had begun, the Taoiseach of Eire, Eammon de Valera made a clear declaration that Ireland would remain neutral in the conflict.  De Valera was supported by the vast majority of the population in Eire in this policy, even though many believed that the British fight was just.  As such, many thousands of Irish men and women went on to volunteer for either military service in Britain, or as workers in British factories, while their homeland remained out of the conflict.

In the middle of 1936, the Irish Free State government, under Eammon de Valera, passed legislation outlawing the Irish Republican army (IRA) in the Free State.  Prior to this, the IRA had been free to recruit, and drill in the Free State, despite having been declared an illegal organization in the North in 1922.  The passage of the bill in the Free State angered some, who still held that they could force Britain to relinquish the six Northern Counties by force if necessary.  Others saw this as a further betrayal by de Valera of his Republican principles.
Having driven out Reza Pahlavi and gained Persian assent to military access, Britain promised to return territories conquered to Persia. If we refuse, our reputation will be severely damaged.
The Persians have rejected Allied demands for military access, what should we do?
Since the Soviets have decided not to cooperate in forcing Persia to grant access, should the UK act alone to gain access?
To help get supplies to the Soviets after the German invasion, Britain decided to force Persia to grant Britain and the USSR transit rights and reduce German influence in Persia.

Following the Fall of France, German occupation of the Low Countries, and the beginning of the Blitz, many Irish from Eire decided to volunteer for service in the British Armed Forces to fight Fascism.  Over 40,000 from the South enlisted and served in British units over the course of the war.

With Britain at war against Germany, and the Blitz full on, many in Eire decided to seek work in Britain to support the effort against Fascism.  In total some 12,000 men and women went to work in Ulster and mainland Britain during the war years.

Following the Fall of France, German occupation of the Low Countries, and the beginning of the Blitz, many Irish from Eire decided to volunteer for service in the British Armed Forces to fight Fascism.  Over 40,000 from the South enlisted and served in British units over the course of the war.

As the Italians entered the capital Addis Abeba the Emperor had already left his country. He fled to Jerusalem first, then moved on to his London exile where he was hardly welcome. Many people criticized his move to leave the country but his main purpose was to appeal to the League of Nations again. In a speech in Geneva his conclusion was that if force was allowed to triumph over the Covenant, then the collective security of small states was threatened. Historically at this point the League of Nations became insignificant.

After the defeat of France and Britain the puppet governments could not deny Germany the return of her former colonies. Deutsch-Ostafrika, Kamerun and Togo are restored. Additionally Germany demanded to get a land bridge from Togo to East Africa. The new colonial order also forced the British puppet government to hand over Nigeria and parts of British East Africa.
On 30th January 1939, Hitler demanded the return of all former German colonies.

British colonialism controlled all Burmese territory as one of India¥s provinces until 1937, when it got the separation from India forming another British dominion. During Japanese invasion, Aung San congregated all patriotic forces in the Antifascist League, a nationalist guerilla that fought against invaders. Once the Japanese were expelled, the struggle for the independence continued against the British, and in 1947, after conceding independence to India, it was absurd to keep control over Burma, so the United Kingdom was forced to grant a limited self-government status. Being Aung San was killed in July. His successor U Nu managed to get an agreement with Great Britain that established the right of Burma to get its independence. The new state Constitution was redacted and Burma began its official life on 4th January 1948.

The negotiations and processes towards the independence of India started after the popular protests and the Indian Congress demands arrived to their critical point. Since 1876, when Queen Victoria was proclaimed Empress of India, the country has been administrated by the British government. In 1935, after a series of conferences in London between British and Indian politicians, the British Parliament approved the Government of India Act. This gave some degree of self-government to India, but it remained a dominion of the British Crown, and that didn't fully satisfy Indian nationalists. After many years of protests like those headed by Mahatma Gandhi, independence has come at last. From this moment they will continue the fight against fascism and Japanese imperialism as a free nation and close ally of the United Kingdom.

The negotiations and processes towards the independence of India started after the popular protests and the Indian Congress demands arrived to their critical point. Everything is ready for India to rule its own destiny and continue the fight against fascism and Japanese imperialism as a free nation and close ally of the United Kingdom. Many Englishmen are against this measure, as the India has been a part of the dominions of the British Crown since a long time ago, and during all this time we have administrated it with justice according to the important role it has in our economy and resource pool. Anyway, it is our compromise with history to decide the future of our dominions in the fairest possible way.

In August 1942, the Indian Congress voted a resolution followed by a non-cooperation movement that severely criticized the British imperialist attitude and demanded to negotiate the independence of India in order to continue its fight against fascist and Japanese imperialist aggression. In India, the discontent was growing due to the application of the 'Defense Agreement' between London and Delhi which stated that an important part of the Indian local founds were used to finance British war effort. There were even some factions like the one headed by Subhas Chandra Bose that thought that India should become a Japanese ally to liberate Asia from white people's hands. The British authorities reaction was immediate and very hard, more than 60,000 people were arrested. The popular protest, vigorous but spontaneous and without order, was repressed, and the national movement reduced to silence until the end of the war.
Some months after British marines landed in Iceland, control was handed over to U.S. forces.
Iceland commands a strategic location for the Battle of the Atlantic. With Denmark falling, we must act to control that position or risk defeat in the Atlantic.

In May 1940, the political decisions of Neville Chamberlain¥s government until then in relation with the crisis and the subsequent war in Europe had proved themselves disastrous. Hitler fooled him in Munich promising that the Czech Sudetenland was Germany's last territorial demand, and Chamberlain returned to England assuring everyone that he had managed 'a peace for our time'. He also wasn't firm enough to protect Poland nor, more seriously, Norway. On 8th May 1940, as German troops crossed Holland¥s borders, a censure motion against Chamberlain was carried out in the Parliament. Through the motion did not succeed, it showed what little credibility the government had, so Chamberlain decided to leave his charge to somebody capable of forming a national government. In first place he asked Lord Halifax, but he declined his offer, so finally, the chosen one was Winston Churchill.

Soon after joining Allies, Poland asked UK and France for help in modernization of its army (mainly air force). Historically, both countries decided to give Poland special credits for military equipment. From UK Poland acquired modern plane engines and a contract on 100 Fairey Battle bombers.
Having driven Vichy out of Syria, Britain returns control of Syria to Free France.
Having driven Vichy out of Lebanon, Britain debates returning control of Lebanon to Free France.

The government of Yugoslavia is asking us to purchase a small number of Bristol Blenheim Mk I bomber aircraft. They would also like to purchase the designs and a license to manufacture some more in their own country. Many members of our government favor assisting the Yugoslav government, the successor to Serbia, as acknowledgement of their assistance against the Austro-Hungarian Empire in the Great War.
Does Britain need to drive Vichy from Lebanon and Syria?

The government of Yugoslavia is asking us to purchase a small number of Hawker Fury Mk II fighter aircraft. They would also like to purchase the designs and a license to manufacture some more in their own country. Many members of our government favor assisting the Yugoslav government, the successor to Serbia, as acknowledgement of their assistance against the Austro-Hungarian Empire in the Great War. The aircraft they are asking for are likely to be obsolete before long, with the advent of new fast monoplane metal-skinned designs.
Fearing Germany would gain bases in the Levant from Vichy, the British decided that Vichy influence in Lebanon and Syria must end.
France has been defeated by the mighty forces of Germany. What will we do? Will we help the French resistance? Or will we leave them on their own?

The victory of Franco showed the world the horror produced by a Civil War without reconciliation. About 500,000 Spanish fled to different countries escaping from fascist reprisals, which were extremely cruel during the war: fascists had already executed 90,000 people. From the very first moment, England declared that it would not accept a massive arrival of refugees, so most of Republicans didn't even try to travel to British Islands.

Spanish Civil War is a war against fascism. Although we don't agree with Republican ideology, it is a democratic nation fighting against tyranny. Maybe we should get more involved to help them. A safe way to do so is to send military advisors and technological means to produce our excellent weapons in Spain.
Ethiopia accepts to give us military access in exchange for their claims.
Ethiopia refuses to give us military access in exchange for their claims.
The Ethiopians demand their claims over Obbia and Mogadishu.

Despite having agreed to creation of the Polish army, Stalin constantly denied war materiel and reinforcements to Polish units. Moreover, he did not give any information about the fate of over 21,000 Polish officers taken to PoW camps in 1939. Therefore Polish government-in-exile decided to transfer all its units from USSR to British-held Middle East.

Despite having agreed to creation of the Polish army, Stalin constantly denied war materiel and reinforcements to Polish units. Moreover, he did not give any information about the fate of over 21,000 polish officers taken to PoW camps in 1939. Therefore Polish government-in-exile decided to transfer all its units from USSR to British-held Middle East.
After the fall of Paris, France collapsed. A loyal Vichy regime has been formed by the Germans. Now, 20,000 soldiers evacuated through Dunkirk, Africa and Spain arrive at our coasts.
After the fall of France, Polish refugees that escaped to France, now escape again, but this time to the United Kingdom to continue their operations against the Germans.
After the agreed period, we are no longer obliged to grant military access to withdrawing Finns. Good riddance!

Lithuania will provide a greater cushion against German aggression for the Motherland, but claims for Memel at this point are too diplomatically dangerous.  We must relinquish the claim in the interest of peaceful relations with the Hitlerites.

Having reassured ourselves that Bulgarians will remain true to us, we can now afford to restore their status as an independent nation, allied with us. There will be time to help our Bulgarian comrades to institute communism in their country after our enemies are defeated.
Changing circumstances led to the end of the neutrality agreement between the Soviet Union and Japan.

While the Soviet Union battled the advancing German army on the steppes of Russia, Japan was busy pushing back the Chinese army in mainland China: neither country could afford a second war front.  Japan initialized a neutrality treaty with USSR that maintained a separate peace between the two countries, even though Japan was one of the Big Three and formally a member of the Axis.

While the Soviet Union battled the advancing German army on the steppes of Russia, Japan was busy pushing back the Chinese army in mainland China: neither country could afford a second war front.  Japan initialized a neutrality treaty with USSR that maintained a separate peace between the two countries, even though Japan was one of the Big Three and formally a member of the Axis.
After the agreed period, we are no longer obliged to grant military access to withdrawing Hitlerites. Good riddance!

Our comrades of Spain have fought bravely against the fascist hordes in their country. They have not only exterminated the shadow of fascism in their land, but also defeated the soldiers, cannons, tanks and planes sent by Italian and German fascism. Now, their country is exhausted and we could send some help.
After a month of backbreaking labor by the brave citizens of Stalingrad, the Stalingrad defensive perimeter stands ready. The workforce can now return to their regular jobs.

The Stalingrad Territorial Army is now fully armed and formed. They will need some time after deployment to organize before they stand ready to defend the city of Stalin to the last man and to the last bullet!

As enemy troops pushed closer to the 'city of Stalin', the communist party again mobilized its human resources. The citizens of Stalingrad and the regions provided a significant support in forming the defense line in the far and close avenues of approach to Stalingrad. 50 thousand Stalingraders fought in the Territorial Army, and 250 thousand participated in the construction of the defense lines of 2800 km long. Four defense contours were created at the approaches to the city: the outside one, the middle one, the inside one and the urban one. By the beginning of the battle they weren't fully equipped, but still performed a vital part in the course of the military actions.
Marshal Josef Stalin of the Soviet Union declared that the Soviets planned to maintain friendly relations with a strong, independent Poland after the war.

The Soviet government cut off diplomatic ties with the Polish government-in-exile in London. The next day, the Soviets explained that Moscow had suspended relations with the Poles and had not severed relations. This marked the beginning of a rocky relationship between the London Poles and the Soviets, who favored a Communist Polish government.

Soviet Foreign Minister arrived in Washington for a conference with the U.S. President and other high ranking American officials. The meeting focused on the supply of Lend-Lease supplies and equipment for the Soviet Union, which resulted in the Master Lend-Lease Agreement in June.

Zhukov has led his troops into a great defeat and our forces in the Far East have been shattered.  This is the worst setback since the war of 1905 and will affect our influence and position in the Far East for years to come.  The Japanese have offered terms and it would be wise to accept.  Meanwhile, there is an investigation into Zhukov's responsibility for this defeat and he is already under arrest pending the outcome of the investigation.
The fighting at Nomonhan village has spiraled out of control and the Japanese Imperial Army is mobilizing all it's forces and massing them along our border.  We are at war with Japan.

Following some earlier clashes, Japanese forces have taken the initiative.  Our Mongolian allies have been driven from Nomonhan village and there has been heavy fighting along the banks of the Khalkin Ghol.  Already the 11th Tank Brigade, 149th Motor Rifle Regiment and the 5th Machine Gun Brigade are engaged in heavy fighting with several enemy formations.  General Zhukov has built up a force of more than 320 tanks and an armored car brigade for a counter-attack on the southern front but if the plan goes wrong the battle will be lost.
With danger now away from the gates of Moscow all capital offices and facilities can get back to normal routine.

In November 1941, the German 'Operation Typhoon' had almost reached Moscow. The 2nd Panzer Gruppe commanded by Heinz Guderian was closing on Tula to the south of the Soviet capital, while the 3rd and 4th Panzer Gruppe were attacking from the west and northwest. During these critical days, to many Soviet officials it all seemed lost and evacuation of the capital began. Historically Stalin evacuated most of the government offices and supplies, but stayed himself to bolster the spirit of the defenders. This demonstration of faith in Moscow's defenses was very important for propaganda purposes.

After a stunning final victory over the German Wehrmacht, the Soviet Army continued pressing westwards. The Soviet Army at once started creating communist administrations and blocked efforts to bring legal governments-in-exile back to power. This was a major diplomatic insult to the Allies and all other democratic countries. Requisitions, confiscation of private property, and brutal enforcement of the new Soviet order were common. The Soviet actions shocked the peoples of all democratic countries.

After the shocking defeats in the border battles, the Red Army desperately tried to stop the German invasion. Facing fast German advance, Stalin spoke to the Soviet nations and the Russian national pride to defend 'Rodina' (motherland) from enemy aggression. This sudden change in Soviet politics, as well as changes in political control of the Army units resulted a boosted morale and reinforced the will to fight.
The capitalist countries have backed down and acknowledged that Korea is in the Soviet sphere of interest. We have installed a communist government that is fully loyal to us in Korea.
The situation has escalated to full war and North Korea is now facing the might of western capitalist armies.  We must make a fast decision if we should intervene or only offer 'volunteer' support.
Although caught off guard by the conflict in Korea, the Soviet leadership reacted decisively and provided much material and advisors to the North Korean armed forces.
Our gambit to gain control over Korea is threatening to result in war.  The stubborn Americans have made it clear that we either back down or face military action.
Our gambit to gain control over Korea is threatening to result in war.  The stubborn British have made it clear that we either back down or face military action.

With growing problems in Korea and several major powers taking an interest in the fate of Korea it became obvious that a joint solution was needed.  The major powers met at the Moscow Conference to settle the fate of Korea once and for all.  Negotiations quickly showed that the only acceptable solution would be joint trusteeship for the four powers - USA, USSR, UK and China.

Shortly after the defeat of Japan, the USSR established a military government in Korea to oversee the rebuilding of the country and counter any capitalist influence. Their arrival meant the end of many of the local KPR governments and created further social upheaval.

This is indeed a terrible day for the people of the USSR. Today the Finnish prime minister requested the full support from the Allies and the Allies have responded positively. We should expect Allied troops on the front any day now. We will crush then like the Finns and emerge victorious from this conflict.

The industrialization of the Soviet Union was conducted according to the '5 year' plans. Those plans meant the end of small stabilization of NEP (New Economic Policy) and going back to the principles of communism - limiting private property in the industry, trade and agriculture. All those plans were executed thanks to the forced work of gulag prisoners, and this cheap and unlimited manpower was present on all 'great building sites of communism'. The 3rd 5 year plan, started in 1938, was different from the previous ones. Based on the huge infrastructure built in the years 1928-1937, Soviet Union started mass production of various armament types, considerably developing its military forces. While industry was still developed, it concentrated on the production of military supplies.

The industrialization of the Soviet Union was conducted according to the '5 year' plans. Those plans meant the end of small stabilization of NEP (New Economic Policy) and going back to the principles of communism - limiting private property in the industry, trade and agriculture. All those plans were executed thanks to the forced work of gulag prisoners, and this cheap and unlimited manpower was present on all 'great building sites of communism'. The first 5 year plan was conducted in the years 1928-1932 and resulted in a large development of industrial infrastructure as well as the horror of collectivization of the land property. The next plan, 1933-1937 was a straight continuation of the first one.

The industrialization of the Soviet Union was conducted according to the '5 year' plans. Those plans meant the end of small stabilization of NEP (New Economic Policy) and going back to the principles of communism - limiting private property in the industry, trade and agriculture. All those plans were executed thanks to the forced work of gulag prisoners, and this cheap and unlimited manpower was present on all 'great building sites of communism'. The first 5 year plan was conducted in the years 1928-1932 and resulted in a large development of industrial infrastructure as well as the horror of collectivization of the land property. The next plan, 1933-1937 was a straight continuation of the first one.

Our ambassador to Switzerland has reported that the Swiss Foreign Minister has refused our request for design work from the Swiss firm of ABB.  This is despite our generous offer of resources for their industries.  Our engineers will be forced to come up with their own design before our battleship design can proceed.

The Swiss firm of ABB has given our engineers assistance with designing the power plant for our new battleship design.  The have given us designs for modern small tube boilers.  That will help us by generating higher steam pressures, which will give a higher speed than our current battleships have.

Our ambassador to the United States reports that their State Department has refused our request to work with the firm of Gibbs & Cox to develop new designs for use by the Red Navy.  This is despite our generous offer to their officials. Our engineers will have to make up for this loss with designs of their own.

The American firm of Gibbs & Cox have given us some designs to consider for production.  Unfortunately, none of the designs is what we were looking for.  We will be able to use these designs as a basis for our own design made by Soviet engineers.

Our ambassador to Germany has reported that despite the generous offer that we made, the Germans have refused to share their designs for modern fire control equipment with us for use in our new battleship design.  Our engineers will have to come up with a design on their own.

As a part of our recent agreement with the German government, our engineers have completed their analysis of the German Bismarck class battleships.  We will be able to use their fire control systems as a guide while designing the systems in our battleship design.

Our ambassador to Italy has reported that despite the generous offer that we made, the Italians have refused to share their knowledge of secondary battery turrets and armor protection schemes with us in order to further our battleship design.  We will be forced to come up with our own design.

Communist delegates from around the world met in Moscow and dissolved the Third International, an organization formed in Russia in 1919 to propagate communist ideals in other countries and to direct communist organizations overseas. Communist parties in other countries would henceforth be autonomous from Soviet influence and direction.
Bulgarian government has folded and is switching to our side. We have taken over their government to assist them in the transition and to ensure there will be no unpleasant surprises along the way.

Bulgarian leadership has offered to switch sides and fight Germans along our side. This was undoubtedly caused by our victorious Red Army and its recent advances. A part of our leadership favors allowing Bulgarians to switch sides, which could finish the war faster. On the other hand, if Bulgarians betrayed Germany when war was going against them, they might well betray us if fortunes turn against us.
In response to the Axis invasion in Greece the Soviet government decided to send 134 fighter planes to Greece to aid them in their struggle

The Polish government, exposed to German eastward expansion, sought closer relations with the Soviet Union by renewing the Soviet-Polish Non-Aggression Pact. The Polish government made efforts to build up a barrier of Baltic and Balkan states to help maintain the status quo in Eastern Europe.

The uprising organized by Polish units loyal to the government-in-exile could not get support from Stalin, who had his own plans for Central Europe. Although still nominally allied with the UK and USA, Stalin totally ignored the Polish exile-government, organizing a puppet government instead. He also blocked Allied attempts to support the Warsaw uprising by denying them to land in Soviet controlled territory, as well as slowing down the offensive in Poland. Ultimately it resulted in 2 months of heavy city fighting and almost total destruction of both the city and potential post-war opponents.

The Vatican decided that it could no longer overlook the atrocities committed in Finland. Pope Pius XII sent a formal condemnation to the Soviet leadership on behalf of the many Catholics that suffered unnecessarily because of the Soviet attack on Finland.

Following our attack on Finland a number of countries have issued formal protests about our operations there. Since we have already been expelled from the League of Nations it won't hurt us much to ignore those complaints.

The Winter War is over and it is time to look forward. Despite our differences in the past Sweden may become an ally in the future. To lay the first stone towards achieving this we should issue an apology for the bombs that we mistakenly dropped on Swedish soil during the Winter War.
Despite the war in Finland throughout the first months of the war USA continued to sell military equipment to the USSR. This amounted to almost $32 million worth of military equipment.

The Swedish government have issued a protest for the bombings on Pajala. We cannot confirm this without Swedish repercussions so we will make our news agency TASS issue an article in which they declare the so-called incident in Pajala a Swedish publicity stunt to attract sympathy for the Finnish cause and deny any Soviet involvement.

Following the bombings of Pajala by Soviet aircraft the Swedish government issued a protest to the Soviets. The Soviets ignored the protest and took it as a sign of weakness and unwillingness to really intervene in the conflict.
It seems that some of our bombers have by mistake flown into Swedish territory and dropped their bomb load on the Swedish village of Pajala. The Swedish government is sure to react on this.
It seems that some of our bombers have by mistake flown into Swedish territory and dropped their bomb load on the beach in the Gulf of Bothnia. The Swedish government is sure to react on this.
It seems that some of our bombers have by mistake flown into Swedish territory and dropped their bomb load on the beach in the Gulf of Bothnia. The Swedish government is sure to react on this.

One of our submarines has accidentally sunk a Swedish transport ship, the Fenris. The Swedish government claims it was in international waters but our submarine captain says it was in Finnish waters and that it was carrying supplies for Finland.

There is no doubt that Sweden and Norway are helping Finland and thereby delaying the inevitable victory of our forces in Finland. We have to protest against this interference in our sphere of influence

Today a vote has been cast in the League of Nations. In light of the ongoing aggression of the USSR against the independent nation of Finland, without proper cause, a majority vote in the League of Nations has decided that USSR does no longer fit the criteria for membership of this organization. It is therefore decided that the USSR is expelled from the League of Nations as per today and all USSR diplomats be returned. Furthermore the League of Nations wishes to speak out its support to Finland and request that all peaceful nations of the world give their support to the Finnish people in their struggle against the Soviet aggression.

Prior to the attack on Finland Red Army artillery units opened fire on the Soviet village of Mainila. They blamed the attack on the Finns and even though the Finns denied responsibility, USSR used the incident to press its claims on Finland.

After the shocking defeats in the border battles, the Red Army desperately tried to stop the German invasion. Facing fast German advance, Stalin called upon the Soviet nations and the Russian national pride to defend 'Rodina' (motherland) from enemy aggression. One of the most notable groups that started supporting the war effort was the Orthodox Church, which earlier was greatly suppressed by the communists.

Bolivia was one of the most important producers of tin. The Bolivian government has decided to sell the tin to the Soviet Union at a symbolic price. In exchange, a Soviet mission will help Bolivia in developing its more remote lands and in improving industry and infrastructure.
In return for our resources, Germany has provided all that we needed to expand our industry base and strengthen our economy.

The Soviet economy is suffering badly from lack of tools, machinery and technical skills. The western powers are withholding their goods from our markets, but Germany is willing to trade us what we need in return for resources and some transit agreements for resources from the Far East.

After the successful conquest of eastern Poland, USSR had to decide what kind of doctrine it should implement in future wars - defensive, based on old border fortifications called the Stalin Line, or more aggressive, based on fast armored units and superior firepower. Both Stalin and his commanders preferred the second option. Development of new weapons received high priority and old fortifications were gradually neglected and abandoned.

We intervened in the Spanish war to help our comrades in that country against the fascist revolt, but even with our valiant help, they haven't been able to crush the rebellion. Now, the Republicans have been defeated and our intervention in this country is no longer needed. It has been a dirty war, and we have very little to win now in that remote and poor country. STAVKA officers think that continuing this war would be a waste of men and military resources that could be better used elsewhere.

As Japanese forces advanced into northern China, hurried negotiations between China and the Soviet leadership took place. Plans were made for the provision of over 200 aircraft, 6000 tons of supplies and, in great secrecy, the sending of a force of volunteer combat-trained pilots. A treaty of Non-Aggression was also signed between the two countries.

After a stunning final victory over the German Wehrmacht, the Soviet Army continued pressing westwards. The Soviet Army at once started creating communist administrations and blocked efforts to bring legal governments-in-exile back to power. This was a major diplomatic insult to the Allies and all other democratic countries. Requisitions, confiscation of private property, and brutal enforcement of the new Soviet order were common. The Soviet actions shocked the peoples of all democratic countries.

Battles in Finland and in the Far East proved the weakness of the Soviet post-purge officer corps. Growing tension between Germany and USSR slightly changed Stalin's personnel politics and some commanders were released from the Gulags. A serious change happened when the war broke out. Many prisoners from the Gulags were sent to the front - including some of the best USSR commanders.

The Soviet Far East borders were far from peaceful and quiet even before WWII. Stalin recognized Japan as an important enemy of the USSR and according to this doctrine he supported Nationalist China and Mongolia to counter Japanese presence on the Asian continent. As a result of growing tension between the two countries, in 1938 Japanese Army units crossed the Soviet border near Lake Chasan to probe Red Army defenses. The Soviet Far East Army counterattacked, but its advance was slow and fights lasted until the end of August. The lack of effectiveness of the Far East Soviet forces cost the life of their commander, Vasilij Bl¸cher. He was arrested and executed by the NKVD.
Having driven out Reza Pahlavi and gained Persian assent to military access, the USSR promised to return territories conquered to Persia. If we refuse, our reputation will be severely damaged.
Persia's rejection of British demands for Allied access has led to British intervention, should we join in?
To help get supplies to them after the German invasion, the USSR decided to force Persia to grant Britain and the USSR transit rights and reduce German influence in Persia.

Stalin always remembered his enemies, no matter how long time ago they opposed him or how far away they were from the Kremlin. One of the most important of Stalin's enemies was Leon Trotsky, former creator and first commander of the Red Army and an important figure of the Bolshevik movement. After he lost the struggle for power after Lenin's demise, Trotsky was exiled from the USSR and ventured from country to country tracked by Stalin's spies and assassins. According to our NKVD operatives, he is now in Mexico. Shall we make an assassination attempt?
The flooding from the destroyed Dnieper Dam is finally subsiding, allowing rivers to be forded. Much damage remains to be repaired though.

The Dnieper Dam, finished in 1932, was the largest in Europe and a symbol of the Stalin era. As enemy troops advanced into the Donetz basin, Russian troops destroyed the Dnieper Dam causing massive flooding and destruction.

Josif Wisarianovitch Stalin could not be called the most important of old date Bolsheviks - but he was definitely the smartest. His specialty was taking advantage of animosities between his adversaries. After seizing absolute political power over USSR he started to use this tactic to control NKVD, Soviet secret police. After Great Purge in Communist Party and purges in Red Army Stalin placed Lavrenti Beria as new chief of NKVD, removing Yezhov and his most trusted men.

Josif Visarianovitch Stalin could not be called the most important of old date Bolsheviks - but he was definitely the smartest. His specialty was taking advantage of animosities between his adversaries. After seizing absolute political power over USSR he started to use this tactics to control NKVD, Soviet secret police. This way Yagoda, former chief of NKVD was succeeded by Yezhov, ensuring Stalin's control over growing power of apparatus of terror.

As a part of our recent agreement to share naval technology, our engineers have sent us the data that we need to finalize the secondary battery turrets and refine the protective system on our new battleship design.

The mission of the RKKF - the Soviet Navy - had since the revolution been of a defensive nature. The shores of the homeland were to be defended mostly by submarines and minor surface vessels. But this policy would change. By the middle of the 1930s it was clear that Stalin was aiming for a large navy, a 'Blue-water Fleet', capable of projecting Soviet power outside of its home waters. An immense program was started, shipyards were extended and envoys were sent out to foreign countries. Their mission - to obtain plans and designs for battleships and large cruisers.

The victory of Franco showed the world the horror produced by a civil war without reconciliation. About 500,000 Spanish fled to different countries escaping from fascist reprisals, which were extremely cruel during the war - the fascists had already executed 90,000 people. Although most of the refugees went to France, many exiles asked for asylum in Russia, but the Stalinist regime made an exhaustive selection and only those who were considered the most faithful and devoted to communist ideology were allowed in, hardly 2000 people altogether.

Spanish Civil War became a war against fascism and Stalin couldn't watch as his communist comrades in Spain fought against Franco without helping them more actively. Russia sent military and political advisors as well as tons of weaponry with the possibility of converting Spanish factories to produce Russian weaponry.

After the fall of Poland Stalin was free to do anything he wanted in the Baltic zone according to the Ribentrop-Molotow Pact. As his goal was full control over all of the countries, he wanted to create an illusion of a friendly USSR. Vilnius (Wilno in Polish), historical capital of Lithuania and one of the more important cities in Polish culture, was a good example of these politics. Historically Vilnus was returned to Lithuania in 1939.

After having expelled the whole Polish army to British-held Palestine, Stalin decided to create his own Polish army in order to use it in his struggle to seize power in Poland after the war. Lend-lease shipments provided the newly formed units with arms and supplies, and Gulag-camps and NKVD prisons were the main source of the cannon-fodder. The only problem was the lack of Polish officers since Stalin ordered them murdered shortly before the Great Patriotic War started.

Despite the Sikorski-Mayski agreement, creation of a Polish army in the USSR met with several problems. The Polish government wanted to use the Polish army as one solid force, securing a future political system after the war. In contrast, Stalin was only interested in sending the newly raised divisions to the front one by one, as classic cannon fodder. Stabilization of the front lines also resulted in lowering Stalin's interest in creating a Polish army. As a result of these problems, the idea of withdrawing the troops to the British Middle East was welcomed with relief by both sides.

Three weeks after the Great Patriotic War started, an agreement was made between the Polish prime minister Wladyslaw Sikorski and the Soviet ambassador to the UK, I.M. Mayski, setting all polish citizens from the Gulags free and creating a Polish Army in the USSR.

We have signed a Treaty of Friendship and Non-aggression with Yugoslavia. This will help allay fears created in our public by Germany's belligerent actions. However, even though they had asked for a clause allowing for military assistance in case of an attack, we were forced to refrain from such a treaty at this time. We hope to further improve our relations toward a full military alliance in the future, should events allow it.
The Russian program of building an army of hordes of infantry required higher and higher draft rates. Boris M. Shaposhnikov promised Stalin to effectively double them for the Soviet effort.

Outer Mongolian cavalry on peaceful patrols in the Khalkn Ghol area have clashed with Japanese troops and been driven back across the river.  It seems the Japanese wish to repeat the experience of Lake Chasan and contend with us over control in the border lands.

The enemy force is withdrawing and our troops have a firm hold on Nomonhan village and the Baintsagan Heights.  It appears the battle is won with minor losses and we have improved our position in the Far East, teaching the Japanese Imperial Army to fear us.
Chinese influence in Tannu Tuva was permanently ended when Tannu Tuva became part of the USSR in November 1944.
General Vlasov's divisions have been captured with the fall of Kiev.

Ravaged by a brutal war, dismembered by German attack, and disillusioned by Allied support (or lack thereof), Yugoslavia capitulated. Germany dictated the peace terms, being the most powerful among the belligerents. Historically, seeing an opportunity to demonstrate the power of the Third Reich, and reward its allies and sympathizers, Germany decided to divide Yugoslavia among its neighbors. Central parts of the country were given to Croatia, a staunch German ally. The Dalmatian coast was handed over to Italians, while the extreme south of the country was awarded to Bulgarians. Hungarians received Vojvodina, a small northern province, while the remainder of the country was occupied by Germans themselves. Germany also annexed Slovenia directly, while deciding to create a puppet state out of the remains of Serbia. Do we proceed with the partition, or shall we take the country over completely?
