The building plan devised by Admiral Doenitz called for submarines to be the focus of our naval construction program.  In order to maintain the size of our submarine fleet, we need to start the construction of additional submarines at this time.

The Spanish Civil War is developing to a struggle between ideologies, and Franco might need aid, since the Republicans are being helped by the Soviets. What should we do? A direct intervention could cause the outrage of both France and England, not to mention the Soviet Union. It could cause a very tense diplomatic crisis that may even cause the war against them.

In the first half (1939-1943) of World War II German economy worked at a slow pace, not switching entirely to 'war mode'. That was mostly due to the political reasons - Germany was apparently winning the war, so there was no sense in mobilizing the industry. All that changed in 1943, when Germany suffered some major defeats including capitulation of the whole 6th Army in Stalingrad cauldron and Allied landing in Africa. Facing combined forces of USA, USSR and UK Germans mobilized their industry by using workforce from occupied countries and redeploying production facilities to counter Allied bomber offensive. While very effective in terms of quantity, it also resulted in lower quality of the equipment and weapons.
The Nationalists have rejected our proposal.
The Nationalists have accepted our proposal. We are now officially in a state of war with the Republicans.
Following the defeat of Czechoslovakia by Germany and Hungary, the agreement signed made prior to the war divided the captured areas between the two countries.
Our efforts to persuade Hungary to join us in a possible war against Czechoslovakia have proven successful. In return we will give them their share of the spoils of war.

Despite our efforts to persuade Hungary to join us in a possible war against Czechoslovakia, the Hungarians have decided that they only wish to revise their borders with Czechoslovakia through peaceful means.
The Hungarian Prime Minister and Foreign Minister have paid a visit to Germany. The Germans tried to influence them in relations to a possible war with Czechoslovakia over the Sudetenland.

The building plan devised by Admiral Doenitz called for submarines to be the focus of our naval construction program.  In order to maintain the size of our submarine fleet, we need to start the construction of additional submarines at this time.

The building plan devised by Admiral Doenitz called for submarines to be the focus of our naval construction program.  In order to maintain the size of our submarine fleet, we need to start the construction of additional submarines at this time.

The building plan devised by Admiral Doenitz called for submarines to be the focus of our naval construction program.  In order to maintain the size of our submarine fleet, we need to start the construction of additional submarines at this time.

The building plan devised by Admiral Doenitz called for submarines to be the focus of our naval construction program.  In order to maintain the size of our submarine fleet, we need to start the construction of additional submarines at this time.

With the completion of the core of our submarine fleet we can slow down the pace of submarine construction.  The country should be able to maintain this pace of construction into the foreseeable future.

The construction plan which was approved by Hitler and the Reichstag calls for the increased size of our submarine fleet.  Construction on the first submarines went well and it is now time for additional units.  These submarines should help the navy control the North Sea and prevent the Royal Navy from intervening in a future European war.

The naval construction program approved by Hitler and the Reichstag calls for the expansion of the submarine fleet.  As a part of that plan, we are going to lay down the first submarines approved by the building program.  These submarines are going to be of our most modern design and should be able to control portions of the North Sea preventing the Royal Navy from intervening in a future European war.

The navy has designed a construction program that emphasizes the construction of submarines over traditional surface warships.  Traditional naval thought says that a fleet with battleships, cruisers and destroyers is necessary to defeat the Royal Navy.  The British say that the development of ASDIC has made the submarine ineffective against protected merchant vessels.  Admiral Doenitz believes that the use of massed submarines will make it impossible for the escorts to effectively protect their charges.  Admiral Raeder has said that he will resign if the alternative plan is approved.  We could pacify Admiral Raeder if we submit a plan which includes some heavy warships into the mix.

Admiral Karl Doenitz is advocating a naval construction program which will focus on the construction of submarines rather than surface warships.  He advocates that the submarine is the only weapon which will bring England to her knees in the event of war.  During the Great War, submarines came close to strangling the trade between England and the rest of her empire.  New submarine technology will be developed which will allow us to field a large, effective submarine force.  The plan is to build over two hundred submarines over the next eight years.  This will allow us to have almost one hundred submarines at sea at any one time.

The navy has expressed doubt in Adolf Hitler's declaration that there will be peace until 1944.  This would give the navy the chance to complete an extensive construction program.  By expressing their doubt, the naval leadership has expressed an opinion that is shared by many leaders within the Wehrmacht.  If we maintain this course of action, it could create difficulties with the High Command which is loyal to the F¸hrer.

The Z-Plan Naval Construction program which was approved prior to the beginning of the war called for the completion of a large, balanced fleet by the end of 1944.  This is the final scheduled program of warships that needs to be started to complete that program.

The Z-Plan for naval construction that was approved before the war had a time table that would allow the completion of a large, balanced fleet before 1945.  All of the battleships that were planned have either been laid down or canceled.  The remaining elements of the fleet are cruisers and destroyers that are required to screen and scout for the heavy units.  There is also a carrier that is included with the program.

The Z-Plan for naval construction that was approved before the war had a time table that would allow the completion of a large, balanced fleet before 1945.  The first battleships in the program have already been either laid down or canceled, but there are still plans for additional battleships, cruisers, and other small warships.  This year's program calls for a large number of warships to be laid down.

The Z-Plan for naval construction that was approved before the war had a time table that would allow the completion of a large, balanced fleet before 1945.  The first battleships in the program have already been either laid down or canceled, but there are still plans for additional battleships, cruisers, and other small warships.  This year's program calls for a large number of warships to be laid down.

As a part of the Z-Plan, there was a requirement for the construction of a number of aircraft carriers.  A new aircraft carrier can provide support for fleet elements while operating within range of enemy land based aircraft.  Carrier based aircraft can also be used to attack elements of enemy fleets.

The Z-Plan for naval construction that was approved before the war had a time table that would allow the completion of a large, balanced fleet before 1945.  The first battleships in the program have already been either laid down or canceled, but there is still a need for cruisers and escorts.

The support that we have given the navy has gone to improve the state of the navy over the years.  With the state of the world, it is advisable that we continue our support for the fleet.  The commitment of resources that this will require will be well used.  The Z-Plan naval construction program that was approved before the war called for the continuing construction of large warships like battleships and cruisers in addition to the supporting warships.

The face of naval warfare has changed.  Surface warships are unable to survive in an area where land based aircraft are present without air cover.  The construction of an aircraft carrier would give the Kreigsmarine the air cover that is needed to operate in areas where enemy aircraft are active.  This carrier will be built to our most advanced carrier design.

The Z-Plan naval construction program approved before the war called for a large investment in naval armaments.  The plan calls for the construction of a battleship and numerous cruisers, destroyers and submarines.  This plan is designed to increase the size of the navy by 1945.  This will benefit us in the peace following the war as we are forced to control defeated nations and assure the position of the German Reich.

Hitler has maintained his promise that the country would not be at war.  This gives us the opportunity to complete the naval construction program that was contained in the Z-Plan.  The plan calls for the construction of one battleship, 2 cruisers and numerous destroyers and submarines.  The F¸hrer assures us that we will have time to complete this building program before we will be forced into a confrontation with France.

The Z-Plan, which was approved by Adolf Hitler, was designed with the assumption that the country would remain at peace for the rest of the decade and into the next decade.  Unfortunately, aggressive policies by Poland, France and Great Britain have resulted in war across Europe.  Construction of heavy warships is not at the forefront of our priorities, but we will need a strong navy to rule the peace that will follow the successful conclusion of this war.  We can decide whether we want to start the construction of a new battleship and supporting warships, concentrate on small warships which can be built quickly, or focus entirely on the army.

The Z-Plan, which was approved by Adolf Hitler, calls for the construction of a large number of warships over the next nine years.  The first segment of the plan was implemented earlier in the year.  The plan calls for the laying down of a second battleship.  Tensions in Europe are at a peak, but the F¸hrer assures us that the British and French will back down and we will have time to complete these ships.

The Z-Plan for naval construction calls for warship construction to be spread out over the course of the next ten years.  The first ship to be laid down will be a battleship due to the long lead time on construction that is necessary.  This battleship will be of our latest design.  We are also planning on laying down two submarine flotillas and a destroyer flotilla to provide balance within the fleet.

The naval construction plan, now known as the 'Z-Plan', was submitted to the Reich's Chancellor Adolf Hitler for his approval.  The naval construction plan calls for the construction of six battleships, 25 cruisers, four aircraft carriers, 14 destroyer flotillas and numerous submarine flotillas.  This new construction will enable us to control the North Sea and the Atlantic approaches.  With Hitler's approval, we can start planning for the allocation of the resources that are necessary for the construction of all of these ships.  If the plan is not approved, it will require us to close shipyards across the Reich due to lack of contracts.

We have evaluated the original Plan X for its application towards the current state of affairs across Europe.  Although our internal evaluation states that a general war will probably start sometime in 1940, the F¸hrer assures the Obebefehlshaber of the Navy that war will not begin before 1944.  The plan that has been developed calls for the construction of a balanced fleet that will be able to challenge the Royal Navy's control of the North Sea and provide access to the Atlantic Ocean.  The plan calls for the construction of battleships, aircraft carriers, cruisers and destroyers over a ten year period.  This will make the German Navy one of the largest navies in the world.  Admiral Doenitz has developed an alternative plan which will focus primarily on the construction of submarines and small warships.

The signing of the Anglo-German naval limitation treaty in 1935 set the size limits for the German Navy.  Because of new construction by the Royal Navy, we can expand the size of the fleet.  The Reich's Chancellor, Adolf Hitler, assures us that any potential conflict with the Western Powers will not occur before 1944 so we will have time to complete an extensive building program.  We will be revising the plan developed by Captain Werner Fox.  Captain Fox's plan takes into account the amount of tonnage that we have been allocated under the naval agreement.  Captain Fox's plan is also known as 'Plan X'.

As a result of the naval limitation treaty that we signed with Great Britain, the Reichstag approved funding for the construction of two new battleships.  Blohm and Voss laid down the keel of the first battleship in July.  Kreigsmarine Werft yard is ready to lay the keel of the second battleship.  This battleship will be built to our most modern battleship design.

As a result of the naval limitation treaty that we signed with Great Britain, the Reichstag approved funding for the construction of two new battleships.  Blohm and Voss is ready to lay the keel of the first of these two battleships.  This battleship will be built to our most modern battleship design.

Today, the Reich Chancellor Adolf Hitler released a decree about restructuring the Wehrmacht.  Hitler is personally taking command of the entire Wehrmacht.  The Department of the Wehrmacht is now directly under his command as the High Command of the Wehrmacht and will also serve as his personal staff.  The High Command of the Wehrmacht will assume control over all affairs of the Reich Ministry of War.  The obligation of the High Command of the Wehrmacht in time of peace is the unified preparation on all spheres of the defense of the Reich according to the directives of Adolf Hitler.

It appears that there are difficulties in General Blomberg's new marriage.  Rumors are going around alleging infidelity and some illicit photographs of his new wife.  This could prove to be an embarrassment to this government because the F¸hrer was a witness at the wedding.  We should be proactive about this situation and dismiss General Blomberg from his post and reorganize the leadership of the Wehrmacht to prevent this from happening again in the future.  If we fail to deal with this promptly, some of our more morally conservative officers could be offended and could cause problems.

An organized partisan unit has struck at our railroad network in the Balkans, causing significant damage to the infrastructure near Zagreb, and causing several shipments to be delayed. We suspect the communists to be behind this revolting attack. Historically, the first partisan unit organized in Yugoslavia was assembled in mid-June 1941, and struck the rail network in a series of sabotages on 22nd June 1941. The immediate cause for these attacks was the war between Germany and Soviet Union. The events of late June will show themselves to be only a beginning of a numerous and determined partisan movement which will tie up many Axis troops in the years to come.

Our allies, the Bulgarians, have been clamoring for more advanced armor, artillery, and anti-tank equipment to match the Red Army. We have an opportunity to send them some of our equipment, which we believe will fulfil their needs. what should we do? Historically, in July 1943, Germany finally agreed to modernize Bulgarian armored force (the 1st Armored Brigade) and supplied it with 46 PzKpfw IV tanks, 10 PzKpfW III tanks, 25 Stug III assault guns and 20 Sd Kfz 222 armored cars plus the necessary howitzers, anti-tank guns etc. In the end tanks ended up fighting its builder instead of the Red Army since Bulgaria switched sides in 1944.

We have an opportunity to influence our potential allies, the Bulgarians. Their armored forces are mostly obsolete, and they have been clamoring for a chance to upgrade them. We are to send them three dozen of our Pz Kpfw 35(t) tanks. Foreign Ministry believes this will increase our prestige significantly. Historically, Germany provided Bulgaria with 36 Pz Kpfw 35(t) tanks in early February 1940. This shipment significantly influenced the eventual decision by Bulgaria to enter the Axis.

We have successfully negotiated a sales deal with Yugoslavia, exchanging our Messerschmitt Bf-109 fighter technology for generous Yugoslav ore shipments, including shipments of valuable bauxite and chrome ore. Our delegation has also impressed the Yugoslav Air Force officers, hopefully bringing our two countries closer together. The promised planes will be built and delivered as soon as they are available.

We have successfully negotiated a sales deal with Yugoslavia, exchanging our Messerschmitt Bf-109 E-3 fighter technology for generous Yugoslav ore shipments, including shipments of valuable bauxite ore. Our delegation has also impressed the Yugoslav Air Force officers, hopefully bringing our two countries closer together. The promised planes will be built and delivered as soon as they are available.

Yugoslav government has expressed an interest in purchasing a quantity of our Messerschmitt Bf-109 E-3 fighter aircraft. While we would normally be cautious with the sale of such advanced technology to potential enemies, Yugoslavs are offering generous ore shipments in return for our aircraft. Also, this could be an excellent way to foster a friendship between our two countries. Should we proceed with negotiations?

Dornier Do-17K tactical bomber was specifically developed for Yugoslavia after demonstration of Do-17M V1 prototype at International Military Aircraft Competition in Dubendorf in 1937. Yugoslav government has expressed a keen interest in purchasing the designs and the license for this aircraft. Allowing the purchase to go ahead could give us some influence with the Yugoslav government, which might be useful in the future.

With Greece out of the picture, the Bulgarians are clamoring to take over the province of Thessaloniki. Since Thessaloniki is an important Mediterranean port, they are offering us military access in exchange for the province. The Greek population of Thessaloniki is already showing signs of great hostility to our rule. Leaving Thessaloniki to Bulgarians will also free up some troops and supplies slated for occupation duty. What shall we do?

Having finalized our business in the Balkans, we now have the chance to resolve our allies' wishes and problems in this area. Bulgarians are clamoring for Macedonia, Italy demands Kosovo, and Croatians are demanding their Adriatic coast. While there is some dispute between Italy and Croatia over portions of the Adriatic coast, we can allow them to resolve their differences on their own time. Shall we divide the remaining Yugoslav territories among our allies, or shall we keep them for ourselves?

Italian failure to deal promptly with Greece is forcing us to handle the matter ourselves. Greece is the last obstacle in securing our southern flank for Operation Barbarossa. Shall we finish what we have started?

Following the declaration of Croatian independence, the provinces comprising the mainland Banovina Hrvatska, a Croatian administrative entity, have been turned over to Croatia without a fight. As Banovina Hrvatska was in many ways a sovereign administrative body, controlled by a Croatian national majority, this arrangement will suit us greatly for the moment.

Having recreated Serbia, we now have the choice as to how closely we shall direct the new country. While some in our government advocate setting Serbia up as a full ally, similar to Croatia, most fear that the Serbs cannot be trusted and that the only thing they recognize is power. This faction demands that we create a puppet government in Serbia and control it more or less directly. What shall we do?

Adolf Hitler outdid himself on Mussolini's state visit to Germany in September 1937. Sensing the Duce's frustration over Italy's treatment by England and feeling an actual kinship with the Italian Dictator, Hitler treated Mussolini to five days of parades, rallies, and official visits. Hitler would even grant a request of Mussolini's to view the ultra secret armament factories of Krupp Steel. Even downpours and guffaws by the German military wouldn't sour Mussolini's mood. In the largest international media event of the time, millions around the world would hear Mussolini and Hitler surprisingly declare that Fascism and National Socialism were equal political movements in the Olympic Stadium. While the international community knew the day would come for a fascist alliance, the magnitude of the event hung a cloud of inevitability of war over Europe. For morale purposes, England would not transmit the event.

Benito Mussolini threatened to go to war with Germany if it proceeded with the imminent annexation of Austria in 1934. Strangely, this marked a major turning point in Italian politics that would come to Germany's advantage. France and England both failed to make good on their promises to support Italy and were seemingly willing to toss Italy to the wolves. Hitler backed down, and as the dust settled the Fascist Administration in Italy began to wonder why it was risking war for the seemingly impotent and scheming Western Powers. By 1937, Italy's international relations had done a 180 degree turn and German-Italian relations were at an all time high. Hitler took advantage of this by offering Mussolini a National Tour of his Third Reich.

Having rejected the idea of a national militia the last reserves of the nation were focused on providing a few more divisions for the army and fortifying the approaches to the capital as well as Berlin itself.

The decision to make Berlin the final battleground changed the face of the city forever.  Buildings were demolished to clear lanes of fire, barricades blocked every road and all open areas were turned into minefields.  Hundreds of thousands of civilians were armed with assorted small arms, light anti-tank weapons and grenades.  As the militia units formed up the factories were shut down or more often converted into impromptu strongpoints.
All but the most critical factories are shut down as the workers form into militia units and are issued with their weapons.  The orders are simple: stand and fight to the last man!

As enemy forces rolled deeper into Germany, desperate plans were made for the Volksturm, a citizens militia, to be mobilized for defense all over the nation.  While often poorly equipped the numeric strength of such a militia would take a heavy toll on any invader, especially when fighting from prepared positions in the cities.
After the agreed period, Soviets are no longer obliged to grant military access to our withdrawing troops.
According to the armistice conditions, we have 4-6 weeks to withdraw all the units from the Soviet held territory. Breaking the conditions of agreement is not an option - at least for now...
The Soviets are advancing through our lines in the East.  We must have more soldiers to combat the Bolsheviks.
Having soundly defeated the Poles in the opening move of our plans, we must now assert our control over their key sectors.
The ancient lands of Greece are now under our dominance.  We must now establish proper control over the key sectors for the betterment of the German Reich.
With the capitulation of Norwegian forces, we must cement our control over this Scandinavian country.  We will control the key sectors for the betterment of the German Reich.
With Denmark firmly in our hands, we must take control of the key sectors for the betterment of the German Reich.
With the total capture of the Netherlands, it is now time to establish control over key sectors for the betterment of the Reich.

With the capture of Belgium, it is now time for German authorities to take control over Belgian industries, transportation, police, and communications.  Personnel from the Reich will be sent to effect this transition into a smooth and effective aspect of the Greater German Reich.

With the conquest of European France well in hand, it is now time for German authorities to take control over key sectors.  Police, Gestapo, and administrative personnel will be reassigned to France for the betterment of the German Reich.

Following the fall of France, and the creation of the Vichy government, German agents moved in to take control of police agencies, transportation networks, and enforce industrial quotas and plans.  Additional Gestapo and administrative personnel followed on, along with reservist units for guard duties.

To meet German demands for labor collaboration between Vichy France and Germany, the Vichy French government established compulsory labor for men between the ages of 18 and 65, and for unmarried women between the ages of 20 and 35.
The Turkish government has decided that it will not enter into a non-aggression pact with us. This means that we cannot be certain what they will do if we attack USSR.
The government of Turkey has decided that it will sign a non-aggression pact with us. This is most fortunate.
The German and Turkish governments signed a non-aggression pact. This treaty kept the Turks out of the war in Europe and protected the Germany's flank for the planned invasion of the Soviet Union.
Following the Anschluss of Austria to Germany, Mexico was the only country to issue a formal protest against it.
Mexico has sent us a trade proposal and offered us oil in exchange for industrial supplies.
Finland has refused to enter into a non-aggression pact with us.
Finland has decided to sign the mutual non-aggression pact that we proposed.
Sweden has refused to enter into a non-aggression pact with us.
Sweden has decided to sign the mutual non-aggression pact that we proposed.
Norway has refused to enter into a non-aggression pact with us.
Norway has decided to sign the mutual non-aggression pact that we proposed.
Denmark has refused to enter into a non-aggression pact with us.
Denmark has decided to sign the mutual non-aggression pact that we proposed.

In a speech in the Reichstag, Chancellor Adolf Hitler officially renounced the Anglo-German Naval Treaty of 1935, which had restricted the German navy to one-third the size of the Royal Navy, as well as the German-Polish Non-Aggression Pact of 1934, accusing the British and Polish governments of attempting to encircle Germany. Chancellor Hitler also renewed his demands on Poland regarding Posen and Danzig and offered bilateral non-aggression pacts to the Scandinavian and Baltic states. In response, the Polish government gave up its demand of a proposed guarantee from Russia and now supported British efforts to attract the Soviet government into a new peace front.

In a speech in the Reichstag, Chancellor Adolf Hitler officially renounced the Anglo-German Naval Treaty of 1935, which had restricted the German navy to one-third the size of the Royal Navy, as well as the German-Polish Non-Aggression Pact of 1934, accusing the British and Polish governments of attempting to encircle Germany. Chancellor Hitler also renewed his demands on Poland regarding Posen and Danzig and offered bilateral non-aggression pacts to the Scandinavian and Baltic states. In response, the Polish government gave up its demand of a proposed guarantee from Russia and now supported British efforts to attract the Soviet government into a new peace front.
France has rejected our generous offer.

The French and German governments signed an agreement by which both states guaranteed the inviolability of the current frontiers and provided for mutual consultation to settle all disputes peacefully.

After Italy's surrender in 1943, there remained pro-fascist Italian troops willing to continue the struggle on the side of Germany. Some 15,000 Italian volunteers spent a period of time training in the south of Germany, returning as the SS Legion Italia. Originally used in anti-partisan operations in February 1944, Himmler was reluctant to grant the unit full Waffen-SS status. But in 1944, when troops of the SS Legiona Italia distinguished themselves in action against the Allied landings at Anzio, Himmler proclaimed them full units of the SS. Later, the SS Legion Italia was granted full divisional status. Elements of the division lasted to the last days of the war, when having run out of ammunition, they unwisely surrendered to the partisans, who massacred the survivors to a man.

With the invasion of the Soviet Union, the fascist regime in Italy was able to whip up a frenzy of support for the Axis, even, and especially, from the Catholic Church which blessed soldiers as they left for the 'Crusade Against the Godless East'. Even after sending an entire Army Corps as an expeditionary force to help the Germans, still thousands of Italians volunteered to join the Heer while Italy's own Armed Forces drastically needed the manpower.

The rapid successes of the Wehrmacht had its price. Newly conquered nations were eager to prove to the German occupation forces that the war was not yet over. Attacks on outposts, sabotaged supply lines, and direct attacks on German units became common in the occupied territories. Even if partisan activity was not overtly damaging to the total war effort, these attacks had at least some impact on the supply lines of the German Army.

On 11th November 1940, Schiff 16 (the raider ship Atlantis) encountered the British cargo ship Automedon. Shelling destroyed the bridge and killed the officers on the British ship, allowing the Germans to board and capture Top Secret mail for the High Command (Far East), new code tables, and a War Cabinet report on British forces, defenses of Singapore, information regarding Australia and New Zealand, and an appraisal of Japanese intentions. The documents, along with 10,000 tons of aviation fuel, were sent to Japan. Some believe these documents influenced the Japanese decision to go to war against the Allies.
The Allies have declared war on Portugal because it refused to stop trading with us. Portugal now asks for our assistance.
Portugal has given in to English pressure and refuses to trade with us.
Unable to supply itself with sorely needed tungsten and unable to get it from traditional sources in the Far East, Germany must trade with Iberian nations for it.

The Union of South Africa government issued a decree prohibiting political activity by foreigners, including non-naturalized German residents, in southwest Africa. The German government protested strongly against this move.

Although the Soviet Navy has been primarily a defensive tool, Stalin has decided that he would like the ability to project power with naval forces built around modern battleships and large cruisers.  As a part of this change in policy, the Soviet ambassador has approached us with a proposal to trade our technical knowledge for resources from the Soviet Empire.  If we agree to this measure, it would allow Soviet engineers into the shipyards where we are building the Bismarck and Tirpitz so they can view the arrangement of their main battery directors and how the main battery optics are constructed.
Latvia has refused to enter into a non-aggression pact with us.
Latvia has decided to sign the mutual non-aggression pact that we proposed.
Estonia has refused to enter into a non-aggression pact with us.
Estonia has decided to sign the mutual non-aggression pact that we proposed.

The German government offered bilateral, non-aggression pacts with the Scandinavian and Baltic states. The Finnish, Norwegian, and Swedish governments rejected the proposal, basing their decisions on a policy of strict neutrality. The Danish, Estonian, and Latvian governments accepted the German proposal.
Prince Paul, the Regent of Yugoslavia, paid a state visit to Berlin where Chancellor Adolf Hitler guaranteed the inviolability of Yugoslavia's borders in a state toast.

The German government called up 750,000 troops for an unprecedented series of military maneuvers. This military exercise came in conjunction with the nationalities negotiations in Prague between the Czechoslovak government and Sudeten Germans.

The Hungarian regent, Admiral Nicolas Horthy, conducted a state visit to Germany, where he was received by the German government with great ceremony. During the visit the diplomats off both countries discussed common issues such as Sudetenland and came to a greater understanding on several issues.
The German government issued a decree making all members of the state liable to short-term labor service in the event of a national emergency.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler conducted another state visit to Rome, and met another magnificent reception by Premier Benito Mussolini. This visit demonstrated the strength and vitality of the Rome-Berlin Axis despite the German annexation of Austria.
In an attempt to halt the Allied conquest of North Africa, Hitler decided to send a German Army to secure the Axis position in Tunisia.

The collapse of Vichy control in Algeria following the Allied invasions of Operation Torch led the Germans to violate the armistice with Vichy and send German troops into Vichy France with the goal to provide adequate defense on the Mediterranean and, hopefully, Tunisia.
In response to the German denouncement of the international control of the German waterways the Yugoslav government has issued an official protest.
In response to the German denouncement of the international control of the German waterways the Czechoslovakian government has issued an official protest.
In response to the German denouncement of the international control of the German waterways the French government has issued an official protest.

Under the Versailles Treaty, major German rivers and canals came under international control. Chancellor Adolf Hitler announced today that the German government would resume control over waterways in Germany.
In a speech at Nuremberg, Chancellor Adolf Hitler stridently denounced Bolshevism and declared his goals of seizing Russian territory for German expansion.
The German government adopted a law which required two-years of compulsory military service in an effort to expand the size of the German armed forces.
The Yugoslav government has declined our generous offer and refused to sign the Barter Agreement.
Yugoslavia has decided to sign the Barter agreement we proposed to them.

In light of the growing demands of the German industry we should try and make a trade agreement with Yugoslavia. This will make us less prone to sanctions and allow our economy to run at higher capacity.
Following the assassination of Wilhelm Gustloff, the leader of the National Socialists in Switzerland the Swiss government has decided to disband the National Socialists as a national organization.
The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1944 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. This year's laureate is Otto Hahn (Germany), for his discovery of the fission of heavy nuclei.
The Nobel Foundation has named the laureates for the 1939 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. This year's laureates are Adolf Friedrich Johann Butenandt (Germany), for his work regarding sex hormones.
The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1939 Nobel Prize in Medicine. This year's laureate is Gerhard Domagk (Germany), for the discovery of the antibacterial effects of Prontosil.
The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1938 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. This year's laureate is Richard Kuhn (Germany), for his work on carotenoids and vitamins.

The Hungarian leadership has rejected the Tri-Partite Pact.  They will not agree to the territorial agreements in our new order and we have canceled all technology and arms transfer deals.  Our influence has diminished as other nations in this region watch our failure with interest.
The Pact has been signed, signifying yet another increase of German influence in Europe.

We have engaged the Hungarian leadership in negotiations about the final disposition of territories in the new European order.  Countries that sign this Pact will be forced to abide by the territorial boundaries that are agreed.  We are also offering a technology deal to our allies.  Shall we go ahead and offer them a part in the Tri-Partite Pact?  Historically this was signed by Hungary on 20th November 1940.

As the Red Army was advancing from the east, the German occupying forces were perceived to be on the defensive in Poland. Polish Home Army (AK), directed by the Polish government-in-exile in London, was eager to prove that Poland still had its army and legal government. It was extremely important to counter Soviet attempts to install puppet governments, as well as gain support of UK and USA for post-war period. Warsaw uprising was part of the plan 'Burza' (Storm) - large operation of partisan units supporting advancing Red Army and installing local administration cells in liberated territories. At that point Germans had a comparatively small military presence in the Polish capital. The decision was based on assumption, that Red Army is so close to Warsaw that it will be able to join AK any day.

As the Red Army was advancing from the east, the German occupying forces were perceived to be on the defensive in Poland. Polish Home Army (AK), directed by the Polish government-in-exile in London, was eager to prove that Poland still had its army and legal government. It was extremely important to counter Soviet attempts to install puppet governments, as well as gain support of UK and USA for post-war period. When Red Army crossed pre-war borders of Poland, AK executed plan 'Burza' (Storm) - large operation of partisan units supporting advancing Red Army and installing local administration cells in liberated territories.
The offer of alliance offered by Adolf Hitler personally to Mannerheim during Mannerheim's birthday was accepted and Finland is now formally a member of the Axis.
The offer of alliance offered by Adolf Hitler personally to Mannerheim during Mannerheim's birthday was rejected.
Stopping the Italian supplies for Finland has resulted in a minor crisis in our relations with Italy. They have issues a formal protest against us in that matter.
A shipment of supplies destined for Finland has arrived from Italy. In accordance to our policy on such matters they have been rejected at the border.

With so many protests against the Soviet attack on Finland we have to take a stand on the issue of aid sent to Finland. We agreed with the Soviets not to interfere in their claims in Finland so perhaps it would be wisest not to allow any aid to travel through our country.

Towards the end of the war Ribbentrop took a personal trip to Finland hoping to get a personal guarantee from Ryti that Finland will not seek a separate peace with Soviets in return for German weapons and supplies.

Towards the end of the war Ribbentrop took a personal trip to Finland hoping to get a personal guarantee from Ryti that Finland will not seek a separate peace with Soviets in return for German weapons and supplies.

Towards the end of the war Ribbentrop took a personal trip to Finland hoping to get a personal guarantee from Ryti that Finland will not seek a separate peace with Soviets in return for German weapons and supplies.

On 4th June 1942, Adolf Hitler made a surprise visit to Finland in order to congratulate Marshal Mannerheim on his 75th birthday and discuss the war with him. During the visit he made a formal request that Finland would join the Axis in their struggle against the communists.

Each year on his birthday, Hitler held a military parade in Berlin in honor of himself. But of these birthday parades, none will be remembered like the one in 1939. It is said that spectators watched as military personnel marched by for six hours straight and while the German people watched in awe of their leader the Allies prepared for a war that now seemed closer then ever.

Bolivia was one of the most important producers of tin. In 1942, the Bolivian government decided to sell the tin to Germany at incredibly cheap prices. In exchange, German-sponsored missions helped Bolivia in developing the more remote lands and in improving industry and infrastructures.

A few months after the German occupation the leader of the Danish Nazi party gave the Danish government an ultimatum. The government was to step back and the Nazi party was to take control of the country. If they refused, he threatened to expose the government for their betrayal of the Danish people. Clausen made this accusation thinking that the Germans would back him in his claims. They did not, and the democrats stayed in office. The Germans knew that backing Clausen would have caused too much dissent in Denmark.

In 1943, new technology allowed British forces to contemplate a raid on the river dams of the Mohne and the Eder. The mission was complicated, using a form of bouncing bomb to destroy the dams during a night raid against a well defended target, but the impact on German industry and infrastructure would be very high. The actual raid, however, failed.

British heavy bombers have carried out a daring raid against the river dams of the Mohne and the Eder. Using a new form of bouncing bomb they destroyed the dams, unleashing a vast flood that has destroyed farmland, industries and infrastructure as well as causing over a thousand casualties.
The Germans extended the Atlantic Wall fortifications all along the coast of the Danish Jutland in order to prevent an Allied invasion.
Niels Bohr was captured while trying to escape to the United States, and was soon pressured into working on the German A-bomb project.

On 29th August 1943, the German High Command decided it was time to take full control of the Danish Navy. The attempt failed and the Danish fleet was scuttled before it could be captured. Germans salvaged what they could, however.

After Denmark refused to hand over 12 torpedo boats to Germany, Germany decided to take them by force. At the same time, the German High Command decided that the Danish resistance had to be quelled, and thereby disarmed all branches of the Danish military. German soldiers soon attacked the naval base in Copenhagen. The Danes had little time to choose whether to scuttle the ships or to surrender. Germans also demanded the immediate disarmament of all branches of the Danish armed forces.

As German soldiers began the attack on Holmen, the Danish Naval Command gave the order to scuttle all ships in harbor, or try to escape to Sweden. Only a couple of minesweepers actually made it to Sweden, while the rest of the ships were scuttled by their crews. Germany tried to salvage what they could. The disarmament of the other military branches provided many supplies for the Wehrmacht.

After Denmark refused to hand over 12 torpedo boats to Germany, Germany decided to take them by force. At the same time, the German High Command decided that the Danish resistance had to be quelled, and thereby disarmed all branches of the Danish military.
The German naval command was lent 12 torpedo boats from Denmark, after making promises to return the ships once the war ended.

In order to meet an increasing demand for Unterseeboot personnel training, the German Navy Command sent a request to the Danish government for 12 torpedo boats, which were to be converted into training ships. The wording of the request indicated that declining the offer was not an option.

In order to carry out an invasion of Norway, and to secure Germany from bombers flying over Denmark, the Germans needed to expand the airport in Aalborg (Aarhus). This eventually became the largest military airport in the world.
The Germans asked that the Danish government give their approval to the creation of a volunteer division for the war against Bolshevism.

On 6th December 1940, the Vichy government ordered the arrest and indictment of ex-ministers and government leaders of the previous French state. The French people immediately demonstrated against the persecution of their former leaders, and the Vichy regime was faced with a decision. Placate the people by withdrawing from all military co-operation with the Axis, or suppressing the voices of discontent.  This infuriated the German government, and many prominent leaders called for the immediate annexation of Vichy territory.

Shortly after the declaration of war, Allied warships began intercepting any ships bound for German ports. Germany found increasingly that expected shipments were not arriving and this impacted their resource stockpiles considerably. Food shortages could only be avoided by importing vast quantities of foodstuffs via the Soviet rail system.

We have shipped obsolete machine tools, steel pipes and other surplus items to the USSR in return for critical resources and foodstuffs. This has allowed us to reduce rationing constraints caused by the Allied blockade.

Remembering the effects of the naval blockade during the First World War, the German leadership set out to ensure that they would be able to import critical resources and foodstuffs during the coming conflict. The Soviet economy was suffering badly from lack of tools, machinery and technical skills, and the Western democracies were unwilling to trade with the Communists. As part of the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact, the Commercial Agreement was signed with the Soviet Union, increasing trade between the two countries almost ten-fold. At peak levels the USSR was providing over 85% of German imports.

German coal exports to Italy were critical for the Italian economy. When Germany was blockaded shipments by sea were no longer possible and rail transport had to be used. Moving up to 12 million tons of coal every year placed an immense burden on the German transit system but we should assign as much transport as possible to help our Italian allies.
German coal exports to Italy were critical for the Italian economy. In the pre-war years, 6 to 8 million tons of coal were sent by ship every year.

Shortly after the loss of Wilhelm Gustloff, the ship Steuben left Baltiysk, Russia. Bound for Kiel in Germany, the ship carried 2500 wounded soldiers, 2000 refugees and a crew of 450. Only one day into the journey she was torpedoed twice by the Soviet submarine S.13 and sank with the loss of about 3000 lives: twice the death toll of the Titanic disaster.

As Soviet forces pressed their advance in East Prussia, millions of German refugees were cut off. Admiral Donitz ordered the evacuation of Kreigsmarine servicemen and civilians from Gotenhafen using the great ship Wilhelm Gustloff. Only twenty miles off-shore the ship was torpedoed by the Soviet submarine S.13 and sank in icy waters. The death toll was six times higher than the Titanic disaster.

On 11th July 1936, German and Austrian officials met to hammer out an agreement. Germany stated that it would honor Austrian sovereignty, and showed a strong friendship between the Austrian and German governments. This served to ease some fears that a increasingly confident Germany would not respect international law and the sovereignty of other nations. However, all this had a secret agenda to provide amnesty for Austrian Nazis, lift censorship on Nazi media, allow the resumption of political activities by Austrian Nazis, and ensure the appointment of men friendly to the Nazis in the Schuschnigg cabinet.
As long as Great Britain still ruled her vast colonial empire in Africa there was no real chance for Germany to get Togo and Kamerun back.

The Tripartite Pact divided the world into spheres of influence. The former German colonies in the Pacific clearly fell into the Japanese sphere. Now that France, Great Britain and Australia had been defeated, Germany was asked to cede Kaiser-Wilhelm-Land, the Mariane Islands, Marshall Islands and the Samoas to her ally Japan.

On 30th January 1939, Hitler demanded the return of all former German colonies which had been distributed among several countries by the League of Nations in 1920. These demands were repeated publicly, and with rising war tension they became more threatening. The German demands were backed by Mussolini. Germans living in Memel and the Sudetenland kept hope for a full revision of the Versailles Treaty, as did many within conservative and rightwing groups.

After the successful German invasion and occupation of the British Isles, the United States was faced with the choice of intervening. They had to choose whether or not to deliver an ultimatum to Hitler, demanding an immediate ceasefire on the British front and a German withdrawal from the British Isles. Bureaucratic elements had steadily lost support for the isolationist policy in the United States after the Battle of Britain, and popular opinion on the sovereignty and independence of the United Kingdom effectively forced the American government to issue the ultimatum to Hitler.

On 6th May 1937, the German Zeppelin LZ-129 'Hindenburg' was destroyed in a tragic accident on the end of her flight from Frankfurt to Lakehurst. It was assumed that a spark from a mooring mast set the great airship on fire. Of the ninety-seven passengers and crew known to be aboard, only twelve passengers and thirty-seven crew members were saved. Germany's perfect record of safety had been shattered by this spectacular tragedy right in front of the assembled media and public. The commercial airship industry would never recover.

In 1938, the German government promised the working class access to cheap automobiles if they bought special coupons. They had the option of honoring the agreement and providing new Volkswagen cars to German workers, or to use the money to finance the motorization of some Wehrmacht forces. Volkswagen started building the cars, and soon the first ones would be finished.

From the thousands of works purged from the museums in spring, historically 650 were chosen for a special exhibit of Entartete Kunst. The exhibit traveled to eleven cities in Germany and Austria. In each installation, the works were poorly hung and surrounded by graffiti and hand written labels mocking the artists and their creations. Over three million visitors were in attendance, making it the first blockbuster exhibition.

In 1938, the German propaganda ministry announced that the German minority in Czechoslovakia was subject to severe oppression in this country. They revealed to the German public that the non-German minority in Czechoslovakia had staged several demonstrations against the presence of ethnic Germans living within Czechoslovakian borders. This caused considerable uproar and anti-Czech sentiment in Germany.

In 1938, the German government promised the working class access to cheap automobiles if they bought special coupons. They had the option of honoring the agreement and providing new Volkswagen cars to German workers, or to use the money to finance the motorization of some Wehrmacht forces.

In 1938, the recreational organization 'Kraft durch Freude' (Strength through Joy) started their new program to mass-motorize the German people. They issued special coupon cards that could be bought cheaply on a monthly basis. In this way, the average German worker could soon afford a brand-new Volkswagen automobile, when the total of 990 Reichsmarks worth of coupons had been purchased. Historically, however, the cheaply mass-produced cars were never delivered to the German customers. The money was used instead to build K¸belwagen armored cars in order to motorize the Wehrmacht.

In 1939, another part of the German Reichsautobahn was completed. Kˆnigsberg and Elbing were added to the destinations that could be reached easily on the network of 3000 kilometers of high-speed roads. All in all, 130,000 men were working on construction of the Autobahn road system.

The director Leni Riefenstahl was famous for her documentary on the 1934 Fascist Party convention in Nuremberg, called Triumph of the Will. It was chosen as best film in the 1930s at both the Venice Film Festival and the Paris World Fair. In 1938, Leni Riefenstahl finished her latest project, a two part film named 'Olympia' on the Olympic Games in Berlin 1936. They were 'Olympia I - The Festival of the People' and 'Olympia II - The Festival of Beauty'. Many cameras and much equipment were needed to make the films. During the making, filming techniques and camera equipment developed rapidly. The films served as propaganda, as they focused on the German athletes as role models for the fascist physical ideal.

From the thousands of works purged from the museums in spring, historically 650 were chosen for a special exhibit of Entartete Kunst. The exhibit traveled to eleven cities in Germany and Austria. In each installation, the works were poorly hung and surrounded by graffiti and hand written labels mocking the artists and their creations. Over three million visitors were in attendance, making it the first 'blockbuster' exhibition.

Ever since the ruling Nazi party came to power in 1933, some artists in Germany had come to hard times. The works of famous artists like Kandinsky, Chagall, Kollwitz, Dix, Grosz or Feininger were considered 'degenerate' or 'Bolshevik'. In 1937, Nazi Party officials purged German museums of works they considered to be degenerate.

The famous German actress and singer Marlene Dietrich (Der Blaue Engel) lived in America since the early 1930s working for Paramount Pictures. In 1936, the German government tried to win her back to star in propaganda movies by offering the incredible sum of 200,000 Reichsmarks per film. Dietrich declined. She became an American citizen in 1939, and later entertained American Forces at the front. She was awarded the Medal of Freedom for meeting a grueling schedule of performances under battle conditions despite risk to her life.

In 1936, Germany violated stipulations of the treaty of Versailles set down at the end of the First World War. The treaty stated that no German military forces were allowed on the western side of the Rhine. When Hitler has troops march ostentatiously into this area, many nations were shocked. Some, such as France, Belgium, and the Netherlands, were forced to decide on a new policy to deal with this aggressive behavior. France went as far as to threaten Germany with war if the military forces were not immediately withdrawn.

Germany was the most important export market for Swedish iron ore. Swedish companies committed to shipping 5000 tons of iron ore to Germany each year in return for German coal shipments that were critical to the economy. After war broke out, the British eventually raised objections to the trade, publicly arguing that it made Sweden complicit in the Axis war effort.

Icelandic bases were strategically critical to the Battle of the Atlantic. With Denmark quickly falling to German aggression, Britain was forced to act swiftly to control the Icelandic region, or risk defeat in the Atlantic. British Marines landed in Reykjavik and seized strategic control of Iceland and Greenland. This was a serious setback for Germany in the Atlantic.

When Fall Weserubung was put into effect, the German ambassador kindly informed Denmark that German troops were about to enter Denmark and seize control. The Danish position was rather hopeless, but they tried to avoid military disaster by submitting to the German will. When presented with the ultimatum, the Danish government ordered its Army to stand down and co-operate with advancing German forces.

Operation Fall Weserubung consisted of plans to seize key airfields in Denmark and then to invade Norway. Germany sought to coup Denmark and then stage the Norwegian invasion from their bases. Some officers believed that Sweden should also be invaded, so that German could gain control of their rich ore fields.

A few months after the outbreak of war between Germany and the Allies, the German transport ship Altmark entered Norwegian waters carrying approximately one-hundred British prisoners on board. In a small fjord off the Norwegian coast, the Altmark was intercepted by a Royal Navy taskforce. British forces boarded the German ship, and set the prisoners free. The nearby Norwegian navy was overmatched, and powerless to intervene. The Germans saw Norwegian neutrality as compromised and secretly decided to strike before they had a chance to join the Allies. The German plan to take Denmark and Norway was code-named Fall Weserubung.

Pre-war Afghanistan and Germany were close friends. During the Berlin Olympics, the Afghan Field Hockey team was given the red carpet treatment, and several officers were actually sent to Germany to receive training while the Games were going on. Germany's Todt organization also worked on massive aid projects throughout Afghanistan. There was also a large rearmament program where the Italians and Germans helped Afghanistan begin modernization. Other nations to help included Czechoslovakia and the United Kingdom.

On 11th July 1936, German and Austrian officials met to hammer out an agreement. Germany stated that it would honor Austrian sovereignty, and showed a strong friendship between the Austrian and German governments. This served to ease some fears that an increasingly confident Germany would not respect international law and the sovereignty of other nations. However, all this had a secret agenda to provide amnesty for Austrian Nazis, lift censorship on Nazi media, allow the resumption of political activities by Austrian Nazis, and ensure the appointment of men friendly to the Nazis in the Schuschnigg cabinet.

Germany put considerable weight into negotiations with Japan over the recognition of Manchukuo. The Japanese government offered considerable trade concessions, including strategic materials critical to German industry. Signing of the agreement meant the end to German trade with China. Following the German recognition of Manchukuo, Japan committed to shipping strategic materials for use in Germany industry to make up for shortfalls from the cessation of Chinese shipments.

The German mission under von Falkenhausen immediately started training Chinese troops but progress was slow. By 1938, only 8 of the agreed 20 divisions were trained and there was increasing talk of war between China and Japan. Germany realized that fulfilling the obligation to China would not help the struggle against the Comintern in the short term, but a withdrawal of the mission from China would cause German financial interests to suffer, and the shipments of strategic materials from China would cease.

Germany put considerable weight into negotiations with Japan over the recognition of Manchukuo. The Japanese government offered considerable trade concessions, including strategic materials critical to German industry. Signing of the agreement meant the end to German trade with China.

The Germans provision of extensive military support to the Chinese did not go unnoticed. The Japanese believed that this interference by a European power was unacceptable, leading them to lodge strong protests with the German ambassador, even going so far as to demand the immediate recall of the German mission from China.

The German mission under von Falkenhausen immediately started training Chinese troops but progress was slow. Only 3 out of the agreed 20 divisions were trained and there was increasing talk of war between China and Japan. Germany realized that fulfilling the obligation to China would not help the struggle against the Comintern in the short term, but a withdrawal of the mission from China would cause German financial interests to suffer, and the shipments of strategic materials from China would cease.

Germany maintained a strong economic mission in China under von Seeckt since 1934. In 1936, many in the German command believed the time had come to change the focus of German aid to China. As the Chinese Kuomintang was fighting against communism in the Far East, Germany provided railroad and manufacturing technology, uniforms, ammunition, armored scout cars, and many other military supplies to China. The new head of the German mission, Alexander von Falkenhausen, was very interested in helping in the struggle against the communists. He offered to organize the training of 20 Chinese divisions up to German standards. In return, Germany asked for tungsten and other strategic materials, none of which were of much use to Chinese industry. This increase in international involvement signaled Germany's resurgence in international politics.

On 23rd October 1940, a historic meeting between Franco and Hitler took place in the French city of Hendaya, near the Spanish border. The purpose of the encounter, held in a armored wagon in the city train station, was to negotiate Spanish participation in World War Two alongside the Axis powers. Spain had previously solicited the rights to Gibraltar and all Moroccan territories, along with enormous industrial and economic help from Germany as payment for its participation. The final agreement ended up being only that Germany would receive the Spanish Blue Division, and to take control of some mines and weapon factories: Spain would otherwise stand apart from the war.

Historically some 40,000 Spanish men served with Germany in an all-volunteer unit called the Blue Division.  However, these 'soldiers' sent by Franco had to be armed, trained and turned into a fighting force.  Serving on the Russo-German front, this unit allowed Franco to claim Spain was participating in the Fascist 'crusade' against Bolshevism, and also provided the diplomatic means to keep Germany out of Spanish affairs.  Germany would also gain control over Spanish wolfram mines.

During the conflict in Spain, many German units and commanders fought for the Rebel cause, acquiring valuable experience with modern warfare in a real war. Unlike the other nations that were involved only to a minor degree in the conflict, Germany took advantage of this experience: it was widely studied by Wehrmacht commanders and its lessons proved invaluable to the further development of German military doctrine.

At the outbreak of the Spanish Civil War, Hitler sent some commanders as military advisors in charge of specific units to Spain, with the intention of testing the new tactical theories of the German army. In contrast with other countries, Germany got quite involved in the conflict and obtained important experience with modern warfare. Tons of weaponry were sent as well, along with the specifications needed to produce more. In particular, Nationalist Spain produced many Mauser Kar98 rifles, which became the standard rifle of the Spanish army. Providing all this help increased Hitler's influence over Spain and put Franco in debt with Germany.

The desperation of Mussolini was an evident sign that fascist Italy was about to crumble and seek a separate peace with the Allies. Since the very first signs, the German High Command prepared plans to mobilize their troops in Italy to prevent the country from surrendering and to re-establish a fascist puppet government. During the night of 8th September 1943, as Field Marshal Badoglio, the new Italian prime minister, was signing a peace treaty with the Allies, German forces surrounded Rome and took over most of the northern provinces. Badoglio and the Royal family quickly fled to Allied territory while the Germans established a new puppet government in the controlled provinces. This was the Repubblica Sociale Italiana, under the nominal command of Mussolini, who was rescued from his imprisonment by German paratroopers.
With the final surrender of Dutch forces, Japanese troops take over the Dutch East Indies as this area falls into their sphere of interest.

With Paris in German hands it became clear that a new world order was emerging. In 1940, the Tripartite Pact divided the world into German, Italian and Japanese spheres of interest. Germany would rule northern Europe, Italy would control the Mediterranean lands, and Japan would control Asia. The Tripartite Pact was proposed by Germany, but Italy and Japan chose to stand apart.

With Paris in German hands it became clear that a new world order was emerging. In 1940, the Tripartite Pact divided the world into German, Italian and Japanese spheres of interest. Germany would rule northern Europe, Italy would control the Mediterranean lands, and Japan would control Asia. The Tripartite Pact was signed only by Germany and Italy. Japan chose to stand apart.

With Paris in German hands it became clear that a new world order was emerging. In 1940, the Tripartite Pact divided the world into German, Italian and Japanese spheres of interest. Germany would rule northern Europe, Italy would control the Mediterranean lands, and Japan would control Asia. The Tripartite Pact was signed only by Germany and Japan. Italy chose to stand apart.

With Paris in German hands it became clear that a new world order was emerging. In 1940, the Tripartite Pact divided the world into German, Italian and Japanese spheres of interest. Germany would rule northern Europe, Italy would control the Mediterranean lands, and Japan would control Asia. The Tripartite Pact was signed by all three powers.
With Paris in German hands it became clear that a new world order was emerging. In 1940, the Tripartite Pact divided the world into German, Italian and Japanese spheres of interest.

In a move to contain the destabilizing influence of the Comintern, Germany consulted with Italy to expand the Anti-Comintern Pact. The Pact was expanded to include Italy, obliging the three countries to share information on Comintern activities and counteract the Comintern wherever they were active.
In a move to contain the destabilizing influence of the Comintern, Germany is consulting with Italy to expand the Anti-Comintern Pact.

In a move to contain the destabilizing influence of the Comintern, Germany offered to sign a five year Anti-Comintern Pact with Japan.The Japanese signed the agreement to share information on Comintern activities and counteract the Comintern wherever they were active.
In a move to contain the destabilizing influence of the Comintern, Germany is consulting with Japan to create a five year Anti-Comintern Pact.
In 1940, a second German expedition was planned to further explore the Antarctic and establish permanent bases.
In 1939, the German ship Schwabenland returned from a long mission in the Antarctic where they surveyed and claimed large areas of land for Germany.
Horia Sima became the new Head of Government in Romania after killing Ion Antonescu. Germany had need of caution, attacking Romania could lead to a war against other major powers.

After gaining absolute power, General Ion Antonescu sought to mimic Hitler's 'Night of the Long Knives' by eliminating his former comrades from the Iron Guard.  On 21st January 1941, the situation exploded and the Iron Guard created havoc for three days.  Implementing predetermined strategies, hordes of Iron Guard Legionnaires staged pogroms in many cities and villages.  Looting, torture and killing was common throughout the country.  Eventually, the rebellion was suppressed by the army.  In a telephone conversation on 22nd January, Hitler offered Antonescu the support of German troops in crushing the rebellion, but Antonescu declined.  After the rebellion was quelled, German troops helped smuggle a number of Legionnaires (including their leader Horia Sima) out of the country.

Many in our government are enraged over the recent events in Yugoslavia. Having refused to stand with us, Yugoslavia will now learn that it cannot stand against us. We shall teach them a lesson they will never forget.

Despite our extended offers of friendship and cooperation, the Yugoslav government has decided against us. Their entreaties of neutrality are meaningless, since we know they have been courting the Allies for some time now. The army has reported that they consider it important that we secure our southern flank, while the advantage lies on our side. Historically, Hitler flew into a rage upon learning of the Yugoslav coup and ordered an immediate attack on the country, even though this delayed his planned attack on the Soviet Union by a few crucial weeks.

The unexpected coup against Regent Pavle and his government after massive expression of popular dislike towards the recently signed 'Pact of Steel' between our government and Yugoslavia has surprised most analysts. Seizing the opportunity, Croatian Ustashe nationalists have proclaimed the Independent State of Croatia in the west of Yugoslavia and are begging for our aid against the Yugoslav loyalists. Yugoslavia is quickly descending into a civil war. Most of our ministers believe that we should offer aid and formal alliance to Croatians, as they seem very enthusiastic in their support of our ideology. This would also allow us to crush the remnants of Yugoslavia quickly, which would allow us to move into Greece, our original objective.

Our military planners are in final stages of preparing for operation Barbarossa, the invasion of Soviet Union. Some officers advise that we secure our southern flank in the Balkans first, which means securing Greece. However, Greece is still standing. In order to resolve that problem, we need to acquire safe passage through Yugoslavia, or even better, a full alliance. We are currently hosting a delegation of the Yugoslav government in Vienna for trade negotiations. This could be the perfect opportunity to press them for concessions.

We have chanced upon the opportunity to import some precious natural resources from Yugoslavia. Our Foreign Ministry has settled on a deal to import a fair quantity at a very low price.  Should another opportunity such as this arise, we will be sure to exploit it fully and obtain more.

After his army was surrounded at Kiev, the bitter Soviet General Andrei Andreyevich Vlasov offered to help the Axis cause, blaming Stalin's paranoia and purges for the inefficiency of the Red Army.  After an interview with Heinrich Himmler, Vlasov was given permission to create his Russian Liberation Army, the ROA, from prisoners of war who were willing to join the Axis cause and fight against communism.

Our Foreign Ministry has completed a deal to import various foodstuffs from Yugoslavia at very good prices. The received food is of fair to good quality, and will definitely further our stockpile of various war materials. Hopefully we shall be able to secure a similar agreement next year.
With so many Turkish nationalists eager to fight Bolshevism, it has become possible for the Axis create a new Turkish division.
With so many Cossack volunteers eager to fight Bolshevism, it is necessary that the Axis create a new Cossacks division.
With so many Ukrainians eager to fight Bolshevism, many Cossacks are volunteering to join the Waffen SS.
With so many Ukrainians eager to fight Bolshevism, many of them are volunteering to join the Waffen SS.
With so many Ukrainians eager to fight Bolshevism, many of them are volunteering to join the Waffen SS.
With so many Ukrainian volunteers eager to fight Bolshevism, it has become possible for the Axis create the Galicia division.

By the time the Third Reich captured Ukraine from the USSR, the country had endured Soviet rule for twenty years. Hoping that the Germans would grant them independence, many Ukrainians volunteered to join the Waffen SS and fight their former Soviet rulers.

By the time that Third Reich captured Latvia from the USSR, the country had only been under Soviet rule for two years. Hoping that the Germans would grant them independence, many Latvians volunteered to join the Waffen SS and fight their former Soviet rulers.

By the time the Third Reich captured Lithuania from the USSR, the country had only been under Soviet rule for two years. Hoping that the Germans would grant them independence, many Lithuanians volunteered to join the Waffen SS and fight their former Soviet rulers.

By the time the Third Reich captured Estonia from the USSR, the country had only been under Soviet rule for two years. Hoping that the Germans would grant them independence, many Estonians volunteered to join the Waffen SS and fight their former Soviet rulers.

The Maginot Line was an imposing series of fortifications designed to slow or halt German armed aggression from the Rhineland. However, should the structures be successfully flanked by enemy forces, they would lose much of their defensive value.
French politicians held several heated debate over whether to be committed to the independence of the Benelux nations, or to the safety of France itself as a first priority.

The Benelux countries were angry with the French decision to concentrate on its own defense instead of seeking to co-operate with the Benelux nations on a common front against potential German aggression. This caused considerable political backlash, pushing them closer towards alliance with, or at least closer political alignment to, Germany.
French politicians held several heated debates over whether to be committed to the independence of the Benelux nations, or to the safety of France itself as a first priority.
This event prevents players from inventing various 'AI only' technologies.

In addition to the effects of the difficulty level you picked when starting the scenario, you now have the opportunity to further increase the difficulty by selecting one of the options listed below. Choosing the third option will trigger a series of events that strengthen the countries that were historically the enemies of your nation.

Many countries hired foreign military advisors and other specialists to help their nations rapidly improve their military technology, in this case armor technology. These advisors were often still in the service of their home nation, or possibly retired or mercenaries.

Many countries hired foreign military advisors and other specialists to help their nations rapidly improve their military technology, in the area of army staff training. These advisors were often still in the service of their home nation, or possibly retired or mercenaries.

Many countries hired foreign military advisors and other specialists to help their nations rapidly improve their military technology in the area of artillery. These advisors were often still in the service of their home nation, or possibly retired or mercenaries.

Many countries hired foreign military advisors and other specialists who helped their nations improve their military technology rapidly, especially concerning infantry. These advisors could be still in the service of their home nation, or they could have been retired or even mercenaries.

During the 1930s and 1940s, the minor countries and the non-industrialized world began to experience the effects of mass industrialization for the first time. This included the benefits of advanced chemical technology, including new refineries, synthetic oil made from coal, and a slew of new industrial chemicals and processes.
A terrible incident happened in one of our industrial centers. This had a devastating effect on our industrial capacity.

Even though the Soviet Union was known as Europe's granary because of its immense cereal production, in times of war, in a country of such huge dimensions, difficult communications and extreme weather, it was usual that some towns or cities didn't receive supplies and food for civilian population in months.

The terrible experience of being a soldier in the Red Army changed something in the minds of the young Russian men who fought in WW2. The war in Eastern front was terrible, and the Red Army's way of fighting made it even worse for the first line soldiers. Any morals and humanity they had vanished with their subhuman life and a certain death awaiting for them in each assault they made. They drunk all that they could find (no matter if it was toxic as long as it had alcohol, many deaths by intoxication were reported), sacked all that they could from conquered cities, raped German women and killed German civilians. They even killed some of their officers. By the end of the war, most soldiers in the front acted like they were part of a horde rather than an Army.

Usually, spectacular parades were held in the Red Square in Moscow to celebrate victories or simply to raise Soviet people's morale. Even in the middle of the war, Stalin made thousands of men, tanks, vehicles and planes (that would be more useful in the front) participate in those parades that were covered with great detail by the Soviet press and propaganda services.

The inhuman treatment that the privates and NCO's had in the Red Army and the perspective of a sure death made lots of soldiers in the Red Army try to desert and escape from the USSR (a nearly impossible option) or to defect to the enemy. During the war massive desertion attempts were made, and terrible punishments were issued. This atmosphere deeply affected the morale of the Soviet soldiers.

A terrible disaster happened in the main oil pipeline that brings oil from the Caucasus to our industrial centers. A enormous explosion was followed by the biggest fire ever seen in the region. Kilometers of oil pipeline and its proximity are burning and although the flood of oil was immediately sealed when the accident was detected, the remaining oil in the tube can still burn for several days. The cost in oil losses and in resources to repair the oil pipeline will be enormous. The NKVD hasn't determined yet if it was an accident or a sabotage action executed by the enemies of the People.
A terrible incident happened in one of our industrial centers. This had a devastating effect on our industrial capacity.

In the team in charge of this investigation there were several subjects that have been found suspicious of disloyalty towards the communist cause. Some of them traveled shortly before the war to capitalist countries and since then they have been making contacts with colleagues from Europe and the United States. It is known that sustained contact with capitalist world can decrease the integrity of communist ideals in weak subjects, and we must discover if our scientists have been influenced. It's not safe to have disloyal people working with the secrets of our country's war industry.

One of our propaganda groups in Soviet Union had been uncovered and possibly arrested, but their work during those years has been very valuable for the party. We have gained information and even sympathy among some groups in the Soviet Union. Maybe some day a Soviet clandestine Nazi party will be created and will fight for our cause.

One of our scientists defected to the enemy and destroyed the results of the work he was conducting. His leaving greatly set back our research efforts. His erratic behavior in the last months made his colleagues think that he was probably in some kind of crisis, but they never really suspected that he was preparing his defection. It is not known how he managed to escape the country, but it's highly possible that he was helped by agents in our own country and evacuated in a submarine.
