His erratic behavior in the last months made his colleagues think that he was probably in some kind of crisis, but they never really suspected that he was preparing his defection. It is not known how he managed to escape the country, but it's highly possible that he was helped by agents in our own country and evacuated by plane.

His erratic behavior in the last months made his colleagues suspect that he was probably in some kind of crisis, but they never really suspected that he was preparing his defection. It is not known how he managed to escape the country, but it's highly possible that he was helped by agents in our own country and evacuated by plane.

In the last few days, a very intense police investigation has uncovered a clandestine group of Soviet people belonging to German Nazi party. One of the subjects is a very well known former member of the military, an Army General who is suspected of having supported the propagation of such ideology between his close friends and relatives. It is known that he held several 'social meetings' in his manor with German visitors who are suspected of being high rank members of the Nazi party themselves, possibly in charge of propaganda campaigns in European countries, maybe even spies or some kind of covert agents. The rumors have spread and people are starting to create really weird theories. A periodical has even accused the military class of preparing a secret Nazi coup d'Ètat.

In the last few days, a very intense police investigation has uncovered a clandestine group of Soviet people belonging to German Nazi party. One of the subjects is a very well known Communist Party high rank commissar who is suspected of having supported the propagation of such ideology between his close friends and relatives. It is known that he held several 'social meetings' at his home with German visitors who are suspected of being high rank members of the Nazi party themselves, possibly in charge of propaganda campaigns in East European countries, maybe even spies or some kind of covert agents. The rumors have spread and people are starting to create really weird theories. A NKVD officer has even accused the intellectual groups in the Party of preparing a secret Nazi coup d'Ètat.

Occasionally, a high-ranking commander was killed on the battlefield. Both Red Army, Air Forces and Navy ceremonially honored the fallen with state burials in honor of their years of faithful service to the country.

Naturally, when the UK entered the war all of its colonies were involved to some degree. Apart from the recruitment of young men for the military, an important part the local funds of the colonies had to be used to finance the British war effort. In some cases this gave groups working for independence more reasons to desire the independence of its country. When Japan entered the war and started to attack British possessions in Asia and the Pacific, some such groups saw in Japan the opportunity to get rid of the British colonialism, and some factions like the one headed by Subhas Chandra Bose thought that India and Burma should be Japanese allies to liberate Asia from white people's hands. Those factions were a thorn in UK's back.

The economy of the UK relied not only in the industry and resources of the metropolitan area and its colonies, but also in the imports from many countries, mainly Canada and the USA. Like it happened in WWI, Germany tried to exploit this weakness by attacking the maritime routes of the Merchant Navy, especially in the Atlantic routes between America and England. Even if escorted, the convoys with the imported resources and weaponry were an easy target for U-boats and pocket battleships, and a lot of valuable supplies ended up on the deep Atlantic sea bed.
A terrible incident happened in one of our industrial centers. This had a devastating effect on our industrial capacity.

This research project was badly designed from the beginning. If we had continued down this path, by the time the research team would have finished their work, it would have been obsolete. The best option is to abandon this line of investigation and start it again from scratch. Of course a good development team will be assigned this time.

This research project was badly designed from the beginning. If we had continued down this path, by the time the research team would have finished their work, it would have been obsolete. The best option is to abandon this line of investigation and start it again from scratch. Of course a good development team will be assigned this time.

Our performance in North Africa is really disappointing. The Parliament is wondering if we really understand the strategic importance of achieving the supremacy in the Mediterranean sea, or if its only a question of ineptitude of the commanders we sent to North Africa. Anyway, the Parliament and the population don't accept more excuses about it, the conditions are bad, the terrain is difficult, but it's difficult too for Axis soldiers and they seem to perform better than our units in those circumstances. We have to solve this situation immediately, because it is creating the impression that maybe the leaders of our nation are not capable to lead our nation to victory on all fronts.

With northern France in Axis hands, its only a matter of time that Germany starts a massive bombing campaign against our cities, factories, ports and airbases. The perspective of a long terror bombing campaign is having its effects in south England's population. Most of the children are being sent out of London, people are trying to leave the cities to live in the country, and some people are even trying to get out of England to North Ireland or Scotland leaving their work behind. Several companies and factories have suffered a decrease in their productivity as a result of the low morale of their workers, and people aren't appearing during their shifts. We have to build a lot of new bomb shelters and protect with any means possible the vital points of our cities, and of course our monuments and symbols of identity. We don't want Saint Peter's to be blown, do we?

The streets of Belfast are full of propaganda posters against Ulster's intervention in the war as a part of the United Kingdom. Several massive demonstrations have been held during the past weeks in Belfast and Londonderry resulting in various violent incidents between Catholics and Protestants. In the last one 2 people were shot to death by an unknown gunman. A woman was also killed by gunfire of unknown precedence, but some witnesses affirm that she was killed by a policeman. We've started an investigation to find out what really happened. It is very possible that the IRA is directly or indirectly behind all those incidents. Our intelligence service is working on it.

The mining sector has always been very conflictive in every nation due to the sub-human conditions of such a work and often because of the exploitation of the workers by the companies who own the mines, but in England the conflicts and riots caused by miner's protests are a tradition. Again, miner's syndicates and associations have produced the spark that started the fire. Their requests are fair, and both the local administration and the Parliament in London are studying how to get to an agreement with them, but it takes time. Unfortunately, the popular reaction to this delay is growing with each passing day. There are several mines in the North of England whose workers are in strike for weeks now, and some violent incidents with several injured people have been registered.

The anti-colonialism groups are on the move again. In a few weeks time, a huge series of demonstrations against the British government have been celebrated in various points of the dominions, mainly in India. Even in England, some intellectuals and public figures have pronounced speeches or written articles that describe British colonial policy as obsolete. Some even gave their support to the anti-colonial sentiment. Although the demonstrations were peaceful, some violent incidents happened, and the police had to intervene. This seemed to enrage the anti-colonial groups even more, and massive strikes are announced.

Occasionally, a high-ranking commander was killed on the battlefield. Both Army, RAF and Royal Navy ceremonially honored the fallen with state burials in honor of their years of faithful service to the country.
As in all democratic countries, in USA public opinion was capricious and changing. Freedom of speech, the base of any true democracy, granted constant, basic level of dissent.

It seems like some of our inventions are no secret for the other countries anymore - our leading scientist has left the country, leaving the project unfinished.

Yesterday Senate blocked our projected budget, calling it 'thinly veiled militarism'. This change can seriously delay our research projects, as we won't be able to support many of them in the near future.

In late 1930s, U.S. economy was regaining its strength after the Great Depression. Fighting unemployment, government supported many infrastructure projects. While those projects were essential to drop dissent, costs of this policy for federal budget were high.

Nuclear research was not without risks. While conducting experiments on detonation of a nuclear weapon, technicians lost control while testing a prototype nuclear device. The bomb exploded prematurely, wiping out a large section of land.

The Wehrmacht often conducted large-scale maneuvers. This required supplying the army with all necessary resources for such training to be effective.
Yesterday, the Reichsmarshall presented his plan for the celebration of the ruling party's anniversary of election. We have to show the world our strength!

During the 1930s and 1940s, the minor countries and the non-industrialized world began to experience the effects of mass industrialization for the first time. This included the benefits of advanced chemical technology, including new refineries, synthetic oil and rubber made from coal, and a slew of new industrial chemicals and processes.
Several divisions of volunteers were raised from among the young men of Germany's Scandinavian conquests.
Several divisions of volunteers were raised from among the young men of Germany's Western European conquests.

Communist experiment is raising a lot of interest in some sectors of European culture. Maybe we should take advantage of this and program a series of events like receptions, theater or concerts of occidental authors to attract ambassadors, intellectuals and cultural figures of influence in democratic powers. Undoubtedly, this would increase our influence and the popularity of communist model in foreign countries, as well as get us closer to other nations.

During the 1920s and 1930s, moved by the curiosity about Soviet communist experiment, some intellectuals, writers and artists from Europe and the rest of the world visited the Soviet Union. In many occasions it was the Soviet Government who invited them with the purpose of showing them the best face of the country and positively impressing public opinion in foreign nations. Some visitors were pleased with the 'tour', others were more sceptic.

The influence of traitors and cowards of filthy blood has affected our young men's valor. A small number of them didn't report to recruiting centers after being called to military service. Although it isn't a serious problem by itself, it can decrease our recruits' and our glorious nation's morale. Maybe it would be appropriate to take measures like improving our recruits' quality of life or developing a propaganda campaign to encourage our young men towards the call of duty.

The influence of traitors to our cause and lack of determination has affected our young comrades' valor. A small number of them didn't report in recruiting centers after being called to military service. Although it isn't a serious problem by itself, it can decrease our recruits comrades' and our country's morale. Maybe it would be appropriate to take measures like improving our recruits' quality of life or developing a propaganda campaign to encourage our young men towards the call of duty.

Dissent and lack of confidence in victory has affected our young men's valor. A small number of them didn't report in recruiting centers after being called to military service. Although it isn't a serious problem by itself, it can decrease our recruits' and our country's morale. Maybe it would be appropriate to take measures like improving our recruits' quality of life or developing a propaganda campaign to encourage our young men towards the call of duty.

Occasionally, the administrative and social collapse produced by a prolonged war could cause the collapse of the distribution of food and other basic goods, even in developed countries. This could have important consequences in those provinces unable to produce by themselves the minimum needed to survive. It was the responsibility of the government to take measures to face the situation.

Economy Minister has proposed to, if it's appropriate, polarize slightly our nation's productivity with nearly immediate effects. He has prepared a series of legal and economic measures whose application would favor in a subtle but immediate way a specific economic sector.

Central government cabinet is discussing the possibility of elaborating a Manpower Redistribution Plan that could produce quick results in the output of a specific sector in case it needs to be stimulated. That way, our worker comrades could be assigned more effectively to the jobs that the state chooses to favor.

The Parliament is discussing the contents of the Economic Activities Plan, that will be applied immediately. Different economic sectors have presented their requests for the plan, trying to get advantage of its application. Naturally, to favor a sector could cause disagreements or even decrease the productivity of the rest.
Disaster has struck the royal court. King Rama VIII has been found dead in his chambers, killed by a gunshot. Investigations suggest a possible plot against the King.

Although nationalism was equated with Westernization, it was not pro-Western, either politically or culturally. Thai Christians, especially those in government service, as well as Muslims, suffered official discrimination. The clear inference of government statements was that only Buddhists could be Thai patriots. At its source Thai nationalism was anti-Chinese in character. Regulations were enacted to check Chinese immigration and to reserve for the Thai numerous occupations that had formerly been held predominantly by Chinese.

Due to conflicts within the Promoter Party, Phot Bhahalyodin has decided that he no longer feels able to lead the government and wishes to return to his military career. Two people were fighting for the position as new head of the government. Luang Phibunsongkhram, who was the most hardline of the two candidates and Pridi Phanomyong who was more liberal in regards to outside influence on Siam.

The Panay incident has escalated to the point that the USA has joined China in war against Japan.  We will show our solidarity with the USA by joining the war, not to mention that attack by Japan is a certainty.
Threats surround us, we must mobilize our forces.
The second stage of mobilization resulted in thousands of troops being called up for active service and transferred the bulk of the defensive duties of the Philippines to national forces.

After the establishment of the Commonwealth Government in 1935, the responsibility for defending the Philippines was being transferred from American to national control in a series of mobilization stages.
In the summer of 1940, the Siamese government demanded that Vichy cede provinces in Indochina that the Siamese had been forced to give up to the French in the 1890s.
While Siam was successful on the battlefield, the war with Vichy was causing economic dislocations for the Siamese government, so when Japan offered a settlement, Siam accepted.
The decision of Vichy to refuse Siam's demands to restore territory would lead the Siamese to invade French Indochina to regain the desired territories.
In the summer of 1940, the Siamese government demanded that Vichy cede provinces in Indochina that the Siamese had been forced to give up to the French in the 1890s.

American flyer Amelia Earhart has made an unexpected landing in Bangkok today for fuel. She had been delayed for two days by weather which forced her to land at Sittwe and Rangoon in Burma to wait out the storms. After fueling she continued on to Singapore. She is going to be leaving tomorrow on the next leg of her trip to Bandoeng in the Dutch East Indies. From there, she will continue on to Darwin, Australia and then to the United States via Hawaii.
We need a strong military in order to protect our new nation from foreign aggression.

As the China incident escalated into full-scale war the internal Chinese rivalries were gradually put aside.  Although the warlords of China continued to be at odds and corruption remained a great problem, there were also many political moves to defeat a common enemy.  Throughout the war, Muslim fighters from Sinkiang fought alongside the KMT forces and gained a reputation for being among the best forces in China.

The governments of Turkey, Iraq, Iran, and Afghanistan signed a non-aggression pact in Teheran, called the Sa'adabad Pact, to counter international tensions. This Islamic front offered the participating states an effective deterrent to the imperialistic designs of the European powers in the Middle East. The agreement secured the Asiatic region of Turkey as the Balkan Pact protected European Trace. Turkey was recognized as the crucial force for peace in Eastern Europe and its prestige bolstered this Asiatic pact.
In 1938, the British met with Afghans to discuss the issues of the rebels and other uprisings from the previous year. The British agreed to hunt down and extradite those responsible.

One of the many rebellions in Afghanistan in the mid to late 1930s, it proved troublesome, but was under control in a few months. It began as a conflict between two tribes, and the Afghan government moved in and set up a fort on the frontier to make sure neither side got it. The rebels slipped into India and Afghanistan demanded the British government do something.
Eight days after the outbreak of hostilities in Europe, Zahir Shah announced his government would remain neutral in any and all conflicts in WWII, unless directly attacked.
With the events in Europe intensifying, the U.S. weighed options on whether to stay and continue searching for oil, or to leave.
With the events in Europe intensifying, the U.S. weighed options on whether to stay and continue searching for oil, or to leave.

In the mid 1930s, the Afghans were seeking contracts with people to attempt to find oil. The primary choice of the Afghan government was the U.S., in hopes of establishing a legation. The Afghans refused to give it the Russians or British, the French showed no interest, and there would surely be protests for giving contracts to Germany and Japan.

The Afghans refused to give it the Russians or British, the French showed no interest, and there would surely be protests for giving contracts to Germany and Japan.

Amanullah, the former leader of Afghanistan, was not very keen on losing power, and made several attempts to recapture his throne. All of them failed however. There was a rather minor one in 1939, that was put down by the Afghan Army.

British colonialism controlled all Burmese territory as one of India's provinces until 1937, when it got the separation from India forming another British dominion. During Japanese invasion, Aung San congregated all patriotic forces in the Antifascist League, a nationalist guerrilla that fought against invaders. Once the Japanese were expelled, the struggle for the independence continued against the British, and in 1947, after conceding independence to India, it became absurd to keep control over Burma, so the United Kingdom was forced to grant a limited self-government status. Being Aung San was killed in July 1947. His successor U Nu managed to get an agreement with Great Britain that established the right of Burma to get its independence. The new state Constitution was redacted and Burma began its official life on 4th January 1948.

The negotiations and processes towards the independence of India started after the popular protests and the Indian Congress demands arrived to their critical point. Since 1876, when Queen Victoria was proclaimed Empress of India, the country has been administrated by the British government. In 1935, after a series of conferences in London between British and Indian politicians, the British Parliament approved the Government of India Act. This gave some degree of self-government to India, but it remained a dominion of the British Crown, which didn't fully satisfy Indian nationalists. After many years of protests like those headed by Mahatma Gandhi, independence has come at last. From this moment we will continue the fight against fascism and Japanese imperialism as a free nation and close ally of the United Kingdom. Finally, occidental politicians have understood that the era of imperialism and colonialism is getting to its end, and that the Asian people are ready to rule their own destiny.

Pre-war Afghanistan and Germany were close friends. During the Berlin Olympics, the Afghan Field Hockey team was given the red carpet treatment, and several officers were actually sent to Germany to receive training while the Games were going on. Germany's Todt organization also worked on massive aid projects throughout Afghanistan. There was also a large rearmament program where the Italians and Germans helped Afghanistan begin modernization. Other nations to help included Czechoslovakia and the United Kingdom.

Historically, seeing the need for modernization to advance the Afghan state, on 24th March 1938, the bank of Afghanistan was founded, centralizing the country's currency and greatly organizing the economy. This did have a negative effect though. It served to increase dissent among the Conservative Islamic groups, who wished for the country to remain closed off, unlike Mohammed Zahir Shah, who was in favor of modernization.
We must call up the reserves to defend our country.

American aviator Amelia Earhart has arrived in Natal as a part of her flight to circumnavigate the globe. She will fly out tomorrow on a transatlantic flight to Dakar in French West Africa. She and her navigator will continue on across northern Africa, Southeast Asia, and Australia, before flying on to Oakland, California after a stop in Honolulu, Hawaii.

American pilot Amelia Earhart has arrived at the coastal city of Caripito on the first part of her flight to circumnavigate the globe. She will leave tomorrow for Paramaribo, in Dutch Guiana, on her way to Natal, Brazil where she will cross the Atlantic to Dakar in French West Africa.
The Bolivian and Paraguayan governments signed the final peace treaty which ended the Chaco War. The terms of the treaty were worked out in arbitration by six Latin American governments.

The Bolivian and Paraguayan governments signed the final peace treaty which officially ended the Chaco War. The treaty provided for the arbitration of the final borders between the two countries, conducted by the presidents of six American republics.

The U.S. administration has announced that it considers the new Bolivian government legitimate and wishes to take up relations with it.

President Franklin Roosevelt declared that Nazi-Fascist influence was growing in Argentina and that the Argentine government had failed to fulfill its obligations under the inter-American agreements. As a result, the U.S. government refused to allow American ships to call at Argentinean ports.
The Roosevelt administration froze Argentina's gold assets in the U.S. as the Argentinean government failed to cooperate fully in the war against the Axis powers.
The U.S. government has announced that it will not recognize our new government.
The government of Argentina became the first state to recognize the military junta, led by Major Gualberto Villarroel, that overthrew the President Enrique Panaranda in Bolivia in late December 1943.

The President of the USA conducted a state visit to Brazil to meet with the Brazilian President. The two leaders met on board a U.S. destroyer off Natal, Brazil and announced their joint determination to safeguard the sea lanes of the Atlantic Ocean.
President Ramon S. Castillo declared that Argentina would maintain its policy of neutrality in the world war.
Following the failure of the League of Nations to stop the Italian war in Ethiopia, the government of Peru has decided to withdraw from the League of Nations.
The U.S. administration and the Brazilian government concluded a series of agreements, through which the Brazilians received financial aid and general economic development assistance.

Following the failure of the League of Nations to stop the Italian war in Ethiopia, and its diminishing ability to protect minor countries, the government of Venezuela has decided to withdraw from the League of Nations.

Following the failure of the League of Nations to stop the Italian war in Ethiopia, and its diminishing ability to protect minor countries, the government of Chile has decided to withdraw from the League of Nations.
The U.S. government has requested access to bases in our country to increase security in the area.

Following the failure of the League of Nations to stop the Italian war in Ethiopia, and its diminishing ability to protect minor countries, the government of Paraguay has decided to withdraw from the League of Nations.
The Argentinean government has declared the Communist Party illegal. This move reflects the growing power of the right in the country.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1945 Nobel Prize in Literature. This year's laureate is Gabriela Mistrel (Chile), for her lyric poetry which, inspired by powerful emotions, has made her name a symbol of the idealistic aspirations of the entire Latin American World.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureates for the 1947 Nobel Prize in Medicine. This year's laureates are Carl Ferdinand Cori and Gerty Theresa Cori (nÈe Radnitz) of USA, for their discovery of the course of the catalytic conversion of glycogen.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1936 Nobel Peace Prize. This year's laureate is Carlos Saavedra Lamas (Argentina) for his role as Secretary of State, President of SociÈtÈ des Nations, and mediator in the conflict between Paraguay and Bolivia.

The elections were not what the government expected. These turned out to be a decisive victory for the left parties, whereupon the government arrested many of the leaders of the left (including newly elected congressmen) on the charge of communism. Most of these leaders were exiled, and most of the leftist organizations (including the Federation of Students) were dissolved. The president then undertook to suppress the left, but at the same time embarked on a far-reaching program of social reform designed to meet the needs and demands of the lower classes and to check the spread of support for leftist movements.
Elections were held for about one-third of the seats in Congress. These turned out to be a decisive victory for the left parties. This is totally against the current government.
A new constitution provided that the president's term should be limited to five years, with no eligibility for reelection.

Despite that Brazil did not pick up on the request for aid to Finland from the League of Nations, Brazilian coffee workers have gathered 60,000 sacks of coffee that they want to send to Finland. This may anger USSR but maybe we should do it anyway.

Following the expulsion of the USSR from the League of Nations and the request by the same organization for aid to the Finnish war struggle we have to decide if we want to follow up on this request and promise support to the Finnish people.

After having promised their support for Finland against the attacks from USSR the government of Argentina has decided that now may be the time to stand up to their word. Maybe we should offer Finland 50,000 sacks of grain and allow them to pay whenever they are able to.

In October 1941, the Peruvian government created a new Ministry of Aeronautics, showing its great concern for the possession of a modern and well-equipped air force.

In 1936, the first wing of combat fighters was created, with its base at the city of Chiclayo. It became the main wing of combat fighters, equipped with Caproni Ca. 111 'Pancho' and Potez 39A-2 planes, and later with Caproni Ca. 114, Ca. 135, Ca. 310 and finally with Douglas-Northrop 8A-3P and North American N.A. 50 'Torito', all of which took place in the war with Ecuador of 1941.

The Bolivian Army was also in charge of the fluvial security. In 1939, in order to improve the quality of the naval service and to recruit qualified personnel, the 'Navy' became a more independent corps and a Navigation School was established.

After the loss of the Amazonian lands in the war with Per˙, the Military Staff recognized that the greatest mistakes in the war were the poor state of communications as well as the great inferiority in aviation capabilities. For this reason in 1942 the Military School for Telecommunications was created, aimed at providing technical personnel to the army. In the same year, a purchase of military planes for the Aviation School was approved, and soon three Ryan PT-22, six Curtiss-Wrigth CW-22 Falcon, six Fairchild PT-19 Cornell and three AT-6 Texan planes arrived to Ecuador from the USA.

In 1936, the Ecuadorian government, headed by Federico P·ez, founded the Academy of Artillery. The Academy was preceded by an Italian military mission in 1922, which aided the development of a modern artillery corps for the Ecuadorian army. The fruits of the Academy were rapidly realized when the first generation of artillery officers entered into service in 1940.

In 1945, the Ecuadorian government decided to formally join the Allies and declare war on the Axis nations. Since the war was nearly over, it was mainly a diplomatic action to show support for the winning cause. It was, however, an interesting move for Ecuador: the official declaration of war allowed the government to expropriate the property of German, Italian, and Japanese citizens. This property was later sold back to Ecuadorians, thus earning some money for public affairs.

In 1942, the Ecuadorian government broke off all relations with Japan, Italy and Germany. At the same time, the U.S.A. were given the opportunity to establish military bases on the Gal·pagos islands and in the peninsula Santa Elena. These bases were specially created to guard the Panam· canal. The German School of Quito was closed and some German citizens were handed over to U.S. intelligence officers.

The Alianza Popular Revolucionaria Americana (APRA), was a reformist political party founded in 1924 by Victor Ra˙l Haya de la Torre. The party advocated social reforms, the emancipation of indigenous peoples, improvement of agrarian conditions, and the socialization of some industries. Originally committed to revolutionary change, the party gradually became less radical. After being implicated in acts of political terror, the APRA was outlawed in 1931. While underground, the Apristas engaged in continual gun battles with the military, thus creating an enduring enmity between the two groups. President Prado Ugarteche tried to appear as a magnanimous and impartial man by freeing some APRA leaders, but keeping others in prison. During the 1945 elections, Prado Ugarteche supported candidate JosÈ Luis Bustamante, but in order to be elected he demanded the legalization of the APRA.

In 1939, president Benavides hesitated to call an election as he wanted to remain in power until 1942. Rumors of a coup begin to arise. In February, Benavides was out of Lima, and his minister RodrÌguez RamÌrez seized the Presidential palace and proclaimed himself President of the Republic. His hold on power was short-lived, as the chief of Security, Luis Rizo, immediately killed RamÌrez. President Benavides returned that same evening to Lima and took control of the situation. A month later he called the elections he had been fearing. The electoral campaign was furious and all candidates had to fight to obtain votes.
Although the Chaco war between Paraguay and Bolivia had unofficially ended years ago, it was only in 1938, after the definitive peace agreements were signed, that peace became official.

Bolivia was one of the most important producers of tin. The government has decided to sell the tin to the Germans at a symbolic price. In exchange, a German mission will help us in developing the more remote lands and in improving industry and infrastructure.

Bolivia was one of the most important producers of tin. The government has decided to sell the tin to the Soviet Union at symbolic prices. In exchange, a Soviet mission will help us in developing the more remote lands and in improving industry and infrastructure.

Bolivia was one of the most important producers of tin. In 1942, the government decided to sell the tin to the USA at symbolic prices. In exchange, the Bohan mission helped Bolivia in developing the more remote lands and in improving industry and infrastructure.

Ecuador was unprepared to meet the Peruvian invasion. The much larger Peruvian army of 13,000 men, supported by a battalion of armor, together with artillery and air support moved quickly into the southern coastal province of El Oro, threatening Guayaquil. The fewer than 1,800 Ecuadorian troops in the area lacked air cover and could offer only limited resistance. The Ecuadorian president's fear of being left unprotected from his political opponents led him to keep the nation's best fighting forces in Quito. Peruvian forces also moved into the disputed Amazonian territory without significant opposition. After a campaign lasting only three weeks, an armistice was arranged. The Rio Protocol of February 1942, awarded to Peru some 205,000 square kilometers of previously disputed Amazon territory. The subsequent Protocol of Peace, Friendship, and Boundaries imposed on Ecuador acceptance of Peru's claims in the Amazonian region in return for Peruvian withdrawal from Ecuador's coastal provinces.

The Ecuadorian government quickly regretted having become a party to the Rio Protocol. The protocol became the focus of a surge of Ecuadorian national pride and concomitant opposition in a new coalition: the Democratic Alliance. The coalition brought together a wide array of Ecuadorian politicians dedicated to replacing the 'president who had been unable to defend the national honor'. In May 1944, an uprising took place in Guayaquil that soon spread throughout the whole country.

The people of Colombia, aggravated by the Peruvian aggression against Ecuador, sent assistance to Ecuador.

The territorial dispute between Ecuador and Peru originated in Spanish colonial times. Upon independence, Ecuador joined the 'Great Colombia', comprised of the territories of Venezuela, Ecuador, Colombia and Panama. In 1829, the Treaty of Peace and Limits of Guayaquil was signed. Subsequently, in 1830, Pedemonte-Mosquera Protocol was signed. They established the MaraÒon-Amazon River as the border between Peru and Ecuador.

After several years of small armed conflicts and ambushes between Ecuadorian and Peruvian border posts, Per˙ decided to declare war on Ecuador in order to gain control of the Amazonian lands beyond the MaraÒÛn river. The Ecuadorian president's fear of being left unprotected from his political opponents led him to keep the nation's best fighting forces in Quito. When the much larger Peruvian army of 13,000 men, supported by a battalion of armor, and working together with artillery and air support, moved quickly into the southern coastal province of El Oro, threatening Guayaquil, the fewer than 1,800 Ecuadorian troops in the area lacked sufficient air cover and were able to offer only limited resistance. Peruvian forces also moved into the disputed Amazonian territory without significant opposition.

We have an opportunity to sell our Landsverk L-60B light tank design to Hungary, along with a manufacturing license. Hungary is offering a good price, and this could also be an opportunity to demonstrate the excellence of our weapons industry and their designs.
We are concerned with recent events in the Soviet Union and must call up all of our reserves to defend our nation from any hostile aggression.
War has broken out in Europe, we are mobilizing our nation.

During late 1944 the Danish resistance movement was feeling pressured by the Gestapo. Several resistance leaders had been captured and they had been imprisoned at the Shell-House, the Gestapo headquarters in Denmark, and the evidence was being collected there as well. A desperate telegram was sent to London begging for an attack on the Shell-House: the RAF had to attack at all cost. On the 21st March 1945, 20 mosquito bombers with escorts launched the attack in 3 waves. The outcome was both a success and a disaster. A success because 16 out of 24 prisoners survived and most of the evidence was destroyed. A disaster because one of the bombers in the first wave hit a lighting pole during flight and crashed into a school. Some of the 2nd wave and all of the 3rd wave mistook the fire at the school as the target and dropped their bombs on the school. 123 civilians, 87 of them children were killed when the school burned down.

The Norwegian government laid claim to one million square miles of Antarctic territory from 20 degrees West longitude to 45 degrees East longitude, the region between Coats Land and Enderby Land. This claim represented 20 percent of the entire Antarctic coast.
The Finnish government dissolved the Patriotic National Movement, an organization which served as the spearhead for fascism in the republic.

The trade provisions of the Oslo Agreement between Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, which had promoted trade between these European states, were terminated. Political concerns held precedence over economic issues. Despite the termination of the trade agreements, relations between the Oslo powers remained close.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1944 Nobel Prize in Literature. This year's laureate is Johannes Vilhelm Jensen (Denmark) for the rare strength and fertility of his poetic imagination with which is combined an intellectual curiosity of wide scope and a bold, freshly creative style.
The Nobel Foundation has named the laureates for the 1943 Nobel Prize in Medicine. This year's laureate is Henrik Carl Peter Dam (Denmark), for the discovery of vitamin K.

The Nobel Foundation has named the laureate for the 1945 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. This year's laureate is Artturi Ilmari Virtanen (Finland), for his research and inventions in agricultural and nutrition chemistry, especially for his fodder preservation method.

Following the request for aid for Finland in the League of Nations, a number of countries have taken up the request and promised to send us aid. It is encouraging to know that we do not stand alone in this fight against the Soviets.
The situation for the Finnish military is getting more and more desperate. They are asking that we send them regular units to help ward off the Soviet invaders.

After the outbreak of war the Swedish government decided that one way Finland could be supported without offending the USSR was in the area of medical treatment for the wounded. It was therefore decided that a field hospital disguised as a single ambulance could be sent to Finland, complete with doctors, nurses, drivers and medical equipment.

In Copenhagen the foreign ministers of Sweden, Norway and Denmark have held a meeting to find a common stand on the issues concerning military aid to Finland. They have decided that none of the three countries will send military aid to Finland, nor will they allow military aid to Finland from any other country to pass through their countries.

The Allies are considering intervention on behalf of Finland in the Winter War, and therefore are requesting military access through our country. This could draw us into the conflict. How should we respond?

In Copenhagen the foreign ministers of Sweden, Norway and Denmark have held a meeting to find a common stand on the issues concerning military aid to Finland. They have decided that none of the three countries will send military aid to Finland, nor will they allow military aid to Finland from any other country to pass through their countries.
We have received an official apology from the Soviet government. They deeply regret the bombings on Swedish soil and would like to apologize for those incidents.

The Allies are considering intervention on behalf of Finland in the Winter War, and therefore are requesting military access through our country. This could draw us into the conflict. How should we respond?

The Finnish ambassador Tanner has passed on a suggestion for a defense treaty between Finland and Sweden. Such an agreement will surely result in us being drawn into the Winter war. If we say that we will consider the agreement, we might avoid getting involved without hurting the Finnish cause.
Uk has promised us that they are readying 20,000 men to aid us in the Winter War if it becomes necessary. They have also dispatched a unit of bombers to us including pilots and replacement parts.

In Copenhagen the foreign ministers of Sweden, Norway and Denmark have held a meeting to find a common stand on the issues concerning military aid to Finland. They have decided that none of the three countries will send military aid to Finland, nor will they allow military aid to Finland from any other country to pass through their countries.

Following the signing of the peace treaty with the USSR giving up large areas of Finland to USSR control, Finnish President Kyˆsti Kallio stated: 'This is the most dreadful document I have ever signed. Let my hand that is forced to sign this paper wither'. Half a year later, he suffered a stroke which left his hand paralyzed. Three months later he suffered a second stroke and died while preparing to leave office and be succeeded by Risto Ryti.
A full division of battle-ready volunteers have arrived from Canada. They should be given weapons and equipment and be sent directly to the front.

The Allies have given us a chance to call for aid. Our front is on the verge of collapsing. We need all the help we can get, but if we request aid from the Allies then the Soviets might not agree to any future peace deals.
The Soviets are constantly bombing our cities with no regard to civilian casualties. This cannot be allowed to continue. We must make a protest to the League of Nations.
Tanner has returned from Sweden with sad news. Sweden has rejected our offer of a mutual defense treaty and hope is diminishing fast.
Tanner has negotiated a defense treaty with Sweden. This could be the turning point in the war.
The situation is getting desperate. Perhaps if we could get out Swedish brothers to join in a defense treaty our luck will change.

In Copenhagen the foreign ministers of Sweden, Norway and Denmark have held a meeting to find a common stand on the issues concerning military aid to Finland. They have decided that none of the three countries will send military aid to Finland, nor will they allow military aid to Finland from any other country to pass through their countries.

Our protest to the Soviets on the bombings of Pajala has not gotten any official response, but this morning the Soviet news agency TASS issued an article in which they declared the so-called 'incident' in Pajala a Swedish publicity stunt to attract sympathy for the Finnish cause and denied any Soviet involvement.

Once again Soviet airplanes have entered our airspace. This time they bombed the village of Pajala. One-third of the village is burned to the ground. It is almost a miracle that there are no casualties. It almost seems as if the USSR is trying to force us into war. Either we act or the Soviets will do as they please, and laugh at our protests. On the other hand, it might be foolish to be drawn into a conflict that could so easily be lost.

Ever since we changed our policy to accept foreigners into our military, both trained and untrained volunteers have arrived from a wide range of countries. These countries include Sweden, USA, England and Hungary and they total almost 10,000. They will be gathered in the Detachment Sisu and fight as a unit alongside our own men.
The British Parliament has donated a large number of artillery guns and ammunition to us. They will be sent to the front immediately.
In light of the recent provocations from the Soviets, the Swedish government has decided to transfer some units to Finland to help us in our struggle.
Sweden has denied our request for military aid, despite the recent provocations by the Soviets.
The recent Soviet bombings on Swedish territory might help us persuade Sweden to take a more active role in our defense. Let's make a request for military aid from them.

The foreign worker camp in Denmark is a huge success. More then 10,000 workers, both Danish and other nationalities, have signed up to work in Finland. The ships with the volunteers have started arriving at our harbors. Let's give the brave people a warm welcome.
Almost 10,000 workers, both Danish and other nationalities, have signed up for work in Finland. It is time to ship them to Finland to free up those Finnish workers.

One of the ways in which the Denmark helped Finland through the Winter War was by establishing a foreign labor camp to gather workers who wished to work in Finland and thereby free up Finnish workers for military duty. Almost 10,000 people signed up for work and were shipped to Finland this way.

The Danish government has decided to establish a camp for volunteer workers who wish to take the place of Finnish workers in our factories, thereby releasing them for military duty. The initiative is greatly appreciated as we need every man who can handle a rifle on the front.
South Africa has decided to help us in our struggle. Therefore, they have sent us some supplies that will be of great value to our army.
From all over England, massive donations have arrived to aid our struggle against the Soviets. These will buy much-needed supplies.

The ongoing war with USSR is taking its toll on our manpower. Many foreigners have offered to join our military, including Spanish fighter pilot Nicolas Beries and Prince Ferdinand of Liechtenstein. Maybe we should revise our policy on this area and allow them to serve with their Finnish brothers.

Following the outbreak of the Winter War, a number of Swedish industry and business people decided to start a collection of supplies and machinery for Finland. This resulted in improvements for the Finnish war effort due to increased production.
Some Soviet bombers have entered Swedish airspace and dropped bombs on the beach in the Gulf of Bothnia. This is unheard of and we must reply and send a strong protest to the Soviets.
Brazilian coffee farmers have donated 60,000 sacks of coffee to our cause and the Brazilian government has paid to have it shipped here. The coffee will warm us through this winter.
Italy has decided to help us in our struggle. Therefore, they have sent us some supplies that will be of great value to our army.

Argentina was among the first nations that promised to send aid after the call for aid from the League of Nations. Now they have come through with 50,000 sacks of much-needed grain for our economy. We may pay them whenever we are able.
One of our transport ships, the Fenris, has been sunk by a Soviet submarine while in neutral waters. We cannot let this pass unnoticed.
USA has decided to give us grants of $600,000, but only under the condition that they are spent for civilian purposes. We are happy for all help and we will try and make the best of the money.
We have received a formal protest from USSR. It states that the USSR knows of our aid to Finland and that it must stop immediately or we may face consequences.
We have received a formal protest from USSR. It states that the USSR knows of our aid to Finland and that it must stop immediately or we may face consequences.
A Danish businessman has donated 50 trucks to us. The trucks will be put to good use and replace some of the ones we lost on the front.

Following the outbreak of war in Finland, a collection was started in Norway to aid the Finnish people. It was named the Backpack Collection because all the gathered money was used to purchase backpacks that were then filled with clothes and food for the suffering population in Finland.

Following the outbreak of war in Finland, a collection was started in Norway to aid the Finnish people. It was named the Backpack Collection because all the gathered money was used to purchase backpacks that were then filled with clothes and food for the suffering population in Finland.

During the Winter War many celebrities and ordinary people contributed to collections in support of Finland. The Swedish government encouraged these collections as they did not dare send help directly through government channels. The money gained was used by the Finnish to buy much needed supplies and to train new units.

Even though the Swedish government did not directly support Finland in the Winter War, it went to great lengths to promote private collections to help both the Finnish people and military. This resulted in large sums of money and supplies being sent to aid Finns from actors and other famous people, as well as from common people who felt that the destiny of Finland could easily become the destiny of Sweden as well.

Following the request for aid for Finland in the League of Nations, a number of countries have taken up the request and promised to send us aid. It is encouraging to know that we do not stand alone in this fight against the Soviets.

Sweden has decided to aid our cause by sending us an ambulance with complete staff and equipment. Actually, it is quite overstaffed and the surplus doctors and nurses have immediately begun working on the wounded in the tent that they have brought, effectively turning it into a hospital.

The Finnish army fighting the Soviets was heavily outnumbered both in men and material. Therefore, the Finnish government sent a telegraph to its embassies in London and Paris requesting much-needed supplies and military advisors. The English decided to send supplies and advisors to Finland.

The Finnish army fighting the Soviets was heavily outnumbered both in men and material. Therefore, the Finnish government sent a telegraph to its embassies in London and Paris requesting much-needed supplies and military advisors. The French decided to send supplies and advisors to Finland.

The Finnish army fighting the Soviets was heavily outnumbered both in men and material. Therefore, the Finnish government sent a telegraph to its embassies in London and Paris requesting much-needed supplies and military advisors. The English did not want to aid directly.

The Finnish army fighting the Soviets was heavily outnumbered both in men and material. Therefore, the Finnish government sent a telegraph to its embassies in London and Paris requesting much-needed supplies and military advisors. The French did not want to aid directly.

The Finnish army fighting the Soviets was heavily outnumbered both in men and material. Therefore, the Finnish government sent a telegraph to its embassies in London and Paris requesting much-needed supplies and military advisors.

Despite being at war, Finland tried throughout the Winter War to keep its obligations to the world community, thereby hoping to gain sympathy for the Finnish cause. Amongst these obligations was the repayment of old WWI war debts to the USA.

On 14th December 1939, the Nobel prize for literature was awarded to the Finnish writer F.E. Sillanp‰‰. Later, he and several other Nobel Prize winners donated their gold medals to support Finland in the Winter War.

After the Soviet attack on Finland, the Finnish armament ministry decided to boost the nation's air force through the purchase of 43 Brewster fighters from USA. The new planes are quickly delivered and put to good use by the Finnish Air Force.
The USA has granted us a loan of $60 million. The money is going to be spent on much-needed supplies and a new infantry division.
The USA has denied our request for a loan. This will have an impact on our troops, as they will lack essential supplies.

Shortly after the outbreak of war the Finnish ambassador in Washington, ProcopÈ, relayed a request by the Finnish Prime Minister Ryti that a loan of $60 million be given to Finland. The money is needed to buy much-needed supplies for the Finnish Army.

Towards the end of the war Ribbentrop took a personal trip to Finland hoping to get a personal guarantee from Ryti that Finland would not seek a separate peace with Soviets, in return for German weapons and supplies.

On 4th June 1942, Adolf Hitler made a surprise visit to Finland in order to congratulate Marshal Mannerheim on his 75th birthday and discuss the war with him. During the visit, he made a formal request that Finland would join the Axis in their struggle against the communists.

Once again our brave soldiers have proven themselves in battle and captured large quantities of Soviet equipment. We also captured a large number of enemy vehicles. They will be put to good use by our new motorized division.
Once again our brave soldiers have proven themselves in battle and captured large quantities of Soviet equipment. This will be put to good use against the remaining Bolsheviks.

Following the independence of Finland, the Finnish women's organizations created the so-called Lotta Organization. The goal of this organization was to recruit women that could perform work that was typically performed by men, thereby freeing up Finnish men for army duty.  In the early 1930s, the organization counted around 60,000 members, but by 1944 they had grown to include as many as 242,000 Finnish women. Almost 100,000 male workers were freed up from factory work by these women and almost half of these were sent directly to the front. Lotta women served in many areas including hospitals, offices, communications, plane spotting, radio operators and weather services.

Following the Finnish decision to give in to Russian territorial demands, it is ordered that all Finnish citizens who wish to relocate from the lost provinces are to be given new homes in the remaining parts of Finland

Following the outbreak of the Winter War in Finland, the people of Sweden rallied in an attempt to ease the suffering of the children of the war. This relief program, where Swedish families took in Finnish children without any compensation, resulted in close to 80,000 children under the age of 13 being sent to Sweden over the following years.

Following the outbreak of the Winter War in Finland, the people of Sweden rallied in an attempt to ease the suffering of the children of the war. This relief program, where Swedish families took in Finnish children without any compensation, resulted in close to 80,000 children under the age of 13 being sent to Sweden over the following years.

We have received notice from the Soviet high command that an alleged attack has taken place by Finnish artillery on the village of Mainila. We are sure that none of our artillery pieces were in range of the border and most personnel were attending church services when the attack took place.

A few months after the German occupation the leader of the Danish Nazi party gave the Danish government an ultimatum. The government was to step back and the Nazi party was to take control of the country. If they refused, he threatened to expose the government's betrayal of the Danish people. He made the accusation thinking that the Germans would back him in his claims. They did and the government is coup d'Ètat.

During the occupation King Christian X rode his horse through the streets of Copenhagen to signal to the people his resentment of the German occupation and thereby increased the dissent amongst the people. This rise in national pride and idolizing of the king did not seem to bother the Germans much.

Following the occupation of Denmark an agreement was forged between the Danish and German governments. As long as no hostile actions were taken against Danish interests by the Allies, Denmark was to keep its status as neutral in the war and no Danish units were to become involved offensively or defensively. The elected government was to remain in office and ensure that no actions were taken against the German forces in the country by detaining all units at their respective bases.
The Germans are attacking Holmen naval base! Scuttle the ships to avoid them being seized by the Germans.

Shortly after the occupation Germany takes control of all Danish reserve AA guns under the pretense of protecting Danish factories. Instead the guns are shipped off to other German interests outside Denmark.
German soldiers are attacking the naval base in Copenhagen. Should we scuttle the ships or surrender? The Germans also demand disarmament of all branches of the Danish armed forces.

Despite the fact that a treaty existed between Denmark and Germany to the effect that Denmark remained neutral during the occupation, the Danish government argues whether to give up the torpedo boats or hold the Germans to the agreement. They are afraid that if they do not give up the ships they might face retribution from the German occupation forces.
Rechnitzer argues that the German request for torpedo boats should be met. The Danish Navy Command sign a petition to have him removed from the Navy Command and the government agrees.
The Germans pay for the large expansion of Aalborg, turning it into the largest military airport in the world.
The Germans have asked that the Danish government give their approval to the creation of a volunteer division for the war against Bolshevism.

In 1938, workers' unions and employers' organizations signed far-reaching agreements on labor reform and conflict resolution. This helped avoid strike action and improved worker morale as conditions improved, providing the foundation of wealth and stability in Sweden for years to come.

As Germany launched Operation Barbarossa they requested rights to transit troops from occupied Norway to Finland. The Engelbrecht Division was transported on Swedish railroads and over the next few years an estimated 250,000 tons of equipment was also transported through Sweden.
Commemorating the 20th anniversary of independence with German help, a German submarine squadron has visited us, and the Germans bring a message of good will.
We have received coal shipments from Germany.

Germany is the most important export market for our iron ore. We have committed to shipping 5000 tons of iron ore to Germany this year in return for coal shipments that are critical to our economy. The British have raised objections but have no right to strangle our vital trade routes.

Germany has informed us that Allied forces are on the move to take the Swedish iron ore mines and cut off supply for Germany. They are sending troops to prevent this from occurring and are asking our full cooperation. Clearly, this constitutes nothing less than a full-scale invasion!
We have received an official note with a declaration of war following the events of the Altmark incident, leaving us with little choice but to seek protection by joining the Allies.
British forces have landed in Reykjavik and seized control of Iceland and Greenland.

The German ambassador has informed us that German troops are about to enter Denmark and seize control. Our position is hopeless, but we may be able to avoid military disaster by submitting to their will.

A few months into the war between Germany and the UK, the German transport ship Altmark came into Norwegian waters with some hundred British prisoners on board. In a small fjord a British taskforce intercepted the Altmark, boarded the ship and set the prisoners free while the outgunned Norwegian navy was helpless to intervene.

A career officer himself, former war minister and violent anti-communist, Quisling was the head of the 'Nasjonal Samling' (National Union) party with the objective of imitating his idols, Hitler and Mussolini, whom he proposed for the Nobel Peace Prize. He tried an agreement with the agrarian party to establish a regime similar to Germany, but failed. In 1936, his credibility was almost gone, and for some time, he lived in Germany, but the German help and the course of the events made him perform an important role for Germany back in his country. He made contacts with the German Navy and on 14th December 1939, had a secret meeting with Hitler to analyze the possibility of a political coup in Norway. During the German invasion he presented himself on the national radio as the pro-Germanic commander of the conquered nation and told the army and population not to present armed resistance. Very few followed his orders.

Canada saw a quick economic rise through the transcontinental railroad completed in 1890, shipping, industries, and settling in the West. The dominion supported Great Britain during the Boer War and World War One, underlining its semi-independent status by signing the Versailles Treaty for themselves in 1919 and by receiving its own seat in the League of Nations. Prime Minister William Lyon Mackenzie King (1921 - 1930, 1935 - 1948) from the Liberals demanded for Canada the conduct of an independent foreign policy on the empire Conference 1923. With the Balfour Declaration on the Empire Conference 1926, Canada was granted independence and emancipation within the Commonwealth of Nations. The Westminster Statute 1931 released Canada as an independent state. The Great Depression hit Canada hard after a period of prosperity in the 1920s. The Conservatives rose to power (1930 - 1935) who followed Roosevelt's policy of the New Deal. In 1934 the Bank of Canada was founded.

Prime Minister William Lyon Mackenzie King (1921 - 1930, 1935 - 1948) from the Liberals demanded for Canada the conduct of an independent foreign policy on the empire Conference 1923. With the Balfour Declaration on the Empire Conference 1926, Canada was granted independence and emancipation within the Commonwealth of Nations. The Westminster Statute 1931 released Canada as an independent state. The Great Depression hit Canada hard after a period of prosperity in the 1920s. The Conservatives rose to power (1930 - 1935) who followed Roosevelt's policy of the New Deal. In 1934 the Bank of Canada was founded. In 1939 the country joined the war against Germany and later against Japan.

After the preliminary peace of San Stefano in the 8th Russian-Turkish War of 1877-78, the newly formed national state of Bulgaria included Macedonia to the Ochrid Lake and a coastal strip on the Aegean Sea. The Berlin Congress 1878, however, limited the country's territory to the region between Danube and Balkans. Macedonia and Eastern Rumelia remained with the Ottoman Empire. Russia, interested in controlling Bulgaria, watched the successes of Prince Alexander I (annexation of Eastern Rumelia in 1885 and the victory over Serbia in 1885-86) with distrust. They forced Alexander I to abdicate after a coup led by pro-Russian officers. His successor became Ferdinand of Saxony-Coburg-Gotha. He achieved the formal independence from the Ottomans and was crowned Czar in 1908. With the idea of a Greater Bulgaria as a vision the country became the driving force in the Balkans League and carried the main burden in the First Balkans War (1912-13). Bulgaria suffered defeat from a coalition of Greece, Serbia, Montenegro, Romania, and the Ottoman Empire during the Second Balkans War in 1913 in which Bulgaria had planned to devour parts of the Balkans now free from the Turks. In the peace of Bucharest, they lost large parts of the gains from the First Balkans War - Southern Dobrudja went to Romania, and Adrianople went to the Ottomans. Of Macedonia which Bulgaria had demanded as a whole they only managed to hold onto a small strip in the Pirin Mountains, the rest was parted between Serbia and Greece. In 1915 Bulgaria joined the Middle Powers and occupied the territories she sought to take for herself. After the Entente's victory the country lost its conquests in the Peace of Neuilly in 1919, plus the access to the Aegean Sea as Greece was awarded Southern Thrace. Ferdinand I abdicated in 1918 in favor of his son Boris III. Prime Minister Alexander Stambuliski (1919 - 1923), leader of the radical Farmers' Party, enacted a land reform and supported the Balkans Federation until he was killed in a military coup in 1923. After a Communist uprising that party was banned, Georgi Dimitrow went into exile in the Soviet Union.

The Berlin Congress 1878, however, limited the country's territory to the region between Danube and Balkans. Macedonia and Eastern Rumelia remained with the Ottoman Empire. He achieved the formal independence from the Ottomans and was crowned Czar in 1908. With the idea of a Greater Bulgaria as a vision the country became the driving force in the Balkans League and carried the main burden in the First Balkans War (1912-13). Bulgaria suffered defeat from a coalition of Greece, Serbia, Montenegro, Romania, and the Ottoman Empire during the Second Balkans War in 1913 in which Bulgaria had planned to devour parts of the Balkans now free from the Turks. In the peace of Bucharest, they lost large parts of the gains from the First Balkans War - Southern Dobrudja went to Romania, and Adrianople went to the Ottomans. Of Macedonia which Bulgaria had demanded as a whole they only managed to hold onto a small strip in the Pirin Mountains, the rest was parted between Serbia and Greece. After the Entente's victory the country lost its conquests in the Peace of Neuilly in 1919, plus the access to the Aegean Sea as Greece was awarded Southern Thrace. Ferdinand I abdicated in 1918 in favor of his son Boris III. Prime Minister Alexander Stambuliski (1919 - 1923), leader of the radical Farmers' Party, enacted a land reform and supported the Balkans Federation until he was killed in a military coup in 1923. After a Communist uprising that party was banned, Georgi Dimitrow went into exile in the Soviet Union. In 1940, Bulgaria received the Southern Dobrudja back through aid of Hitler. In 1941, Germany was permitted to march its troops through Bulgaria on their way to the invasion of Yugoslavia. They were granted official rule of Thrace and Macedonia, and later that year, they would declare war on Great Britain and the U.S.A., but not on the USSR.

After slavery was abolished in 1888, the republicans gained much support from all parts of the Brazilian Empire. In 1889 the revolt began with a revolt of the military garrison and ended with the declaration of the Republic of Brazil. The 1891 constitution was patterned after the U.S. constitution, granting considerable autonomies to the respective provinces. Under the first elected presidents the domestic situation stabilized, but Brazil got into the cycle of economic crisis - Sugar Crisis of 1890, Coffee Crisis of 1896, end of the rubber boom in 1913. Meanwhile, Brazil's foreign minister, Baron Do Rio Branco extended the Brazilian territory through a series of treaties with British-Guyana, Columbia, Bolivia, Peru, and Uruguay, adding over 250,000 square miles to the country. Growing industries and a high influx of immigrants led to a strong industrial proletariat, changing the society of Brazil. The flourishing exports after World War One came to an end with the Great Depression of 1929-30, especially when the prices for coffee and rubber plummeted. A movement of social reformist officers called 'Tenentismo' took advantage of the situation, supporting the revolution of Get˙lio Dornelles Vargas who established an authoritarian rule with strong presidential powers and highly reduced autonomies of the federal states, turning Brazil into a dictatorship by and by.

Meanwhile, Brazil's foreign minister, Baron Do Rio Branco extended the Brazilian territory through a series of treaties with British-Guyana, Columbia, Bolivia, Peru, and Uruguay, adding over 250,000 square miles to the country. Growing industries and a high influx of immigrants led to a strong industrial proletariat, changing the society of Brazil. The flourishing exports after World War One came to an end with the Great Depression of 1929-30, especially when the prices for coffee and rubber plummeted. A movement of social reformist officers called 'Tenentismo' took advantage of the situation, supporting the revolution of Get˙lio Dornelles Vargas who established an authoritarian rule with strong presidential powers and highly reduced autonomies of the federal states, turning Brazil into a dictatorship by and by. In 1937 he proclaimed the 'Estado Nuovo', disbanding the congress and banning all parties. Looking at the richness with natural industries, Vargas began focusing on the development of heavy industry, aided by the U.S.A. Even though Vargas restricted the influence of big landowners and pushed through social reforms which improved the situation of the poorer of his subjects the social classes remained the same.

In foreign politics Bolivia suffered hurtful losses. A border conflict with Chile led to the Saltpeter War 1879 - 1883 which Bolivia lost despite an alliance with Peru. Having to cede the coastal province of Antofagasta in the peace treaty of Valparaiso in 1884, the country lost its access to the sea. In 1903 Brazil and Bolivia signed the Treaty of PÈtroplis, granting Brazil the important rubber province Acre. A sum of 2 million Pound Sterling didn't compensate the loss. Attempting to secure access to a port in the Chaco War with Paraguay (1932 - 1935) caused the loss of the larger part of the Chaco Boreal region, but at least secured access to the Paraguay river leading to the Atlantic Ocean (finalized in the Treaty of Buenos Aires 1938). Chaco War and the Great Depression brought an end to the positive economic development since 1895 when tin became main export good. In the face of protest movements of the middle class and the mine workers military governments with state socialist tendencies took over.

In 17th century the Lama Ngawang Namgyal who had fled Tibet managed to unify the country and to secure his further conquests through the building of monastery fortresses (Dzongs). The first spiritual and secular ruler of Bhuatan, called Shabdung, helped the Drupka Sect to win and transferred the Tibetan governmental system of Dalai Lamas to Bhutan. The Drukpas (Druk = Dragon) gave the country its name - Dragon Land (Druk Yul). The succession of the ruler was based on reincarnation. Shabdung Namgyal supposedly separated the country into three regions which were ruled by princes (Penlop). In 19th century only two of the three houses were still of importance - the Tsonga-Penlops east of the Black Mountains under the Wangchuk family and the Paro-Penlops who governed almost all of western Bhutan. With the election of the Penlop of Tsonga, Ugyen Wangchuk, on 17th December 1907, as the first Druk Gyalpo (Dragon king) the Shabdung system was replaced by a hereditary monarchy. Externally, Bhutan came into conflict with the expanding British East India Company who drove the Bhutanese out of the Indian regions of Cooch Behar between 1772 and 1774. During 1864-65 Bhutan lost claims to parts of the Bengal and Siamese Plains in the Second British-Bhutanese War. In the Treaty of Punakha 1910 Bhutan formally became a British Protectorate but retained its internal autonomy.

With World War II rising at the horizon, Belgium is facing grave problems. Being one of the winners of World War I, Belgium was also to receive payments from the German Empire. Those payments never came and the Belgian economy was stagnating. The current, mainly liberal, government of Paul van Zeeland hasn't been able to turn the tide and dissent among the people is rising. Authoritarian & nationalistic parties like the VNV & Rex are quickly gaining votes, and are openly flirting with Nazi Germany.

After World War One Austria had been reduced to its German core land. On 12th November 1918, the republic was proclaimed. The provisional national assembly created a preliminary constitution and appointed a coalition government under the social democrat Karl Renner (1919-20), replacing the previous majority vote system by a system of proportional representation, including suffrage for women. Goal of national assembly and government was the unification with Germany, made impossible, however, by decisions of the war's victors. A constitution declaring Austria a federal state was installed in 1920. In the election held thereafter, the social democrats lost to the conservative Christian Socialists who would become the dominating power in Austrian politics in the following years. Their governments, however, didn't succeed in stabilizing the young republic. Before the background of great economic problems the society drifted to the radical lefts (Republican Protection League) and rights (Heimwehr). Several times Austria was on the brink of civil war. A change of the constitution in 1929 to strengthen the role of the president was designed to further stabilize the country. In the early 1930s the Nazis gained support in Austria, too. Conservative Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuﬂ took the Nazi's successes as an opportunity to abolish the constitution and erect an authoritarian regime. After unrests in 1934 Dollfuﬂ banned all parties except his own Vaterl‰ndische Front and installed a constitution after fascist role models. He was killed, however, during a coup attempt on 25th July 1934. His successor, Karl Schuschnigg continued his policy, seeking to settle tensions with Germany and to protect Austria's sovereignty.

The Commonwealth of Australia was formally granted independence on 1st January 1901, joining the British Commonwealth and becoming a staunch ally of Britain. Its fortunes since that time have been mixed, while its economy has grown steadily since independence, it suffered heavy losses during the Great War, suffering the greatest casualties in proportion to total number of troops involved of any of the Allies during the war. Nevertheless, it was through the Great War that the ANZAC (Australian and New Zealand Army Corps) won a reputation for outstanding bravery surpassed by none, serving with distinction in Palestine and Flanders, while forever embedding the peninsula of Gallipoli in Australian folklore. The boom period of the 1920s ended with disaster as the Great Depression ruined Australia's economy and, at its worst, put up to a third of the country's workers out of a job. By 1936, the Australian economy is still suffering from the depression, and Australia is by no means ready for war. Yet, should war come, no one doubts they will continue to stand by Britain.

By December 1941, Australia has been at war for over two years, and Australians have fought first in Greece, then in Crete, and finally in North Africa alongside their Commonwealth allies, where the Anzacs are currently battling Erwin Rommel's Afrika Korps. Yet, with the attack on Pearl Harbor on 7th December 1941, and the following Japanese push for expansion into the south Pacific, Australia seems to be in a difficult position. If the Japanese attacks are successful, the Australian mainland could be in danger for the first time in the war, and at the moment Japan's strike south is going very well, with the first obstacles being overcome on the Malayan peninsula and Britain's navy in the Far East effectively crippled with the loss of HMS Prince of Wales and HMS Repulse to Japanese bombers. Australia's critical hour appears to be upon her, and the question of withdrawing troops from North Africa to bolster the mainland's defense is thus being seriously considered.

The Commonwealth of Australia was formally granted independence on 1st January 1901, joining the British Commonwealth and becoming a staunch ally of Britain. Its fortunes since that time have been mixed, while its economy has grown steadily since independence, it suffered heavy losses during the Great War, suffering the greatest casualties in proportion to total number of troops involved of any of the Allies during the war. Nevertheless, it was through the Great War that the ANZAC (Australian and New Zealand Army Corps) won a reputation for outstanding bravery surpassed by none, serving with distinction in Palestine and Flanders, while forever embedding the peninsula of Gallipoli in Australian folklore. The boom period of the 1920s ended with disaster as the Great Depression ruined Australia's economy and, at its worst, put up to a third of the country's workers out of a job. Yet, despite continued economic problems and a lack of enthusiasm spawned from memories of the Great War, Australia entered the war against Germany on 3rd September 1939 without hesitation. With the world at war again and a new generation ready to fight it, the question remains whether the Anzacs will continue to uphold their reputation as a fighting force equal to any in the world.

In 1880 Argentina owned large areas suitable for their prime agricultural products: cattle and wheat. More workers were needed, increasing the number of immigrants. Financial capital, however, was largely controlled by the British who invested in infrastructure, controlled most banks and trade businesses, and that capital soon made Argentina the leading exporter of beef and wheat in the world. In the wake of this development an urban middle class formed as well as an industrial worker class. Both called for more representation in politics to be achieved through changes to the electoral system. The radical UCR (UniÛn Civica Radical), founded in 1889, fought for those goals and came strong out of the reform of the electoral system which the conservative president Roque S·enz Pena pushed through in 1912. In 1916 the first universal elections were held in which HipÛlito Irigoyen of the UCR won. For the first time the middle classes had political influence. In foreign politics Argentina steered a course of neutrality while social legislature was to take away some negative effects of the wave of industrialization in the country. The period of economic rise and the second presidency of Irigoyen was ended abruptly with the Great Depression of 1929-30. Conservative politicians and generals claimed the presidency after a military coup, but none of them could overcome the social tensions.
